Almost Opaque Pitch Black Color, Big Foamy Had, Lots Of Foamy Lacing. Like Most Stout Virtually No Aroma. Toasted Malt, Sweet Chocolate, Creamy Light Vanilla, Moderate Bitter. Easy Drinker. Smooth. Enjoyed It. My Favorite Samuel Smith Product So Far, The Only One Worth Repeating. Recommended....

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2013 Perfect stout. Just perfect. I loved every minute of it I loved the aroma the pour was gorgeous great head beautiful color. Smelled of quality. Taste was out Of this world. Wicked beer. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500 ml. bottle. Its been years since Ive had this beer, so I guess its time to revisit and rate it. It pours a nice dark brown color with a thick, lasting tan head. Looks really nice. The aroma is pretty mellow with sweet chocolate, light notes of coffee, bread and a hint of treacle. The flavor is light, but pretty creamy with some cola sweetness up front followed by some acidic roasted malt. Minor herbal bitterness in the finish with more coffee and dark chocolate. Not as good as I remember, but still a pleasant stout.

Great oatmeal stout! Perfect balanced, nice aroma , full bodied and easy to drink.

Has a nice fluffy head that lasts throughout. Initial taste is coffee, raisin, with some vanilla. Very good easy drinking stout. Bottle has been aged a year.

Pours deep, dark brown with a fluffy tan head that lasts a bit before settling to a coat. Aroma is sweet brown sugar candy and yeast. Taste is malt, sweet oatmeal, mild coffee. Very nice hoppy bitter balance to close. A touch watery, but a true classic.

335 at my place with Caesar. Pours black with small creamy white head. Aroma is English yeast, roasted malt, a little mold, some very dark chocolate. Taste is yeast, big English yeast bite gross. Roasted malt. Vanilla. Not great.

Samuel Smith's oatmeal Stout: pours a solid black with a light brown foamy head. It has a nice aroma of dark malt, toast, and a small amount of coffee. The flavor is dark malt and toast upfront with the semi sweet finish over a medium body.

A beer that truly qualifies for the German flüssiges Brot epithet, food and drink in one. Great moutfeel, beautiful color, very nice aroma, this beer hits all the right spots. Great label, though it could do with a little more attention from the printer.
Pours dark brown little head. Aromas of brown sugar, bread and Oates. Taste follows nose. Light body with somewhat oily texture and medium carbonation.

From 10/13 notes. Pours deep rich brown with big 2 finger head. Nose is nutty, roasty coffee, molasses. Mouthfeel is smooth, light and creamy. Taste is roasty almonds, coffee, nutty, molasses. Finish is creamy bread, mild bitterness. Very good.
Za tą szpetną jak diabli etykietą kryje się doskonały stout, pełen kawy z bardzo długim, acz nienatrętnym finiszem. Solidnie nachmielony, pełny w smaku, wręcz syty. Polecam!

Bottle. Clear, almost black color, against the light ruby. After transfering nice brown foam which reduce quickly but lacing glass. Smooth aroma. Dark chocolate, oatmeal, sweet coffee, roasted malts, liquour. After heating a bit hoppy. Taste: milk chocolate, oatmeal, some sweet coffee, mixed with soft bitterness. Medium body and carbonation. Smooth and silky texture. Good oatmeal stout - very balanced and drinkable.
bottleat Brick Oven Bistro. cant believe that i have not rated this yet. medium bodied, medium roast, great mouthfeel. deleicious
Sorry, but i must have got a bad 4 pack. tastes like metal. Love oatmeal stouts, but this doesnt do it. Has a nice head though.
caramel, toast, roasty, chocolate, coffee, hay, tan foam, black liquid, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, sticky, average carbonation, good stuff,,,,,

Aroma: Smelling of bread, dates, coffee and brown sugar.Appearance: A dark brown colored beer. A off-white head with some lacing and some curtains.Taste: Tasting bread, figs, coffee and hay.Palate: Medium low carbonation, a oily texture. A good body with a slightly dry finish.Overall: Nice, balanced.Note: Bottle 550 ml at a De Klomp tasting. Reviewed 2013-10-05.

Appearance: Pours a crystal clear ruby black color with a finger or two of a pretty dark, tan head. Quite a bit of carbonation as well, which I wasnt really expecting.

Smell: A lot of roastiness, with a pretty significant caramel note. Theres some coffee, but Im not really getting any sorts of chocolate aromas. This beer has a very good nose on it.

Taste: For being supposedly the best oatmeal stout in the world, Im pretty largely let down for a few reasons. Ill assume this is due to my ignorance, but anyway... first of all, the mouthfeel isnt at all what I thought it would be. Rather than a smooth feel, its pretty light with a surprising amount of prickly carbonation. Second, the flavor is just lacking. It isnt bad, but it sort of tastes like watered down coffee. As it warms up a bit, I also get a minor dark fruit flavor that I find odd, but it does add a bit more depth and intrigue to the beer. Ive been under the impression that (of ones Ive had) oatmeal stouts have a relatively thick, creamy mouthfeel with fairly mild carbonation, and have a nice, bold flavor. I dont get it with this.

My dad claims that this is the best beer that hes ever had, but Ive had better oatmeal stouts that were made right here in Michigan. I know my opinion is an unpopular one, but it is what it is. S.S.O.S. is a drinkable, easy-to-session sort of beer, but its not how I like my stouts.

Deep brown with creamy head. The aroma is all malt with a touch of cereal. It has a medium body with silky, smooth texture and average carbonation. The taste is mildly sweet to start and leads into a bittersweet, semi-dry finish.

550 ml bottle at Sliders Sports Bar in West Hartford, CT. Pour is black with a light tan head, some lacing. Smell is chocolate, slight coffee and dark malt. Taste is chocolate, a bit of coffee and a faint bit of oatmeal, dark fruit and hops. Very smooth, great mouthfeel. Classic stout.

This one was a big want more for me for a while, being a big fan of oatmeal stouts. I thought it was very good but actually a little overrated. I know it is supposed to be world class oatmeal stout but there are definitely ones I would choose over this.

Wow, this is a great oatmeal stout! Incredibly smooth and easy to drink with minimal bitterness. Great dark, roasty, malty flavors that hint at chocolate but dont quite present as the typical chocolate/coffee stout duo. Excellent beer.

Fine brew with delightful aroma. Silky and smooth however the taste is a bit plain.

Serving type: bottle

Appearance- Pours a think extremely dark brown black with a creamy tan head and nice sticky lacing

Aroma- Roasted oats with a sweet malt smell

T/P- This is a very smooth stout. The taste has a nice sweetness to it that lingers very nicely. The carbonation is right on with this one

Overall- This is a good heavy stout. It is very drinkable, and one that you could drink all night.
Poured deep, dark reddish brown with a frothy beige head. Aroma of roast malt, sweet berry fruit. Medium , smooth body, flavour of the sweet fruit, milk chocolate, dry, bitter sweet finish.
Diep zwart met crème schuimkraag. In de geur Bastogne koeken met koffie. Smaak bitterzoet crème en toffee, body is iets minder dan gemiddeld, Goed door drinkbaar stout.

Bottle - Roasted malts, dark fruits and molasses. Jet black with a rich brown head. Coffee, chocolate, little bit of licorice and a nice coffee finish. Slick on the tongue, a great example of an Oatmeal Stout.
Overall pretty decent stout, got it at a bar in los angeles, bottle, rich, but easy to drink
Favorite stout to date. White head, deep black body. A little bit sweet, a perfect balance. A dry creamy finish.
Bottle.from The Crown. Gorgeous thick cream head. Dark Cola appearance. Liquorice and strong molasses aroma. Sour and bitter chocolate taste, very nice indeed.

Pours a really dark brown with a small offwhite ring of foam that leaves good lacing. Aroma contains a nice roasted malt presence but not overpowering, Some nice "whole milk" sweetness in there too. Taste is sweet but not too much with a light bitter. Mouthfeel is smooth and "oat-y". Medium body, medium carb. Not bad at all!

Espuma abundante, permanece basta tiempo, se cuelga, negro muy oscuro, mucho cuerpo, un amargor muy controlado, una cerveza muy equilibrada y perfecta con un chocolate

Pours medium/dark brown with thick off white head. Smells of roasted malts and caramel. Tastes of bitter, roasted malts, and toffee. Sharp flavor with medium carbonation.
Poured from a bottle, San Diego. Spicy, alcoholic, roasted malt aroma. Dark brown-black body, strong creamy head. Silky, smooth, creamy body. Sweet, gentle flavor. A very nice beer!

Gold foil covered brown pint bottle into snifter glass, near black/super dark brown with foamy light tan head. Aroma of roasted malt sweetness, caramel, molasses, oatmeal, some chocolate and some smoke. Taste is very smooth and creamy; adding notes of dark chocolate, dark fruit, some nuttiness, powdered sugar with a slight earthy hop note. Medium body, low carbonation, creamy, smooth, sweet with roasty finish. Very good oatmeal stout, easy drinking.

Pours dark, almost black with a foamy tan head. Nose is molasses. Taste is sweet and malty. A bit thin for an oatmeal stout. Nice brew.

Very dark brown fading to almost black. Nice brown head but didnt stay long. Very good aroma of oatmeal and cocoa. Medium bitterness and has full of flavors: oatmeal, bready and roasted malts, chocolate and cocoa. Very good oatmeal stout, definitly one of these you must taste.

Bottle. Dark brown with a small, creamy, excellent lacing, slowly diminishing brownish head. Aroma is roasted malt, licorice, smoked wood, coffee. Flavor is sweet and moderate hoppy bitter, light acidic. Not very complex. Finish is roasted with hints of cocoa. A bit watery, almost no aftertaste, but not bad.

Aroma: dark chocolate, nutty. App: black to the point of disappearing in it, thin but lasting tan head. Taste: sweet, slightly floral. Palate: fairly thin but long finish. Overall: good but not great. Pretty straight forward.

Cerveza con una gran apariencia a la de un café expresso. Es una cerveza suave, de gran calidad y muy redonda. No recomiendo que se beba después de una cerveza muy lupulada o amarga porque sino se pierde notas de sabor. Final dulce. Mejor beber no demasiado fria.

A very good sweet stout nice aroma with a wonderful mouthfeel and taste help the beer to compliment itself. Wonderful somewhat bitter chocolate finish. This is one of the better sweet stouts for a reason. Should be on everyone's beer to try list.

Bottle (550 ml). From Chris, thanks! Black with a medium creamy and fully lasting beige head, good lacing. Aroma is light but delightful with chocolate, roasted malt, raisins, toffee and bread notes. Taste is moderately sweet (lactose sweetness) and also light with the same features as aroma. The raisins notes are even a little more present. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Rich and super silky mouthfeel. One of the best Stout available on the market, it worth the high ratings. Superb balance! A perfect beer to accompany a meal.
Great Stout at a great price, staple when Draught Guinness no longer pleases.
user_location: San Antonio Pero Aqui, Texas, USA

text: This and its nut brown cousin are two of the first really good beers I ever tasted. After all those years it still holds up just fine, with a flavor full of malt, roast, and chocolate. Finish is a little thin compared to a lot of todays big stouts, but that just makes this both very drinkable and very tasty. Great beer from a great brewery.
Hands down, the best oatmeal stout Ive had so far. Thats the only way to describe this classic.

500ml bottle. One of the beers that first started me on this expensive journey and always happy to have a bottle or two during the holidays when we get gift packs with this in it. Mahogany brown with a nice light brown bubbly head. Some wet oats, slightly roasted malt, somewhat bitter, smooth, moderate carbonation and body, easy to drink with a oat and barley finish. Still like this one.
Pleasant chocolate and oat aroma. Pours thick brown with a nice tan head. Sweet flavors but not enough bitterness for me.  Nice creamy and fizzy mouthfeel.

Dark ruby brown with a large tan head that leaves a lot of lacing. Aroma is dates, treacle, plum, chocolate, mixed berry jam. Very creamy mouthfeel, full bodied, sweet on the palate with subtle hints of bitterness and umami on the finish. Taste is chocolate pudding, plums, dates, raisins and a hint of sweet English breakfast tea. I say, quite a good drop!

500ml bottle. Dark brown-black colour, frothy foam tan head and aroma of malt, brown sugar, dark fruits & chocolate. Taste is malty with dark treacle, raisins, chocolate, some slight roasted notes and a bittersweet finish. Silky smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied, soft carbonation. Very drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a deep rich brown (as you would expect) with a thick tall tan head that lingers quite awhile. Tastes of molasses and roasted malt. Very deceptively light. Extremely well done.

Appearance is pitch black with a creme colored 1-inch head, almost no lacing. Aroma is of alcohol and toasted malts. A lot of depth in the taste... sweet licorice and light bitterness, with a bittersweet lingering taste. Very silky on the palate, with soft carbonation. Overall a very drinkable and delicious stout!

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2015  Appearance: 2" dark cream colored head recedes slowly. Moderate lacing. Color is dark brown with no carbonation visible due to the opacity.

Aroma: strong aroma of coffee, chocolate, licorice, cocoa.

Mouthfeel: lighter than I would expect but still medium bodied with a dry finish finish. The oats add a silkiness to the mouthfeel.

Flavor: pick up the oats, chocolate, cocoa, some licorice, not as much coffee as the aroma, but there is an astrigent dryness in the finish. Hop presence is in the background of these prominent malts but due linger in the aftertaste.
Dark black like oil. Thick foamy tan head. Beautiful beer. Roasted, almost charred really good stout.
Well...this is my favorite dark brew! Ive had it a couple times before just never rated it. Hands down better than Guinness IMHO!

Pours a slightly thick black with a small tan head. Mildly roasted sweet caramel and chocolate malts fill the senses along with some sweet oatmeal grains dark fruity esters. Taste same as aroma. Palate is a rich creamy body with light carbonation. The finish is sweet mildly roasted caramel and chocolate malts, some dark fruity flavors with light bitterness on the end for balance. A very good, tasty and nicely balanced brew. I like.

Decent oatmeal stout, obviously flavors of oatmeal, chocolate bit nutty. Milder flavor for this variety, somewhat smooth. Good, but wish it was bolder, made to appeal to the masses and it will do that.

Pours black with a durable thick head. Roasted malt dominates the aroma, and alcohol started to creep in as it warmed. The roastiness takes a back seat to sweet flavors, but comes back in the aftertaste. Flavors seem to remind me of molasses, although the subdued mouthfeel is thinner than some of the other stouts I have tried. Very drinkable stout.
A great all around stout. Black as night when poured with perfect head. Not to heavy with great finish. Great intro to English stouts.

The appearance of this beer is a very dark brown color with a large off-white head. The aroma is a very pleasant combination of roasted malts, chocolate malts, caramel malts, and vanilla, and the taste is slightly umami, mildly sweet, and a touch sour. Although the taste is quite nice by itself, the palates fusion of a full body, long malty finish, oily texture, and soft carbonation makes the whole picture of the beer extremely enjoyable.

Pours very dark brown with a big tan head. Dark roasted malts in the aroma giving it a bit of coffee and raisins. Nice semi-sweet chocolate taste without the harsh, roasted finish of a dry stout. Full, velvety mouthfeel.

Bottle @ Elfos Pub, Perugia, Italy. Pours with a dark brown, hazy colour; long lasting tan rocky head. Aroma is moderately malty, with notes of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, licorice, cocoa, wood; little hoppy, with notes of herbs; little yeasty, with notes of dough. Taste is moderately sweet, a bit bitter, slightly sour, and moderately salty. Medium to full body, smooth creamy texture, soft carbonation, medium to long lasting sweet finish.
This is a go to beer for a great smooth easy drink. It does not have a heavy feel to it like other stouts.

Pours nearly black with a thick creme colored head. Taste of bitter chocolate and caramel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Im drinking this stout right now. It is indeed a fantastic beer. I only wish it was a little more viscous. Instead of "velvety" texture, its more an easy going, watery kind of thing. Its gots some flavors coming out that one might generally expect from some belgian brews. I cant say its the best stout out there but it is really tasty.

550 ml bottle. Pours very dark brown with a very big pillowy head that fades very slowly and lingers nicely. Leaves nice lacing. Aromas are caramel, light roast coffee, vanilla, cocoa, and dark bread. Taste is so smooth. One of the easiest stouts to drink out there. All of the aromas come through as you drink it and they balance nicely. Medium body with a creamy mouthfeel, slightly oily too. Overall, its seems so simple at first but it grows on you as you drink it.

pours opaque black with large tan foam head. Aroma-coffee malts with alcohol smoothness. HInt of spiciness and caramel. Carbonation, caramel, coffee. The beginning is uncomplicated but is made up for my a smooth as milk caramel middle with gentle non-bitter coffee end that is so smooth, maybe some maple. The most drinkable stout Ive ever had.
Black with a thick frothy head, no distinctive roasted flavours but it has a stout base although not the best tasting.
Dark pour in glass aroma of coffee, little head, bitter aftertaste, good drink overall

So good, so cheap!  This might be the best "bang for buck" beer that you can find in most liquor stores.  Tastes like 2/3 banana nut bread 1/3 vanilla ice cream.  If you havent had it yet, not sure what you have been doing with your beer life, but stop passing it by and get some.

Pours inky black with a 3 finger fluffy brown head that settles to a nice ring. Aroma is toasted malts and subtle English-style hops. Taste is chocolate, some coffee, toast, and oats--pretty standard for a stout but done exceptionally well. Smooth, silky mouthfeel with just a touch of carbonation. This is an excellent, sessionable stout that is well worth the money. For $3.50 a 550ml bottle, youll be hard-pressed to find a better deal.

stout muy sabrosa, sin mucho amargor y con mucho aguante nel paladar. muy facil de beber.
lo que me paez, ye que-y falta un poquiñin de aguante a la espuma, pero bueno, detalles sin mas pa rellenar los 75 caracteres jejejejeej.
cojonudisima!!!!&

A very drinkable stout. Quite smooth and balanced. Easily quaffable and actually quite refreshing. Barely any aroma to speak of which is normal for this type of beer. Flavors are roasted malt predominately with hints Of chocolate. Body is not as full as other oatmeal stouts.

bottle, pours very dark brown (pretty lively!) with reddish tinge and a fluffy off white head. Aroma is malt, dark fruits, dark rum, some treacle, a little minerally. Full and foamy in the mouth, a bit lighter than expected. Flavour is maltiness, more dark dried fruits, dark sugars. Its sweet, slightly bitter, very moreish, and very drinkable!

Poured from 22oz bottle to shaker. Pours a nice dark brown almost black color with a light tan head. Ivan smell coffee and caramel notes, and the taste is exactly how it smells. Very smooth finish, great beer.

Wonderful full bodied stout. This is the pinnacle of outmeal stouts. This beer has a silky smooth texture with a clean bittersweet finish. This was one of my first dark beers as a youngster and really gave way to my appreciation of good dark beers. I thank you Sam Smith

Full disclosure: I largely credit Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout for developing my appreciation for dark beers back when I was young. The aroma of this beer is powerfully fruity and malty with the slightest hint of earthy oats. Very appetizing looking with a tan colored head that lasts. Taste is silky and bittersweet and very approachable. Acidity from the roasted grain and crystal malts balances the residual sweetness perfectly and hops are a background note. Palate is broad, richly malty, and silky-smooth. Will buy again and again.
Pours dark with a tan foamy head. alty aroma. Bitter taste with some spice and sweetness. Nice bite on the tongue going down.
Bottle. Deep ruby/caramel coke with a rich, tan head. Candy, light malt and caramel aromas. Similar flavors with a silky mouthfeel.
Strong oatmeal and yeast aroma. Black color with tan head. Looking stouty. Taste sweet! Nutty vanilla and raisin taste. Pretty damn smooth.

As anyone can tell by my high rating numbers for this beer, I really am a fan of Smith's Oatmeal Stout. The number one seller for me is the richness of its taste. I really enjoy its full mouthful, and that coupled with a caramel, chocolate, and coffee-like flavor, makes me happy when I pour a glass of this into my favorite mug. The head is full, and the latticework is enticing. Darn good beer!

beige head that disappears quickly and slight lacing. coffee coloured. sweet aroma, solvent, caramel, wood, butter toffee. sweet taste, malt, oats and weak bitterness. sweet caramel like aftertaste. medium body and soft carbonation.  bottle 35.5 cl @ baden baden
The head is medium, the body darkbrown, almost black. It smells roasty, oatmeal, darkmalty. The taste is darkmalty, roasty, oat. 12/12/11/11/12/11
Malty with light hops, decent head size, slightly bitter and sour on the finish...ok...

Bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Has an odd aroma to it, there is the normal roast and chocolate but also has a little bit of a funky note as well. Medium mouthfeel. Smooth is how I would describe this beer, both is feel and taste. Slightly sweet with a touch of roast bitterness. Pretty tasty.

When I poured this beer the inside of my glass became completely covered with tiny bubbles. It came out black with a frothy brown head that gradually fades. Aroma of rich dark malt and roasted oats. It isnt as rich or heavy as you would expect from its appearance but still has a dark malt and oat flavor. Its somewhat bitter like black coffee. Its fizziness causes a light sting on my tongue and lips.

Great super traditional oatmeal stout...smooth and real easy to drink... I say smoking tasting but I was by a fire...

Poured from 550ml bottle.  Huge fluffy tan head.  Smells of bread, molasses, raisin, vanilla and alcohol.  Black pour with dark brown at the edges when held to light.  Smooth, full, creamy and silky on the tongue.  Hint of sour,  bittersweet, slightest touch of salt.  Carbonation is very soft, bordering on flat.  Long sweet finish.  A fine stout.
My favorite beer overall!  The aroma wets the palate, for the taste that melts you in your seat.  It has a smooth finish.  Good frothy head, and for looks its a pint with a gold top ;)  5 Stars

Lovely from draught at my local Samuel Smiths pub, Blue Bell, Preston.
Also pretty fine from the bottle!
Bottle. Pours black with small beige head. Roasted malts and coffee aroma. Roasted malts and sweet taste, a little bitter. Medium body.
Pours dark with a beige head. Very slight sweetness on the nose. Subtle sweetness into the mouth which turns to bitterness into the swallow.  Was OK.

How these beer escaped my early ticking?  well I do remember how this happened; i was busy drinking.  the go to sammy smith, at least it was for the hippies who frequented spirit haus.  funny how fads start, even in choice of craft beer.  Okay oatmeal stout, a little thin and metallic for my tastes then and now.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with light brown head. Decention retention, settles to thick cap with lacing. Aroma is malty, roasted, nutty, and sweet. Flavor is malty, roasted malt, roasted/burnt grain, hint of chocolate. Malt heavy finish. Tastes fine, but not nearly as much oatmeal flavor as I recall, oatmeal comes across more in sweetness than in actual flavor. Soft carbonation, medium body, and a smooth texture. A good beer a pretty good oatmeal stout.

Poured from a  550 ml bottle.
Nice pitch black color, with a beige and dense head leaving a marked and deep lace. Bread and roasted malts aromas with hints of black coffee.
Looks great, smells great.
What about the taste? In a word- medicinal.
The taste does not linger, but that is how I describe it.
I have probably had three oatmeal stouts BETTER than this one in the past 12 months. I know I am out of place with the other rave ratings here, but that is what I am feeling.

550 ml bottle into imperial pint glass, bottled on 8/3/2012.  Pours crystal clear almost opaque dark brown color with a nice 2 finger dense and fluffy light tan head with incredible retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lasts.  Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass.  Aromas of caramel, cocoa, molasses, oatmeal, dark bread, toast, light apple, floral, and earthiness.  Very nice aromas with good balance and complexity of malt notes with some light fruitiness.  Taste of caramel, molasses, cocoa, oatmeal, toast, roasted malt, dark bread, floral, and roasted earthiness.  Light floral bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, molasses, oatmeal, cocoa, toast, roasted malt, dark bread, and earthiness on the finish for a good bit.  Very nice balance and complexity of dark malt notes with moderate hops; with great flavor robustness and zero cloying flavors after the finish.  Medium carbonation and body; with a creamy and slick mouthfeel that is nice.  Alcohol is very well hidden with hardly any warming noticed after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent oatmeal stout.  Very nice balance and complexity of dark malt flavors; and very smooth to drink.  A very enjoyable offering.

1Pt. 2.7 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured Black with a huge foamy head. Aroma of roasted malts, some fruit and some coffee. Taste is quite sweet, malty, caramel and fruit (very consistent) nice bitterly and dry finish. Super nice and very enjoyable stout nothing super fancy just a very well made stout.

bottle. Pours dark black, tan head, slight ruby tinge when held up to light. Aroma of roast and chocolate and vanilla. Nice smooth mouthfeel, taste is a little astringent but nice roasty malts and very well balanced. Good beer.

Deep black pour topped by a fluffy tan head, maybe a dark red-brown highlight at the very edge of the glass. Lots of fruit on the nose, a bit like a fruit cake but with more of a roasted note. The taste is a blend of chocolate, dark fruits (currants and raisins especially) and a little coffee. The mouth feel of this beer is pretty amazing - silky smooth. Lightly sweet finish, little if any astringency, and an apple/spice aftertaste. Very nice oatmeal stout.

Light bodied but chocolatety. Grad too sweet.

Poured from a bottle into glass. Extremely dark brown body, almost black. Light brown head dissolves quickly to just the edge. Aroma is pretty small. Not much going on in the nose other than some roasted malts, faint coffee. Sweet up front, chocolatey and coffee, a little chalky. Dry bitter finish that goes on for a bit.
Honestly Im disappointed with this beer. The aroma and flavors are pretty weak. What flavor is there is accompanied by a metallic taste. In my opinion theres not much going on here.

Bouteille 500ml. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez dun mélange de chocolat noir et de chocolat au lait sucré, moyen de malt rôti  avec des notes de caramel, de mélasse et de fruits foncés. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement doux-moyen ainsi quune texture moyennement crémeuse. Goût légèrement fruité (prunes rouges, notes de mûres) avec un léger goût de mélasse lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de caramel, de malt rôti doux, de chocolat noir avec de légères notes de chocolat au lait (notes lactiques) puis en finale lon retrouve des notes de réglisse noire, de houblon herbeux et de noix grillées. Post-goût moyen-long, légèrement amer de chocolat noir et de rôti avec des notes fruitées (mûres) et des traces de noix grillées. (2006)

Dark brown-red with a fluffy meringue head and some lacing. Nose of dark fruit and cherry coke. Mildly-carbonated with a milkshake/malty mouthfeel and an aftertaste consisting of caramel, white chocolate, cherries, and vanilla ice cream.

Hints of burgundy adorn the edges, other than that, its an all black stout. The oatmeal really is the star here. Along with flavor, it adds heft to the velvety texture.

The mineral flavors from the English hard water are there, too, but it just adds to the character. Quick hit of hops at the end, but the roasted and smokey flavors take over in the finish.

Theres a very good reason this is a classic.

Pours an opaque, very dark brown with glints of cola brown around the bottom and edges when held to the light. A large, fluffy, dark caramel-colored head forms quickly and retains a little better than average. Once it dissipates, splotchy and spiderweb lacing is left on the edges of the glass, while a thin cap sits atop the beer. Aromas are comprised primarily of sweet chocolate and sorghum. While these aromas come through distinctly, they are not overly bold. There are also notes of roasted malt and ripe cherry. Mouthfeel is smooth, and not too viscous. The mild hop on the finish accentuates the light carbonation scrubbing. Flavors come through almost as distinctly as the aromas. However, everything is mild. In a time of craft brewers competing for the biggest beer, its nice to sip a stout that has a lot of flavor in different varieties without having my palate overwhelmed. Mild chocolate, sorghum, and ripe fruit esters occur, essentially in that order. I regard this a quintessential stout.

Bottle from Beers of Europe cons 2013-03-30 Uddingston
- Dont know why I have missed out on this one???

Bottle a black colored beer with a white head aroma roasted malts dark fruit spicy and hops flavor roasted malts spicy citrus some fruits and hops

Pours almost opaque, deep umber brown. 1.5 finger head which was almost non existent after a few minutes in a Samuel Adams beer glass. Aroma was sweet and bready, and a bit weak. Notes of caramel, bourbon, roasted, hearty oat. Very nicely balanced, not too sweet or too bitter but enough of both. 
Very drinkable, and for a stout thats a good thing. 
Damn good beer.
Doesnt have much of a smell, which is odd for a stout.  Taste is a little thin and carbonated.  Its okay, but nothing special.
2013 - 03 - 21  550ml bottle. dark brown colour. small tan head. roasty, earthy aroma. bit bitter taste.

Samuel Smiths, mica cotica. Nera opaca con poca schiuma poco persistente. Al naso le classiche note di caffè e cioccolato, con una venatura piuttosto dolce. Al palato ingresso dolce, con note di caffè, cioccolato, legno bruciato e tabacco. Finale luppolato con un retrogusto piuttosto intenso che invita al sorso successivo. Equilibrata complessa e buonissima con leleganza da birra inglese. Cin cin, Sir.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2014 Jan 2013 - nice mouthfeel, smoky and well rounded mild and slightly sweet flavour, with hardly any bitterness and an enduring tacky burnt rubber finish (albeit mild of course).  Overall, very nice.   [EARLY RATING - DUE A RE-RATE]
500ml bottle, pours dark brown, no head, smells of coffee and molasses, tastes of coffee, toffee and burnt toast. Full body and overall a splendid stout.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2013 355ml bottle. Pours a deep black with a finger and a half of light tan head that slowly fades. Aromas of roast malt and sweet chocolate. Taste is chocolate, oats, and roast malt flavor with a bit of coffee and nice sweetness throughout.
Very dark beer. Pours with a nice head, not lasting though. Taste of, caramel, malt and a bit roasty. A nice stout.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2016 Pours black with a 2 inch tan head. Smells of malts and caramel with notes of chocolate and coffee. Tastes of chocolate, roasted malts and some coffee. Creamy and slightly bready with a medium full body and a dry finish. A fantastic oatmeal stout.

Dark cola like color with a small amount of tan head that dissipates down to some nice marbling on the surface. Smells of dark fruit, banana, grain, caramel, vanilla. An ever so slight spice as it first hits the tongue that gives way to a beautiful sweet malty caramel, brown sugar with very little hop bitterness. I get the fig, raisin, banana in there as well as a sweet oatmeal. The taste is overall relatively subtle which is my only complaint, but doesn't subtract too much from my score. Very lovely stout.

Bottle. Pours inky brown-black with billowing foamy tan head. Simple nose of caramel, dough, cereal, and oats. Super smooth and buttery in the mouth- really quaffable. Clean finishing, warming and round without brig overly heavy. Really quite good once you get into it.

Bottle. Pours almost black with a big khaki head. Nose opens with chocolate, a slight metallic twinge, a hint of vanilla and some roasted malt. Some dark fruits appear in the nose as it warms. 550 mL bottle. Cost exactly $3.99. To Hill Farmstead stemmed glass it pours a darkish brown with which sustained a frothy khaki head one to two fingers in length. Aromas of rolled oats, refined sugar, copper alloy, peanut butter, sorghum molasses, cinnamon, and sweet potatoes. Tastes of organic peanut butter, oats, candied sugar, and London yeast. Ends slightly artificially sweet, but otherwise a decent stout.
High quality stout here. Dark pour with decent head.  Im not a lactating mother - but I could see the nutritional value of this...

It took me a third of the bottle before I finally "got" this, but when I did... wow. Roasted coffee with a fruity woody English barleywine flavour. I cant believe this is 5%, thats insane. Oats can apparently trick you with the viscosity.
A little bitterness, but otherwise its complex in flavor (roasted coffee with a unique earthiness) and very drinkable. A session stout if there ever was one.
Pours almost black with a big creamy tan head and nice lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt, molasses, and coffee.  Taste is sweet with roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and a slight metallic taste.

Lots of malt in the nose and a little candy/liquor. Sweeter taste than I remember, as much dark fruit as coffee or chocolate, almost like a bock. Smooth, wonderful balance. If theres such a thing as an "all day stout," this would be it.

text: Pours a very dark black colour with just a touch of light coming through with a small off white head that slowly dissolves into a thin ring around the glass. (bottle, 35.5cl) Dark brown, almost black coloured hue with a beige and firm mid-sized foamy head. Roasty malty, leafy aroma with notes of liquorice, dark chocolate and a tinge of mocha. This is still one of the very best out there.  It has such a depth of flavor and aroma.  Not heavy, but perfectly balanced.
Simple enough but extremely pleasant, the gold standard for the oatmeal stout style. The more I drink it the more I like it.

Pours a very dark brown color with a frothy light brown head that sticks around for the longest time. Working my way past the frothy top, the beer is full of great, smooth, and mellow flavors. The ingredients are so well blended together its hard to pick out certain flavors but theres the obvious robust malts, oatmeal, roasted barley, and yeast as indicated on the back of the bottle. Quite a fine beer and a must drink for any beer advocate member.

My favorite beer. Liquid bread. Barely beats out Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter only because of its history. Search the Internet for article by Alan Moen "The merchant of beer" and see why the introduction of this beer to America is a watershed moment in the microbeer revolution.

55cl bottle at The Swan, Durham. Pours jet black with thick off white/tan head; loads of thick lacing. Aroma is light chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, oat cereal, light smokiness, burnt sugar. Pours dark brown with a thick tan head. The aroma is not very strong. The taste is suprisingly pleasant. Light and crisp with light chocolate and mild coffee notes. This beer is pretty delicious and I would have no problem drinking it as a session beer.

Black with some tan head,spotty lacing.
Aroma has some chocolate,roast,caramel,raison,some woody tones,
Smooth creamy,good chocolate roast,smooth roast in  the finish,some dry woodiness,some tart buttery tones with caramel semisweetness.Prettty nice.

Pours a not quite opaque black with slight chestnut fringes, big frothy head which condenses into a crema top, aroma is dark malts, milk chocolate notes. Taste is a bit more chocolate with a nice bitter touch at the end, Little bit thinner than I would expect from an oatmeal stout. 

via Beer Buddy

Dark brown pour. Thick tan head. A lot of chocolate and dark roast in aroma. Taste has some of the chocolate and sweetness that comes with the oatmeal stout. A little bit if funkiness from open fermentation. Not quite as clean and hoppy as I'm use to from American styles but it was very good. 

---Rated via iPhone

Fantastica stout inglese. Color marrone scuro, opaco, schiuma marrone chiaro compatta ma non molto persistente. Laroma presenta, oltre alle tipiche note di una stout, anche accenni liquorosi. In bocca il malto torrefatto pervade senza disturbare. Il luppolo e il "bruciato" si bilanciano perfettamente. Finale secco e lungo. Di facile beva.
Delicious oatmeal stout. I dont feel that it has as much flavor as other Sammy Smiths.

Toasty, roasty and a little bit of coffee notes. Smells slightly sweet. Nice brown head, not pitch black but rather reddish on the edges of the glass. Taste is sweet malt, not bitter at all. Roasty taste. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Great oatmeal stout, personally would prefer a little bit less sweet taste.

550ml->SA glass.  Deep brown with nice tan head.  Aroma is sweet with some coffee and malt.  Tastes of malt, grains, some coffee and chocolate, with a soy sauce finish.  Good, but not near ecpectations.

While completing a "Hall of Foam" list at my favorite local pub, this is one of those few beers that kept slowing me down as Id backtrack and forgo any progress and have another at least once a month. Silky, dark, delicious, and smooth. This is the taste Im anticipating every time I pour a Stout and, more often than not, Im let down. When Im not its all the better.

A really smooth meal type beer,  distinct flavors and invigorating for the palate - not my first and certainly not my last 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bitter roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and smooth milk chocolate, some dark sweet fruits. Very smooth and tasty 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle - Pours a beautiful deep brown-black with a massive creamy tan head. Medium roast, milky with hints of cinnamon, peat, and a touch of whiskey. Taste is much of the same, with the medium roast giving just enough bitterness to offset the toffee and sweetened condensed milk hints. Finishes sweet, but with a roasty bitterness that lingers for awhile in the mouth. Thinner than I expected, but silky smooth. Wow, what a wonderful beer.

550ml bottle. Intense, voluminous head took up half the pint glass even after a slow pour! Opaque black gold (Lovibond 39). Head finally subsided and a thick, messy (read: awesome) lace clings to the side. Can't smell a thing. No aroma. Like milk. Taste is understated, yet complex. Some toasty malts up front, with a twist of bitter hops (very slight) at the end. Great palate, silky mouthfeel and creamy texture - again, like milk. Delightful.
Very smooth beer. Puts black with tran lacing about an inch thick. Notes if caramel. Taste is a milky slight bitter maltiness. Quite good.
Bottle to pint. Looks good; black with beige lacing. Smells and tastes malty and roasty. Good on the palate. A great example of the style.

brown mocha/cola head poured into samuel smith pint glass. near bottom light shows its a dark red but top under head allways looks black and it seems jet black away from light. Smell is the best its a airy light heavinly smooth chocolate smell,made me so happy and excited. Taste is some water,smooth sily chocolate,some of that sourniss a bit that darker beers can have,oatmeal & brown sugar. So good this beer! 8.95/10 :)

Looks good and smells mmmmm. Lightest dark chocolate and creaminess on the tongue but it seems to lack some of the cpmlexity and dimension I remember. Four square really but still relevant. Will it ever be served via cask??

Bottle, served in pint glass. body is dark and opaque. Brown, creamy head which slowly fades into a film which lasts all the tasting. Good lacing. Aroma is led by toasted malt: chocolate, coffee, bread. Palate is silky and delicate, lighter than the expected from the appearance and the aroma. Taste is absolutely delicious: coffee, bread, chocolate; a little of bitter notes to compensate the high sweetness. Long, medium dry finish.

Ok, I love this beer.  Pours black & silky, like out of an oil can.  No head, strong aroma, nutty.  Heavy body, medium-bitter, malty & toasted, slight herb and sweet notes.  The oatmeal by which others are measured.
Pretty tasty brew, I wish it had a higher alcohol percent but beggars cant be choosers
Pored from a 12 oz bottle at a tasting. Pours a dark cola with a tan head. Molasses and caramel in the nose. Dark cherries and chocolate notes. Very nice.

Bottle at the Cittie of Yorke (£5.50 - BE WARNED!) - 29/10/12.
Mid black with a thick creamy tan head. Good lacing ensues.
Roast malt, treacle toffee, light barley/oats on the nose.
Taste follows allied to some molasses and leather.
Medium bodied with moderate carbonation.
Ok stout - dont understand why this beer attracts such high ratings???
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: nice stable creamy brown head, roasty aroma, medium dry bitterness with sweetish hind in ending, medium body, slick feel, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, good balanced Stout very nice
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

text: [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ One finger mocca foam. Roasted coffee notes. Smooth gentle dry sweet palate. Great ancient brew.

Very opaque chocolate brown color with a creamyish tan head. Nose is cocoa and bitter chocolate malts, slightly clean and astringent. Maybe a little wood and nut in there. Cereal grains and more woody chocolate in the mouth. Refuses to be a heavy viscosity beer like the Lion but is more than medium in mouthfeel for sure. Amazing to me that the Brits brew these over-the-top beers and keep them around 5% consistently. Way to go Samuel Smiths!.

What a presentation - pitch black with gigantic fluffy head that lingers and lingers, revealing beautiful lacing.  Aroma - dark, rich, bready malts that command multiple whiffs - oatmeal also present.  Flavor - oatmeal with dark, rich, yet not over-bodied stout characteristics, balanced bitterness, bitter and malty aftertaste that goes on and on.  Mouthfeel is just exquisite.  What an amazing beer - DEMANDS to be savored.  In the upper echelon for sure.

soft oatmeal palate, not extremely heavy, not too thick, nice simply sweet buttery aroma, good drinking beer, a little froth, smooth texture, 5% alcohol...I wish it had a higher alcohol %tage, Nice beer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
SMOOTH dark beer. Clean flavor. This is the best oatmeal stout Ive encountered. Surprisingly easy to drink. Perfect carbonation.
Nothing wrong with this beer.  Nice dark brown/black pour.  Good rich smooth mouthfeel.  Chocolate, light dark fruits, light sweetness, lactose, and all around tasty.

Bottle 500ml @ Geokkjer
Pours almost black with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, oatmeal, chocolate and caramel. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a long chocolate and oatmeal finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Opaque black with thin,bubbly, tan head a couple of inches thick. Light bubbly lacing across the side of glass. Head fizzes away really fast.

Very nice smells of cocoa/coffee, roasted malt and slight grain/malt sweetness. Very pleasant and long-lasting on the nose.

Thick mouthfeel of smooth creaminess, sweetness, dark roasted malts, and chocolate. Delicious, pretty much a dessert beer. Medium to thick body, with medium level of carbonation.

This is one outstanding stout! Thick, creamy, tasty and satisfying, you cannot go wrong. I will sure as hell have this again, as long as I can find it.

Mmmmmmm, silky. This glides through your gob, nothing like a dump. Sweet and bitter, much like life. So this is life. In a mouthful. In a glass. Is the mouthful or mouthalful? Or should that be mouthhalfful? But that just seems silly. Either wall its all semantics. Or all about the Benjamins. Or its all about what you make of it. Or who you know. Or what is right and wrong. People talk a lot of guff. Im going to write a story called the Guffalo. Or Guffalot. Pah.

Pours almost black with a tan head. Aromas of chocolate, bread, and roasted malt. Taste of chocolate, like a dark chocolate that has lots of fruit notes in it, and a hint of tartness (in a good way). Nice roasty malt and light hop bitterness with a slightly dry finish. Palate is awesome, soft and creamy. Easy to see why this is a classic.
color negro espuma marrón y poco persistente. aroma a cereal alcohol frutos  negros saborbueno con notas ahubuen equilibrio

Pours a nice not-quite-black with a strong tan head. Not much to the aroma - chestnut, malt, a little cocoa. Taste is something else though - just sweet enough, great malt characteristics, and ridiculously smooth. One of my favorite stouts.

Pours jet black with a tab head that lasts nicely. Super smooth palate, goes down very easily. Tastes of burnt malt, coffee, and a great sweet-bitter balance. Lovely.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz. bottle. Pours an almost black color with a thin tan head that doesnt last very long. Very sweet aroma with roasted coffee notes. Medium body, coffee flavor with a little sweetness to it. Smooth finish, slightly dry. Excellent!
UPDATED: OCT 7, 2012 Very smooth oatmeal stout and so easy to drink. Best Stout I have had so far!

This brings back a lot of good memories of basically being the first stout that I ever really liked.  Drinking in the lot for a winter Phish tour.  Dark brown to black with a thin tan head. Aroma of milk chocolate and coffee. Flavour is very smooth roast chocolate, slivery nice texture. Finish is creamy smooth. Very nice.
A classic that drinks like a meal. Hearty, wholesome, deep, dark and delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 What a beauty! No wonder this beer from Samuel Smiths has set the standard for oatmeal stouts. And such high standards. How can one not love this beer? Smooth, silky, velvety, creamy. Is it the oats? Not much of a nose, just some roasted malts - the basics. It pours very dark brown, with a firm creamy head that leaves layers of cream as it subsides, like an old geiser. And it has that sexy colour of classy lingerie. Full-bodied, sweet and bitter, PERFECTLY balanced ,a hint of chocolate, but it never gets on the way. Cozy, comfy, hearty, the finish is so elegant that you deeply regret when your country does not import it on a regular basis. Perfection in a bottle.
Great stout. Silky smooth, good head, excellent flavor. Almost too smooth but very enjoyable. Hadnt really liked an oatmeal stout yet, but this one was a winner.
Very dark amber.  Head forever - thick light brown and sticks around for the whole show.  Smooth and thick - almost milky.  Good bitterness at the finish with just a hint of the "soy sauce" flavor.
On a cold day, or simply at the end of one, you cannot go wrong with Sammy Smiths Oatmeal Stout. Perfect balance of bitter and sweet. Creamy and and very smooth dry finish. Love it

Bomber bottle poured deep brown hue w/ a huge creamy tan head that is fully lasting with good lacing. Soft carbonation. Nice level of aroma gives a sweet coffee smell. Taste is sweet licorice cappuccino and brown sugar. Body is medium & the roasted taste lingers.
Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a moderate off-white head. Smells a little sweet. The oatmeal really comes through in this one, but not what I expected in a stout.

0.355l bottle from 2D2Dsupda. This is a dark brown one with a nice big almost fluffy chocolate head. The aroma is not extreme in any way, but subtle and delicate with chocolate and a mild roastiness blended with some soft licorice. Smells quite nice this in a non-extreme way. There is lots of flavor in this "lightweighter". Really smooth and again, delicate. It has clear sweet and quite tasty chocolate tones all the way. Its average carbonated and has a mild oily and smooth mouthfeel. Also a good bitterness - like in bitter chocolate. Soft licorice root and in the finish I get a mild roasted acidity in the dry aftertaste. Was expecting much before trying this, and it really delivered the goods! 10.08.2012
Bad.  Aroma is far off.   Looks okay, but the palate is horrible.  The flavor is also bad with burnt malt over cloying sweetness.  Really disappointed.
Delicious and well balanced, with a complex aroma and and easy bittersweet finish. Very easy to drink stout with a great velvety palate.

Bottle.  Pours black with medium/large light brown head.  Aroma of toffee, grapes, and sweet roasted malts.  Flavor is incredibly smooth with sweet roasted malts and oatmeal.  Very well balanced.  I didnt think I liked stouts much until I had this!

Dark pour to match the taste. Deep roasted malts. Chocolate, vanilla , oats. Very well balanced and very underwhelming. In a good way. Goo stout

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
roasty, black, frothy, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, thick feel,
A very good oatmeal stout and one of the best widely available.  Smooth and rich with a velvety mouthfeel, vanilla and earthy taste along with the expected coffee and rich dark chocolate.

If this beer is for lactating mothers, I will breast feed for eternity!! Flavorful, rich, with its own character, like a  woman in her 30's. One of the best oatmeal stouts in the market so far.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A beautiful pour, dark and opaque brown/black with a nutty brown head thats reasonably thick and lasts a reasonable amount of time that leaves a nice lacing. Its my second favorite looking beer. 
I really couldnt get much of a scent from it. I dont think Im experienced enough to really catch the notes yet. A deep deep inhale I can smell something, faint, and its nice, but I cant place the spice or floral or what it is. Its like a richness thats right on the edge of perception. 
The taste is not as sweet as I would have expected, but this was my first oatmeal stout. Didnt know what to expect, but I like my Apple and Cinnimon Oatmeal breakfast, so I think I expected something sweet subconciously. *grin* 
Theres a sharp bitterness, almost a burnt taste. Like what I would expect burnt oats to taste like. But its only slightly annoying. More interesting, actually. 
I found I had to drink it a little colder than I normally like dark beers. Just under or at refridgerator temp. (What, about 50F I think?)
12 oz bottle of perfection.  Long time standard for whats good in an oatmeal stout and still among the very best.  Next time you grow weary of the wheat switch on over to the oats.
Pours very dark with a caramel colored head. Tastes of chocolate caramel and spices. Great stout. Bought from earth fare in bottle.

550 ml bottle.  Aromas of chocolate and caramel with vanilla undertones.  Deep dark brown in color.  For such a luxurious looking appearance, I was dismayed that the body was so thin.  I would have preferred something a little more full and creamy.  However, the taste made up for the lack in body.  It was deliciously sweet, but not overly so.  And had a mild bitter finish.

This is a very smooth beer in all respects.  I suspect I will be enjoying another one of these in the very near future.

Opaque black, dense tan head. Thick, grainy aroma. Grainy again on the palate with plenty of dark roast malts. A nice taste of dark coffee, full creamy body, hints of anise and raison. Sweet and bitter finish. Pleasantly surprised  that its more roasty/bitter and less creamy than expected.

Bottle.  Deep dark brown almost black with initial tan head, no lace. Aroma of oats, dark roasted malt, dark fruit, soy, some rich hops well balanced.  Flavor is the above with some lactic sourness, more dark chocolate sweetness and bitterness.  Texture is velvet and it ends a little dry and smokey with not much bitterness.  Really an oustanding construction with restraint and balance despite being full flavored

An opaque, wonderfuly 
silky and smooth textured ale with a complex, medium dry palate and bittersweet finish.
Rich chocolate brown with large brown head. Nuts, floral aroma. Creamy texture, has a whipped cream feel to it. Smooth, smooth stout. Somewhat bitter

Aroma: Not very powerful. Slight aroma of treacle, licquorice and milky coffee.

Appearance: Very dark brown body with ruby highlights. Massive, frothy tan head. Good lacing. 

Taste: Mild treacle flavour and quite nutty. Restrained dark fruit notes. 

Palate: Medium body with a silky smooth mouthfeel. Average carbonation. 

Overall: Not quite as tasty as Kernels 1890 London Stout, but this is still a fine example of the style.

Bardzo smaczny owsiany Stout wyprodukowany metodą Yorhshire square. Tradycyjna receptura oddaje w pełni aromat jak smak tego piwa. Lekko palone w smaku, a na końcu lekka słodycz, piwo gęste i treściwe, Kolor zupełnie czarny bez prześwitu. Kremowo-puszysta piana lekko brązowa. Bardzo mocno i wytrwale stoji nad pintową szklanicą. Polecem bo to arcyklasyk:)

500ml bottle from a garden centre! This one has four pages of straight  five out of fives, which I dont agree with, but it doesnt surprise me. It has a smoky nose, burnt malts and coffee. As expected it poured a rich black with a frothy tan head - I poured it over five minutes ago, and it is still the same - the palate though is as good as anything Ive had this year, with s taste of flapjack and liquorice. So smooth. Excellent, not a FIVE but maybe my best score Ive awarded.
The perfect beer.  Itll turn IPA drinkers into stout lovers.  Or not, but its still good.
Flagship beer for the brewery.  Pours a deep chocolate out of the bottle.  Definitely try it.

Medium strong aroma has medical herbs, sweet licorice. Expresso black, medium long head, lacing. Taste has slightly sweet coffee, licorice, dark ripe fruits. Full bodied. Low carbonation. Nice smooth stout with good balance, one to enjoy.
Bottle from Alko. Black color, beige head. Sweet roasty taste with oatmeal, coffee and chocolate. Smooth finish with plum. Very good stout.

A-- black with a tan head. got 2 inches of head before it slowly went away. Not a lot of carbonation either and no lacing.

S-- a sweet coffee smell, like a lot of sugar put in a good cappuccino. A little burnt but not like overdrawn as coffee can be. Also get some brown sugar.

T-- Sweet but like an overdrawn cappuccino, not near as much oatmeal as I remember. Still reminds me of a sweeter version of a coffee stout.

M- Kind of flat but still a coffee feel. A little bit of a coffee bit but very good. Get the feeling of eating oatmeal with a decent amount of brown sugar.

D-- The strong suit of this beer I have always thought. Very drinkable. Could do several of this and never get tired of it. An excellent combination of ingredients. Just to me lacks more oatmeal. 

Have not had this in a log time and a perfect session beer. Not real heavy but it can leave you full. Probably better sipped and enjoyed.

Bottle shared.  Pours very dark brown with a large tan head.  Aroma of coffee, oats, caramel, chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavour is medium sweet and light bitter.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied and soft carbonation.

Poured an opaque black colour with a two-finger thick beige coloured, foamy head that laced well. Aroma of sweet malt and roasted grain. Taste initially of roasted and sweet malt then roasted grain with slight bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium body but thinner thasn other stouts. Slightly sweet finish makes this a drinkable beer.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2012 Aroma is sweet, lots of chocolate, toffee, malt, coffee is surprisingly hidden. Appearance is black, but not thick as most stouts. The taste is very good, this is very well-balanced. Slightly bitter, but sweetness takes over. Well done. Not thick at all, could be a good thing for drinking lot of. Very very very good.

500 ml bottle. Black with a nice beige head. Smells like chocolate. Taste is chocolate, oatmeal and coffee. Predictable oatmeal-ish bitterness. Medium bodied. Soft on the palate. Good, but Ive had better.
0.355l bottle. Pours dark brown/almost black with a beautiful long-lasting brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, cream and some reisin. Dark malt, coffee and reisin in the flavor. Awesome beer.

black color, aroma of roasted malt, oats, pine, flavors of sweet chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, vanilla, marshmallows, oats, pine, creamy texture, great balance, high drinkability, one of the best stouts ive had
Nice balance. Roasted barley and dark chocolate to the nose. A chocolate and coffee taste.

A: dark brown with a decent sized beige head and a fair amount of lacing.

S: sweet oats, roasted malts, toffee, caramels.

T: good tasting brew, with all of the aspects of the aroma coming through nicely. The beer is slightly sweet. I would prefer a bit more roasted malt and crispness from the oats.

M: slightly thin and sweet.

D: a solid example of the style.

Very good. One of my favorite, this traditional oatmeal stout does everything right. Rich malty dark black colors. Aroma is of raw malt, hint of oatmeal, toasted nuttiness.  The flavors are the same with a touch of coffee/chocolate. Sooth as hell

pours an almost opaque brown with a huge tan head.aroma is malty and nutty.flavor is bittersweet and has a wonderful creamy texture to it.lots of beautiful lacing on my glass.heavy bodied and so drinkable.has a slight bitter finish.this is definitely a top tier oatmeal stout.had it many times and will continue enjoying this.
Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Chocolate, oatmeal, dark malt sweetness in flavor. Aroma is pretty muted, some dark sweet malt tones.
A wonderful beer. Better than most oatmeal stouts Ive had. Something about it is smoother and sweeter than the others. Im happy to know this beer exists.

Nice, roasted, slightly chocolatey flavor with a delicious head. Pretty sweet. Not too bad though. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Drinks of the world, Zurich.
Pours dark brown with a big tan head.
Lots of rosted malt, some chocolate, coffee and dark fruits. Impressively heavy and rough for a 5% beer. However, I expect an oatmeal stout to be smoother.
I feel fortunate to taste an authenic oatmeal stout. Creamy, sweet and delicious. Very easy to drink and the finish was ballanced. Very well done Sam Smith!
Very smooth stout. Not quite as sweet as i expected. Rich oatmeal coffe flavor. Very nice head even from the bottle. Better than most.

Bottle. Black with a tan head that fades to a ring. Fairy minimal aroma, hint of metal, chocolate and coffee, something slightly vegetal going on as well.  Taste is a bit more robust, chocolate, coffee, caramel, some dark fruits and again a slight vegetal note. Full bodied, smooth, balanced and with a clean finish. Quite nice
Excellent stout. Full bodied but Smooth and easy to drink. The smell doesnt do the taste justice
From old backlog. Dark brown colour with tiny head. Malty sweet beer. Have retest someday
Sweet, mildly bitter stout. Tastes better the more you drink. Good for volume drinking

Brown black with a dimpled tan head.  Aroma is a bit like gingersnaps made with treacle, and taste is the same, with a dark, slightly tart edge. Lighter in body than expected, and pretty easy to drink, though very boldly flavored.   $2/22oz

Pours dark brown with lasting tan head. Aroma is light, with chocolate, coffee, malts. Taste coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, malts. Some sweetness and mild bitterness. Full body, dry coffee and chocolate finish. Outstanding stout
Dark thick and tasty.  Does this beer really require a review.  Go out and get one, you wont be disappointed.

Poured a deep, dark brown, almost black with a tan foamy head.  Aroma is coffee with faint chocolate.  Taste is toast and dark chocolate.  Good stout.  Cant believe I got the urge to try it on the hottest day of the year so far.
Thick, fluffy head defined by caramel and milk. Strong body with coffee and chocolate notes.

Bottle pour. Tan head, excellent duration. Dark black in color. Coffe, dark chocolate and roasted malts on the nose. Incredibly complex taste. Coffee, oats, dark sugar perhaps molasses. Long finish. The first beer in a long time to make me say wow!

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2015 Impenetrabile color marrone scuro con lievi riflessi rubino in trasparenza, soffice e spessa schiuma color nocciola. Aroma dolciastro e zuccheroso con sentori di ribes, bacche, nocciole e più lievi note di malti abbrustoliti; gusto anchesso dolciastro e leggermente fruttato/caramellato, che evolve verso un finale amarognolo e debolmente tostato. Al palato è setosa e mediamente corposa, ottima effervescenza debole che solletica la lingua e aiuta a renderla particolarmente beverina; fantastico retrogusto persistente che lascia la bocca "pulita" con note di frutta secca.
an overall lovely beer.  one of the best beers in terms of laying on the palate.  a bit of sweetness balanced with a great light maltiness.

550ml bottle from an LCBO in Markham. Aroma was delicious with some great malty and caramel smells. Pours a very dark brown with moderate chocolate milk head. Taste didnt quite hold up to the smell, there was the expected maltiness, coffee, chocolate and caramel, but a slight lactic or soy sauce sourness crept in. Maybe my bottle wasnt super fresh. Palate was solid, but not as dry as I was expecting. Overall, a very good stout, but not the best Ive had.

550ml bottle. Pours dark almost opaque black with a medium brown head with impressive retention but weak lacing. Aroma of toffee, dark fruit, roasted malt, port, chocolate, and caramel. Taste is very sweet with minimal bitterness and mild sour notes. Texture is silky with soft almost flat carbonation. Incredible. Very similar to a foreign stout such as Lion Stout....

355 ml bottle. Pours rubyish almost opaque colour with a large foamy head. Aroma has roasty and caramel malt, strong licorice and a hint of chocolate. Quite sweet flavour has some of chocolate, banana and a hint of licorice. Medium bodied. Rather thick mouthfeel. Long toasty licorice finish. Has plenty of character by being so sweet but cold be slightly more bitter for my taste.
Bottle. Dark brown to black with a thin head. Aroma of milk chocolate and coffee. Flavour is very smooth roast chocolate, slight velvet texture. Finish is creamy smooth. Nice

Pours black with thick dark tan head.  Aromas of coffee, roasted nuts, oatmeal, brown sugar, and malt.  Very complex aroma in general.  Coffee out in the front for flavor, fading hints of chocolate and malts.  Very delicious and understated stout.  Definitely keeping a couple in the fridge.  Isnt trying so hard to be special.
Deep pitch black poor with a nice mocha coloured head.  Chocolate and coffee aroma with the flavour of both on top of a nice roasted malt background.  Smooth and silky, went down extremly well.

550ml bottle. Big thick coffee coloured head of foam atop a deep dark black beer. Strong aromas of roasted malt and chocolate with a flavor to match. Thin in the mouth but this is not a bad thing. Perfect beer for the weather as autumn fades into winter.
very dark brown with two finger head. excellent stout. very easy to drink with pleasant chocolate and coffee flavors.

33 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 18.01.2011
Aroma is roasted with milk chocolate, some oat and coffee. Flavour has chocolate, oat, some cocoa and hints of coffee. Ive had couple of these, but every time this is just too thin and light for my taste. Even at a room temp.
Coffee, oats aroma. Taste slightly porter like bitterness! Somewhat watery at The end
Very dark brown. Good sized and decent holding head. Roasted malts, coffee, dark fruits, milky. Decent and good full bodied and taste.

A beautiful beer by samuel smith. The aroma is excelent and the color is dark brown with a light brown creamy head.  Thank god for oats.  The taste is chocolately with a hint of sweetness at the end.  Choc. Malt was used for sure and maybe a hint of roasted malt or barley.  Very good in deed no hop bitternes and no after taste.  It was smooth and enjoyable with a medium/full body and it was great all the way to the last drop.  Worth a buy and many rebuys.

bottle .  very dark chocolate colour with big tan head  . looks inviting .  aroma is malt , demerara sugar , chocolate , coffee notes.  taste - sweet chocolate hit then toasted malt , caramelised ( almost burnt ) brown sugar  with slightly bitter balance  . good body  , medium carbonation  . a nice beer
Wow!  Nearly black.  Thick tan foamy head.  Creamy malty taste, with some smokiness, almost like bacon.  A bitterness on the tongue to balance the bodacious amount of malt.

bottle
aroma, grainy, some maltness, slight chocolate
color, dark brown,light tan head
taste, slight chocolate on front, slight bitterness, malt ceral backend
overall, pretty good
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text: 550ml bottle. Very dark brown colour, almost black. Big fluffy creamy head with chocolatey nuances. Very very nice aroma: sweet and spicy, vanilla, caramel, oak, cocoa, brown sugar, a hint of hops. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, prunes, burned sugar, hints of vanilla. Good balance between sweetness and bitterness.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2012 Bottle. Coffe, caramel and nuts aromas. Pours really dark, with nice creamy tan head, persistent, with some lacework. Oily texture, full body and low cabonation. Taste is some roasty, chocolate and sweet flavours. Average dry finish. Really nice brew, but palate-saturating.

Magnificent. Pleasantly malty, with that caramel-bread notes, deep undertones of chocolate and coffee. The hops are pleasantly restrained, providing enough to balance the beer without dominating it.

Of special note is the mouthfeel of this beer; the higher protein content due to the oatmeal grants this beer a very silky mouthfeel; straining it through ones teeth is a delight.

550ml bottle. Pours dark, almost opaque black with a thick brown head which dissipates slowly. Aroma is of coffee and chocolate. Mild flavor, with roasted malt notes, as well as chocolate and coffee. Rich, almost chewy on the palate. A little bit of aftertaste

Originally reviewed: 7/21/08. Poured a very dark cola color. Very thick with a huge foamy tan head that held throughout the drink. Good webbing along glass side. 

Smelled of chocolate, fresh bread, some malt. 

Has a slight metallic bite to the taste. Very thick and chocolate-like, a little dry. Very heavy drink. Wouldnt recommend this bad boy with a meal, its a meal in its own right. 

Overall, pretty good brew. Though its not my favorite style, Id reach for this one again.

Bottle. Pours a seemingly fathomless oil-black, becoming dark ruby with a well-fined translucence becoming apparent toward the bottom of the glass; slow settling, nicotine-stained head. Incredibly seductive aroma of chocolate ganache, rum-soaked raisins, trace treacle, hay, blackberry; medium sweet with a teasing, lactic sourness, soft spritz lending a moussy quality to the body and a breathtaking finesse to the easy, dark-mild finish. Drunk far and wide, I see, and deservedly so
After reading other reviews, maybe I got a bad bottle.  Bitter, resinous, not smooth in the least.  Drain pour.

Poured a dense opaque ruby brown with a robust tan head and nice lacing. The nose is malty with maybe a hint of smoke. The flavor is roasted malts and a coffee notes. There is also a slight touch of fruitiness in the middle. The aftertaste is pleasingly bitter. The mouthfeel is light to medium. This beer is smooth and pleasing. Little carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

550ml bottle - pours super dark ruby with plenty of beige head.  Nose is roasted caramel malts.  Flavor adds smokiness, bread and a little resin.  taste is sweet and a tad bitter.  Easy to drink but the aftertaste is a little off (ever so slightly.
Poured from bottle dark brown color with tan head. Aroma of caramel malt. Taste is caramel, toasted malts, oatmeal and nuts.

pours a deep almost black, amber with a tan head. lots of roasted malts in the subtly sweet aroma.more roasted caramel in the flavour, with a solid body that finishs extremely smooth with a subtle bitterness to finish. one of the most drinkable stouts ive ever had.

0,355l bottle from Csakajósör, Budapest. Clear, deep brown color with medium, light brown head. Classic stout aroma with caramel and roasted malt, but the oat makes it mild, smooth and creamy. Light bitter taste with some smoke. Light body, creamy slick texture, soft carbonation. Creamy, oat finish. Very ease, light and very drinkable. Despite this, the aroma is rich and delicious.

Great head retention and lacing. Smell has roast malts and even hint of smoke. Palate very full - taste goes through stages. First a nutty bitterness then a full bodied, almost fruity taste of alcohol. Finishes off with a little touch of sour with more nutty bitterness. Wonderful stout. 500ml bottle.
16.9 oz bottle pours black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and a hint of chocolate.  Taste is pretty much the same.
Pours jet black, topped by a small tan head. Aroma of rich roasted coffee. Taste is a combination of mocha, caramel malt,  chocolate, and oats. Finishes on the bitter side. Medium to full bodied.

Poured from 355 ml bottle at Limerick Pub in Wheaton, MD. 

Pours an opaque, near black with a 2-finger brown head that recedes quickly.  The lacing is briefly pretty good, but slides back down after a couple seconds. 

Mild aroma of molasses, dark fruit, roast coffee and chocolate. 

Taste is a gentle blend of milk chocolate , brown sugar and roast coffee. 

Slightly above medium body with light carbonation.  

This bottle lacked the full flavor and body that the last one I drank had.  The beer was fresh, so maybe more age would have helped.  It wasn't bad, just not as good as I remembered.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

0,33l bottle from Csakajósör Budapest, deep brown color with medium head. Iron aroma, i not feel it in taste. Good creamy taste, caramel, roasted malt, fruits. Good aftertaste. Easy drinkable, fine stout. I recommend it!
Bottle. Dark brown with big foamy head. Light citrus aroma and roastiness. Tastes not too sweet and roasty. Kind of sweet after taste.
Pours a dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma of caramel malt. Taste is caramel, toasted malts, oatmeal and nuts. Medium bodied.

Pour out of 550 mL bottle is dark brownish black with thin tan head, aroma brought notes of big char, roast, hints of smoke with some dark chocolate and coffee, hints of caramel, slight dark fruits and oat notes as well.  Taste is fairly creamy but the roast and char kills it, some slight tobacco and chocolate notes as well, finish fairly bitter,
A dry and roasted flavor with a crisp bite, a good amount of hops,  and a bitter finish.

Smooth, mild coffee to perfection. Could have stronger aroma, but theres a whole heap of flavour that balances beautifully. Little less carbonation would be better. Top beer. So glad it is cheap and easy to buy.
Pours a black color with a nice tan head and spider web lacing. Wonderful aroma of coffee, roasted malt, oatmeal and caramel. Taste is much of same in a perfect balance. Mouthfeel is full.

Nearly black, dark tan head, hevy lace.
Scent is faint...dark roast malt, oatmeal, vanilla.
Taste is wonderfully smooth oatmeal and slightly bitter chocolate.
Creamy, slick.
An excellent stout.

A: Pours an almost black body, but it isnt impenetrable to the light. The head is fantastic, its a light leather color that starts off at four fingers (due to my aggressive pour, and stays at one finger for quite a duration. Excellent (almost maddening) retention and lacing overall.

S: Bakers chocolate, roast, and a tiny bit of dark fruit and licorice. This is gonna be great...

T: Not quite as chocolatey as the nose would dictate. Theres more of a roasted malt flavor as the dominating note, with generous hints of chocolate, coffee, licorice, smoke, and perhaps a little raisin appearing on the palate at various points. Quite complex, and quite delicious!

M: Medium carbonation, and I have to say, a little thin textured. Not watery by any stretch, though. The oats give it an excellent creaminess - though perhaps not quite as silky as I would have liked, and the finish is just dry enough to satisfy immensely. The drinkability factor is disturbing...Im having to refrain from guzzling this down in one sip.

O: Once again, Sam Smith nails it. A bit pricey to be an everyday drinker, but cheap enough to make a fantastic once-a-weekend treat. Personally, I like the Sam Smith impy stout a hair more, but really, this is a must have for dark beer fans.

Pours a very dark brown almost black color with a very small tan head, Aroma is of dark roasted malts, and bit chocolate. Taste is oats, coffee, and chocolate. Mouthfeel is full and drinkability is excellent.

Dark as night with a solid, slight off-white head.    Aroma of grasses and malt.  Tastes great (oats, malt, lactose) with a silky smooth palate. Not very complex, but solid.  What I wish a Guinness was.

Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout is seriously praise worthy. Its heavy and dark and, as you can see, pours with a hell of a head. Its got legs, too, with lots of foam clinging to the glass all the way to the end. It smells pretty good, but the taste is where it really delivers, and of course thats what matters. Its very smooth, very rich, but with some nice hoppy kick at the end, and I think it even tasted better as it warmed.
Like most Samuel Smith beers this feels a little watered down and overpriced.

550 ml bottle courtesy of Hugh. Pours dark brown, almost black, with a frothy off-white head that leaves lots of trace and lacing while dissipating. Smell is sweet, tiny sour and malty with toasted malts, vanilla, toast, banana, oatmeal cookies, chocolate and toffee. Taste is sweet, tiny bitter and tiny metallic with bread, sweet dried fruits, banana, milk chocolate, tobacco and hints of coffee and toast. Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy and medium bodied. Finish is sweet and bitter with toasted malts and coffee. A good beer with an amazing mouthfeel.

Aroma has hints of dark fruits and roasted malt which mirrors the taste, with a nice mineral and metallic bite in there for good measure. I think however that the dominate feature of this beer is the texture. It is supremely smooth and silky coating the mouth in the most delightful fashion. A classy stout.
Pours very dark brown almost black color with a creamy head. Aroma is roasted malts and oatmeal. Flavour is roasted malts and coffee. Very tasty with a full body.
Bottle. Darkest brown with a good tan head. Roasted malt in abundance. Coffee and chocolate with a very well measured bitterness and the mildest acidity. Good finish. Tidy.

Full bodied, full flavored but less balanced than other stouts. It pours dark and with a decent sized head. It smelled and tasted of dark malt, chocolate and coffee. There was some hop in the finish but not too much. It does remind me of Guiness, but more refined.

Nearly opaque with nice silky tan head.  Smells of coffee, chocolate, roasted barley and toasted oats.  Chewy texture but silky at the same time.  Tastes like it smells.  Starts of chocolate then it moves to roasted barley and coffee before finishing with toasted oats and then more chocolate.  Hops obviously muted but offers a nice balancing bitterness.  Very tasty beer.
Bottle, pours a nice dark black, roasty malts, aroma and flavour has lots of oats with some good coco body amd it was a nice offering

Poured from bottle Union Jacks Broad Ripple Indiana.  Oh my this is a delight.   dark brown with slight head.  Really kicks with that smokey hop favor.  Fits the bill watching football (soccer) on a Sunday with friends.  RECOMMEND 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Syrupy chocolate and coffee aroma. Beautiful pitch black appearance with pale brown head. Nice full stout

Aroma is very sweet and plenty of chocolate. Aroma is very strong and very pleasant. Flavor at first comes off somewhat bland. Reminded me of Guinness at first. Starts off with coffee and syrup and malty. Soon chocolate became very strong in the taste. It also is somewhat creamy and sweet. A little smoky but nothing too offensive, actually kinda nice. Balances out nicely and is pretty good. Nothing bold but it is a pretty good beer.

Bottle @ Old Chicago Foco Harmony. Fairly clear, dark brown appearance with a light brown head. Poor head retention. Somewhat charred, grilled, oaty, a touch nutty, caramelized malty aroma. Burnt toffee, caramelized oaty, light chocolate, light espresso flavor. Somewhat buttery.

This is it. One of the best. Even the head is creamy. Slight bitterness, but coffee and roasted malts rule the day. Flavor is thick but it's smooth and doesn't feel heavy. This is awesome. Proves you don't have to get something rare or hard to find to get a fantastic beer.

Dark pour with a toffee colored head.  Coffee and bitter chocolate with dark fruit in the nose.  Like  a creamy milk shake with hints of dark chocolate.  Full bodied but light.  Smoothly coats the tongue.  Stand out beer, can go with several different foods.

Classic brew. Pours black with a pillowy tan head that really sticks around. Smells of chocolate and light coffee. Flavor is light roast, chocolate with a slight tang. Great silky mouthfeel and balanced finish.

Bottle. So solid and dependable. You really cant go wrong with Sammy Smiths. The oaty coffee scent sat over a dark brown/black appearance with a foamy head. Medium/thick bodied palate and a creamy texture. The front taste was Guiness-like then it faded to sweet roasty coffee and oatmeal notes.
