Poured black with a foamy head. Smells mostly of chocolate, but also has a banana aroma. Tastes of coffee and has a creamy mouthfeel from the oatmeal. I can see why this beer is the standard for the category

50cl bottle from Kermis.
Thick off white head.  deep black pour.  smooth stout taste.  Yummy!

Nice dark smooth black color. Very nice smooth sweet smell of nuttienes with a taste of dark malt with hints of chocolate and prunes and a slight hint of oatmeal. Mouthfeel is nice and smooth that supports a nice easy drinking stout.
Poured from bottle into pint glass, great flavor and aroma, definitely a must try stout.

Black with a faint red tint and a lasting microbubble tan head. Fruity, roasted malt with dark chocolate that encourages me to drink. Medium smooth body, slightly grainy from the carbonation. Soft bitter roasted barley, oats, milk,with coffee elements. Light lingering acidness. Not as good as I hoped but decent.

I reguard this and Barney Flats as my two most favorite Oatmeal Stouts. Wonderful rich caramel and coffee flavor. Silky smooth pour with a thick copper and bubble rich head. Goes down great with great aroma of chocolate and caramel. Find it hard to not grab a a bottle everytime I pass it at the store.

09/11/2011 Emporio del Gusto (330ml bottle). Nera, con riflessi color caffè, quasi impenetrabile, schiuma abbondante, bianco sporca, abbastanza persistente. Aroma intenso di cioccolato, caffè, luppolo. In bocca è molto ben equilibrata, cioccolato, caffè, con una interessante nota salmastra. Corpo medio-basso, carbonazione soft. Molto ben equilibrata, bevibile, gradevole, elegante. In una parola: Inglese.

A classic caramel, definitely will keep this around as a steady foundation in the collection. Smooth and sweet, with a coffee brown pour and a thick but fleeting head. The scent is weak but sweet and inviting, the hops barely noticeable behind the strength of the malt. A heavy taste, mild bitterness, with some of that hard-to-define "umami" trailing in the aftertaste. The fullness of the body and overall sweetness makes this an interesting pairing option for a variety of foods, or a great beer to sip on its own. Simple and straightforward, but excellent.
Pour from a 12oz bottle. Inky dark brew with tan head. Aroma of roasted grain, chocolate. Taste is rish and sweet, chocolate and malt, a little dry in the finish. Smooth palate. Excellent brew.
Black as night pour - oil can color and viscosity.  Aromas of black malts, chocolate and dark night.  Sliky mouthfeel, very smooth and pleasing.  Excellent.  Would buy again.

Bottle; black with small brown head; aroma-roasty, sweet, bread, chocolate; taste-medium sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, average carbonation, long tart finish. Sweeter and creamier than theri imperial, less coffee taste with a lasting mouthfeel. Love it

About as solid as you can get when it comes to oatmeal stout.  Samuel Smiths is the beacon in that category with a beautiful pour (deep, lovely with a tasting head), a great aroma (roast, malt, hint of coffee), and a fantastic taste (caramel, coffee, roast, a touch of dark chocolate).  Smooth and creamy, this is a beer that  doesnt disappoint, and is a beer that I could drink all night, every night.

Sorry to be cliche, but the aroma is roasty, malty, oatmeal.  The appearance is lustfully dark, opaque with a tan two finger head.  Smooth, coffee taste with a luscious, syrupy finish.  Very little bitterness.  This is an excellent stout - I prefer it to their Imperial Stout.

550ml bottle pored into standard pint glass

a: deep amber color, almost black, decent 1/2" head with nice retention, plenty of carbonation

s: sweet malt, chocolate

t: sweet up front with oat, chocolate, and malt. finish dry like most stouts.

Black beer with a light tan to light brown head, which is composed of many tiny bubbles and diminishes somewhat quickly. The aroma is of roasted malt. Not particularly strong, but inviting. The taste is wonderful and full of many flavors including chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee.
taste like a burnt biscuit:caramel, bread, hay, cereal, coffee, nuts, toast, roasty, resin, spruce, herbs, dough, barnyard, basement aromas,

Pourded a nice head , almost like a rootbeer in appearence. Very dark, could not see through thye glass even with direct sunlight. Medium aroma, not as prounounced as some Stouts. Low carbonation is fron end loaded, rich roasted coffee, topasted marshmellow hints at the end, very creamy, not bitter. Hop taste is throughout. Make sure you drink his at just below celler temp (10 minutes in fridge) , to get the full range of flavor. Very good on its own or served with an english stilton. or  scotch broth soup.
Bottle from the LCBO.  Dark, nice tan head, aroma is chocolate, bread, oatmeal I suppose.  Sweet, smooth & perfect for the spicy roti I had paired with it.

bottle from british bar, lisbon, portugal. Dark dark color with touches of read at the bottom. Brownish thick head. Low carbonation. Medium sweetness and bitterness. Coffee, toast, oatmeal and wood aromas.

Picked this up for $3.75 for the bottle at a local beer store. First time having it. Poured into a tulip glass.

A - Poured a smooth, dark brown color with about 8 fingers of head but I usually pour pretty vigorously. Through the glass, I see nothing but there is some light coming through at the edges.

S - Im getting bread and oats for sure. Theres a syrup scent and maybe some earthiness. Very deep and rich but nothing that truly stands out.

T - Tastes like it smells. Oatmeal, bread, syrup, earthiness and very very relaxed stout taste of malts and crackers. 

M - 50/50 carbonation / liquid upon swish. Light bodied and very drinkable. Its beer but not in your face. The linger of malts is very pleasant. 

O - Decent beer. Drinkable, easy to consume and sold almost everywhere. Solid A in my book.

From notes.  First reviewed 6/16/2009.  Poured from a 550 ml bottle into a pint glass.

A strong midnight black color, with an off-white/tan head of modest size. No lacing, but very nice head retention.

Brisk chocolate and molasses control the aroma, with a definite starchy undertone.

A strong sweet chocolate flavored malt up front, with more sublte dark fruit flavors alongside. The oats add a depth to the flavor. A smooth, coffee bitterness settles in after the malt and resides in the mouth until after the sip is gone. The flavor is strong, smooth, and complete in each dram. 

The iInitial feel is quite smooth, with a sharp crispness from the surprisingly confident carbonation. 

I would not have thought an oatmeal stout could be this drinkable.

Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout has a very thick, creamy beige head and a dark brown appearance. The aroma is of dark cherries, grain husks, dark chocolate, and dark-roasted coffee. Taste is of coal, licorice, dark fruit, chocolate, deep-roasted barley, sweetness, hop bitterness, and coffee. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy, and Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout finishes mostly dry and surprisingly highly drinkable. Overall, this is a most excellent beer. RJT

Pours dark with a dark brown foam head that stays on the top of the brew, light passes through glass. Smells of yeast, oat, small hops and sweetness. Taste of well balance oat malt, medium hop presence provides a nice bite, also: yeast. In between thick and thin great body for any stout fan. Finishes with a little bite and oat malt. Classic Oatmeal stout I dont understand why other companies cant get Oatmeal Stouts right but this is possibly the best.

Bottle pours kind of black with a head. Tastes and smells of bread, coffee, oats chocolate, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, pretty good beer like the tastes its a goodie I always forget to go back to.
This is one of my favorites.  Nice complex flavor, and its easy to drink.  Great beer!

Bottle. Pours black with average, frothy beige head; medium retention and spare lacing. Aroma is heavy bread malt, oatmeal, dark fruit, and licorice. Flavor is heavy malt, light hops, and average eaters; creamy mouthfeel and finish. Full body, with low carbonation and warmth.

Bottle 550ml, pours almost black with a ruby tinge, tan head that settles to a covering. Ground coffee, dark berry aroma. Medium mouth feel with a medium amount of carbonation. Lactose coming through from the oatmeal, sweet, rum raisin, roasted coffee, with a dry bittering yet sweet milky finish. Good flavours overall

Enjoyed in bottle form at the Globe Pub in Chicago, IL while celebrating a friends birthday.  Appearance is black with thin white head.  Aroma rich in.chocolate malt and oatmeal, bit of lactose, smells nice.  Taste dominated by chocolate malt, oats add to the rich body, very light bit of lactose, very solid oatmeal stout.
Dark pour with a decent size head. Creamy and taste of coffee and malts. Very smooth and easy drink-ability.

Pours pitch black with beige lacing head. Aromas are  wood, bubblegum, , grains, leather, malts. Texture is medium thick, smooth little tart with mouthful carbonation. Palate oats, grains, some nuts and licorice. Aftertaste is sweet with dryness with slight bitter edge. Finish is dry and medium short. Balanced brew, quite nice.
pours black, with minimal caramel head. Minimal aroma, some oaty notes. Very smooth tasting with plenty o chocolate and oatmeal. Great brew
500 ml bottle. A beautiful beer, dark black with a thick off white head. Sweet and roasty nose. The flavor is roasted malts, hint of chocolate, caramel. A nice creamy finish. A easy drinking stout.
What can I say that almost 2500 have not said.  Great beer! I only gave it an overall score of 19 because Ive had one Oatmeal Stout that was better than this...

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2012 + lekker ligt
+ ligt stout smaak
- had wat meer na de eerste smaak verwacht
Dark roasted. Huge taste for a "low" alchohol stout. Long aftertaste, sweet caramel. Good on a cold winter night
Full flavored, not too roasty, lots of slightly sweet complex flavors that linger and are perfectly balanced. As good a stout as any, and definitely one to come back to many times.

Bottle on numerous occasions. I always drink this in Sam Smiths pubs, so I thought I would finally rate it. It pours very, very dark brown, with a thick beige head. The nose is blackcurrant, blueberry, raisin, roasted malt, cocoa powder and caramel. The taste is chocolate, roasted malt, cherry, blackcurrant, coffee liqueur, lactose, varnish and caramel, with a long dry-roasted finish. Medium to full body and moderate carbonation. A classic oatmeal stout. Delicious.

Jai des sentiments partagés sur cette bouteille parce que je dois passer outre certains détails pour vraiment lapprécier. La fermentation ouverte apporte toute sorte détrangeté comme les notes de raisins, la finale un peu acide et les esters de levures en arôme. À travers ça, une stout velouté habité par le chocolat et la mélasse douce. Plus je la bois, plus je la trouve comme la London porter de Fullers en plus onctueuse et funky.

Surprised to see I had not yet rated this.  Pours deep dark brown with an offwhite head.  Aroma is caramel, dark chocolate, oatmeal and roasty.  Taste is sweet with some nice dark chocolate bitterness.  Smooth and slick mouthfeel.

Appears dark brown/black, some red notes, nice chocolate colored head. Aroma is non-descript and hard for me to pin down, sweet but nothing shining through for me. Taste is sweet with faint hops, raisins and dark chocolate predominate. Medium bodied with low/medium carbonation. An intriguing beer that on writing this review, makes me want another.

The oaty creamy flavor is invites for another sip, and another.  The smooth head gives it the taste one expects from a stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

550ml bottle. Dark brown verging on black. Nose has malts along with a hint of chocolate and vanilla. Silky, sweet and seductive, but prone to slipping by a bit unnoticed, despite how rounded and well-balanced it seems. Not a beer that floored me, but a quaint and pleasant offering nonetheless.

Outstanding beer. This is one of the best if not the best Oatmeal Stouts that you can buy. Samuel Smiths knows how to make beer. Appearance is dark with a hint of ruby.  Taste is fantastic. If I could only drink one beer a day, this would be the beer.
Nice head with light tan color. Coffee roasted aroma. good coffee roasted taste but not overly present

Dark malt, fruity esters, and some floral character in the aroma.  Decent head, but does dissipate rather quickly.  Smooth mouthfeel with modest carbonation, chocolatey, dark malty taste.  Dries out into a bitter dark chocolate finish.  Very well balanced.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2012 550ml bottle. Hard to say anything new after twenty-five hundred other samplers. This is probably the best ordinary stout available, where ordinary designates strength not quality. Its dark brown with a ton of tan foam. This head subsides, but will stick around at quarter inch. Aromas of chocolate roast malt, brown sugar, molasses, light roast coffee, and milk. The oats impart themselves in a delicious way resulting in a heavy sweet front  and  long malty  finish with a balanced bitterness. Definitely not a dry stout.  Syrupy but easy to drink. The best of the Tadcaster beers, in my opinion.
Pours black with a thin off white top.  Aroma is slightly sweet and mostly malt.  Taste is solid malt flavour, slight chocolate and sweetness.

Very nice dark opaque color. Not too much tan head with a nice lace. Lovely smell of chocolate, coffee, molasses, and roastiness.  I do get the smell of the malts too.  Med/full bodied, carbonation is perfect.  Really get the caramel and roasted malts in the nose after the sip.  Its a tad sweet.  I enjoy it.

Pours jet black, large mocha head. Aroma of milk chocolate, light coffee, chocolate chip cookies. Amazingly smooth mouthfeel, light bodied, medium carbonation. Flavors of chocolate, cream, cinnamon, oats, with an appetizingly dry finish. All this packed into a sessionable 5% ABV. About as good as an oatmeal stout gets.
I love this beer. Probably my favorite stout. Smooth, creamy, roasty, sweet. Bittersweet chocolate finish and almost no hop character.

I think this is the standard that other oatmeal stouts should strive for. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Really liked this oatmeal stout...dark roasted notes and dried fruit aromas. Silky mouthfeel...nice slightly bitter coffee finish..on tap at toasted frog in grand forks

550 mL bottle from the LCBO, served in a branded pint glass. Pours black with a large, thick tan head. The head remains and leaves behind dense lacing. The nose has notes of toasted malts, chocolate, herbs and earth. The flavour is moderately sweet up front and becomes more so through the middle. There are notes of roasted malts and chocolate, along with a hint of herbs. The finish is long and malty, with complementary herbal hops. On the palate, it is full in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a nice oatmeal stout with a beautiful creamy texture and delicate chocolate notes. It is very well brewed, but it is a bit sweet for my taste. 2012-01-06
Honestly, I was a little disappointed with this one. Too sweet, and kind of one dimensional. Decent, but not as good as I was hoping for.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2012 Bottle.  Pours an almost solid rich dark brown, with a light brown head. A very smooth, almost chocolatey taste, with a smooth ending.  Very nice!

December 14, 2011
5% abv, 550 mL bottle, BBD: none, refrigerated, pint glass

Aroma of coffee, red wine and dark chocolate. Pours a deep dark brown with thick porous tan head of about 1.5". Tastes of creamy chocolate and roasted cocoa with liqueur sweetness. Slightly sour in the finish which is a little too thin for my liking.  Good, but not quite the creamy richness I like in a stout...

This would be on my recommended dozen or so (bottled ... Never had casked) beers that everyone should try. I compare all other bottled stouts to this one the same as I compare all stouts on tap to Guinness on tap - which is miles above Guinness in a bottle 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2012 My favorite beer which I know like the back of my hand.  Sweet oatmeal goodness.   A meal of a beer that is even more delicious as it approaches room temperature.   My desert island / death row beer.

500ml bottle in an English pint.  Pours very dark brown with a fluffy, light tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, a little bit of oatmeal, some light chocolate, and floral hops.  Flavor the same, with a little dark fruits or something thats off.  Smooth texture.  A pretty good stout.

Poured black with a thick creamy brown head that left great lacing. Aroma was coffee and caramel but somewhat faint. Taste had a nice roastiness to it with coffee, some caramel sweetness, and a good bitter balance. Pretty strong lingering aftertaste.

Aroma: A little light on the aroma.  Smells are caramel, chocolate, a slight bit of coffee.

Appearance: Black as can be with a thin brown head.

Taste: Oatmeal, coffee, chocolate, toffee..

Palate: Sticky.. almost chewy..

Overall: A really solid brew.  This is one that will fill up your stomach and history says that its actually got some nutrition in there.  Definitely enjoyable and a welcome choice when available.
Sicuramente o molto probabilmente è una delle migliori stout del pianeta, aspetto fantastico, naso delicato di avena e tostato ed in bocca una pulizia ed equilibratura pazzesche...

12oz bottle. Black brew with a bit of fading tan head. Lighter carbonation, light body, easy to drink. A bit of lace. Some slight oiliness in the aftertaste. This beer is definitely different from the American oatmeal stouts that Im used to... The aroma seems to have a dark fruit component to it, along with the usual coffee / chocolate stoutness here. The sweetness seems to be more of a fresh taste rather than a desert taste. A nice subtle bitterness in there, as well. Not bad at all... But Im not sure if I prefer this take on the oatmeal stout more than the American-style

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 Bottle into a Lager glass. So smooth its almost like cream. Dark black in color, in the light a ruby glow. Very low nitrogen  taste, Sweet and bitter with a clean carmel finish. On the high $ side, but worth it by far. I will have it here as long as I have space in the wine frig.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is rich and fruity. The flavour is dark fruit, raisins with a bitter tobacco edge. Smooth bitter/sweet finish. Silky mouthfeel. Really good.

Wow. Jet black, viscous, tan head. Doesnt smell of much. Great almost Bordeaux-like body. Low hopping, vinous, rich, resinous, mildly toasty, mildly molasses-like. Just great frankly and other than the alcohol has hit home I wouldnt know from the taste it was 5%.

20-DEC-2011, bottle @Brewpub.
Dark, dark brown with lasting light brown head.
Almost bourbon nose with cocoa, vanilla, and hoppy bitterness.
Roasted malts. Sweet coffee and high fruitiness. Dried fruits like prune and raisins.
Very smooth and delicious. A rebuy.

Tawny dark brown pour, some light visible around edges of glass, light brown head and great retention.  Aroma is nuts, raisins, sweet malt, some hints of roast but overall very fruity, tons of fermentation character from the yeast strain.  Taste is raisiny sweet nutty malt with a mild touch of roast, leather, prunes, and tobacco.  Body is medium, silky, low carbonation, sweet malty balanced finish.

Bottle. Black with a billowing khaki head. The nose is of mellow coffee, dark bread. The taste is a bit savoury, with moderate sweet notes, mild bitterness. The mouthfeels medium/full, the finish a bit watery. Overall, not my favorite member of the sam smiths lineup.
Easy drinking stout. Nothing overly bold about the flavor or aroma, but it was a very smooth stout that would be great on a sunny fall day.

Pours black with three fingers of fluffy tan head.  Roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee aromas.  Roasted grain, coffee with cream, chocolate, and nutty flavors.  Silky, oily mouthfeel.  Medium body and carbonation.  A nice easy drinking session beer.

355 ml. bottle. Almost black "colour" with dark brown hues, and a large, creamy tanned head. Roasted aroma, oatmeal cookies, some chocolate and bittersweet fruits. Roasted taste with licorice, chocolate, oatmeal cookies with raisins, a little bit coffee, dark fruits. Finishes with these notes, and a slight acidity. Medium body with a smooth texture and a soft carbonation. Excellent beer!

Brown pour, rather than deep black, little head.  Nice aroma of roasted malt.  Dark malty flavour, good body, some bitterness at the end.  There arent any really distinctive flavors, but it has good body.  Pretty nice.

I must have gotten a bad bottle. This stuff was light bodied and boozy, both in flavor and aroma. It was not an enjoyable drink, and for 5% abv, it was a rough ride down the gullet. It was pitch black, sweet and tasted like hard alcohol.

dark brown-black with an aroma of tobacco and bitter coffee. Pours with a fluffy tan head. Sweet up front in the mouth with a hint of oak and smoke. The oats give it a creamy texture and a long milk chocolate finish. Again a slight metallic hop but not too distracting from the overall.
One of the most delicious beers Ive ever had the pleasure of drinking. If the prices were lower, I would drink this all the time.
Has that classic English flavor similar to Ringwood Brewery Old Thumper. Creamy, roasty, toasty and delicious. Chocolate and coffee. Easy to drink and a long  long finish. Damn good.
Pours a deep black with nice off white head. Aroma contains chocolate, roasted malts, some malty sweetness. very nice. flavor is easy and smooth yet lingering and complex. superb.

A 12 oz. bottle poured to a shaker at Lunar Brewing Co., displaying a ruby highlighted, darkest brown color, brownish tan froth & bubbles head, and clingy curtains & spots of lacing. The aroma was roasty malt, cocoa and caramel, with a touch of sweet, dark molasses, and a hint of soy. The flavor was similar, less the soy, with moderate hop bitterness, a medium body, and a blend of light sweetness, soft carbonation, and a creamy mouthfeel that projected a pleasant mellow nature to the palate. A tasty, benchmark Stout.

This beer got me into craft beers.  I was drinking light beers, but always enjoyed the occasional Guiness or Beamish.  And then I tried Sam Smith Oatmeal Stout.  There was no going back after experiencing the way a little oatmeal can smooth out the body of an exceptionally crafted stout.

Pours black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is malty, chocolate and a bit of vanilla. Aromas nicely complement the flavor profile.  Bittersweet with chocolate and vanilla flavors.  Wish the flavors were a little more intense, but otherwise very nice.  Finish is bitters with a lingering sweetness.

Bottle.  Black pour with a big tan head.  Aroma is complex.  Some vinous notes, some whole milk, and a little bit of toast.  Taste is sweet and includes toasted marshmallow, milk, and sugar.  Smooth mouthfeel.  Medium body and carbonation.

The aroma is full of deep malts and coffee notes bordering on espresso. The color is deep deep brown almost black.  The beer forms a thick tan head and leaves long lacing down the glass.  The taste is full of roast malt and finishes with coffee.  The palate is silky full and smooth, likely from the oats.  Overall a great stout.  Went delightfully with roast beef and swiss crustinis, spinach salad with balsamic vinegar, a brie with cherry preserves.
Aroma was somewhat lacking compared to similar oatmeal stouts.   Good taste, although not on my "gotta try this again" list.

Appearance: Black. Tons of carbonation. Huge frothy beige head. Aroma: Very malty. Notes of chocolate, coffee, vanilla. Palate: fairly thick bodied, but smooth. slightly oily. Taste: sweet. strong malt taste.

Shockingly not yet rated. Enjoyed a bottle the other night and remembered how much I like this beer.  Like other SS beers, almost a definition of the style and a great example of balance and restraint, something that seems lost these days.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2012 Beautiful pour.  Thick tan head.  Pure black body.  Aroma is caramel. Tastes cocoa and caramel....and maybe a hint of coffee.  Smooth and thick.  A very very nice stout.

pours a nice black colour with a one finger head and the aroma has a hint of caramel chocolate oatmeal and roasted malt the taste has a hint of chocolate caramel oatmeal this is a very good stout worth buying again.

550ml bottle from Picks poured into an English Pint. Pours black with about 2 fingers of frothy tan head. Aroma of light caramel malt with a bit of coco and vanilla. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Good chocolate taste with a nice bit of vanilla. Medium bodied with a creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. I could drink this every day.
Nice brown head with excellent body.  This is more of a meal than a drink.  Wonderful taste.  Thick, rich and satisfying.  Wonderful finish to the last drop.
Bottle. Dark beer with some sweet tones,heavy palate and smell,really nice one.

Bottle from The Glasshouse, Brewer St, London. Colour is very dark brown/black opaque, creamy head in colour and texture. Nose is dark pruney and raisin fruit, sweet condensed milk, oats and brown sugar. Taste is dark fruit, prunes, raisins, roasted malt, brown sugar, condensed milk. Nice sweet stout but unlike Carribbean stouts, its nicely balanced and not cloying. Really lovely. Theres also powdered dark cocolate on the finish. My only criticism is that it doesnt really grow on the palate in terms of flavours.

500ml bottle.  Opaque brown-black.  Big beige head laces the glass.  Sweet chocolate and pungent rum soaked island fruit aroma, very reminiscent of a Caribbean Stout.  Chalky, burnt tones, but an overwhelming sweet raisin flavor is what this one is all about.  Really not so exceptional at all, Id like to believe this is an old bottle, as it in no way confirms my recollections of this beer being great.

Bottle at home. Dark brown/black, thin tan head fades to nothing, very little lacing. Nose is slightly meaty, dark chocolate, dark fruit too. Palate is reasonably sweet up-front, juicy fruit, smooth carbonation. Vanilla notes too. Big roasty cacao notes too. Really well-balanced, rich but never too sweet. Burnt toast and woody finish. Great stuff.

Bottle pours brown ish black with a red tint and beige head. It has a slightly sweet nose but a more balanced taste. It is lighter bodied but full of flavor, a good but fruity with red apple. Molasses lingers with some lightly burnt toast. This is very drinkable.
So far this is the best beer Ive had. Nice hints of chocolate and oats. Very smooth and easy to drink.
UPDATED: DEC 31, 2011 Bijna zwart met nauwelijks kraag. Zachte stout. Iets gebrande mout, caramel en zoete chocolade.
Bottle 355ml. Pours dark brown with a rich light brown foam. Aroma high in oats, chocolate and nuts. Smooth creamy texture. Not Bad.

Poured from a 550ml bottle into a tulip glass.

A: Pitch black with small amounts of carbonation bubbles coming up to the caramel colored thick foam head that clings to the side as it dissipates. It retains a nice tan lacing.

S: Roasted coffee with hops is big on the nose and it smells as if it has a higher ABV than it does. Nice scent that opens up as the beer warms up.

T: A nice slightly hoppy flavor with a sweet flavor up front with a nice roasted semi-dry finish. Chocolate notes are present, but very subtle. 

M: Medium to thick with a creamy mouth feel that goes down surprisingly easy. Very little carbonation here, but it works.

O: This is damn near a perfect beer. Very subtle flavors that are well balanced with a pleasant smell. The availability of it combined with the price and its ease to drink pushes this to be my favorite stout I think. Very tough competition, but man this is a good beer.

Aroma is sweet - and that almost overpowers the roasted notes. Beautiful in appearance. Tan head that clings to the glass and will not let go. The taste is pleasing. There is certainly a sweetness to it that almost goes too far but stops short of excess. Carbonated a bit much but in suit to the style. The smoothness is tough to match. So silky - One of its greatest features. Overall a pleaser.
UPDATED: SEP 26, 2016 Fantastic stuff. Very smooth. Slightly oily texture from the oats. Toasted aroma and flavor. Minerally taste and aroma. Serving: Bottle

very smooth,  lovely soft carbonation.  pours a really heavy brown with dark tan head.
aroma of stewed coffee.  quite good in the mouth, but I felt a little let down in the flavour department. some good roasted malt hints and dark fruit.
all in all pretty decent, but not quite heavy and rich enough for my stout palate.

Bottle to a pint glass.  Looks a little flat in the glass, but taste makes up for it.  Smooth drinking oatmeal stout.  Goes down easy without any overwhelming chocolate/coffee flavor you get from the Imperials.  More sweet than bitter on the finish.
This is one of my top 5 Brews. Very Flavorful,Tastes of  Roasted Malts and Oatmeal, A smell of Coffee and Chocolate. The Head is very creamy and lasted a bit..Cant get enough of this Brew
Good strong stout with the smell I have appreciated since my first really outstanding beer.

Aroma: Doughy, with hints of cereal.
Appearance: Black with a thick, tan head.
Taste: Medium, chocolatey sweetness with a hint of bitterness in the finish.
Palate: Full body, slick, creamy texture, soft carbonation, long finish.
Overall: This beer is very smooth and silky, and I could see it getting me into a lot of trouble. Its a tad too sweet for my taste, but its really well put together and I could see this pairing with any number of deserts, chocolate cheesecake for starters.
Really smooth stout.  Mild bitterness.  Creamy.  Well balanced.  Subtle flavor of roasted malt and a hint of chocolate.  Id like it better, if it was a tad more robust.
Bottle. Completely opaque, the pour is slightly thinner than I expected. Head is brown, thick, and creamy. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malt. Creamy, smooth mouthfeel; nice lingering sweetness.

Pours an amber tinted brown with a densely packed beige head. A beautifully roasted nose with light espresso notes. Mildly sweet middle with a burnt roasted malt and some chocolate. Sweet finish with bitter roast. Overall, a great brew.
Pours super black with a frothy long lasting head. Aroma of a fresh sea breeze. Taste of coffee with malt. A very slight hint of anis finishes with the perfect amount of bittering.

Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Pours an opaque, very dark brown color with creamy, creamy, creamy beige head, great retention. Aromas of grain, malt, coffee, chocolate, some fruity phenols. Balanced bittersweet flavors with a complex grainbill: bready, nutty, toasty, roasty, some hints of apricot, plum, dark cherries, molasses. Very nice aftertaste. Such a good beer, the very model of what oatmeal stouts should be.

pours dark colors with off white head in a creamy fashion. pours thick like syrup. mouthfeel of very thick, syrup, milky flavor. reminds me of left hand brewing milk stout. had some pinches of malt and chocolate but overall was a thick creamy treat

Pours dark cola, good head (short lived), minimal lacing.  Taste is clean roasted malt without all the "new" stout chocolate/coffee additions.  Straight, pure, clean bitter finish, great drinking, good for sessions or sipping.

Bottle at home in NH, shared with Charlie (he liked it). Pours ruby-brown with a dense, beige cream head. Lacto roast aroma. Medium sweet flavor, slight burnt sugar, dark fruitiness, lacto sugar sweetness, faint cocoa. Light to medium in body with average, smooth carbonation. Sweet finish, more lacto sugars, faint cocoa roast, faint chocolate. A very solid beer overall. Glad to finally get around to having/rating it.
550mL bottle from LCBO.  Pours black as night.  Taste is just wonderful - smooth and roasty, and it feels thick and smooth on the tongue.  A first-class stout.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark black body with a creamy tan head. Good retention and nice lacing as the head slowly trickles down.

S: Roasted malt, oats, and some sweet chocolate. Delicate but not muddled.

T: Like the nose, quite a bit of nice roasted malt and soft oats. The sweet chocolate makes its way in but doesnt overpower. Maybe just a tad bit of coffee as well.

M: Medium bodied with a nice creamy texture. Smooth carbonation. Nice lightly bitter finish.

O: A very nice oatmeal stout. Not my favorite, but this is the classic representation of the style and one I wouldnt turn down.

Bottle 33cl. Black beer with a fantastic and creamy brown head, with medium persistence. Coffee and forest fruits aroma, toast and roasty malt. Taste is sweet, dense, creamy, with a smokey hints. Full bodied beer, also creamy with average carbonation and roasted finish. A pleasure for all senses.
Date: September 24, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Minneapolis Beer Fest.  Full description not available as I sampled way too many beers in 4.5 hours!

Appearance: Deep amber, almost black, ruby reflections. Medium white head, good persistance.
Aroma: Medium intensity, notes of coffee and soy sauce, a mineral hint.
Taste: A fantastic body, dense, velvety despite the low alcohol content. Intense yet light, fresh, really drinkable. A gentle touch of coffee, some mineral notes, a medium, yet elegant, bitter finish. Good.

Well, heres another addition to the AW BHoF!!!  This hearty brew pours up a rich, dark  (near black) body sporting an exceptional tan frothy head which provides for some excellent lacing as this brew was savored.   The sense of smell is flooded with rich oats, robust/strong coffees, malts, caramel, and molasses.  The taste is absolutely out of this world!  Smooth, rich, creamy; these terms pale in comparison of the uniqueness of this fine brew!  Theres just enough bite from the hops that keep this from being on overly sweet brew.  What I enjoyed most were the teasings of toffee and chocolate aftertastes.

A - Sweet Malty caramel with dried fruit
A - Black brown with cream colored head
T - Light full sweetness with roasted bitter
P - Full and soft
O - A good well rounded stout...would love one on a cold night
Older bomber. Rich and creamy, a little one sided but definitely a charmer. Lingering malty finish.

Pours black with tan head. Smells of chocolate, sweetness from the oats, a touch of smoke and some coffee. Chocolate, coffee, a smokey note, creaminess and caramel come through in the taste. Medium on the palate with nice mid length roasted finish.
Really? I think everyone has tried this beer. One of the best oatmeal stouts.  Great blend of oats and barley.
En stadig stout. Fyllig och kompakt. Visar att en öl inte behöver vara stark eller besk för att vara kraftfullt. En av de bästa engelska stouts jag druckit. Fint skum.

Dark brown, almost black beer. Frothy beige head. Delicious aroma, full of sweet breadiness, dark syrup, roasted barley, herbal hops and a hint of coffee. Later some dark fruitiness appears. Medium sweet at first, bittrish and slightly sour in the finish with dark chocolate. Velvety soft texture, medium bodied. Tasty beer.

The pour is black with a tan, frothy foam.  The aroma is yeasty and fruity (cherry ?).  The flavour has similar notes of dough and fruit (raisin) accompanied by roasted and chocolate notes.  Nice full body and no alcohol warmth.

550ml bottle. Nose is lots of malt and some oatmeal after it opens for a bit.  Pours black with a nice tan linger cream top.  Taste is roasted malt, with nice oat back palate. Very subtle chocolate and cocoa powder adds a delicate bitterness counterpoint.  Mouthfeel is silky and cream, with very subdued carbonation.
Dark brown color with good big head. Aroma of malt. Flavor is little sweet but good.

Thanks to Chipalsa for giving me this beer that I shouldve tried ages ago. Nose is pure malt. Lots of grain with some roast behind it. Some solid molasses and raisin in there too. Superb. Oh, and some chocolate. Poured out dark brown with a creamy milk chocolate colored head. Initial thoughts on the taste is how sweet and smooth it is for a stout. Not bitter at all. Malt is everywhere but not overpowering. Sooo smooth. Taste, again, is grain/oat with a hint of roast and light raisin. Probably the easiest drinking stout out there and very refreshing. A summer stout in my opinion.

550ml bottle. Pours almost completely black with a nice brown head that stays forever. Aroma of roasted malts, some dark chocolate and a bit of smokiness. Tastes like a stout should taste. Tastes just like it smells with malts being in full effect and the oatmeal starting to show itself. Also has some dark fruit that became noticeable about halfway through. Medium bodied and sits well on the tongue. Drink it around 50-55 degrees to get the full experience, too cold and its complexity wont show itself, which is the story for most every stout or porter. This is a beer thats not hard to enjoy in my opinion. Not my favorite stout, but its a damn good one.
Not the thickest mouthfeel of oatmeal stout but it does have good flavor. It is a good beer
Black with a small off-white head. Aroma of roast malt, grain, molasses and licorice. Rather sweet, almost sugary flavor with a hint of licorice

It poured a dark brown color with a small head, just a ring of foam after about a minute. The aroma was of dark roasted malts, and a tiny bit chocolate. The taste was similar, but with a hint of oats.
bottle from LCBO. slight roasty aroma. black pour with big light brown head. roasty chocolate and coffee flavours. very easy drinking, especially for the style. very good for a light stout.

12oz bottle picked up at the state wine store 
Appearance: Pours dark brown, almost opaque, with a small tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted malts, oatmeal with bitter dark fruit 
Taste: Smooth mouthfeel of roasted bitter malts, dark chocolate with a spicy finish 
Nice and smooth.

Bottle, 35,5 cl. Pours gorgeous black with a red shine and a lovely light brown head. Aroma is really malty, I mean, just like raw malt, really rural grain, chocolate behind that, sweet cocoa, vanilla, a hint of roast, raisins and charcoal. Taste is nicely balanced. Sweet oats, caramel, chocolate, malts, and a bit of bitter roastiness. A hint of a porter-ish roasted tartness on the sides of the tongue. A nice treat from one of Englands best breweries.

Glad to see Samuel Smith switching to brown bottles.

The beer pours a very dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of chocolate and roasted malt notes, with some lactose and oats mixed in. I also somewhat surprisingly get some cinnamon notes which go very well with the other flavors. Medium to thick mouthfeel and low carbonation. A very nice Oatmeal Stout.
Awesome beer. Beautiful blackish brown color with a brown head. Nose of roast and oat, with flavor of nice roast, malts, and oat. Great beer. Drink it a lot, and love it every time.

Pours dark brown with a large, chocolate milkshake looking head. Smells of sweet oats and roastiness. Tastes sweet, with virtually no bitterness. Full-bodied with a smooth, gummi texture and no mouth-carbonation, Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout finishes smooth and refreshing.

2 finger  head disapates into thick lace
ruby red when put up to the light
Chocolate with hints of caramel and coffee. 
smooth/creamy drink
Overall a top notch Stout and one I will continue drinking. (I Can see this rating improving)
Bought from Slowbeer in Melbourne
Very black colour with some ruby red shining through when held in direct light. Smells like coffee, dough, caramel. Tastes roasty, coffee, iron, alcohol. Good mouthfeel.

Dark brown almost black color with a nice dark red glare coming through. Light brown, light creamy head. Smell dark chocolate and coffee. Taste coffee, dark chocolate, roasty and alcohol strangely enough. Sticky texture, lightly oily. Good carbo, ok body.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2015 This is an incredibly smooth drink with lots of character and a really great soothing effect. It pours beautifully and develops a modest head, of which is keeps some. The aroma contains all the elements expected of a stout, but it is very sweet and, not surprisingly, has a huge oatmeal backbone. The roasted malts and dark chocolate, though present, are not dominant. The taste is mostly sweet, but the bitter character character is there. There are caramel and chocolate notes, as well as some roasted malts and, of course, the really creamy oatmeal base. No trace of alcohol whatsoever. The body is full, smooth, with velvety carbonation carbonation.
Pours very dark with a a rapidly disappearing light brown head. Slightly sour taste. Medium body with minimal carbonation. Very drinkable.

Appearance: Thick black body with a thick brown head. Aroma; Oatmeal, bran, malt, chocolate, iron, coffee. Flavour: Creamy and frothy, caramel, coffee, chocolate, definite oatmeal, milky too with a long tasty bitter finish.

This poured an incredibly deep brown, with a very thin tan head. Smells sweet and thick of chocolate, raisins, molasses and a touch of vanilla. Roasted malts are all round the nose. The taste is incredibly smooth with notes of chocolate and roasted coffee tickling the senses. There is a hint of nuttiness and dark chocolate in the finish that is both cocoa bitter and then suddenly sweet. A very well balanced stout.

Pitch-black stout with beautiful brown creamy head. Smells malty sweet, with bonds between coffee and caramel. Starts malty bitter with good hop aroma. A sweet aroma of coffee takes the upper hand, combined with a lot of caramel and sweet malts. The middle part remains bitter malty, with proper degree of sweetness and lots of coffee flavor. Goes into a coffee roasting, bitter, caramelly finish!

Bottle. Pours almost pitch black with a big light brown head. Decent lacing. Slightly tart, roasted aroma with hints of vanilla. Flavour is tart, roasted and a bit metallic, with notes of coffee and liquorice. Smooth roasted finish, slightly dry, with a lingering coffee note. Overall pretty good. 10.07.11.

500 mL bottle from Beers of Europe into a pint glass.  Dark as night but the head is a bit cornetto-like.  Very rich first taste, chocolatey and very nice indeed.  Rich and choclatey aroma, just like it tastes.  Sweet as well, without the bitterness you can get from some stouts.  On further tasting it does actually, which isnt a bad thing.  A very fine stout indeed (and Im not just saying that as a Yorkshireman).
(Bottle 5/7-2011) Low lasting head, creamy taste, looks great in the glass, but the watery taste kind of let it down a bit. Tasted cold.

I am a huge fan of this Oatmeal Stout. HUGE!
Roasted, Caramel, coffee aroma and flavor to follow. Not over bearing. Seriously, I become a regular at a pub/bar that serves good ole Sam Smith. Yeah, we are close like that, he lets me call him Sam. 
The appeaarance when poured is like arts and crafts. A true art and dedication goes into the Samuel Smith brewing techniques. The finishis so good that A.) you are happy it comes in a larger bottle. Then B.) you have to order your second before your 1st is completely gone. 
Its like coffee at 5am, a must and well appreciated. Hugs Mr. Smith, big hugs!
Almost black with light brown head. Sweet and bitter taste. Aroma of caramel, toast and a faint of nuts. Very good.

0,5 l bottle, Csak a jó sör.
Poured black, with a small, tan, creamy foam. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel, coffee, hints of ash and dark fruits like plum and raisins. Light body, with medium carbonation. Roasty finish. I like heavier stouts, but this one stands its ground. Good one.

Bottle 50 cl. Black with a fantastic lightbrown head. The aromas are roasted malty, chocolate, plumb and more dark fruits. The taste is quite sweet with a roasted and chocolate aftertaste, hmmmm nice!

550 ml bottle from LCBO.  Pours a virtually black, dark brown with large beige head and lots of lacing.  Aroma is lightly roasty with anise and raisin.  Taste of licorice, dark fruit, chocolate and a hint of roastiness.  Lovely smooth, creamy mouthfeel with some dryness in the finish.  Impressive.

Aroma: Bitter sweet chocolate, coffe, nutty, oat meal cookies. Bready.
Taste: Chocolate, coffe, raisins, burnt.
Mouthfeel: Dry, medium body, nice carbonation.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2011 Bottle courtesy of Clyx. Chocolate, Coffee and fudge and some roasted notes. The smell has a pleasant nuttiness to it. Taste starts of with a lot of roasted malt and some chocolate. The body is medium to full, witch is quite nice seeing that the beer is only 5% abv.  It finished quite dry with some bitterness to it. Its a good stout but quite generic...

355 ml bottle from Alko. Pours almost black with tan head. Aroma of molasses, dark chocolate and coffee.Somewhat sweet taste with similar components as in the aroma.Sweetish finish with prominent bitterness.

Finally got a chance to try this today, from a 550ml bottle at my local supermarket.  The aroma didnt amaze me, but I perked up when I saw it pour dark brown, almost black, with a nice tan head.  This is an easy one to drink, with a sweet chocolate flavor in front of roasted malts and maybe a hint of coffee providing just enough bitterness which I missed until the aftertaste.    Since this one is widely available in my neighborhood and not too expensive, I will definitely come back for more and will start to check out other oatmeal stouts.

Bottle. Almost black with a dark brown tinge, and a large creamy tan to light brown head. Aroma: roasted, oatmeal cookies, some chocolate, fruit. Taste: roasted, licorice, chocolate, oatmeal cookies with raisins, candy, some coffee, dark fruit, a slight acidity. Medium-bodied, smooth, medium carbonation. Very nice!
Bottle. Clear red-black body with an average sized dense light borwn head. Aroma-taste of tar, wood, smokey with a sweetish chocolate body. Full bodied with loew to moderate carbonation. Nice.
Dark ebony colour with medium head. Aromas of oat, caramel, raisins and some strawberries. Taste is mild sweet, not stout like. Medium body with creamy texture and slightly dry finish

Bottle. Dark brown pour, solid tan head. Aroma is roasty, slightly creamy, toffee, caramel and licorice. Flavor is bitter roasted and creamy sweet. Very nice balance and thick body, really drinkable. Very nice brew.
Fine head and good laces. Black. Nose is dark espresso with a little bitter chocolate. Fine body and good length.cream, chocolate espresso, sweetness. Over all very drinkable

An opaque almost black color with a creamy tan head.  The aroma is a bit oaty, roasty, and alcohol.  The flavor is roasted chocolate, anise, and alcohol despite a relatively low ABV.  It does leave some nice lacing and warms the belly.

This brew pours a very dark brown, almost black. The head is creamy but short. The aroma is roasted and nutty. There is a mild chocolate presence. The taste is bitter and sharp and the mouthfeel is moderate finishing dry. This brew is really nice and flavorful, going down smooth

8 June 2011, bottle. black, foamy tan head that fades fast. tangy stout nose and faint chocolate. full body and mildly fizzy. a bit creamy. really good stout. not as malty. oatmeal isnt a flavour but it affects the malt profile. i really like this. a bit acidic but only faintly. bitter chocolate and lots of balance. really nice!

55cl bottle. Pours opaque with a nice head which mostly hangs around.  The nose has smokiness and really delicate chocolate notes. The taste has definite chocolate, maybe liquorice on the end. The palate is great - big in structure, so creamy in texture but then it drops away elegantly at the end. Overall, a really nice beer.

02/06/2011 55cl bottle @ Klaas place - BB: 04/2012 (2011-245)  Thanks to Klaas for sharing the bottle! 
Clear (not cloudy, visible while pouring) very dark brown to black beer. Small beige head, pretty stable. Aroma: sweet caramel, mocha, milk chocolate, bit of tobacco. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body, creamy texture. Taste: little sweet, sour red berries, mocha, little bitter, milk chocolate, caramel. Aftertaste: bit sour, coffee and dark chocolate.

This brew pours a very dark brown, almost black.  The head is creamy but short.  The aroma is roasted and nutty.  There is a mild chocolate presence.  The taste is bitter and sharp and the mouthfeel is moderate finishing dry.  This brew is really nice and flavorful, going down smooth.
Bottle at home. Dark brown pour, light brown creamy head. Aroma of oatmeal and malt, faint raisins as well. Taste of hops and caramel, with nice oatmeal throughout. Slight bitter hoppy aftertaste.
Bomber.  Pours black with thick tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and grain.  Flavor is oat, chocolate and grain.  Very nice and sessionable.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2011 Bottle. Very dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Some milk in there. Taste is the same. Fantastic brew. 
One of my favorites, this beer is soft creamy with a touch of bitterness like the poke of feathers in a down pillow. Sublime.

330ml bottle from Alko

Pours black with a small head. Aroma has hints of chocolate and rye. Taste has medium body with notes of chocolate, caramel and rye. Finish is smooth. Enjoyable stout.

Went back-to-back with Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter. Similar to the Old Brewery Pale Ale/India Ale, this is really almost dead-on with the Taddy Porter for flavor. Maybe a bit more punch on every level--thicker head, slightly more aroma, stronger flavors--but still a super-mild, drinkable stout. Nothing of the viscosity of so many stouts out there (especially American stouts). I really liked this because of its pairability: I had this with some pretty rich Ben & Jerrys ice cream (New York Super Fudge Chunk), and the pairing worked beautifully. The ice cream was so flavorful that a bigger stout probably would have been too much. Sipping the Smiths after each bite just brought out this really nice chocolate softness.
Nice dark cola color with a tall fizzy head. Has a slight chocolate scent and taste.
Bottle at Brewpub, Copenhagen. Black with a nice lasting beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, chocolate, hops and rye.

(bottle) Poured a black-brown colour with creamy long-lasting beige head.  Wonderful dark chocolate aroma and some muted aley flavours.  Mouthfeel was velvety and persisted on the tongue. Finish mostly roasty bitterness but some residual sweetness.  I enjoyed this stout.

Pours a dark brown with beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, toast, and a bit of chocolate. Mild sweetness, a little roasty with a bit of hoppiness. Light, smooth body. A good oatmeal stout, but nothing really distinguishes it as special.

Nutty, earthy, bound by malty accents and stiff thickness. This oatmeal stout is, by all accounts, a four course meal. A frothy and caramel head blooms and then dissipates until a creamy, fuel-colored body appears. This is a pure comfort beer from top to bottom. Would love to drink this while watching pond hockey or after shoveling a driveway.

I received this one as a gift for the 12/10 Christmas season.  I opened it up on 4/30/11, and it had a beautiful sweet toast bouquet and poured with a reasonably lasting head and dark smooth texture.  The initial malt taste matched that texture with some gypsum and coffee tones, and finished with a combo citrus/herbal hop format.  A standard for sure!  I liked it.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: I dont think there are too many better beers out there.  Certainly, not this style.  A classic English beer, dark black pour, excellent balance.  The finish is a charcoal toasty flavor. my favorite part.  I had one for breakfast this morning, is there a better breakfast beer out there?  I have never had a bad beer from this brewery

UPDATED: MAY 15, 2011 Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout is simpal supar! It reminds me of the days in my youth in Milan listening to Louis Prima while admiring the glorious butt-cheeks of the lovely Italian girls passing by while I sipped a fine Aperol in a café.

The flavor is delicious like many fine Stouts while not overbearing. It does have an initial strong stout punch but lingers with sweet after tones and settles well within my mouth.

Update 5/14/2011..............

Ive tasted this beer once again with vigor and  solitude. While i would love to caress the butt-cheeks of a sweet woman while drinking as I type this, it should be noted that this fine beverage is quite sensational while fully full boost buzzed on alcohol or even other simpal supar feelings.

this is a special strong ale for the love of KSA and all that is holy to the remaining portion of love and special beverage consumers - I love this fine beverage please......
Smoky aroma, solid black in appearance, very good looking. Thick, brown head. Slightly bitter, hops come through in taste. Smooth, solid stout.

Dark brown/black colour. the liquid is very complete and has a nice strong structure. pours a thin tanned white head that stays nicely. aromas are full and deep; malt, roasty rye, bread, a lot of earthy scents, and even banana, twisted herbs. a medium sweet taste with low bitterness. the body is medium, nicely balanced with the taste. a very good beer for a Finn who likes the tastes of rye and bread with deep refined details.
Opaque, dark brown pour, light tan head, decent little lace. Sticky mouth, mild aroma, mellow, sweet flavor.  Exactly what it should be.

Bottle. Pours a clear and dark brown beer with a beige head. The aroma is malt, roasted, ash and smoke. The flavor is following the nose. The palate is soft with sweetness. Overall a balanced beer above average.
Black with a light brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, coffee and light smoky. Flavor is quite sweet and moderate bitter. Dry and roasted bitter finish. Soft and smooth. 100910
(bottle)  A creamy and mild stout with rich roasted flavors.  Great palate and lingering aftertaste.  One is not enough.

Appearance:    dark coffee with a nice creamy tan head and residual lacing.    Aroma:  nutty, roasted oats and malt, some coffee.    Taste:  	smooth, toasty, nutty with a light hint of sweet chocolate and smoke.    Finish:  medium toasted oats, lightly dry and slightly bitter.    Notes:    Stronger oat flavors and aromas than Ive seen in other examples of the style.  Nice coffeeish and nutty characteristics as well.  Medium carbonation; nice stout.
Black pour, medium brown head. Roasty raisiny aroma. Flavor is the same, with even more dark fruit, and chocolate. Tasty.

A dark brown pout with a light tan head. About three fingers of head, very creamy looking, fluffy, good retention and lacing....a very strong aroma that hits me once the cap is off, very malty, mostly sweet chocolate with a hint of vanilla on the finish, pretty good, lacks depth...The taste is more of the same, mostly malty but overpowering or to sweet. Light coffee finish rounds this off. A fuller feel than most English beers. Easy to drink.

This is tasty, and abover average in all aspects, however Im just not super impressed. Id probably have again but cant strongly recommend it

Toasty and roasty oatmeal that seems to be simmered over a blazing campfire in the adirondacks.  Color is sharpie black but then turns to a mild dark chocolate hue.  Taste is fluid in the deep mohogany smokey stoutness the subsides.  I get a bit of burnt chocolate most likely from that fire.  Then some hidden caramel nuggets.  Then some mild molasses that flows through the grapevine.  the head is prevalant enought to look nice but subsides quickly then leave an everlasting thin rim around the glass for each sip.  definately a classic stout here.  solid through and through.
Pours very dark brown with a medium brownish head. Aroma is roasted malts and oatmeal. Flavour is roasted malts with a hint of coffee. Nice full body.

Bottle at the Duke of Argyll, Soho. Definately one of the best sam smiths offerings that ive had. Pours a dark brown, with a decent brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, dark chocolate and some vanilla oats. Quite sweet, but could definately have a couple of these.

Bottle like the picture.  Quickly dissolving thin head that leaves a little sand over the opaque body with nice lacing.  I like the looks of this.  Aroma is of caramel malt with a little bread and dough and some roast.
Some beers mix between nose and taste a little like the wet cardboard of a corked wine, and this is one.  Mainly, this is a little sweet and little sour.  Body is medium.  Carbonation is lively.  Finish is long and a little bitter.
Overall, its just OK.
Pours dark brown with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, smooth, chocolate, coffee and light liquorish.

tostato e torreffatto piacevolmente accompagnati da un sentore di latte.
mi ricorda delle caramelle che da piccolo mi regalava il mio fornaio

550ml bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is deep cola with three fingers of foamy beige head; retention was decent, as well as a generous show of lacing.  Nose is lactose, oatmeal, toffee, and very light roasted malt.  Taste is a beautiful blend of toffee, dark chocolate, oatmeal, and roasted malt.  Unlike the nose, these tastes are all clearly defined.  The first thing that hits is the toffee and roasted malt, this fades slightly and the oatmeal and dark chocolate pull a double punch.  This blend fades into a semi-dry, slightly bitter finish.  I wasnt expecting the world from this brew, but thoroughly enjoyed it.  Because of the ABV, and smooth easy drinking, this would be one heck of a session beer to keep around!

550ml brown bottle.

It pours a dark brown with a creamy off-white/tan head. It leaves some decent lacing.

The smell is pretty good,it is smokier and roastier than I expected. There is also a hint of earthy hops.

The flavor is pretty great, I am thoroughly surprised. It has a decent level of roastiness and a leveling bit of sweetness. It also has some interesting tang. The mouthfeel is a bit thin at times, especially in the finish, but overall it is nicely bodied.

After a while it gets a bit sweet, but overall a solid brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-22-2011 01:17:03
Pours dark with a creamy head. Full bodied, but a bit too sweet to be a favorite

Bottle. Pours a dark brown-black with a high, pillowy, light brown head. The nose is all dark fruit -- smells like a date bar, and I mean that in a good way. Flavor is rich and sweet, with molasses, PX sherry, and coffee overtones; finishes cleanly and sets you up for another drink. This beer is proof of something good in the universe.

Bottle pours deep brown with a tan head.  Aroma shows notes of roasted malt, chocolate, and a definate oat presence. Flavor shows the same with additional notes of coffee, nuts, and a touch of smoke.  Overall
body is moderate and soft with well balanced bitterness.

Easy drinking beer.  Pours dark brown with fluffy tan head. Aroma is roasty with some nuttiness.  Very smooth in the mouth, with a very sticky feel.  Tastes of cold coffee and caramel.  Long lingering finish.  Would drink again.

Bottle. 
Near black brew with some sticky white head. Roasted malt and chocolate aromas - just enough sweetness.  Silky smooth mouthfeel, this is a very enjoyable oatmeal stout.

Tökéletesen fekete színű, eszméletlen krémes és kitartó bézs habbal, nagyon imponáló tehát a megjelenése. Illata pörkölt malátás, kakaós és kicsit kávés. Ízében már ezek mellett a gyümölcsösség is megjelenik: likőrbe áztatott mazsola és aszalt szilva érződik, de azért a pörkölt jegyek határozzák meg az italt, kandiscukros édesség és a kávés-kakaós szárazság váltakozik ízlelés közben, valamint a komlós kesernyés ízek is megjelennek a végén. Közepesen testes, nagyon jól iható, tartalmas ital, valahogy éreztem közben, hogy ez igen, ilyennek kell lennie egy rendes stout-nak!

Pours black with a tan head that dissipates. Chocolate and roasted aroma, a touch of dark fruit. Medium- bodied, sticky and chewy. Semi- dry flavor with a mild bitterness and a little twang from the Irish yeast. Wonderful. Enjoyable from start to finish.

Carmel, coffee and hay aromas coupled with a resin that lingers in the nose. Black with an amber tint when held up to the light. Also impressively clear in appearance. Minimal brown head. Heavy sweet taste with a light bitter finish. Very Good!! Medium body on the palate with a thick texture. Flat carbonation (which works very well) with a pleasanty, lingering finish. Absolutely among the finest beers I have ever tasted!!!!

550ml bottle.  Pours black with a creamy caramel coloured head.  Very heavy mineral note in the nose, molasses, dates, cocoa, burnt sugar, earthiness.  The taste is medium sweet with smokey notes up front, dried fruits, faint citrus, faint wood, big molasses in the finish with more smoke.  Definition of solid.

Pours black with a billowing caramel colored head. Very bubbly and good lacing. Aroma is nice and bitter with some roasted barley touches thrown in. Taste is somewhat sharp at first but transitions into a smooth oatmeal and roasted barley finish. Medium bodied and quite dry/bitter.

Poured from a 550ml bottle, black with tan head and lacing throughout.   I got alot of chocolate and doughy hints.  Very smooth on palate, slight bitter finish.   My first oatmeal stout, not bad, but not something I would drink all the time.

Poured from bottle, pours black with a light brown head and lacing through out the entire glass,  aroma is sweet with malt and has grain and oat notes, the flavor is smooth and has decent amount of chocolate in the finish with the oats, still not very impressed with these brews.
Expected a lot, but it was a little disappointment. totally black. light brown head. quite heavy mouth feel. Malty, syrupy sweetness. Happy to have had it though.

Like revisiting an olde friend after not seeing him for years, Sir Sammy still delivers a receptive bow. Pours a deep brown with garnet firing the bottom. Head is light brown and full. Oil and oat fill the aroma with recessive hints of chocolate. Coating mouthfeel is medium, less than expected, with biscuit. Chewy, yet oily, this is a nice stout. Sweetness lingers throughout with a roasted cocoa.
Is it just me or is everything from SS just damn good. That well that they have  been using since 1758 is working out quit well for them. A certain smoothness comes with this oatmeal stout.

0.355 l bottle from Csakajósör, Bp.
Very deep dark brown colour with a creamy beige head, which leaves a thin film behind.
Sweet, dried fruity and roasty nose.
Moderate sharp start followed by a slick and oily mouthfeel with a sweetbitter and fine aroma of roasted and chocolate malt, raisins and licorice. Flavours of sugar balanced by a dark chocolate liked taste in the sweetbitter finish, which drains the palate and remains in a long dried fruity-roasty/licorice aftertaste.
Great, very enjoyable and complex brew.

550 mL bottle in a shaker.  Dark chocolate pour with frothy head.  This one was awesome.  I cant believe its taken me this long to try this one.  Rich, well developed flavors.  Definitely a great go to stout.  Nothing wrong with this one.

Bottle from Alko.  Opaque dark brown beer with offwhite head. Roasted malts and licorice in the aroma. Taste is roasted malts, licorice and oatmeal. Light-medium body and everything in a good balance. Tasty but quite light.

Poured into a snifter.

4.5 A: Black color. Two fingers of thick, creamy light brown head. Great retention and plenty of lacing. Nearly perfect here.

4.5 S: Plenty of strength in the aroma for a 5% stout. Oatmeal is very apparent with healthy amounts of roasted barley, dark roast coffee, and a hint of dark chocolate. Also, this is surprisingly nutty, which I wholey welcome. Very nice.

5.0 T: Again, very flavorful for such a small beer. Light lactose-like sourishness. Roasted and toasted malts. Coffee is full force with nuttiness right behind. Some molasses and just a touch of breadiness. Really good!

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Moderate, but lively carbonation. Super smooth, but I wish the body was a bit thicker making this creamier. Still, not bad for how light it is.

5.0 D: Even with some minor issues in the mouthfeel, this is one hell of a beer. Sam Smith is pretty much the king of UK. Just about everything Ive had is tops for the country. This is exceptionally tasty given how small of a beer it is and allows you to drink plenty of it, which is why I wish I had more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-22-2010 23:38:02

355ml bottle. Pours a very dark brown, almost black with some dark latte-colored, creamy foam that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is at first strongly of roasted malts, but reveals quite a bit of liquorice with some syrup and coffee. Taste is of liquorice and coffee with some sweet syrup and roasted malts, but not nearly as much as in the aroma at first. Finish is a surprising and sweet nougat combination of milk chocolate and nuts. Ashy and bitter aftertaste. Palate is creamy and velvety with a little bit too much carbonation for my tastes. Excellent dessert beer.

550 mL bottle. Pours a dark brown, minimal head, just a ring of foam after about a minute. Aroma is of dark roasted malts, and a tiny bit chocolate. Taste is similar, but with a hint of oats. Silky mouthfeel. Pretty good.

Enjoyed from a 16.9oz bottle in an English pub glass.  The beer pours the distinctive deep brown to black color, with a high tan head.  The nose shows notes of caramel, biscuit, toffee, and slight roasted notes.  The palate is exceedingly smooth in comparison with other examples of the style, showing noticeable, but restrained, medium and medium-high English caramel residual malt sweetness.  Carbonation is light, but enough to keep the beer from seeming overly full on the palate.  The finish lingers, with a slight note of coffee, as well as toffee.  The oats seemingly serve to smoothen the palate.  Overall, clearly the paradigm of the style; enjoyable in every conceivable manner.
UPDATED: MAR 4, 2011 One of the most pleasant tasting beers out there. Light chocolate and frutiness. Very good beer.

Flaske 355 ml flaske. Mørkebrun hælde med et stort nødebrunt hoved af middel varighed. Aroma af mørke frugter, chokolade, og noter af rosin. Smagen er virker sød med noter af farin og chokolade. Afbalancerede eftersmag med et strejf bitterhed.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2011 I pour a 355 ml bottle of this dark black beer almost completely in a glass. Beer forms a nice asymmetric layer of beige coloured foam on the top. Aroma: Lightly fruity, lingonberry. Sweet toasted malt, little syrupy. Roasted. Taste: Lightly sweet, umami.

In mouth the beer feels like a melting chocolate that subsides gradually. Medium body, noticeable carbonation.

Overall: Very good.

A particulary pleasant head. Surprisingly similar to a Guinness. Not an awful lot more to say.

Alright I admit it opens up quite a lot. A lovely smooth and effortlessly deep fruitiness being its main draw.

500ml bottle from Firefly. Pours an opaque black with rich head. Aroma has a little chocolate, sweet with little roasty note at the end. Flavour is very rich and complex, a little chocolatey but balanced out very nicely. Finishes clean and bitter. Very good.

Tätä on tullut juotua moneen kertaan, ensin Amerikassa ja sen jälkeen Lontoon reissuilla. Musta olut ja vaalean ruskea vaahto. Lakritsinen ja herkullinen kauraleipäinen tuoksu. Lakritsinen ja hieman paahtunut maku. Lisää kauraa. Todella tuhti 5-prosenttiseksi olueksi. Yksinkertainen ja herkullinen olut hyvältä panimolta. Harvemmin olut tuoksuu näin kauraiselta.

Drank a bottle alongside my Saras cheesecake.  They offset perfectly. Roasty, dry and smooth.  Youll never find a wine that pairs with cheesecake better than this stout. Also, its pretty light, like you could drink about 15 and eat brownies, cheesecake, whatever. Yum.

Pours an opaque brown with decent size brown head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Deep dark sweetness in the taste but with a clean crisp coffee finish with just enough bitterness to make it very very smooth.  Very smooth silky palate that finishes quite clean with only the slightest sugary stickiness.

Bottle. Dark browm, small and very short light brown head. Moderate, malty  oaty and sweetish lightly roasted  brunt aroma. Body is medium, sweetish malty  oaty flavor, light roastiness. Finish is average, malty and lightly sweet. Oat in beer is always turn off for me. Nice burnt aroma though.

Pours an opaque rich walnut with some copper against the bright light, a frothy beige head sticking to the walls of the glass. Smells of faint roasted coffee in the morning and malted grains in the mill. Quite an uncomplicated taste but refined, subdued, that of roasted barley, very, very low acid and bitterness from the English hops, a lactose sweetness pronounced most noticeably in the superb aftertaste that lingers like cane sugar syrup with medium, easy to drink body. As I say always comparing great European beers to most of their U.S. counter parts (see Founders Breakfast Stout for example) a brewer, like a suitor vying for the attention of a woman, shouldnt go over the top to cheaply try and impress. Stick to a balance of ingredients as Samuel Smith does in all their beers.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2011 550ml bottle as part of the LCBO Sam smith pack. Pours opaque black with nice tan head. Light toasty light sourness from the oatmeal on the nose, touch of caramel. Medium carbonation, medium body. Great flavours here, nice bitterness and a touch of grassy hop flavour backed up by a sweet caramel followed by roast and a touch of acidity on the finish with the satisfying astringency of the oats.

355 ml bottle. Finland.
Black colour with small tan head.
Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, molasses and some sweetness in aroma.
Flavour is roasted malt, dark chocolate, mild notes of coffee, some sweetness and even fruitiness. Might be nutritional at least its good.

Pours a sludgy black with a thin, creamy tan head.  The aroma is wonderful; chocolate and coffee with a little bit of syrup-like sweetness.  The taste is simple, but on-point.  The creaminess really stands out with the chocolate, and theres just a little bit of hop flavor to keep everything balanced.  The mouthfeel is thick, as this brew is as heavy as it looks.  Very filling and very satisfying.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2011 Bottle. Black colour with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and caramel. Roasted malt, coffee, cocoa and caramel. Medium-bodied and some bitterness in the finish.

Poured into a Sams Perfect Pint glass. Had a nice appearance to it. Not too dark for an oatmeal stout and didnt have too much of a foam head that was an off white color, it lingers around sticking to the glass even after your done. It seems to look better after you start drinking it. Has a nice chocolate, molasses, and grainy aroma to it. Feels very nice on the pallet, almost drinks like a porter, seems a bit more carbonated than most stouts, its also surprisingly drinkable for a stout as well.
Pours an opaque brown with cocoa head.  Smells of hay, bread, and mildew .  Medium body. Tart finishes to a smooth, doughy burnt body.  Well balanced and delicious.

Review from notes, sampled 3/6/2008
03/06/2008
Ive always been afraid to buy any of the Samuel Smith products because of that clear bottle they come in. So today I stopped at the local and the oatmeal stout had just arrived and was still sealed in the case box. Theres no way that one is light struck, now is the time to try it!

Pours a solid dark brown with fluffy off white head that laces itself on the way down the glass. Aroma is faint chocolate and caramel. Taste follows the smell. Mouthfeel is medium thin, creamy, and drying. The chocolate taste lingers after each sip. Decent brew, definitely not like the American oatmeal stouts Ive had. This one is much more sessionable. I could drink a few of these.

Revisited on 12/13/2009
I ended up with a Sam Smith Gift pack at a holiday party Yankee swap so I thought Id do a better job reviewing this beer.
Beer pours a deep dark brown with the faintest of ruby highlights when held to light. Large fluffy mocha head sticks around forever and laces the glass all the way down. Smells of molasses, oatmeal and a hint of chocolate. Taste is filled with caramel, molasses, chocolate, a bit of dark fruit. Finishes kind of dry with a lingering subtle roast bitterness. Mouthfeel is just short of creamy, medium body and carbonation. I actually think I like this a bit less than the first time I reviewed this. Its a decent enough beer, but nothing special. Maybe I just enjoy the less subtle American version of everything. My score reflects the first time I tried this.

what a classic beer, this is extremely filling but strangely it makes you want another, or some chocolate chips cookies. nearly a milk stout in the way it feels like velvet going down, so unbelievably smooth. great roasty malty flavor with hints of chocolate and honey. yum yum yum

355 ml bottle. Black beer with a thin tan head. Sweetish roasted malty aroma with elements of coffee, chocolate and spices. The flavour is sweetish, roasted malty, with oat and milk chocolate. Smooth carbonation. Very pleasant.
Not as "chewy" as I would expect.  Brown head dissipated to longer-lasting lace.  Warm nose, hints of chicory.  Quick finish.
23rd March 2008  Silky smooth stout with a nice balance of sourish malt, lightly toasted malt and a little fruitiness, Very drinkable.

330 ml bottle.
Pours a dark brown colour with a long-lasting white head. Aroma of strong wheat, malt and caramel. Flavour of toasted malts, nuts, caramel and cream. Medium bodied with a thick mouthfeel. Bitterish finish. Well balanced and smooth.
Bottle. Poured black with small tan head. Aroma is herbal jägermeister and finnish home brewed low alcoholic beer. Flavour is roasted malt and hints of fruitiness.

Poured into a Samuel Smiths English pint glass.  Jet black color with a thick creamy tan head.  Head subsides slightly but thin layer remains.  Aroma is primarily sweet and malty with strong oatmeal notes, along with some notes of cocoa, some spices, and nuttiness.  Mouthfeel is full bodied but with a creamy and smooth texture.  Flavor has a nice dry roasty/nuttiness to it but with creamy malt flavors in the background.  Overall this is a delicious stout.  Its flavors are mild and there is not one particular standout characteristic, but the overall drink is very enjoyable.

Served in a weizen. A - Deep, complex aroma of earth, wheat, molasses, caramel, and malt. Really surprising and wonderful. Ap - Pours deep burgundy with a nice 2-finger head that oddly, is the color of the label. T - Wow. Just...wow. Molasses, caramel, burnt sugar, malt, chocolate, and coffee notes abound, with minimal discernible bitterness. Absolutely amazing. O - Im so glad I found a place that sells this. I could drink this anytime, and its truly an amazing beer.

550 ml bottle. Aroma a little sweet with slight caramel, a little earthy slight coffee from the roast. Appearance jet black with a medium creamy tan head that hangs on for a while. Well balanced sweetness up front that dries out just enough in the finish. Some chocolate notes. Slight bit of fruit in the after taste. Mouthfeel is full and silky. A very pleasurable beer that is easy drink several pints of.

Bottle @ Home. Almost black with a nice light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, bitter chocolate, coffee. Taste is mostly like aroma, bitter coffeelike finish. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. Nice and easy drinking stout. 130111

Bottle from Alko. Poured almost black color with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt and milk chocolate. Flavor is similar with some coffee and milk. Very smooth. Nice and drinkable stout, but not my favourite.
UPDATED: FEB 29, 2012 Very thick, full body.  Easy to sip.  In most ways the better stout compared to Guiness, except in price.

Black beer with a beautiful, quite weak and beige head. Aroma is tastefull, roastiness, coffee, chocolate and some sourness. Very smooth and pleasant to drink. Taste is roasted with balancing sweetness, also chocolate, coffee and some liquirice; overally this is quite sweet stout. Pleasant, smooth and enjoyable stout, I have only good things to say about this beer.
0,355 l bottle. Very dark color, nice creamy head. Aroma includes roasted malts and coffee. The major factor is, however, the milky smoothness that dominates the palate. Very enjoyable and balanced.

Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout. Pours out a great off white head that both had great retention and lacing. Great head here. It has a dark rich brown color, almost black and gives off a roasted coffee and roasted malt aroma. You can taste the malts and oats in the beer as well as some hints of roasted coffee and has a sweetness under the bite. Smooth and creamy body with just the right amount of carbonation to carry the flavor through. This is good stuff.

Not sure how one could improve on the flavor of this beer.  Its outstanding.  Aroma is rich in dark malts.  Leather, toast, coffee, cola all evident,  Gorgeous ruby brown head with an inviting thick tan head that drops to a thin but persistent cap.  Taste is sweet.  Strong roasty character but not particularly acrid. Maybe a hint of vanilla and brown bread.  Extraordinary creamy texture thanks to the oats.  This is truly exceptional.

12oz bottlepours a rich foamy light brown head that laces and black color.  Aroma is rich dark malt-chocolate/roasty, secondry spice/earthy hops.  Taste is sweet/rich dark malt-chocolate/roasty, lactose, secondry spice/earthy hops.

chocolate and coffee aroma; taste is rich, deep - chocolately with malt, coffee that lingers and changes into the aftertaste.  great texture and body, leaving warmth of alcohol without the slightest hint of it.   as reliable a brewery as can be found.
(bottle) very dark brown with small tan head; aroma of caramel, soy sauce, oily palate; pleasant sweetish flavour, quite good

Was not a fan of this the first time I had it, but some time passed and I gave it another go, much to my satisfaction this time around. Pours black with two fingers of foamy head. I guess Im used to American and Russian Imperial Stouts; this is considerably less viscous. Smell is tart and earthy with oatmeal, with a bit of chocolate. Taste is similar to smell more enjoyable; slightly tangy with roasted malts and a bit of sweetness. Medium bodied, smooth but still creamy, with soft carbonation

Its certainly good, but dare I say its overrated? Pours beautifully dark black with a foamy beige head. Faint chocolate and soft grain in the aroma. The flavour is quite understated, oat and roasted notes, quite dry. The smooth texture is remarkable and is the beers best feature.
55cl, English brewery, thx to MadsNP!, not complex Stout, yet easy to drink, very balanced, clear, good head, good brew
Tastes just like a bowl of grandmas oatmeal! No, not really. Its a stout. Pretty damn good.
When i drank this i really got the taste of oatmeal  farely dark but a good roasted flavor not a very strong beer but tastes amazing
