Almost black. Nice stout body, low carbonation, smooth. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt and a milky sweet smell that I can only attribute to the oatmeal. Taste is pretty sweet, a little too much to suit me, and a little roasty. Its well done, and I can see why its so popular, but the sweetness threw it off a bit for me.

From bottle into pint glass at Beer Bistro in Chicago.  As good as folks say it is..Dark but not as black as some....thin head but that may be more the pour.  Smooth, silky, sorta sweet...a pleasure to drink..  Love that a beer this flavorful can by only a 5% abv; you can drink it all night and still function the next day....taste is better than booze, and this is the proof of that.

Dark brown to black with ruby highlights. Aroma has some sweetness and choc malt character, moderately complex. Smooth mouthfeel from the oats witha some residual sweetness there too. Soft carbonation, but I prefer that with a stout.

12oz bottle. I drank this from the bottle so I can not fully describe the aroma, or say anything about the look. I could pick-up chocolate, coffee and roasted barley in the aroma. Taste: big notes of sweet milk chocolate, strong coffee, roasted barley. Finish was dry and had a nice bitterness. Solid medium body. Overall a very good beer: good depth and very balanced.

Black pour with some reddish brown edges and a frothy, dense, tan head.  The aroma is chcolately rolled oats, brown sugar, a hint of coffee, and a little rum raisin bread.  The flavor is creamy chcolate and oats with some brown sugar and hints of tofee, coffee, and dark fruit.  The body is creamy, medium, with soft carbonation.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a pint glass.  Black with deep amber around the edges.  Dense, 3 finger light brown head that dissipates into a thin ring around the edges of the glass.  Leaves lots of lacing.  Strong aroma of bread, roasted malts, some toffee, some flowery notes.  Tastes sweet with just a hint of bitterness.  Mouthfeel feels like a creamy Coca Cola.

Pours a nice, dark brown with a fairly-nice tannish head with some lacing. The smell is lots of malty bread with a bit of a roasted character. Taste adds a little bit of chocolate to the mix. The mouthfeel is very, very nice with a beautiful smoothness from the oats. Very drinkable. A beautiful cold weather session brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-12-2010
This beer is a classic and just like all classic this beer will go down in history. While I prefer other stouts over this one, I will continue to return to this landmark brew.
what can i say about this iconic beer that hasnt already been said? the problem i had with it was it was too sweet for me. still tasty though.
Dark brown color with a nice-sized head. Rich, creamy taste, with some nuttiness. Dry but not too bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2014 pours very dark brown with a small light beige head, some retention and lacing. torrefied and roasted malts, some caramel and burnt nuts, grassy, earthiness too, few berries. moderate carboantion, medium body - oily but could be bigger, semi-sweet resinous-coffee finish. good.
This is one of the best stouts out there... bitter but sweet flavors of chocolate and oatmeal, nice dark color... great stuff, cheers!

Opaque, dark brown almost black color.  Luscious, tan, thick, flamboyant head.  Prolific amount of lacing left behind.  A new ring after each sip.  Dark ruby/red highlights visible only when held directly to the light.  Aroma was of roasted coffee malt that also smells of cream and dry oats.  A delicate sweetness comes forth from the cream.  Even uncovering a chocolate milk scent.  Outstanding.  Dry, roasted oats opening the taste.  The coffee is inconspicuous at first, but really shines as the beer crosses the palate toward the throat.  The silky smooth chocolate milk is more distinguished in the taste.  Wonderful.  Medium mouthfeel.  Dry with a pronounced warmth after the swallow.  Smooth and creamy.  Precise and appropriate.  An almost slippery or oily finish that I found very delectable.  Wow!!!  Thats about all I can say.  Truly an extraordinary Stout.  I really sdont see how Sam Smiths does it.  Every beer is well rounded and good.  The only reason this didnt get a perfect score for me is because if there is a better Stout I want to leave myself some wiggle room.  Other than that.  Its the best stout I have had thus far on my short journey.
Pours dark with a brown head. Very weak, chocolate aroma. As expected, it is sweet and syrupy, but not a very unique flavor. After taste goes away quite quickly and doesnt have much to begin with.
Poured a black color.nice frothy head. Lite sweetness.  Velvety feel with a creamy smooth flavor.   Complex.  Med to full bodied.   Smooth, smooth, smooth stout.

Tonight, I am going through my favorite beers of all time and this beer had to make the list . Very bold taste and smooth flavor. I love this beer and its a Philadelphia legend for real beer lovers. Highly recommend for you stout lovers.
Great beer first time I had it. Will try again and update my rating on it.

550ml bottle from the LCBO.  Pours black with a thick tan head.  Nice chocolate and coffee aromas.  Mouthfeel is thick and oily.  Great body.  Tastes sweet, with hints of chocolate, and some roast malt.  Very nice.

550 ml bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black, nice tan head. Nose is roasty,chocolately. Full body, smooth, creamy. The body is great, and it hits the front of your mouth with the rich roastyness, but then the finish is thin and kind of weird- sourish rotten? oatmealy kind of spice?- I dont know Im new to the style.

Dark brown pour with a tan head, excellent retention.  Aroma of sweet malt, nuts, toasted bread.  Medium body, moderate carbonation, definitely a silky/milk texture, finishes bittersweet.  Has that UK yeast flavor.  A good beer.
Wonderful aroma of coffee, roasted malt, oatmeal and caramel. Thick mouth feel. Dark black in colour with a good tan head.

550 ml bottle purchased over a year ago.  Pours a cola brown hue with tea-colored highlights and two fingers of beige head.  Aroma has interesting smoky malty tones (leather, soy sauce, campfire smoke) with lesser notes of dusty grains and perhaps some dark fruits.  Flavor also has quite notable leather and soy sauce elements and much lighter chocolate and fruit notes.  The finish is quite dry for a stout and almost has a salty feel.  Practically no sweetness anywhere in this brew, but full of tangy-ness.  Has my bottle developed some off flavors with the aging?  This may qualify for a re-rate with a fresher bottle.  (2310, 419)

Enjoying a bottle during Patriots Viking game.  Pours a black coloration with small quick disspersing beige head.  Taste is of chocolate, coffee, otas, some smoke, cereal, and a hint of banana.  Perfect carbonation and amazing mouthfeel.  easy drinking and delicious.

Brown cramy head. Black colour. Aroma is malty with fruits (banana), coffee and cereal notes. Flavor is malty too with fruity and light roasty tones, ending in a gently smoked with cereal accent finish. Medium bodied.

Bottle: Pours a dark brown with a bit of highlight at the bottom of the class - Nice beige head , with nice retention , once again. Sweet, almost fruit apple aroma courtesy of those hops I keep encountering as I progress through these SSmith brews. My first thought is that this is the best SSmith brew Ive had so far. The marriage of hops, malts, oats, and a bit of sweetness seems just perfect, honestly. Sorry Rogue. Medium body, love the silk feeling as well . I think its perfect for what it is - and Im guessing some people agree.

550 ml bottle in a pint glass. Large head which fades slowly. Smells of chocolate and bread, nutty, flowery and slightly fruity. Taste is full, bitter, sweet and a small hint of salt. Very good stout, with a huge flavour for its ABV.

Bottle. Pours rich dark brown (mahogany highlights in the glass), minimal head that almost completely disappears when left to sit for a few minutes. Nose is all sweet: chocolate, slight coffee, cream. Taste is more chocolate, slightly nutty, nice smooth mouthfeel from the oats. Fairly straightforward, but nicely done.

Foil around cap is annoying to remove, I guess it builds the anticipation and causes you to work up a thirst if you didnt already have one.  Roasted barley gives a sweet creamy coffee aroma.  Low fruitiness.  Nearly black, opaque.  Tan bubbles are very fine and form a ring around the glass.  Flavor is smooth caramel and dark roast.  Hops make a brief appearance up front and to dry the finish.  The balance is generally more bitter then I expected but still sweet.  Medium low carbonation, thickish creamy body thats somewhat viscous.  Easy drinking but hardy.  Yay beer!

I had this brew a few times before so time for a review. I cracked this bottle watching the Pats game it was a nice day for a stout. Bottle poured into a imperial pint glass gave me a perfect two finger tan colored head that sticks around for a long time. Then it just leaves this sticky lace clinging to the glass. The body of the brew is black as one expects from a stout. 

The nose on this brew is good you get some nice roasted coffee and chocolate to it. The flavor is roasted but with a nice sweet molasses note as well. The mouthfeel is thick and full so your mouth feels like you should be chewing this brew. This brew got me into Oatmeal stouts and it sets the standard for me.

I can do two bottle of this at a time but you just get to full from it to do any more. I think of it more as a meal in a glass than a drink

This beer pours out the same as any other stout, nice dark opaque color, with a wonderful light brown head. Head is about two fingers and is very present through the whole beer. Aroma is that of caramel, dark malts, toasty and some bread. Very roasted sent coming off this beer. Taste is very nice, lots of malts, some toffee and even coffee. Very nice flavors in the mouth, with a very nice finish. Very sweet throughout and pleasant. Towards the end getting some more bread and earthy flavors. For sure a beer you want to try as this has the makings of one of the best stouts! Definitely one of the best I have had yet.
Pours black with a medium, brown head. The oats are very present, making for a silky mouthfeel with flavours of chocolate, oats, milk and coffee.

550 ml bottle, Pours a deep maple w/ a towering peaty head, aroma is mineral-tinged roasted malt w/ some notes of chocolate and coffee, smooth and silken w/o the often-accompanied cloying sweetness, some roastiness on finish and a slight carbonated bite, fantastic example of the style
Bottle at Pizzeria Paradiso.  Very light and thin, just a bot of smoky chocolate and thats about it.  Pretty simple stuff.

Very dark, but not quite "black" - huge billowing head thats gone fast (though that may be because of my glass).  Mostly chocolate aroma comes through followed by the taste of bitterly roasted malt.  Its a nice oatmeal stout - on the other hand, I really like the style too.
550ml btl. Pours dark with a nice tan head. Has a strong malty aroma almost soapy. Nice malty roasted start with a very mild bit of hops then that cocoa bean finish. Nice.

Pours black with very rich brown head leaving nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel, roasted malts, coffe, chocolate, fruits ... very intense. Flavor is so sweet and lean, oatmel cereal, fidges, fruity, just great. Palate is lean, sweet and round with notes of acidyness. Finishes with sweet fidgy flavor turning to bbitter tart hoppy aftertaste.

Pours dark with a brownish head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, caramel, malt and a hint of alcohol. Taste is warm smooth and pretty complex for something as mild aas this is on the palate. Tasty. Will definitely get this again.

Just cracked open a year old bottle and poured into pint glass.  Beautiful Huge tan head.  Brings me back as I used to drink this in my youth.  Classic oatmeal stout. Smooth and silky.    Serving type: 12oz bottle

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2017 Bottle from Beers Of Europe [181216]
Here we go again..soft dark malts, sweet dark choc malts, smooth silky malts, slight savoury, no roast, tasty dark malts. Palate  - Medium carb and body, bit fizzy but can be swirled out...its those tasty smooth rich dark sweet malt...very nice 4/7/8/4/15 3.8


Bottle from Beers Of Europe [150115]
Aroma of rich dark sweet malts, dark sweet chocolate. Taste of sweet dark quite rich malts, dark sugars, molasses, not a complex beer, finding the malts over sweet.
Palate - Bit over fizzy, needs a swirl to get rid of excess carbonation. Finding this over sweet. Finish as no bitterness, just sweet dark malts, but they do have good rich flavour.
Overall - Not as impressed with this now, but still quite decent. This particular bottle was rather too sweet, with no hint of bitter roast to offset the sweetness. Id go for the Imperial Stout which is better than this. 4/7/7/3/14 3.5

This was my first rate...time to re rate after nearly 3 years and around 1400 beers
Bottle from Beer Hive, Edinburgh [040713]
Appearance as before
Aroma of soft roasted malt, dark caramel, soft chocolate, smooth fairly sweet dark malts..aroma is subtle 
Taste - smooth dark roast, soft chocolate, mellow bitter roast, deep dark malts, touch of bitter hop, touch of dark fruit, well-blended,more subtle and not as complex as I remember. Its the dark malts in this that are very good.
Palate - Medium carb, but I always swirl it to get rid of a lot of the carb as it is then much smoother....fairly oily body, smooth texture, good balance, not too bitter or sweet....it is fairly sweet. The finish has that smooth silky quite rich sweet dark malt...then a fairly bitter slight burnt dusty dry finish
Overall - Well this bottle just didnt seem to be as good as the others Ive had before...bit disappointed tbh...still a decent stout though 4.3 > 3.7

Bottle from Gordon and MacPhail, Elgin [280910] 8/4/9/5/17
Black with ruby edges, huge frothy tan head with great lacing
Aroma of roasted malt, sweet dark caramel malts, chocolate, some sweet sugars, smooth.
Taste - Roasted malts, smooth quite sweet dark caramel malts, chocolate, smooth coffee, some light burnt notes, some bitter hops, fruity berries in their. Outstanding complex well-blended flavour for the abv. 
Palate - soft carb, medium to full bodied, silky smooth, sweet malts with some gentle bitterness, creamy. Finish - very smooth, some burnt notes, light roasted malty lingering finish.
This stout is outstanding - I havent found better at the abv. Must be world-class.
Delicious. Smooth with a nice oatmeal finish. Not too stout, but well balanced and very creamy. Pours dark with a nice brown head.

550ml bottle.

Pours a dark, dark brown thats close to black in the glass with light showing through the edges underneath a huge, thick tan head that shows excellent retention and leaves tons of lacing.

The aroma is nice for a light stout with tons of lactose sweetness and oatmeal.  Lots of roasted malts, coffee and a bit of molasses.

The taste has lots of oatmeal up front with light coffee and chocolate hints.  A bit of bitterness and nuts in the finish with some molasses again coming out.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and silky smooth with a fine but moderate carbonation.

This is one of the best oatmeal stouts out there.  Creamy, very complex and surprisingly flavorful for a 5% ABV beer.  This is one of the beers that got me into craft beer and its just as good as I remember it.

Bottle poured int tulip glass. unique aroma and taste that is clearly a derivative of the oatmeal (I am assuming oatmeal had some part of the brewing process). Not much head, very dark however with a ruddy tint as my drink neared completion.. Everything about this drink seemed subtle to me, it almost seemed a tad boring at first and the finish was extremely quick. further into the drink I started to pick up a little more but still not very exciting. The beer has this progression from the grainy/oatmealy flavor to this coffee flavor then an abrupt end with the swallow. This beer was easier to drink than some stouts and has a enjoyable palate. but I found it more on the boring side.

From a 550ml bottle on 19/9/2010. Has an aroma of brown sugar, raisins, and roasted malt. Has lots of flavour, including more brown sugar, dark fruit, chocloate and caramel. Theres quite a bit of sweetness present but its balanced by a nice bitter finish. A very enjoyable stout.

One of the finest examples of an oatmeal stout in the freakin world!  The yeast lends an almost oak-like ester with enough diacetyl to add a very smooth mouthfeel.  Roast, light chocolate, and oaky leather all balance beautifully.
Pours dark brown with a creamy light brown head. Roasted malts, oats, bit of chocolate on the nose. Similar flavor. Palate was spot on. Low carbonation, full bodied, creamy, very drinkable.
Medium body, black pour with a thin brown head.  Mild coffee aroma, accompanied with a smooth, somewhat sweet palate.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2011 Bottle. Very dark brown pour with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Some milk in there. Taste is the same. Fantastic brew.

Nice little stout, it achieves a frothy texture, even in the bottle, allowing it to drink like other stouts on nitro. A slight sweetness, you will get largely chocolate flavors, with a slight roasted undertone. Dark color, but with its light and frothy texture, it goes down easy.

Dark brown, nearly opaque pour with a two finger tan head. Aroma is very sweet. Lots of chocolate up front, some caramel and nuts, just a touch of coffee. Excellent creamy body, much thicker than the ABV would suggest. Low carbonation. Great chocolate flavor. Definitely picking up some nut and caramel, maybe even a hint of vanilla. Has the flavor and body of an imperial stout, but with a much more manageable alcohol level. Im a relative newbie to rating, but so far this is my favorite beer and as close to perfection as Ive ever tasted. Fantastic.
Pours a dark brown to black color, nose is roasty, taste is not very oatmealy, thin body and normal stout flavoring.

Pours into a snifter dark brown with red notes.  Head is minimal and tan.  Aroma of roasty malts and chocolate.  Palate is thin for a stout, but medium overall.  Taste is same as aroma....roated chocolate flavors...with some toasted cream or marshmallow.  Very earthy stout that is a classic and one that you are never disappointed with.

Black with a light brown creamy foam. Quite dry aroma of black coffee, dark chocolate, nuts and oats. Cocoa and coffee in flavour with nutty and roasty undertones. Thick mouthfeel. Black chocolate and almonds in the long aftertaste. VERY nice Stout

Appearance is good.  Tan head is present if poured correctly, great lacing.  Color is black with dark red/brown tint.  Taste is rich, great balance of sweet and bitter with a coffee/chocolate undertone.  Great roasty aroma with hint of oats and coffee.  Overall a great brew to pair with a good seafood dish and/or breakfast.

Pours black with a touch of red.  Medium head and decent lacing.  Slight licorice aroma mixed in with a touch of cardboard.  Ever so slightly sweet flavor in addition to the mild roasted malt flavor.  It almost reminds me of a fresh toasted honey wheat bread.  Overall, this is a very solid brew.  Ill have to drink more...

Mild and sweet roasty aroma, molasses present. Black color with nice full tan head. Taste is roasty and molasses, some dark fruits, toffee. Mild and sweet. Roastiness is present but in no way overpowering. Nicely sweet as well. A perfect balace of roasty and sweet. Neither even begins to overpower the other. They come together so well.... the two make their own unique flavor. Leaves a very pleasant taste in the mouth. A very nice drinking beer. Smooth and creamy. Palate is medium and coats the tongue very well. Carbonation is barely present. Bitterness is from roasty malts, not carbonation. Overall this is another marvelous beer from Samuel Smiths. By far the best example of the style I have had.

A-pours a dark brown, almost black liquid with a creamy tan colored head leaving a good bit of lace.

S-the nose is soft and subtle, sweet chocolate, anise, some dark fruits, and a hint of bitter coffee in the very back

T-the taste follows the nose, fantastic balance of flavors, sweet milk chocolate, faint touch of anise, a nice bit of dark fruit juice, the oat is definitely present with an ever so subtle slightly burnt coffee flavor in the very back.  the flavors are soft and creamy.

M-the feel is as it should be, light to medium body and extremely smooth and creamy, the carbonation is just right to hold the body but not interfere with the creamy finish.

D-this is a well balanced stout with soft creamy flavors and a body to match.  great beer, great flavors, well done stout!

Bottle.  Pours very dark brown, nearly opaque, with a foamy brown head.  Aromas of sweet caramel, toffee, cocoa, and vanilla.  Roasty cocoa flavor, sweet toffee, caramel, and some very nice roasted malty notes.  Medium carbonation, creamy, and medium to full-bodied.  A very nice beer.

Pours black, sporting a creamy, lasting, tan head. Lace is not bad. Nose is pleasant with a distinct London ale yeast character, sweet malts, chocolate, roast, some fruits and maybe a little earthy hops that I didnt expect. Taste is sweet at first with roasted fruit notes, malts, and English yeast. Then shortly after, it drie out nicely and leave almost some sour malt and roasted grains. Mouthfeel is rich, creamy, and smooth. Carbonation is low and perfect. Very nice mild stout.

My first oatmeal stout, from a four-pack of 12 oz bottles. I waited for the first cold, rainy day of late August to try this one, and as much as I enjoyed it, not sure I "got it" entirely. Very weak head without a more aggressive pour (managed to get an inch and a half of thick foam by pouring more aggressively). Smells of molasses, chocolate, and, although I think the name was working numbers on my brain, oats. Tastes very smooth, with a long finish, and an aftertaste like a Hershey bar. Glad I drank it, but wont go rushing back for more.

My first Oatmeal Stout and admittedly it confused me alot.  Almost pitch black in color with a nice light brown foamy head.  Smell was of oats and sweet chocolate, and a hint of molasses.  Smell got more rich when beer was turbulated.  Taste is unique (for someone inexperienced with oatmeal stouts).  An almost nutty oatmeal character is foremost on the palate, followed by Hersheys milk chocolate and some light, mild hoppiness towards the end for a semi-bitter finish.  Very creamy with light, light carbonation.  Definitely got better with the flavors easier to recognize once it warmed a little.  Not mind blowing, but I am glad to have finally tried it.

Bottle. Black pour with good looking tan-white ring of foam. There is a little weird fermented/moldy aroma. When you go beyond it, you get molasses, intense toffee-caramel and sweet chocolate. Taste is well developped; chocolate, oats, burnt toast and of course molasses. Palate is creamy and smooth. Reminds me of Fullers London Porter. Drinks very well. Too bad the aroma is off.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2011 Poured black with lasting, off-white head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Was very full-bodied, thick and creamy. The first taste to greet you is the roasted malts and delicious oats. These are backed up by notes of chocolate, caramel and coffee. The bitterness comes out in the finish, which is nicely bitter but not in hop head country. Very smooth and lasting finish. A little dry. This beer was well-balanced, full-bodied, smooth and very, very tasty. In fact, it could very well be the best beer Ive ever had!
Bottle pours a dark brown almost black beer with a thin tan head. Scent of roasted malts and some coffee. Taste is light sweet with not much bitterness. Creamy feel with a dry finish.
pours an awesome opaque brown-black with a fluffy tan head. nose of caramel, molasses, dk. fruit. flavor is dark fruit, fig, molasses. Nice malty finish. Smooth mouthfeel.

(12oz bottle) dark brown near black pour with dark tan creamy head. Nose of alcohol, sweet raisin bread, honey, and toasted cake. Taste of mild alcohol, toasty raisins, honey, other dark fruits on the back of the tongue. Well carbonated and tingly palate finish with a really delicious sweet And somewhat chocolaty linger.
550 mL Bottle.  Pours black with a big brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, light roasty malts, coffee, and fleshy fruits.  Not very sweet, medium bitterness; this beer is surprisingly smooth.
Pours black with thick creamy tan head and foamy lacing.  Notes of chocolate, raisin, and expresso.  Well balanced taste is reflective of aroma with a slightly bitter finish.  Smooth and creamy.

Bottle Dark brown body with a creamy tan thick head. The aroma is light roasty with snotes of dark fruit, tobacco and some chocolate. The flavour is roasted with notes of light coffee, some caramel and dark fruit. Long roasted finish.
UPDATED: SEP 7, 2010 Had this after a Guinness and Becks so my taste may have been hindered, but I really enjoyed this beer. A combination of coffee and chocolate without being too strong.

strong aroma; chocolate, toffee, and possibly turkish delight and rich cherries. 
rocky strong head, black in colour. 
much smoother than anticipated; medium bitterness, light sweetness.
velvety and smooth palate. adorable to the mouth. the after taste is sweet, a little bit and slightly burnt, but really lovely. 
a really good oatmeal stout. would love to be able to sit down to one of these every night of winter.
Had the big bottle of this.  Very good all around, slight taste of oats, good body and great finish.

Appearance: Poured a dark brown almost black color with a nice thick light tan colored head. Nice lacing throughout.

Smell: Hints of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Very appealing.

Taste: Slightly sweet chocolate up front. Nice coffee and cocoa taste in the middle with a hint of bitterness which pushes aside the sweetness. Great tasting beer. Very robust flavor. Very nice aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Very smooth and creamy. Great texture. Nearly perfect.

Drinkability: Great drinkability, especially on a cold day. Its a heavy beer but not so heavy to not be highly enjoyable.

Overall: Excellent stout. One of, if not the best Ive tried. Very good
Pours moderately thick, dark almost black, reasonable head. Taste is malty, plenty dark roasted flavours and oats, some coffee.  Taste is full bodied and dense, a little sweet.  Pretty good.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2011 This beer was purchased with a special occasion in mind: the culmination of my 100th beer since of legal age, and one of my best friends 21st birthday. With all the pressure placed on this one beer, I must say that it lived up to expectations and then some. The pour of this beer is as dark as night. The aroma, probably my favorite part, smells just like an espresso. The taste and palate of this beer are nothing but assertive thanks to the oatmeal. I am left with the opinion that oatmeal brews are always a good idea.
550ml bottle.  Pours pitch black with a loose tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt and coffee.  Nice roast flavour to start and a strong, coffee, bitter finish.  Thick full mouth feel.

550ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a light brown, pillowy head. Strong coffee notes dominate on the nose, with the merest hint of port behind it. There is a moderate degree of bitterness to begin, fading into a smooth, bittersweet dark chocolate finish. A quality stout indeed.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 (bottle) pours a pitch black colour with just a tinge of ruby and a massive dense creamy brown head. aroma of toasted grain and espresso, smooth brown sugar, with some hints of dark fruit and bitter chocolate. flavour is the same, with bigger notes of chocolate, some light herbs, lactose, flaked oats and a long roasted-bitter finish. medium-bodied with smooth carbonation.
55 cl Bottle. Deep black color with nice tan hean. Alcohol, anises and molases aroma. Taste is quite the same, alcohol, molases and anises and nice carbonation

55cl bottle. Pours a dark brown color with a large tanned head. Aroma is pretty simple, with notes of roasted coffee and sweet malt. Taste is similar and not complex at all, with again coffe and chocolate notes. Good palate. Too simple brew to me.

Pours a nice dark brown with a mocha head which settles quickly into a thin layer leaving decent lacing.  Nice aroma of coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Nice flavor with coffe and chocolate along some nice roasty, toasty notes.  Nice velvety mouthfeel.  Very good oatmeal stout.

Im not normally a stout drinker but needed a stout for a brisket recipe (which turned out very good) and was able to drink most of the bottle.  Its very smooth and not a very strong after taste.  Not a bad stout.

Poured from the bottle into a Samuel Adams glass.  The pour produced a dark brown, nearly opaque body with hints of red when viewed up to the light, near the bottom of the glass.  The head was thick and dark tan in color and took some time to settle down.  Perhaps I have a cold today, since the aroma of the ale is not asserting itself. I was able to pick up sweet chocolate notes, along with grain. The flavor is bittersweet and smooth in texture.  The dominant profile is roasted grains, almost burnt, with a medium to heavy body.
This beer is beautiful. Almost black and a dark tan head. This is one of the best stouts Ive had.

12fl oz bottle poured into a mug.  Dark brown with ample creamy tan head.  Aroma is toasted malt.  Flavor is toasted malt, vanilla, dark chocolate.  Creamy mouthfeel, average carbonation.  Finish is bitter and lasting.  Good brew.

(Bottle) Poured black. Head medium sized and light brown. Aroma contained roastedness and liquorice. Palate was full bodied, soft and dry with medium caronation. Flavours were roastedness, liquorice, hops, coffee, lightly sweetness, saltiness and bitterness. Aftertaste contained liquorice and bitterness.
A very aromatic stout that pours black as oil with a thin off white head. Tastes of toffee, oats, and cream. Maybe a tad coffee. A great brew, really fantastic
UPDATED: JUL 24, 2010 Lactating mothers, you say? Perhaps drinking Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout regularly encourages breast growth? Brian Zembec could have saved $100,000.
poured black with a tan head aromas of coffee,roasted malts,and ligh chocolates taste is of all being thin in body creamy and smooth

Nice, dry oatmeal stout. Really, I was hoping that I would like it more on this go round. Its not bad or anything. I just probably wont ever buy one again. Of Sam Smiths lineup, Ive only loved the Taddy Porter. I appreciate most of their beers, but I often end up feeling a bit underwhelmed and disappointed. This beer is a dry stout with a full, smooth feel. Its dark, nearly black with brown highlights at the extreme edges. The head is beige and leaves some lacing. The aroma is chocolate malt with that dry note that I usually associate with Irish Dry Stouts (oh, Guinness...). The mouthfeel is creamy and full. Its the best part of the beer. Good beer but not great.

Bottle. Pours an almost opague black color with the exception of some ruby reddish notes notes comming thorugh, when hold up to the light. The head is big, frothy and creamy looking with a nice tan color. Aroma is of roasted and sweet malts, chocolate, coffe and a burnt note. The flavor is again of roasted malts with quite a decent amount of sweetness from the oats. I also get a burnt charcoaly flavour with some chocolate, liqourice and a faint amount of hops. The body is medium with cross between a silky dry and water y mouthfeel. Overal a very well balanced and excellent oatmeal stout!

Bottle:
1 mm vast beige lacing/foam.
Smell is a mix of malts, sweets/sugars, coffee, iron and dark chocolate.
Color of beer is black.
Taste is delicious: a very soft palate, perfectly balanced with ingredients and carbon dioxide (low).
Hints of coffee but not bitter tasting, but rather soft and smooth. Hints of spices. Taste like theres more alcohol in this beer, but no alcoholic taste whatsoever!
Just a very very light grassy aftertaste. Bit sweet, some dark chocolate. Nice soft dark chocolate aftertaste, soft and smooth hints of oatmeal.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
Very rich dark color but not much aroma to me. Great chocolate coffee taste and great finish over the tongue. 
Will buy again for sure.

Pours a really dark chestnut brown, opaque, not as dark as I thought it would be. Quite aromatic: Toffee, chocolate, and the oat malts come through pretty strong. More sweet than not on the nose and in the mouth. Palate is different - not as viscous as many of the stouts Ive had -- its more like a 1% milk, or something like that. Lots of little bubbles, not much lacing. Carbonation is right on. Really decent.

Creamy, mild aroma of chocolate / cocoa, milk, lightly roasted malts, and maybe some cinnamon. Black with a tall, tan, fine, milkshake head. Sweet, milky flavor with minerals, chocolate and rather light roasting. Light roasted bitterness comes in at the end. Smooth and dessert-like. Tasty and without faults. Extremely enjoyable, though perhaps not innovative or challenging. A pleasure.

Originally a drink for lactating mothers, oatmeal stout was described as nutritional on early labels. Oats are in the same family as barley, and a small addition yields great flavor. Popular in the late 1800s, the last oatmeal stout was brewed before the First World War until Samuel Smith reintroduced this style in 1980. 

Almost opaque, with an unusually silky texture and complex, medium-dry velvet palate. Bittersweet finish.

Has a nice roasted aroma with chocolate undertones and a slight coffee.  The appearance is nothing less than perfect; black as night with a nice small tan head.  The taste is great with a nice smooth aftertaste; coffee, chocolate, and very malty.  It is a little too thin on the mouthfeel, but maybe that is just me.  A great brew, will get again.

Bottle, 355ml. Pours a pitch black, opaque colour with a nice, fluffy, tan head. Aroma is discreet, sugesting some sweetness, pretty average really. Body is lighter than expected, smooth and creamy. Not too sweet, and not too much else really. Low bitterness, kind of watery, nice roasted character. Nice.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2011 Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours a very dark brown with some ruby highlights and small light brown head.  Good lacing, medium/thin body, and nut and molasses aroma.  Taste is roasted malt, nut, some chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  Excellent Stout, not harsh like some others.
Has a light brown head. Very dark brown color.  Sweet taste with a bittersweet finish. Very smooth going down. Aroma is molasses

Pours near-black and fairly thin with a fine and quickly disappearing brown head. Nose is weak with a little nuttiness and sweet malt to it. Flavor is surprisingly bland with only faint hints of stout roastiness; the primary taste is the oatmeal, with a little yeast and alcohol detectable as well. Finish is very short and oatmeal dominated. I was disappointed with this beer after seeing such high ratings for it before I tried it...a very average beer, IMO.
Pours very nice brownish black in the glass. Nose is very nutty, some caramels and coffee. Taste is much the same. The nuts really shine through. A little chocolate malt too. Rated 7/17/2000

Oh yeah ! One of the top Oatmeal Stouts out there. Pours a dark brown with red highlights. Head is beige and quite creamy, with heavy retention and good lacing. The aroma is mostly molasse with some sweet candy. Mouthfeel is kind of watery, slightly oily, but very smooth. Decent bitterness throughout, but some sweetness from the oat. Notes of chocolat are thrown in there. A very good oatmeal stout, but would like to compare it directly with the St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout (as this one is one hell of a brew).

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2010 Bottle at the Fox and Hound on Gulf Fwy in Houston poured into a Pint glass.  Dark as night with a dark tan head that stuck around a bit.  Smell is yeast, licorace and copper.  Taste is sweet - malt, raisin and licorace.  A little sour on the finish.  Not nearly as good as I had hoped.

Bottle 550ml. Exceptional, alone and with spicy food too. Aromas of chocolate, liquorice, caramel, and spice. Taste is sweet, with nice bitter notes, and long duration. Palate is creamy, and medium-bodied. Black, with a creamy off-white head.

Pint bottle to pint glass.  Pours dark coffee with nice head.  Lots of lacing.  Smell is complex, dough, coffee, chocolate and alcohol.  A semi-sweet chocolate finsih.  Great palate, very full.  A damn nice brew.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2015 Pours dark brown like cola with a dust colored thick sudsy head.  Good retention.  First impression of the smell from 2 feet away was of banana bread, or some fruit break, baked with sugars like molasses and brown sugar.  A closer sniff yields chocolate, bark, and leafs.  Taste:  wow, sweet, cookie dough, root beer.  Its not so dense, but boy is it pleasant.  flour.  Not even so much chocolate as these lighter sweet flavors.  I didnt think it would live up to the rating but now I see why.  Im actually glad this stout has only 5 abv (as opposed to the monstrosities Im fond of).  Im tempted to take a deeper swig.  Theres the coffee, subtle, on the front.  Some hops/oat comes later.  Yah for this,  Id pick up a case of this one.
Dark in color with a tan head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Roasty flavor of coffee, chocolate, and sweet nuttiness.
Unique, velvety as advertised -- a bit sweet and sour on the finish. Great mild stout.

(Old BA rating - bottle)

Overall the appearance was akin to most other stouts/imperial stouts that I have tried, so it looked nice to me.  Smell was enticing, and had a pleasant nutty, toasted aroma. Very suprised by the taste, a touch of sweet alongside traditional smoky stout flavors. No one element overtakes another. Mouthfeel was smooth over the tongue and palate. 
Drinkability is the only thing that didnt stand out as much as other attributes. However, its a really good beer, and served as a good starting point for trying oatmeal stouts.

Bottle.  Pours nearly black with a medium tan head and some lacing.  Aroma is sweet and malty with some chocolate notes.  Flavor is roasty and malty but very smooth.  Sweet but with a dry finish.  Notes of chocolate and vanilla, maybe also a bit of fruitiness.  Medium palate; much lighter than youd expect.  Velvety mouthfeel.  Lots of flavor, but easy to drink.
Bottled. Black pour, rocky tan head. Roasty, coffee nose, some estery notes. Roasty, smoky, malt flavor, soft mouthfeel, with fruity undertones. Sweet flavor balanced by a nice, dry finish.
Pours nearly black with a beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and light smoke with some fruity notes. Flavor is lightly sweet, a little roasty bitterness, coffee, and some smoke in the finish.
My favorite Sam Smith beer.  Deep black with nice head.  Rich and flavorful and rather smooth.  Nice touch of sweetness, without being too much.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2010 Pours smooth and brown with a moderate, thin head.  Aroma is toast and oats.  The taste is somewhat dry, somewhat bitter, with a little bit of oats (as promised.)  A little too light for a stout in my opinion, Id like something a little heavier.  Overall, nothing bad though, a good session beer.

This is my all-time favorite beer. It has no weakness other than the fact that its too rich and heavy to drink more than a pint or so. Hardly a problem, there are many other excellent porters, stouts, and blacks to drink, many from the marvelous Tadcaster brewery.

When I first heard that there was such a thing as an oatmeal stout I had a hard time comprehending it. I didnt know who would want to drink a beer that tasted like oatmeal or had an oatmeal-like texture. Well, oats are just another grain, much like barely, only sweeter. So making a beer brewed with oats is not all that unorthodox, actually. Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout is a great example of how tasty and smooth a beer can be, even with the word oatmeal in the name.POUR, COLOR AND AROMAI was only able to find this import in 18.7oz bomber bottles, and due to the bottle shape, it poured very rough with constant glugs, but thankfully did not produce a gigantic head. The beer is opaque black in body with a light brown, foamy head which lingered throughout the life of the beer and left some lacing on the glass. The aroma was surprisingly mellow with a general malty, sweet scent.TASTEIm a fan of stouts because they tend to have a strong, roasty quality to their taste. But with Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout the taste was a bit in the opposite direction. The flavor here is remarkably sweet with a general malty palate. It certainly doesnt taste like your breakfast oatmeal, but it does have a very robust, yet mellow taste. Chocolate and vanilla seem to be underlying flavors, making this an excellent choice as a dessert beer. Whats interesting is the beer does not have a creamy texture as many stouts are know for. It has the basic mouthfeel of an ale with a great incorporation of hops so as to have a distinct bitterness. FINISHTheres no direct correlation between taste and finish, as some of the sweetest beers can be hard to drink. However, Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stouts gentle, sweet taste is made even better by the fact its so smooth. The brewery describes it as having a velvety texture and a bittersweet finish. I couldnt have said it any better myself.BODYA beer like this just goes to show the versatility of the stout style. Many people would just assume this is a heavy beer, either in terms of potency or sheer weight, but its surprisingly light. At only 5% ABV, Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout is lightweight-friendly (especially considering its delectable taste). I wasnt able to find out the number of calories and carbs, but Id estimate their numbers are fairly average and comparable to a mass-market lager. This is NOT a beer that sticks to your ribs, and would work well as a session brew if it wasnt so rare and expensive.FINAL THOUGHTSI cannot fathom why Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout is not as popular as, or even more well-known than Guinness. This beer is much tastier and easier to drink, and considering its relatively light body it could be enjoyed by anyone. Talk about not judging a book by its cover!NOTE: watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UAaoCJPfXds

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2010 Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout pours an opaque black with a beautifully contrasting tan head.  It has a bold aroma consisting of caramel, bitter-sweet chocolate, and roasty coffee.  The taste is a medium, roasted coffee, bitterness and a hint of oats with a bittersweet chocolate finish.  The palate is medium bodied, thick, and silky with soft carbonation.  Overall, Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is a delicious style-defining brew with both a complex flavor and palate.

550ml bottle, very dark pour, very flavorful roast coffee and chocolate after taste, dry feel towards the end with an abrupt scent through the nose,red, brown, tan foam, minimal head, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, average carbonation,

550 ml bottle. Pours black, light tan medium head with good lacing. Dry but smooth mouth feel. Good balance of malt and hops. Im not sure what oats do to the flavor since I havent tried many oatmeal stouts,

Bottle. Malty, notes of caramel and chocolate, also licorice . Beautiful opaque black colour, with a tan/off-white head. Notes of sweetness, medium bitterness with a pleasing dry finish. Silky on the palate. A full-bodied a filling beer. Ive had a better example from the bottle than this one however, so it suffers for that.

Drank from from a pint glass poured out of a 4 pack bottle.  Aroma is mostly of raisisn.  Taste is more of the same with a hint of dark chocolate and roasted malts.  Not as flavorful or as potent as the newer American stouts, but still a classic that is easy drinking and enjoyable.

This beer makes me feel sorry for those whose only experience of real British stou is a 32 degree Guinness on St.Patricks Day. Silky smoothness and restrained plums mark this classic. Poured from a 500 mL bottle into a Trappist glass.

Very dark amber, caramel in color with a frothy tan head that left nice lacing. Smelled of chocolate malts, slight leather, plum and raisin notes. Medium/full body with light carbonation and a clean, dry finish. Mild toasted nuttiness, malts with dark chocolate, caramel, and herbal notes. Very tasty stout with subtle flavors. A good sessionable stout.
UPDATED: JUL 21, 2010 50 cl bottle. Dark brown with tan head. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate and coffee

To be honest, I thought Id like this beer a lot more than I actually did. It was no doubt good but not as wonderful as I thought it would be. The body was a beautiful dark black with a small cream colored head. The aroma was of roasted malt, some coffee, and a faint amount of chocolate. Not really exciting but good. Taste was about the same. It got better as it warmed up which brought out the malty goodness of this stout. It was my first oatmeal stout which is good but Im not sure if it really knocked my socks off. Its still a good beer though.

550ml bottle 
5.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on November 18, 2009 after purchasing a Christmas pack of Samuel Smith ales from one of my local LCBO outlets.  The beer poured a very dark brown with a 1" light brown head that lasted.  The aroma was roasted malt, coffee, and nuts.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied, creamy, and medium carbonated.  The flavour was exquisite...and nice combination of roasted malt tones, coffee, caramel, and a bitter finish.

Great oatmeal stout from the bottle.  Excellent dark color, full body, creamy.  Balanced aroma... hints of chocolate, but not overly sweet taste.  Nice finish... should be, but isnt too heavy.  One of the better OS in a bottle.

550ml bottle poured into my Samuel Smith pint glass...

Very dark brown body with a creamy caramel-coloured head and some nice lacing.

The aroma has got a good amount of roasted malts (but not over-roasted), with sweet chocolate and espresso beans notes. Some creamy oats, some floral notes. A touch of dark fruits (sultana raisins, prunes). Very intriguing.

Wow, the taste is extremely well-balanced and flavourful! Starts out with some serious roasted coffee bean notes and milk chocolate, followed by an exceptional creaminess from the oats. Then you get some bitterness and sourness. The after-taste is slightly roasted and bitter-sweet, with a tiny bit of burnt malts. This definitely beats the other oatmeal stouts Ive had!

Medium-bodied, with some moderate carbonation. Exceptionally smooth, even creamy. The alcohol is not present at all.

It goes down very smoothly and doesnt get boring not overwhelming. This is one of the best stouts out there, and nothing is really compromised in this beer. You get enough of everything.

Beautiful black liquid contrasted by a cream colored head towering about 1,5 inches. The aroma is earthy with a hint of roasted coffee and chocolate, however rather bland and weak. The taste is light but complex with a lot of grains and a hint of coffee, though I must say I felt a slightly metallic aftertaste which brings down the grade a notch.. It is smooth to the palate and makes a rather easy beer to drink, perfect session beer.

Overall it is a great beer with some minor flaws, deeply recommended.

Bottle.

A - Black with some mahogany hues on the edges. Large thick, creamy and foamy beige head. Good retention leaving a good lacing behind.

S - Dark and milk chocolate along with some espresso and coffee notes. Some roasted malts, oats, nuts, and other earthy flavors. Some sugar smell too, more sweet/less roasted than many other stouts.

T - Similar to the smell. A good amount of oat and grain taste, with a slight roasted taste. This goes along with an earthy taste. Good amount of chocolate and some coffee taste. Also a good amount of molasses/brown sugar. Slight herbal towards the finish. Ends with a definite oat taste, almost oat cookie like.

M - Medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Very silky and smooth. A fair amount of chewiness, but not quite as much as I was expecting from an oatmeal stout.

D - Very good drinkability. Smooth and goes down easy but also has a full mouthfeel. The taste is nice and doesnt overpower. A bit of sweetness and bitterness. A good amount of oat taste.

Notes: Very nice beer that isnt as bitter as some other stouts but it has a good stout taste. Full oat taste, with a little roasted flavors, but not a lot of roasted taste. Good for a session or for a slightly special occasion.
Great Stout. Very smooth with a rich caramel flavor. It is even better on Tap.

An interesting beer that barely feels like a stout. Almost feels more like a porter in the mouth. That being said, its a delicious beer - I just dont know how to drink it most of the time. Sweet, very light, and with a distinct taste of oatmeal (surprised?) and brown sugar. One of my favorite beers thats available anywhere.
Not bad. Aroma was kind of weak. Flavor was roasty chocolatey and malty but I noticed a very slight metallic taste (Some might not notice this). This beer felt very nice on the palate
19 ounce bottle a dark pour tan head.A sweet aroma taste of chocolate,coco, coffee, .A real nice stout

bottle - Pours a dark black color with small off white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is fairly roasty, with notes of cream and ash. Flavor is malty, faintly roasty, touch of raisens and coconut and wet stone. Finish is balanced, with a touch of sweetness. Overall this is pretty good, definitely different, more minerally than others within the same style.
had in Pittsburgh with he trial team. nice brew. aroma of raisins and oatmeal. pours a dark black. medium head. flavor is moderately thick and smooth. not too much roast. easy to drink.

Dark dark brown, nearly black pour, with a dense, thick, tan head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma of lactose, bread, caramel, and roasted grain.  Taste is well balanced, the sweetness comes through at the beginning with a nice sour and bitter tang at the end.  An excellent example of the style, well done.  You could probably live on this stuff if you had to.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2010 Bottle. Pours a dark brown, almost black color with a small beige head. Leaves nice lacing in the glass. Taste is malty, some chocolate, coffee, caramel. It has a smooth, somewhat watery mouthfeel, but is very drinkable due to the low carbonation. Aftertaste is a bit sweet, not too much and not really bitter either. I heard this one was good, but its much better than I thought.

Dark brown pour from bottle.  Light taste of roasted coffee and nuts, with a silky smooth mouthfeel.  Slightly bitter finish.  I happen to like Samuel Smith beers, as they are always well done and balanced.  This one might be their best.

Situation: Penn State celebratory 19-17 victory over LSU...
Glassware: Sam Smith tulip--what else?
Appearance: opaque, velvet velvet black body that illumintaes the S.S. logo dramatically; brown head forms a short milky ring...
Aroma: pleasantly lactic with a slightly burnt, toasted finish--but mostly a welcoming aroma...
Palate: smooth and soft; inoffensive in its presence and ever inviting of another sip; approaches the smoothness of a milk stout, butmaintains a backbone...
Taste: lactic and velvety, an appealing taste that fulfills both the front and back of the mouth; enough smoke to round it out with weight...
Overall: Samuel Smith will always have a place in my glass--and this is the third sampler I ve got (thanks Jer), so Ive got some extras--and revisiting this classic is a pleasant reminder of how nice drinking a beer can be: tasty, classy, relaxing and reinvigorating a New Years Eve drag simultaneously.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 Bottle at The Bar in Gables. Dark beer with a coffee/chocolate aroma. Did not pour it, so I do not have head details. Tasted much milder than I expected. Hints of coffee and chocolate and some earthy notes. Not bad at all. Best beer I had at The Bar. I need to drink this again and re-rate, my current rating seems lower than the average. Maybe the dreary ambiance at The Bar did it?

*Drank it again today, much better this time, the chocolate taste was more noticeable, with some nice roasted flavors. Better, but still did not wow me.

12oz bottle from Wal-Mart.  Pours a deep, dark brown with mahogany highlights over a creamy, tan, sticky head.  Aroma of sweet malt, light freshly roasted coffee and hints of milk chocolate.  Flavor is lightly sweet and then a mixture of bitter-sweet chocolate and espresso coffee.  Some toffee also.  Medium body with a full, creamy mouthfeel.  Nice moderate, lingering bitter finish.

Everyones favoriate Sam Smith, Oatmeal Stout, pours a light brown head and fills the pint with a bread basket of brown stout.   The malt is flavored with roasted oat(meal) brown sugar and a nice full body.

Poured a rich chocolate brown, with tall creamy cafe au lait head.   Large head on a gentle pour.  Rich sweet aroma, recalls molassas and maple syrup.   Sweet rich flavor recalls molassas ginger bread,  toasted oats as it warms.   Lingers, with a sharp finish.   Low carbonation, rich filling but light feeling in the mouth.  Warming.  Sippable, not quaffable.
Pours a lacing, light brown head with a dark brown body.  Aromas of roasted malt and brown sugar.  Flavor is roasted, oats, and brown sugar.  Finish is smooth and slick.  Full body.
Very good. Smooth palate. Dark & sweet, yet smooth & light. Not much head, looks like coca cola.

Pours inky dark chestnut brown, with a big beige head, very fine clinging lacing.  Aromas of chocolate, molasses, oatmeal bread, and subtle cherry and earthy notes.  Medium body, velvety, creamy, crisp.  A little bit thin for a stout, but too thick for a porter.  Sweet chocolate, toffee and oatmeal flavors slowly fade into a little bit of crisp citrus, just enough bitterness in the finish to be perfectly balanced.

Poured from a bottle into a British pub glass at slightly below room temperature.  Very persistent, thick, creamy, tan head.  The aroma is quite interesting and pleasurable.  Roasted malt is most apparent with caramel in the background.  The flavor is incredible, to say the least.  Roasted and caramel flavor predominate up front and finishes smooth and creamy, very nice full body.

12 oz. bottle. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Strong aroma of roasted oats - some barley and coffee and a bit of chocolate too. Flavor is of roasted oat, as well, with a sudden hit of malt and, later, a hint of coffee. Pretty sweet actually - a bit of caramel with but a hint of bitterness. Medium palate - not terribly thick for a stout, but has a slight syrupy character. Creamy. Very creamy. Edifying in a familiar sense. Reminds me of the old home... when beverage seemed sweeter and decisions simpler. Defines bittersweet in the finish.
UPDATED: APR 14, 2012 Bottle. Nice pour and head. Aroma of roasty oats, grain, spice. Flavors range from oaty and grainy to chocolate. Rich color and complextion. I enjoyed it.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2015 12 oz. bottle from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons); shared with my Boo. Aroma: Light cocoa; moderate oat presence; light raisin/dark fruit notes. Appearance: Ruby black pour with a tuft of tan head that settles into a skin. Flavor: Fruity up front with some oat personality; chocolate comes in more midway and the finish dries up everything very well. Palate: Light body, slick texture, soft carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: A beer with a distinct character, even from other oatmeal stouts Ive tried.
Pours dark brown with tan head.  Smell of roasted malts and chocolate.  Nice body to this one.  Taste is much like the smell.  High quality oatmeal stout.
Aroma of metal and roasted malt. The beer is dark with a brown head. Flavor is also malty and with a nice roasted flavor to it.

This was my first time ever having an oatmeal stout, and I have to say I am very impressed with this. Brown head, dark brown to black appearance. Smells great, malty with caramel and chocolate. The taste is great, oats, coffee, and fruits stand out, with a stout taste thrown in. Proper balance of watery and syrupy on the palate. The aftertaste was semi-sweet with the oats standing out. Overall, great beer, I will most definitely buy this again.

Dark brown, copper edges, massive foamy tan head builds over the top of the glass. Aroma of biscuity sweet malt, cream and chocolate. Taste is mild, nothing really stands out over anything else. Finish has a slight burnt malt/dark chocolate bitterness. Good balance, a little thinner than most stouts, soft carbonation.
medium body, full body, nuts, caramel, black, frothy,  lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium sweetness, full body, thick feel, fizzy, astringent,

Poured this beer into a pint glass to drink.  The beer had a dark brown-black color with a big, creamy and bubbly dark tan head that had long retention and decent cling.  Its aroma featured chocolate, caramel, the presence of oats, some earthy hops and a touch of vanilla and maybe coffee.  The beer was sweet and flavorful with notes of chocolate, oats, and some vanilla, along with a slight grainy bitterness.  It was a creamy, wetter beer with lower carbonation and a bit watery; slightly thinner on the palate.  Overall a very good oatmeal stout.

Bottle (odd shape forces head if not poured carefully). Pours a deep brown/black with a nice frothy khaki head that has excellent retention. Smells slightly of cherry and oat, slight malty sweetness. The slight cherry is present in the flavor but the oats stand out. Touch of coffee flavor too. Medium body, slightly syrupy texture, low carbonation.

Pours opaque black (dark red highlights) with a tan lingering head from the 19oz. bottle: Aroma has lots of oats, roasted malts, chocolate and some mild spices. Roasted malts dominate the flavor with some oatmeal, lesser hints of vanilla, and dark fruit. Slightly sweet, exceptionally smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Medium bodied. Warming. Drinkability: Smooth. Rebuy: Yes. #259 on 28012010, DG.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2010 The aroma is a delicious mix of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, and, yes, oatmeal. The appearance is -- like most other stouts -- beautiful: a dark brown or black depending on how picky you want to be about it. Has a thick, frothy (fluffy, even) tan head. The head actually reminds me a bit of a rootbeer float. Tastes sweet and lightly sour; not much bitterness here. Has a light body, a creamy silk-like texture, and little carbonation with a mildly sweet finish. In short, this is a damn delicious beer. Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout isnt something I can drink a lot of, but it is exactly what I would expect an Oatmeal Stout to be.

Bottle at home.  An old favorite of mine that I recently had another of and decided to rate.
 Aroma is a plesant blend of oatmeal, chocolate, and vanilla.
 Appearance is a black/opaque pour with frothy, nearly rocky beige head.
 Tastes of oatmeal and coffee, with background flavors of chocolate and vanilla. 
  Palate is a medium to full  body with creamy thick mouthfeel and soft carbonation.   Finish is long and bitter, but plesant.
Overall... an old favorite, what more can I say?

Bottle. Black with large beige head. Aroma is earthy with chocolate, oatmeal, and vanilla. Flavors of oatmeal, chocolate, toffee, vanilla, and coffee. Medium body with oily/foamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.

(bottle from Weber St. Liquor in Colorado Springs). Black color. Medium tan head, which is mostly diminishing. Light oatmeal and soy sauce aroma. Sweet malt/oatmeal flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Fair lacing.

550 mL bottle pours deep, reddish brown/black with minimal creamy tan head that retains fairly well into a pint glass.  Aroma of oat creaminess, roasted malt, milk chocolate, subtle coffee, toasty.  Prominent malt and vanilla flavors with accompanying oat sweetness/creaminess, cocoa and slight cappuccino, ever so slight berry in the finish, bit bready and yeasty.  Medium carbonation level and body with a fizzy/cream mouthfeel.  Quite drinkable and easy on the palate.  Tasty stuff.

Kept passing over this, finally picked it up, glad I did. I will check out other oatmeal stouts when I can in the future.

 A very solid and smooth  stout... a different aftertaste than the dry stouts Im used to, but a good one.
 Will probably buy again.

Bottle - 12 oz - World Market - Sweet malty aroma poured black with frauthy brown/tan head with good retention.  Thick grainy and malty tastes across the palate.  Barley and oatmeal flavors are not overpowering - again a sweet smell before each drink.  Im more of a amber style drinker but the overall impression is pretty good for this one.  My lower score then average ratings might be due to my lack of experiance with stouts (oatmeal especially).

Appearance: 0,55 l Bottle from Biererei, Vienna via armando. Pours almost opaque, dark brown color with maroon highlights. Very impressive decent-sized, creamy-textured tan to brown head with decent lacing.

Aroma: Grainy oatmeal with some cheesy or earthy yeast backbone with rather sweet than sour, lactic, creamy character.

Flavor: Semi-sweet initial flavor of nutty, grainy malts and raw oatmeal feel. Somewhat sourish and creamy at the medium, and a very restrained toasted/roasted caramel-malty ending. No noticeble hops.

Mouthfeel: Lovely, silky, smooth palate.

Overall: A classic oatmeal stout with charming appearance, balanced roasted malty, dry coffe, and oat-flaky flavor profile, silky texture and smooth finish.
Pours out of the bottle dark black with a decent sized tan head that lingers for a while. When held up to the light has a reddish hue around it. Taste is sweet with a slight oatmeal aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Classic gold foil Bomber. Pours a silky smooth black with rich cappuccino head. Aroma is dark roasted malts, oats and caramel. Taste begins slightly smoky with roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate flavors followed by oats and espresso. It finishes cool and dry with a smoky aftertaste. Overall flavor is incredibly smooth, cool and creamy. One of my all-time favorite Stouts.
Suppressed aroma, full-bodied w/ hints of chocolate and coffee.  Dark brown like cola, great flavor and satisfying.  Everything a Stout should be.

Dark brown, almost black color with no head.  Aroma is of malts, grain, chocolate, and English water.  Taste is of malts, toffee, dried fruit, and of course English water.  Leaves an aluminum taste in the end.

Very silky pour with a light head with a decent amount of carbonation. Light to medium body that tastes like roasted malt with a very light sweet aftertaste. Not that special in my opinion, I enjoy a more robust oatmeal stout with less sweetness and more bitterness in the aftertaste.

A nice black pour with minimal off white head. Aroma dominates 
by chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts.  Flavor brings out the dark toasty chocolates.   Overall a real nice brew.
Bottle.  Pours a clear ruby hued brown with a thin tan head.  Sweet caramel and roast aromas.  Medium bodied, sweet and with some caramel and plum flavors.  Light malt on the finish.

Pours almost jet black with a few fingers of tan slowly dissipating head.  Oats and chocolate in the aroma.  Its a tasty stout, nice and thick, with a little bitter aftertaste of sour milk and chocolate, and some yeasty bread notes throughout.  Refreshing and a pretty good stout.

550 mL Bottle. Deep black-brown body with a beige foamy-frothy head that settles to a tenacious ring that just wants to cling all over the glass. Aroma of toasted malt, a subtle but sharp combination of ripe banana and pineapple, innuendos of raisins and prunes, and an astringent floral undertone. Dark and toasted malts and a blast of caramel on the tongue; just a bit sweet for my liking but no points deductions here. The flavor is heavenly nonetheless. Some cocoa in the aftertaste with the sweet dark malts. Sweet malts linger in the finish. If I was the one making this beer, Id just cut the sweetness a bit. Otherwise this is some good stout.
bottle: pitch black with no head. Arouma of chocolate, caramel and oats.  Creamy mouthfeel. Chocolate, roast and prunes. Finishes dry and bitter.

12 oz. bottle, the third from a four-pack. Roasted, tart, woody, fruity smell. Very much an ale in the aroma. Scents of rich chocolate, cotton candy, and brown sugar. Pours a clear dark brown with an amber hue and a large amount of thick, uneven, taupe head. Produces good lacing. Roasted cofee dominates the taste at first, but sweet fruit comes to take over. Tart, lemony flavor. An unfortunate but weak hint of metal is present. Carob, cantalope, and yellow plum elements. Dry, bitter aftertaste. Light to medium body. Soft and smooth in the palate, as an oatmeal ale should be. The palate would score more strongly if it were not lighter than ideal. Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is an entertaining, likable, and thoroughly English brew.

Another bottle I picked up from Bacchanalia in Cambridge. This one pours black with rub tints and a big, tan head that sticks around a while. Coffee with chocolate and hints of hops as well as some dried fruit on the nose. A dark coffee malt flavor with a smooth follow through and hints of chocolate. Some hoppiness in the end with a lingering coffee taste, this beer becomes more complex as it warms...

Black with a foamy tan head. Stewed fruits, coffee and caramel nose. Has the usual luscious oat texture. Chocolate sweetness, with some roastiness and a finish that has just enough hops to avoid sickliness. I drank this with barely a chill on it and wished it were cooler. Half way down the bottle I fetched some Red Leicester to eat with it. That worked well, and I think the sweetness would have been too much for me without it. I really dont understand how this is rated similarly to their Imperial Stout or to St Ambroise Oatmeal stout.

Pours a jet black with medium, foamy tan head.  Lacing throughout. Aroma of sweet malts - toffee, coffee, dark caramel, chocolate.Smooth and silky on the tongue, very nice and well-balanced.  Sweet? Yes but not overwhelming.  Not too dry either - very nice beer but I agree with many others - this is not a session beer, but savoring a 550 ml bottle is very nice indeed!

One of my "first" favorite beers.  Pours like a brown stout in color and is on the sweeter side like a sweet stout.  There is a nice roast on the finish which is semi dry and slightly lactic.  I havent had one in a while, but it is as nice as I remember.

Bottled. This was I think the first good beer I ever bought after finding Ratebeer and deciding I was going to start rating. It was also the last beer I drank before I began rating. And it has been 5 years and 2600 ratings before I have revisited it.

I remember thinking it was incredibly sweet at the time, and the flavor was very different to me. I see that sweetness now, but it is way more mellow than I perceived, with most of the character being chiefly lactic. There is a little bit of roast and grain in there, with a slightly carbonic, oaty note. Im not sure how crazy I was about this at the time, and I know Im not crazy about it now, although to me it is still one of the only truly sweet "sweet stouts" Ive yet drank. Very few oatmeal stouts dare approach this level of sweetness that is not just a byproduct of underattenuation.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2010 A terrific beer and a particularly interesting stout. I enjoyed the texture and flavours better when it was colder - as when its warming down the toasted notes and the coffee become a tad overwhelming.

A smooth, sweet stout and one of the better beers from Sam Smiths. Too sweet to be sessionable, IMO, but a bottle makes a nice dessert. A good-looking beer: coal-black with a lavish cappuccino head showing lace and length. Restrained aroma of cocoa powder, quince paste, raisins and tokay, spoiled in part by that a pasteurised boiled-lolly taint. Medium-bodied and creamy. Minimal bitterness and "roastiness". Chocolate pudding, blackcurrant jam and oodles of sugars. Nice balance for a sweet stout. Dry finish. (500ml bottle from Leura Cellars)

550 ml bottle from Kellers IGA.  Pours an opaque near-black with a half-inch tan head and some nice visible carbonation right after the pour.  Aroma of roasted barley malts, chocolate, yeast, and hops- light aroma overall.  Flavor of sweet roasted malts, chocolate, oats, yeast, molasses, and dust.  Medium bodied, with carbonation that provides a bite.  Not as smooth or creamy as advertised.  Very dry.  Not a bad beer, but overrated.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2013 Dark black ruby hue off white creamy head .... aroma of rosted malts, chocolate and light cocoa .. taste of roasted malts, sweet caramel, chocolate, coffee and cocoa .... not too heavy mouthfeel is oily and slick .... smooth little bittersweet end ... a great brew and highly drinkable abv hidden well

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2010 (cl-btl/br-btl gl-foil cr-lbl, "the celebrated", 550ml, 5%)

bk-lct, thick foamy tan head,  full body, ^co2,

aroma: sweet-malt oat fresh-hop, 

taste:
T1 oat sweet-dark-malt 
T2 hop-bitter ^nutty 
T3 nutty-oat §brownie-crust 
Tf §toasted, 
metallic note threatens but doesnt surface.
sipper (due to co2 & body) but fairly sessional.
this really needs a large 22oz mug and a vigorous pour.
really pairs well with chocolate cake, as neither dominates, but both taste very different when tasted side by side, which makes it quite interesting and enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a huge brown head that slowly diminished. A richly intense aroma of chocolate, oats, coffee, tar and smoke. Creamy mouthfeel with a smooth bitterness that lingers well past the finish. A delightful stout if all aspects.
550mL bottle, pours jet black with a thin coffee head. Aroma is roasted malts, coffee and oatmeal. Flavour is dominantly oatmeal, mouthful is creamy and medium-bodied. Nice stout.

Szinte teljesen átláthatatlanul fekete sör,vékony de határozott világos bézs színű krémes habbal a tetején.Illata édeskés,csokoládés zabkorpa kekszhez hasonló.Íze édeskés,csokis amibe frissen pörkölt kávéaroma is lopakodik egy kis égetett cukorral és vaníliával.Tetszik hogy nem túl élénk,teste nem túl sűrű de mégis érezni hogy igen tápláló ital.Utóíze engem arra emlékeztet,amikor régen otthon a főzött kakaóba barna kenyeret dobáltam és amikor teleszívta magát kikanalaztam. Aztán kiszárad a száj tőle és hosszan így is marad,hacsak nem iszunk rá még egy kortyot.Remek ital,nekem nagyon bejött!
Pour is dark with a tan two fingered head. Medium body, oily and lasting. Nose is sweet oatmeal, bitter chocolate, and malt (hoppy). Taste is similar with a lasting oatmeal flavor. Great, cheap brew.

Poured black with a thick 2 finger, lasting head that produced excellent lacing.  Aroma was malty oatmeal with a few roasty notes.  Taste was roughly matching.  A nice medium bodied, creamy stout for a cold thanksgiving weekend.

Pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is very sweet.  You can really smell the oatmeal.  Goes down very smooth with tastes of oatmeal and coffee.  Aftertaste is very sweet oatmeal.  Excellent brew.

Bottle. Dark black body, with red hints. Small pale brown nice head. Dry aroma, hoppy with chocolate. Medium light flavour. Some chocolate. Not heavy, medium bodied. Light sweet and bitter finish. Easy drinking stout. (At home, 31.10.09)

Bottle at a tasting. Dark black with a big creamy and fluffy head. Nose is sweet and oatmeal. Some fruits. Taste is roasty and sweet. Very soft and mellow. Some fruits. Quite drinkable. Well balanced. Need to revisit.

0,5 l bottle, bought at Biererei, Vienna.Deeeeep black body with a small but delicious, creamy tan head. Sourish oak/tannin in the nose with roasted malt, coffee, dried fruits like plum and raisins. Medium bodied with tastes of coffee and deep roasted malt, some wooden-vinous casks, some hidden spicy vanilla and bitterness. Roasted-coffee aftertaste.

Smells very heavily of deep dark malts and a bit of hops, but only the normal amount for this type of beer. Very, very dark, there was a very nice bit of fine head on the pour but it fades too quickly. The taste is a hazy layering of smokey malt, mid to end finishing hops and alcohal taste. Quite a nice blend, but each element is quite distinct in the flavour. Extreamely smooth, with an aftertaste of each of the flavours for just and instant. A great brew!

Pours black with medium-sized head. Faint aroma of nuts and raisins. Taste is sweet, almost no bitterness, you have your basic dark malts but no specific flavor stands out, drowned out by the sweetness I guess. At least the aftertaste is fairly dry. Very creamy mouthfeel. Didnt really dig this one.

Pours very dark with a nice lingering tan head. There aroma is just nice, but the flavor is deep and complex. The palate is thick and creamy, and the flavor is bittersweet without being overly sweet. This beer would be better with a higher alcohol content and perhaps some more bitterness.

550ml bottle -drank out of a tulip glass, large tan quickly fading head and great lacing. Aroma of roasted dark malts & oats.  Flavor matches aroma with the oatmeal and dark chocolate standing out. With a little cocoa powder for good measure. Palate is creamy, then dry and ashy. A classic and tasty stout.

Anna says this is why she thought she didnt like stouts.  After tasting a few other stouts, nothing really stands out here.  Seems to be pretty widely distributed so I could see myself drinking it again if faced with a limited selection.  Otherwise Id pass.

nice head on this one. nothing especially remarkable about this stout, but its pretty good all around. doesnt quite have the roastiness or bite of some other oatmeal stours. its only 5% abv, maybe a suped up version of this stuff would be killer.

In the past, I have condemned anything coming out of England.  Im still suspicious of English ales, but Samuel Smith actually gets it right from time to time.  Stouts are my favorite style and I do not give a free pass to any.  This is good.  Probably my third time trying, but first time rating.  Sweet / bitter balance is supreme with this one.

355ml dark brown bottle, as pictured.

Colour is pitch black, with a big, frothy beige head. Great retention, generous lacing. Very pretty beer. ;=)

Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and hazel nuts. White coffee note, too.

Heavy-bodied stout with thick, creamy mouth feel. Low carbonation, just right.

Flavours include caramel, licorice and coffee. Not too sweet, not too bitter - extremely well balanced - and no "coal like" notes as in Guinness Draught and some other stouts. Dry, bitter finish and lingering espresso after taste. 

Heavier in style than their "Taddy Porter", a supreme winter beer. One of the great stouts out there, and, with the bitter finish, highly sessionable. A great beer, from a great brewery, of Britain.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2011 Aroma is warm and sweet and represents everything I love about stouts.  Sweet and savory nose. Very rich body full of oatmeal and mincemeat (out standing to pair with a mincemeat pie, or bread pudding!) Theres some coffee and molasses in there too.  Finishes smooth and malty with some bittersweetness after words.  Sometimes this is all the beer I need!
I wasnt really that blown away by this one. Has a pretty good aroma of oatmeal and malts. Dark color when pour with off white foam head.

Poured from bottle into Imperial Pint.

Exceedingly dark brown that might as well as be black. Thin, persistent oatmeal colored head that leaves a trace of lacing.

Aroma of roasted barley, light chocolate and dark fruit. Mild smell as most English Ales are, but it lasts throughout the beer and is quite pleasing.

Nice semi-sweet roasted malts with notes of chocolate, caramel, dark fruit and oats. Minimal bitterness.

Low carbonation, extraordinary smooth and creamy body for a 5% abv beer.

The smoothness and the mild roasted malt profile make this a very easy to drink stout. My favorite Oatmeal Stout, but overall I prefer other types of Stout, such as American Stouts, Dry Stouts, Foreign Stouts and Imperial Stouts.

550 mL bottle from Farm Fresh.  Wow!  Im really surprised this gets such a positive rating.  Dont get me wrong, this is a good stout but I dont think it deserves such a high mark.  At any rate, heres my review:  Black pour with a creamy tan head.  Dark roasted malt aroma with some molasses and faint espresso.  Milk chocolate, coffee, and oat flavor.  A good, but certainly not great, stout.

Bottle into pint.  Dark brown pour with an aggressive dark brown airy head.  Im pretty seriously confused by its high rating.  Compared to other oatmeal imperial stouts I found this to be very watery and light without much going on in the body of the flavor.  Id much rather have Hoppin Frogs BORIS any day over this.

I am writing this about 2 days after drinking it, so may have to go back and pick up another to give a better qualitative analysis.  Pours black and opaque, beautiful finger-and-a-half head which releases an array of aromas: roasted malt, nuts, coffee and oats.  Delicious balance on the palate, with just the right amount of oat flavor.  All I can imagine is how much better this stout would be if the ABV was, lets say, doubled...
Pours black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malt.  Medium bodied, and excellent oatmeal and malt flavor.  This is definitely the best oatmeal stout that I have had.

Bottled: Light roasty malt aroma. Notes of coffee, cacao and chocolate. Black color with a foamy, brown head. Flavor is sweet malty, fruity, intensive notes of cacao, hints of plums and cherries. Roasted malt and a nice hop bitterness in the end.
UPDATED: NOV 5, 2009 Roasted malt aroma and flavor of oatmeal and malt. Nice and creamy with a bittersweet finish. Superb stout.

Pour a black color with a tan creamy head.The aroma is of roasted malts, with some coffe notes.The taste is just great.Its very sweet and malty.The mouthfeel is creamy and drinkable.Bottomline its one of the best of the best.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark, syrupy black with a light tan head.  Aromas of roasted malts, metal, and a tinge of banana.  Metal aroma disappears on the palate.  Flavors of roasted malt, banana, coffee, and tinge of chocolate.  Medium to heavily bodied.
Aroma is earthy and roasty. Looks dark brown, with a big light brown head. Taste is of mostly dark, roasted malts, some smoke and earthy flavours.
Pours Dark brown with a hit of red and a very tan head. Subtle and balanced flavor of malt and grain with a little sour note.
Pours dark and smells wonderful. Taste is wonderful, sweet malts, caramel and a roasted nutty flavor that is balanced and makes you want another sip. Yum.

550 ml bottle.  Aroma of roasted malt, sweet smelling, and undeniably English.  Pours almost black; reddish tones come out when held up to the light.  Thick head, long retaining, decent lacing.
