Tastes of roasted coffee, sweet malt.  This beer has remained in my top 10 for at least ten years, and for good reason.  I know of no other stout that tastes quite like this.  One of the greatest beers in the world right here.

Pours a dark brownish-black with medium off white head. Aroma is nutty and malty. The flavor is a bit fruity with hint of nuts and a smooth finish of coffee. Sweet, with a thin bitterness. Great beer.
From a bottle poured dark ruby color with a small amount of head.  Nice sweet malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours almost black but dark ruby if held up to light and with a tan head that hangs around. Aroma has lots of roasted malt and chocolate as well as a little coffee and some mild spice. Flavour is just great; again the roasted malt and chocolate dominate but the oatmeal comes through nicely as well as lesser hints of vanilla and a little dark fruit. Exceptionally smooth, creamy mouthfeel with a slightly sweet finish. Almost perfectly balanced, this is an excellent stout, possibly even better than their imperial, which is high praise indeed.

Beautiful dark colour with an extremely large creamy brown head. Wonderful looking. It has a bit of a weird flavour, slightly soured but not too elegantly. It is quite smooth, but the body is a little weaker than would be expected from the style. Overall it is fairly good and a nice hearty stout, but it is not unique or exceptional. I wouldnt mind trying it on tap but I wouldnt bother buying bottles again.

Nice dark beer with a medium sized head.  Sweet roasted malty aroma.  Medium bodied.  Wonderful roasted flavor with a nice oatmeal taste to anchor it all.  A few dark fruit and coffee flavors come through, but mostly the oatmeal base and maybe chocolate melted by a camp fire.  Smooth with a crisp finish.  Not overly complex but very enjoyable.

Bottle from Chappys in Dayton.  One of the first stouts I ever tried, a few years ago, before I started rating. Drinking it again for the second time and wow, what a difference it makes after some more beer experience.  I remember before, it was too strong for me, haha.  Now, the flavor is sweet, almost fruity, and with dry finish. The oats stick out and go well with the rich malty flavor.   Im starting to really love oatmeal stouts, and oatmeal beers in general.  The palate is smooth, not overly thick, but soft.  Ill be drinking some more of this soon.

Pours black, beige head. Sweet aroma of malts and oatmeal. Thick and creamy lots of oats, and lots of chocolate malt flavours. Roasty, slightly bitter, with a dry aftertaste that leaves you wanting more. THis is a great stout one of my favs. If I was a morning drinking kind of guy this is the beer I would have with breakfast. I think the perfect food pairing for this one would be Bacon, eggs and Toast. Great Beer!!

Very interesting aroma on this, not what i was expecting from a stout.  Red apples, spice and cider, with a hint of hickory smoke.  Apple again on the palate, molasses, maple syrup and plum.  Very unusual, and very good.

Very dark robe almost opaque. Rich creamy head. Smells of oatmeal malt with bit of toffee. Sweet oatmeal Stout overall, but taste is a bit disappointing.Not enough complexity and ...I dont know missing something.

Out of the typical 550ml bottle. I used to sit and pick off the gold foil years ago, to get a clean feel of the bottle mouth when I drank these straight out of the bottle like a fool. Into a chilled 24oz mega mug. Pours a super nice dark brown, almost black, with a good head that lasts pretty much the whole time in the mug. Smells of sweet chocolate, flows silky smooth with a long sweet after taste, not bitter at all realy. One of the sweeter, easier to drink stouts, out in the single bottle market, for many ears now.
18 oz Bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black with a tan head. Sweet taste. Oatmeal flavor is very apparent, but not overpowering. I will definitely buy this again.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick, creamy pale tan head with stunning lacing. Nose is big roast malt, chocolate, and a certain creamy character that must be attributed to the oats. In the mouth this beer feels amazing, silken, roasty, a bit nutty,not the most complex stout, but an immensely enjoyable one.
Bottle from the Majestic at Eastchase.  Great taste. Oatmeal is obvious, but not overbearing.
Bottle. Pours dense, dark brown with a creamy tan head. Aroma of sweet malts, oats, and roasted walnuts. Firm, crispy body with a great finish. Tasty stout.
i enjoyed this brew immensely. A creamy, satisfying, drinkable meal in a glass.
Not to bad I thought it was a mild stout it was dark like guiness not so much head
bottle, pours black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is oatsy with grain and a nice roasted malt backbone.  Flavor is nice and roasty silky smooth with tons of black malty goodness.  I love it.
Excellent stout.  Sweet malty aroma.  Taste of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Smooth and drinkable despite the robust taste.

550ml bottle.  Pours a deep dark brown with a tan thick creamy head.  Smells of rich oatmeal malt and a sweet english toffee.  Rich flavor of roasted malt, oats and coffee with a slightly bitter finish.  Thick, smooth and creamy.

Bottle - pours a cola-like black color with a thin tan head.  Nose of chocolate, roasted malt, amd coffee.  Could sit and smell this beer all day - reminds me of a freshly ground bag of coffee.. just smells so good.  Taste of roasted malt, oats, and chocolate coffee.  Body is thin with the perfect amount of carbonation for the ideal mouthfeel for this stout.  This is without a doubt one of my favorite oatmeal stouts - which is a style that ranks very highly in my house.

The British sure know how to brew a fine oatmeal stout!  Deep black with just a tiny hint of reddish-brown light penetrating under a thick, rich head of beige that lasts in a condensed form through the life of the glass.

Roasty oats, amongst other malts, and a nice touch of milk chocolate and a bit of sugar in the nose.  The flavor is power-packed with *heavily* roasted malt, a bit of cookie dough, and some dark chocolate and toffee notes.  This is one of the most drinkable stouts ever, with a low ABV, creamy texture, and smooth finish.

Black pour with ruby tints. Awesome persistent head and lacing.
Aroma shows sweet roasted malt with some creamy coffee and milk chocolate. Not too exciting, I was expecting more.
Very similar flavours, with roasted grains, milk chocolate and some nutty notes.
Good full, creamy body.

its easy to give a review when youre currently drinking something... with that said, this stuff smells like fresh baked oatmeal cookies and tastes more malty and coffee like than oatmealesque. easy going down and smooooooth. real smooth on the swallow. my only complaint is i do believe its a bit watered down and that is why i would assume its only 5%. regardless for my first time trying it i love it, samuel smith makes some real solid stuff.

From bigpatmcnelis... Poured into a snifter, dark in color nice one finger head. Good aroma of oats and coffee. Taste is the same, nice oat, roasted malt, coffee taste. Nice texture, perfect beer for its style. Overall a very enjoyable stout. Thanks Pat

12oz bottle. Celebrating my 21st birthday rating my first purchase. Pours a solid black with a thick, creamy head. Has a sweet toffee like aroma. Good, thick mouthfeel that lasts on the tongue with a hint of hops on the backend cut by the brown sugar/chocolaty sweetness. I was looking for a good oatmeal stout and found one.
Nearly black with a fairly thin tan head.  Very rich, toasty flavor and rather filling.  Aroma reminds me slightly of licorice.  Finishes bitter and slightly chocolatey.  Very solid oatmeal stout.
A dark brown to black beer with a 2 finger head. Aroma was fruity,& slightly roasty. The taste was silky in the mouth. Do I taste oatmeal? It is a good beer.

55cl bottle
dark brown, large light brown smootyh head.
nice roasty aroma, roasted coffee, sweetness, brown sugar, faint licorice, faint chocolate. many notes to the aroma.
flavor is roasted brown sugar, roasted grains, coffee, roasted grains.
palate is a bit watery.
taste is good, especially considering the low abv.

Poured from a 1pt bottle into a glass pint.

The color is A very deep dark black with a light brown foamy head.

The smell is of chocolate, a little toffee and roasted malts

The taste is smooth, creamy, a malty flavor is very deep in the background with a toffee tone.

This beer is quite smooth. Goes down real nice and is one the best stouts Ive had. The overall feel is strong but does not overpower.
Single bottle into an English pint glass.  Creamy and delicious - absolutely one of my standby oatmeal stouts.

A very good stout.  Looks good and has a nice aroma.  Not quite up to the standards of the Stone Imperial Russian or the Great Divide Oak Aged Yeti but pretty darn good.  Then again it contains half the alcohol and has a much thinner mouthfeel.  But still worth a try by all means.
The aroma is lovely, I could spent days just smelling this beer. It looks like other stouts, but the oatmeals make the difference. Lovely and great

Pours out lighter than expected, a dark tawny with a decent viscosity. A quick rush of bubbles stretches the thick khaki head farther into the near black body. The head sits atop calm and frothy, lasting the whole glass, and leaving a bit of slippery lace. The aroma is very roasty, with a little bit of chocolate, an some toffee. The flavor is sweet and milk chocolaty at first, then seamlessly fades into a coffee rich dryness. The mouthfeel is a little on the light side, but is as smooth and glass and retains in the mouth very well. Top notch stout.

Very handsome in the glass...a dark brown pour that settles into a deeper black with some ruby highlights. The head is long-lasting, dark tan in colour, and retains some very impressive lacing throughout the entire pint. I could detect very little smell at first, but as this warmed up, i could get some chocolate, coffee, and considerable nutmeg traces. This is a very malty, balanced beer whose taste centers mostly on cereal-like flavours and is rounded out by some subtle coffee and roasted barley. The finish is semi-sweet, contains hints of cacao, and has a nice dry feeling.

lets not actually rate this beer. This beer is like a swedish super model, Beautiful, sexy, and overwelming.  This beer poors  like niagara falls, the most beautiful site.  It pours smooth, almost as smooth as the quaker oats man himself.  this BEER is like your first crush, mysterous, beautiful, and wanting, and when you first taste her, you dont know what to think but the love of your life.  Almost like your favorite celebrity sitting naked in front of you. Smooth like a babys butt like they say, smooth like a babies butt. Just like in Old Greg on youtube, "Baileys, as close as you can get without your eyes gettin wet".

pUrchased a 750 ml at La Mesa,CA BevMo for about 4 dlls . Really good, i think its quite strong fro just 5% like it reads, anyway mm really dark opaque brown color, really coffee-like thing white a very big and porous beige head, taste a lot like a Guinness, didnt notice quite much diference between a an oatmeal and a Barley stout .however really nice light-toasted and sweet aroma.
Bottle @ Metro. 5%. Beautiful dark brown pour with a fairly weak tan head with mild lacing. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, malts. Taste is oaty, thick, rich, with a hint of chocolate. Superb.

Bottle. Dark chocolate brown with a tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, and dark fruit. The flavor is sweet with a light roasty bitterness. Full body with a decent amount of carbonation to lighten it up and a long dry finish. This is a great beer that first got me into stouts way back when, its just as good as I remember it.
Very dark with large, dark head. Very mild but pleasant aroma. Smooth chocolaty/coffee flavor. Thinnish mouthfeel.

bottle into a glass-FIRST DRINK-Deep roasted flavor, Ill admit im a novice when it comes to stouts, but this is one of the best ive tried. HALF GLASS-Holding up nicely, very well made beer, those English bastards. FINISH-Holds up nicely, only gets better as it warms.

Jet black pour with 1-inch thick tan head. Aroma is assertive like rubbing alcohol, roasted barley, oats. Smooth texture with a medium body. Begins with malt sweetness - molasses, caramel and chocolate, chewy toffee - and continues into a balancing hop spice bitterness, though subtle. Finishes on a cadence of dry and bittersweet coffee flavor. Malted barley combined with oatmeal and more roasted barley add a nice nuance to this beer which separates it from the average stout. Slick palate and a somewhat abrupt finish.
A devilishly dark and complex beer. One of my favorite stouts -- and one that stands tall among any beer in the category.
Had about 10 beer drinkers do a taste test of about 15-20 dark beers from all over the world.  This one came out on top by a landslide.  Great beer!!!

Bottle. Poured  black in color with a nice foamy thick long lasting tanned head. The aroma was that of molasses, dark fruit and chocolate malts with a hint of coffee. Medium body with sweet malt, dark fruits (cherry) flavor in the beginning, followed by coffee bitterness and some chocolate. Finish is short but well balanced.  Great Stout.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2012 Bottle. The Pour was a deep dark brown almost black with a nice creamy tan head that lasted throughout and had some excellent sheeting of lace. 

The aroma was heavy of a burnt cereal malt and a sweet doughy yeast with a nice hints of oats, coffee, molasses and dark chocolate.

The taste was very malty and mildly bitter sweet with a dark chocolate overtone at first and finished about the same with a nice note of coffee towards the end. The flavor stayed with you for a nice long time, with a smooth cocoa coffee flavor left lying on the taste buds.

Mouthfeel was extremely full in body and had a smooth creamy texture with a very soft carbonation. 

Overall a great boldly robust Stout and still one of my favorite brews...
Pours dark with good lacing. Avery nice complex beer. I love a good stout and this is one of the best. I f not perfect let me know.

Slight roasted oat aroma, not overpowering. Opaque black body with a large tan head. Slightly bitter taste because of the coffee overtones. Medium body with a long chocolate and coffee aftertaste. Decent stout, not bad, not great.

Classy label on this one.  It poured a dark and clear colour, with a most active creamy head, light brown in hue.   The aroma was subtle, with hints of chocolate and maybe a pinch of malt.  The taste was rather more definite, certainly a healthy amount of coffee at the forefront, perhaps some chocolate lurking behind.

0.33 bottle Pours dark/black with a dissipating brown head.Roasted malt and licorice aroma.Some tar.Nice and carbonated , roasted coffee flavors.Sweet with a dry finish. Medium to full body .
A very nice stout.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours pitch black with a creamy, light tan head.  Roasted malt, a little wood and some soy sauce make up a relatively light nose.  Nothing truly spectacular so far.  Medium carbonation with a medium-light mouthfeel.  Nice roasty character, light earth notes, some wood, and soy sauce make up the palate.  Nice, smooth mouthfeel.  Finish is medium with some lingering roasted and wood notes.  Overall a stalwart example of a stout that is enjoyable just about any time.

Bottle. Black with a thick and dense cappuccino coloured head. Aromas of coffee with sugar, toffee, roasted malt and cocoa powder. Flavour of sweet malt, roasted malt, chocolate, dried fruit and coffee. This is a classic..
pours black with nice tan lacing.  smells of caramel, roasted malt, and some bitter chocolate.  taste of roasted malts and sweet toffee.

Bottle from a pizzeria in west philadelphia. I am genuinely surprised to see the high ratings on here - I usually rate on the low side, but not like this! Pours like hot maple syrup. Tastes like cold maple syrup (e.g. 1000% too sweet). Smells like a bad cup of coffee. Finish reminiscent of oatmeal that was cooked along with a bar of soap. Either I got a bad bottle, have gone quite mad, or something seriously weird is going on.

Bottle at the Chandos, London. Sweet gentle roast malts with a hint of liquorice and toffee. Plenty of fresh tasting english hops in the finish. Good mature natural tasting carbonation and attractive lacing. Classy beer.

Bottle:  Pours very dark brown with a ruby red hue. Large light brown head eventually disappears.  Not an overly powerful aroma, but you can pick up some chocolate, cream, oats and sweet fruit.  Very smooth tasting.  Nice chocolate malty taste with hints of raisin.  Bitter cocoa finish.  Not a heavy stout but its not lacking in body.  Dry, creamy texture.  Not too sweet, not too bitter.
Pours a very nice dark brown color.  Smells of oatmeal, almost raisin.  Complex taste, with coffee, chocolate, malts and other grains, smooth and enjoyable.

Pours similar to a dunkelweisen, dark with a tan head.  Had a hint of chocolate on the nose and had a very nice grain taste with a tart finish.  This is probably the smoothest beer Ive ever drank, goes down like its not even there.
Bottle, black color.  Aroma of roasted malt with raisin notes.  Very smooth taste highly drinkable.  Strong dark malt taste with a slightly sweet taste that has raisin undertones.

12oz. Bottle: Aroma is lightly sweet. Smells of roasting, malts, a little cream, and chocolate. Poured black in color with a large, creamy, brown head that lasted throughout. Small lacing. Opaque. Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter. Tastes of malts, chocolate, oats, and roasting. Very well balanced. Medium, silky body. Soft carbonation. Dryish lightly sweet, lightly bitter, malty-chocolate finish. Overall, a very good sweet stout.

Pours a beautiful dark chocolate with a deep beige head. Moderately strong aroma of mocha coffee and some roasted malt. Some great barley flavor with semisweet chocolate. Incredibly smooth and creamy. Although not thick, theres some decent depth here. This is a good one.

Bottle.  Pours a black body with a tan head.  Subtle oats and a nice smooth lightly roast y body that is thin and session able.  Overall a nice mass production oatmeal stout. Never a bad choice for a simple oatmeal stout.

Dark dark brown, with hints of red showing around the out side of my glass, a brown head that lasted a very long time capped off this beer. The smell was amazing deep roasted malts, chocolate chip cookies, and coffee rise up from my glass, making my mouth drool. Bitter coffee and chocolate malts give the beer the perfect balance of taste a bitterness. The mouth feel is full but maybe a touch chalky but no matter how I see it is amazing. I taste roasted marshmallows in the finish and a bitter dark chocolate after taste is left lingering in your mouth. Simply an a amazing stout, this has restored my faith in stouts that has been dwindling lately.

Can I change the sampled ammount to around a million? I love this beer. Not quite totally black since there is some light penetration that shows an intensly dark cherry hue. Produces decent sized brown head that is fun to watch while it bubbles down. Retains enough cap to cover entire beer for about half the pint and make some solid lacing rings early on only. None of the qualities of this beer are harsh, strong or overwhelming - everything is in perfect balance and leans towards the milder side which is the main reason that it is so easy and enjoyable to drink. Aroma has sweet warm roasted malts and a good blend of coffee first and chocolate second. Defenetly more coffee - but both of those aromas are quite mild which is nice for once. Taste is very well rounded with the obvious roasted malts and coffee flavours that are excellent. Perfect mouthfeel. Incredibaly smooth and thick with the perfect ammount of slight dry tart bitterness. I dream of this beer in a never emptying pint...always slightly warm and always fresh. My favorite stout. Samuel Smith makes excellent beer period.

0.55 l bottle my parents brought from London. It poured dark brown body with medium sized fluffy brownish head. Very nice aroma, coffee dominated, caramel, chocolate, some herbal spices. Coffee is dominating the flavor, too. Its nicely balanced, slightly bitter and sweet, notes of chocolate, caramel, peat. Creamy and full bodied. Sweet finish. Best beer in tonights tasting, I may liked it more than Doggythedog did, but we both have too high expectations. Very good anyway, but for sure, not the best around.

0.55l bottle courtesy of and shared with heavy (huge thanks!) Poured a black (extremely dark red) body with a fluffy tan head that collapsed unevenly at a medium pace. Weak oily roasty malty nose, notes of chocolate, some odd herbal notes too. The taste is sweetish and roasty, smoth chocolatey taste, finely balanced, light bitterness, weak vinuous notes, some smoke, light roasty aftertaste. Overall quite nice but neither the flashiest nor the tastiest beer around.

355 ml bottle.  Very dark, chocolatey appearance with a small coffee colored head.  The flavor was pleasant but the body was not as full as most stouts.  Nice chocolate bitterness upfront with a sweeter finish.

A nice looking almost jet-black beer with a small tan head that dissipates. Smells great, like chocolate and burnt toast with some biscuitiness.. The flavor is a tad weeker, with some roasty notes but fairly watery. Mouthfeel not so chewy for a stout.
Bottle, 5% at KØ09. Dark brown colour. Mild malty flavour, dark malt. Low bitterness. Good mouthfeel, nicely chewy, but the carbonation is a little high. Subtle but very nice.
Bottle. Malt and ripe fruits in aroma. Dark brown colour with light brown head. Sweet flavour with just discrete bitterness. The oats are probably there but not very easily deciphered. Very mild.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2009 A nice beer. What more is there to say about this beer, really? I didnt get much oat out of it, and to my mind its not 99th percentile beer, but its good. I probably wouldnt buy it again, because I prefer other stouts but for readily available stout its not a bad fallback.
Nice black pour with a cream tan head. Sweet caramel, chocolate and roasted malts aroma. Medium body with a slightly sour finish. Couldnt taste much oat but a very good beer.
Very thick creamy stout. Not really an oatmeal taste but definitely different than normal barley.

Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. A perfect bottled ale. Beautifully red-tinged black appearance, with a caramel coloured head. The sweet, malty taste is perfectly accompanied by a juicy fruity flavour and a roast, slightly smoky aroma. Plenty of body, but neither heavy, nor cloying. I wish they did this in cask, but when the bottle is this good, there cant be too many complaints. A beer I regularly come back to.....

Frothy cream colored head, smelled of chocolate.  Super strong tasting beer, chocolate, coffee, roasted nuts and an orange citrus like bite made for a suprisingly strong palate.  Could drink this as a meal replacement it was so thick.

Bottle.  Nice looking pour; dark brown with a medium, firm and long lasting dark tan/light brown head.  Aroma of oats, fruit, roasted meat, caramel and vanilla.  Flavor really had a nice blend of sweet vanilla and caramel, with some roasted oats and light meatiness in the finish.  Palate was pretty good, surprisingly almost bordering on watery.  However, it worked and made it quite drinkable.  After taste was quite tasty.  Can see why this is much loved and surprised I havent rated this (although I had it a good 4 or 5 years ago).
Deep dark brown with a nice size tan head. Slightly bitter dryness on the palate.  Excellent malt hop balance. The 550 ml bottle is filling.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2009 Dark malt and chocolate aroma Pours almost black with a bit of little red tent. A very thick stout.Flavor is barley, strong chocolate/toffee , vanilla and dark fruit. Finish is  dry, aftertaste of chocolate a sweet bitter after taste. some I didnt get much carbonation going down. Good beer though.

Pours opaque brown/black, with a small, tan head. Aroma is very roasty, with malt and dark chocolate undertones. Flavor starts out on rich, sweetish malt, then progresses to a nice roasty and bitter finish. The palate is outstanding, very full and smooth. Maybe Samuel Smiths best beer.

Aroma of sweet dark malt, some chocolate.  Pours very dark brown with a little red.  Flavor is roasted barley, dark chocolate, a little hazelnut and dark fruit.  Finish is very dry, aftertaste of chocolate lingers for a while.  Medium carbonation.

bottle. Pours deep brown, capped with a medium sized tan head. Aroma is on the sweet side, with oats, roasted malt, and some chocolate. Flavor is sweet as well, with chocolate, oat and barley. Medium bodied, with a slightly nutty finish. This was one of the first "good beers" that I tried, its nice to revisit it.

550 ml bottle. Pours a dark brown having a frothy tan head. Aromas of licorice, dark fruit, roasted malts, nuts and a nice sweetness. The flavor here is smooth and velvety with roasted malts, nutty, with a hint of oat, chocolate, and coffee. A well made oat stout. Sweet with a little bitterness. If this was at the bars here I would only drink this.
Delicious stuff - just simply too pricey for even the average above-average beer lover. Good, but not as great as its made out to be.

This is a fantastic stout. Its a bit more drinkable than other stouts. I would highly recommend this stout to anyone who is broadening their stout horizons. This is a great starter stout. From here move on to Old Rasputin and Stone Russian Imperial Stouts!!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2010 Pours opaque black with a thick tan head. The taste is dark, nutty and reminiscent of roasted vegetables and is balanced out by a gentle hop bitterness. Its also very thick, but smooth and not syrupy. Overall, you cant get a better stout than this.

Pour was black with a light off white head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and cofee.  Flavor is similar, with the roasted flavors a good smooth sweetness from the oatmeal.  Hints of coffee and toffee.  I really appreciated this, but I cant say its as good as many people say.

Pour is black with small brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, wet dog, and milk. Flavor is coffee, roasted malts, slight coco, and vanilla. Weird nose on this one, but it tastes much better than smell. Decent.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: 12oz bottle 4/17/09-Pours a black body with a nice tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee. Taste of the same with some sweetness and toffee coming through. This medium bodied stout is a little light in body but is still tasty but was expecting more from this brew.
This is just an amazing example of an oatmeal stout.  Flavor is sweet and the palate is smooth.  This beer looks great with nice tan head.  A classic.

Great oatmeal stout.  The only place this beer suffers in the palate.  Perhaps a bit overcarbed for style.  Still, it is smooth and sweet with both caramel and toffee notes coming through.  A very nice low alcohol stout.

Bottle. Deep dark brown pour with tan head. Roasty nose, nuts, oatmeal, mild chocolate and caramel malts on the nose. Even sweeter, with molasses notes on the tongue. Light, refreshing, silky palate. Lovely low alc stout. A fine beer.
Very good oatmeal stout but sometimes hit or miss in the bottle. Definitely still a good one though.

The pour is near black with a large tan head that was long lasting.  One of the most impressive pours Ive seen.  Smell is of caramel, chocolate and oats.  Taste is sweet malts with a hint of dark chocolate and cofee.  The initial sweetness is balanced by a slight bitterness.  Mouthfeel is smooth for a stout., but the body feels somewhat thin for a stout as well.  Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is a solid stout, but I think that I expect more out of something this pricey.

This stout poured beautifully, viscous and thick, dark drown to black with a firm long lasting tan/cream head. Strong sweet aromas dominate, toffee and caramel with some chocolate. My first (and immediate) impression on tasting was LUSH; this beer was amazingly smooth, a lovely velvety feel in the mouth but much bigger than the previous stouts. Sweet malt flavours up front, mildly bitter with some caramel flavour and a burnt coffee finish. The note I wrote in my diary is this is what stout is all about,  I loved this beer and have bought it a couple more times since despite its incredible price tag.

Bottle.  Poured a large, frothy, light brown head.  Clear, deep brown-black body with ruby showing in narrower areas of the glass.  Attractive lacing as the head subsides.  Malty nose - caramel, roasted coffee and dark chocolate, but none of the three are overpowering or especially bold.  Light, hoppy aroma of flowers, herbs and earth.  Medium, creamy body with soft carbonation.  Bitter-roast finish with some additional hop bitterness.  A delicious stout that is subtly and deceptively complex.  The craftsmanship really shines in the flavors - all of the traditional stout flavors are there and they make their presence known, but they are blended such that no particular flavor slaps you across the face.  Masterful.  Ill have another, please.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 Bottle. Tre Små Rum. Gothenburg. Black colour with a creamy lasting pale brown head. Mildly roasted, very smooth, chocolate, earth, lightly acidic, coffee, oats, sweetness, not very bitter. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle. The aroma is nice, roasted malt, light sweet, a little bit of cacao and coffee. The head is large, light brown and creamy-foamy with a long duration. The body is black. The taste started light bitter, the duration is long and the finish is silky. The texture is very creamy, the body is medium strong with a soft carbonation. A very nice Stout!
UPDATED: MAR 12, 2013  tasty stout.  oatmeal time.  dry cocoa.   nice body.   pleasant cream and roast.  nice.
Bottle. Real good Oatmeal Stout. Slightly sweet, with a nice flavor. Very smooth, and really drinkable..
Dark pour that lets in a little light. Aroma has several sweet notes but is not overpowering. Taste has the slightest hint of maple but stops at that. Decent and above average.
550 ml bottle at 3 Små Rum, on March 26, 2009Clear dark red color, fluffy tan head. Malty, sweet, raissin, chocolate scent. Sweet, dry, bready, cocoa taste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.

Hey! Who sppiked my Vanilla Coke? This guy is sweet, thick, and dark. Chocalet, nutty, and above all, more vanilla than any beer I have ever had. This bitch kicks ass, definitely the best that Samuel Smith has to Offer
Pours very dark with medium head. Flavor is crisp, goes down smooth. There is a slight bitter aftertaste. (550ml, $4.50)
Great flavor and smooth. One of the best Oatmeal Stouts out there in my oppinion.

Pours a pitch black with small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt with hints of sweet fruit.  Flavor is nothing unexpected.  Pretty smooth with a dry finish.  Not a bad stout, but not a great one either.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 I had high expectations for this beer, and Im happy to say that I was completely blown away. The smell is high on yeast with a little citrus, interesting but not too special. The taste is everything. Think breakfast: chocolate mocha (heavy on the coffee), yogurt with granola, and a few blackberries. Each flavor has a constant presence and no component really overwhelms the others. Plus, although a dark stout, it goes down without resistance (which some people might not like). But I really have nothing bad to say: today, I found a new favorite beer.

Poured a dark dark brown with a big tan head.  Aroma was nutty and roasty.  Flavor was surprisingly sweet, with some nice nut charcter and a good deep malt flavor.  Oatmeal always adds a specific note to a beer, and it was very present in this one.  Almost slick in the mouthfeel.
Pours dark, lots of flavor in this one.  Sweet taste goes down easy.  Good after dinner beer

Bottle. Pours a black color with a creamy two finger tan head. Very rich and creamy. Aroma is roasted matls, and lots of chocolate. Very thick and heavy. Flavor is rich and smokey. Full body. Great beer.
Bottle - Black with a good tan head.   Medium carbonation. Full bodied. Sweet,  roasted malt, smoke, coal tar. Slightly sticky. Nicely balanced with a medium bitter finish.

Poured black with a thin dark brown head.  Aroma is of roasted malt and slightly nutty.  Flavor is of burnt malts some coffee and a light smokieness.  Body is suprisingly thin.  Very little carbonation.  Sweet mild smoked finish with no bitterness.  Disappointing.
Smoked sweet malt, coffee aroma. Caramel flavor, licorice notes. Smoked smell. Bitter coffee finish. Dark brown body, thin texture, medium-low carbonated.
bottle..brown..nice oatmeal stout really..nice classic brew..nice light tan head..vanilla and smoke bitter coffee at the end..

UPDATED: APR 28, 2009 550ml Bottle. A dark brown/black color with a huge light tan head that lasts a while then fades to a thin cap leaving loads of lacing down the sides of the glass.Aroma has lots of sweet chocolate,some vanilla and licorice notes and a hint of grain.Flavor is kind of like those chocolate oatmeal no-bake cookies with a hint of vanilla,smoke,and a kiss of bitter coffee at the finish.A medium to full creamy mouthfeel,with just the right amount of carbonation. A well built stout , by any measure.

Brown with some ruby highlights and a creamy large slowly fading beige crown.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, oatmeal and a touch of smoke.  Taste of oatmeal, chocolate and dry and roasted malts.  Creamy palate with a mild dry finish.  Pretty good.

Deep amber color with a rocky tan head. Light coffee aroma with a hint of chocolate. Silky body with a nice roasted coffee flavor, a mild graininess and a slightly dry finish. Very smooth, mild and sweet for an oatmeal stout, no harsh bitterness.
Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head.  Sweet coffee aroma.  Very smooth and well balanced with flavors of oats, roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate.  Great stout.

1 Pt. 2.7 fl.oz. Black pour with a thick brown head. Semi-sweet tasting- smooth tasting all around. Very tasty beer, th flavor rolls over the tongue. this is one of the first quality beers I have ever had back in the earl 90s. It still is top.
Yes!  Less ABV than expected, and so very smooth to boot.  Finish is the bitterness of good quality chocolate.  550ml bottle a perfect size.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2009 Good ass stout.Very tough for a  5% stout.Ive got Sri Lankas Lion here & this feels almost as heavy as that beast,depsite being way less boozy.Heaps of chocolate and silky roast malt flavours.
Dark brown colour with light tan head, Bitter coffee nose, light carbonated and thinner than expected
Deep brown in color with a good sized tan head. Aroma is of malt, oats, chocolate, and coffee. Taste is of milk chocolate, caramel, oats and roasted malts.

Bottle poured into a pilsner style glass. Poured a very dark brown, almost black, with a good sized tan head. Very good lacing.  Aroma was very malty and bready. Like slightly burnt toast and coffe. Taste was fantastic. Very coffee like with a hint of oats. A little bitterness at the end... barely noticeable. Very smooth and rich. I was very impressed, this has moved up to the top of my favorites list.
Bottle poured and let a nice head develop. Was a great choice to try being the 1st from Sam Smith I had. It had a great body and lasting flavor to it. Not overpowering at all.

Bottle.  Poured brown black with thick lasting light beige head.  Aroma of malt, oats and coffee.  Full mouth with  a smooth body, malt, oatmeal, coffee and toffee.  Lasting malt finish.  Seek this one out.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 bottle. Poured almost black with a creamy tan head. Coffee aroma. Full, kinda syrupy mouthfeel. Burnt malt flavour, sweet molasses and coffee notes. Bitter acidy finish.

wow. This beer is like a nice dessert after dinner. I challenge any beer to be better than this, and hold every beer I drink to this standard if it wants to rank any higher. The body is a nice thick dark body, with a mocha colored head. the aroma is a roasty oat smell. Surprising this has a bit of a sweet flavor, and the oats are definitely present, chocolate, and roasty nut overtone are in the finish. It goes down very smooth, with just a kick of bitterness at the very end. Everything is perfectly blended. This just may be a perfect beer.

Bottle.  The color is dark brown, almost black.  The head brownish tint and fluffy.  The aroma is roasted oats, coffee, chocolete, and roasted barley.  the flavor is sweet, oats,  chocolate, and a finish of coffee, with very little bitterness. Extremely smooth.  and has lacing,   Overall a good stout
Bottle.  Deep brown/black brown head. Aroma: bitter chocolate, coffee and roasted oats. Flavor: Sweet chocolate malted flavour, with a balanced bitterness

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2009 550ml bottle. Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout. This is the one that started it all for me. My dad would purchase a few of these every now and then to share, and as a result, I began to develop a liking of dark beers as a teenager. It pours opaque brown/black with a marvelous tan head. Aroma of sweet roasted malts with hints of caramel, chocolate and fruits. The flavor is outstanding. Initially its sweet roasted malts, later followed by the taste of dark fruit, chocolate, coffee and hint of dry hop bitterness. Full of flavor that does not overwhelm. Extremely smooth and creamy and incredibly easy to drink. While this is not the absolute best beer that Ive had, it is simply a classic and one of finest examples of the style. Thanks Dad.

50cl Bottle from De Bierkoning. Almost black in colour, creamy off-white head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, a hint of liquorice. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, liquorice. Nice lingering roasted coffee bitter finish. Very soft and smooth mouthfeel, a bit watery at times, but really good flavours that all blend in very well. Would love to try this from tap.

Sampled at the Sam Smith tasting at Blacklick Wine and Spirits on 2.5.09.  Dark brown pour with a medium tan head.  Sweet and malty chocolate aroma with coffee and some hop.  Sweet malt flavor with chocolate and coffee in the finish.  Still my favorite these guys make.
I enjoyed the oatmeal character of the beer. Very smooth and velvety. Aroma was lacking a bit. Flavor was good, with notes of roasted coffee and oatmeal.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2009 A true classic and one of the originals from way back. Still one of the better Oatmeal Stouts available out there.

updated 5/1/08: Despite my nostalgia for this one got to knock it down a couple points. There are just too many better oatmeal stouts to be found these days to keep it ranked as high as I had it. No disrespect to Mr Smith though.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 The first thing I noticed was the gold foil on the cap XD.  But seriously, the head was a decently dense tan that hung around for a little while.  The aroma was nothing fancy, and honestly even the first taste wasnt particularly overwhelming.  But after the 2nd, 3rd, 4th tastes you will fall in love with this beer.  Perhaps slightly too carbonated, this beer fills the mouth with roasted character.  It then leaves a delightfully warming aftertaste of oats leaving you to long for a second pour.

Poured from 550ml bottle into large dimpled mug.
Aroma - Dark roasted malt, dark chocolate,and coffee.
Appearance - Opaque black with creamy two finger tan head. Head dissipates rather quickly leaving nice lacing that fully coats the glass.
Flavor - Tastes pretty much like it smells. Some dark fruit that I didnt pick up in the aroma. Bittersweet aftertaste; but thats not a bad thing.
Palate - Not slick like some oatmeal stouts. More of a dry stout with the edge taken off. Carbonation comes through just enough to make it a bit lively on the tongue.
Overall - Another great Samuel Smith product. Traditional and delicious. Would love to try this from a nitro tap.

Bottle as shown. Pours a dark brown with a medium creamy light tan tan head.  The aroma is roasted malt, with chocolate, nuts, and coffee. Good stickyl lacing on the glass. The taste is a dry roasted malt with oatmeal and toffee. A good stout from Samuel Smith.

Solid stout, not quite one of the best but good. Very dark brown with a tan head.  Roasty aroma with some coffee.  Toasted oat taste, nuts, and some coffee hints.  Really creamy on the mouthfeel.  Bloody ell!

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2009 Brown/Black pour. 2 finger light brown head. smells, well, like a stout. taste pretty dang good, Extremely smooth, and a nice thick creamy mouthfeel. Sweet, but not even close to being sickly.  Taste like dark roasted coffee in the end for me. Hops shows up just enough to balance this one out. Nice Brew! i really like this one...
Great thick pour, very roasted feel, wonderful smoothness throughout, finishes with perfect light bitterness with oats.

Poured from a 1 Pt. 2.7 fl oz. bottle. Looks coffee brown, with a low frothy cream-colored head. The aroma has a strong coffee overtone with some malt and smokiness. Smoother tasting that expected, with just the right carbonation. There is a pleasant domimance of oatmeal towards the end, which really seems to lighten the whole taste. I really enjoyed this stout.

Simply awesome! I had one at a bar about a year ago and it tasted slightly off. I gave it another chance the other night and was blown away. Im assuming the one I had at the bar was just old. Pours a lovely thick, lingering head. Nice oat-y/nutty finish. Nearly a perfect stout.

Bottle. Heavy toasted and coffee aromas for the malt, light resin and dough for the hops and yeast, with hints of wood and brown sugar. Head is large, creamy, off-white with excellent lacing and is fully lasting. Color is dark brown. Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly acidic to start and finishes lightly sweet and acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, watery but almost syrupy and has a lively carbonation. Well rounded and rich in flavor and aroma, a nice Stout.

Purchased 355ml bottle from Cellars Wine & Spirits in Shorewood, MN. Pours a clear dark brown brew with a thintan head that slowly dissipates to a fine film and ring. Aroma of toasted dark malt, some oatmeal, chocolate, a hint of berries and some toffee. Taste is medium bodied, with flavors of toasted dark malt, some chocoalte, toffee, and a hint of coffee. Finish is semi-sweetitw h a mild toasted dark malt aftertaste.
Bottle from Bier Koning. Black body, nice head. Fruity, malty nose.  Creamy taste. Distinctive and delicious.
This is truely a great Stout...Samuel Smiths make great beers and this is one of my favorites..Nice aroma with and very creamy..I recomend this beer year round

There is a wonderful aroma of choclate, coffee and roast malt.

The beer pours to the most beautiful latte like head with small bubbles tracing up the edge of the glass into the head. The body of the beer is jet black and almost reflective in the glass.

The first taste of the beer is amazing, it starts with a sweet chocolate taste and moves across the palate to a crisp dry coffee finish, which lingers and lingers.

550ml bottle. Pours a black body with a half inch, tan, quickly fading head that remains pretty lacy. Aroma is distinctly "english." Berry fruits, smooth oats, light chocolate, and a faint english roast. Flavor is light and sweet. Has the smooth oatiness to it and mainly berry sweet. Underlying chocolate and a light roast. Leaves a minimal english spice, but not very bitter. Palate is light and carbonated while still velvety and swift. Overall, not my cup of tea. Not what I look for in a stout. Not bad, but disappointing.

Pours black with a small tan head that diminishes quickly. Taste is raisins, milk chocolate, sweet caramel. Aroma is the same. Silky mouthfeel with medium-low carbonation. A good oatmeal stout, drinkable and enjoyable - my favorite beer from samuel smith.

If forced to pick, probably my favorite brewery.  The head is capuccino colored and big, with tightly nit bubbles.  Not much aroma, just a hint of malt.  Taste is sweet, and full of malty flavor, but its also very mellow.  Palate is soft and silky, and feels great on the tongue.  Not overly complicated, but one of my favorite stouts of all time.

[550ml bottle.] Opaque reddish brown body with a soft creamy cream head; rich roasted malt and chocolate aroma, slightly smokey; silky smooth texture with a bagfuls of roasted malts giving a complex mingling of flavours - nuts, smoke, toffee, chocolate, coffee and fruit are all there; well rounded sweet finish with a definite oaty feeling. An excellent stout.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2009 Wonderful beer. Will always be a favorite. Low in alcohol compared to some high octane imperials. This beer doesnt need to change. Smooth as can be with just the right amount of malt and chocolate flavors. Thank you Sammy Smith for this classic.

Bottle
Good  roasted aroma, some chocolate and malt. Tastes bitter but not overly
very good blend
I like this one
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle.  Obsidian black with a dark brown head and roasted malt aroma.  Perfect balance of maltiness and hops and ends with a somewhat clean finish but at the same time a trace of roasted malt that makes you crave more.  My favorite oatmeal stout!

really dark brown color and beige head
smooth carbonation
smells of chocolate, toffee and coffee
tasts of chocolate,coffe,toffee,and hidden dried fruits
aftertaste is bittersweet and roasty

A black colored beer, with a thick foamy dark beige head. The aroma of coffee with chocolate, laurel liquorice, roasted malt and fruits. The taste is dry bitter, coffee, dark malts, with notes of chocolate and fruits. The aftertaste is long bitter.
My absolute favorite stout beer.  Good to have when you are really hungry.  Has a nice flavor, especially when it has a slight chill.

Pours black into the glass with a small off white head.  Aroma is chocolate/coffee and slight notes of raisins.  A great velvety moutheel gives way to flavors of roasted grain and chocolate.  Really a great stout.
Black with a small off-white head. Aroma of roast malt, grain, molasses and licorice. Rather sweet, almost sugary flavour with licorice notes.
This is my favorit stout to date of any style. Highly recomended. The oatmeal stands out and is distinguisable. Chocolate and carmell stand out. Awsome
Poured a clear dark brown, with a minimal head.  Strong chocolate with undertones of coffee.

Clear mahogany pour with bonus points for a 1 inch cream colored head that just never leaves.  Nice lacing, as well.  Fragrant chocolate, coffee, and nuttiness.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, and caramel.  Quite thin for the style.  A good sessionable stout.
Love this beer.  Wish it were easier to obtain in good condition as I have found it in dusty bottles more often than not.

The 1st Oatmeal Stout I had ever had and still my favorite. Pours very dark with a thin, creamy head. Aromas of bittersweet chocolate, roasted coffee, I sense a taste of fig or date and a brown sugary finish. Love this one!

Nice dark black color, good aroma. Taste was very heavy, definetly not a session beer, more like 1 bottle with dinner

The fruit taste comes on a little too strong, but a pretty good beer overall

Dark brown with reddish glimts and large beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, caramel and coffee notes. Sweet flavour with plenty off coffee , roasted malt, chocolate and caramel notes. Finished sweet.
Pours dark with a thin tan head.. I tasted a tiny bit of chocolate. I like it but dont love it.

Black with large long lasting tan head. Unfortunately the appearance is the best thing about this beer. Aroma is faint choco. Taste is light bland bittersweet choco. I like the aftertaste most of all.
bottle.  Dark brown with a nice tan head. Nose was of roast malt and oats.  taste was definitely malts with some oats.  Mouthfeel was medium with a dry finish.  Decent.

Bottle Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Poured  dark brown with a dissipating off white head  Aroma was roasted malt, dark fruit and a touch of hop. Flavour was slightly sweet with roasted malts n oats. Finished nicely bitter with hints of licorice and  bitter sweet chocolate.  Would seek out again.

0.355 l bottle. Almost black dark brown color with small head. sweetish and roasty aroma wtih salty licorice and a hint of grass. The flavor is also sweetish and roasty with coffee, salty licorice,  toffee and fruity esters. Dryes up to coffeish finish. Rich and fairly full bodied. Tasty but I could not pick any oatmeal character.

This is one fine brew. Very dark stout, and very smooth and rich. Slightly sweet, without a bitter aftertaste. 

I have had this one several times, but not for a long time. I had forgotten how good it really is. Excellent.

Pours completely black, just a few tiny garnet highlights when held up to a bright light, with a huge fluffy brown head that lasts very nicely.  Nose is fairly faint black malts, not much coffee or chocolate, just a lot of barley.  It is a tiny bit smoky.  Flavour is more smoky than the nose.  Not overpoweringly so, just nice.  There are a lot of dark malts, and it is pretty sweet.  Very creamy and smooth.  Excellent beer.

Poured from a 550 bottle.
Look was DARK brown, almost black, with a tiny tan head.
Aroma of cocoa beans, coffee, caramel malts, dark chocolate bars, and just a little bit of hops.
Tasted a lot like it smelled, with a very well balanced sweetness. There was some stale cold coffee, malt, dark chocolate, and a slight bitter hop.
The mouthfeel was thick and creamy. dry and chewy. It left a trail of foam/cream down the middle of my tongue all the way down my throat. The mouthfeel was absolutely perfect.
Overal a fantastic stout. I could drink this all winter, by the sip, or by the chug.
Thanks to CaryTheDude for this one. Dark pout with big, tan pour. Aroma of  CoCoWheats, milk chocolate. Flavor is Dark chocolate and oatmeal. A bit dry finish. For my first Samuel Smith, I dug it.
Black with large long lasting tan head. Unfortunately the appearance is the best thing about this beer. Aroma is faint choco. Taste is light bland bittersweet choco. Not much else to say.
THis much flavour in a 5 percenter is a great feat. the sessionable stout with a big, slightly sweet flavour profile. If it had more of a nose it would be absolutely amazing

550ml bottle from the LCBO as part of a Samuel smith Gift pack with a glass
The aroma is nice toffee and chocolate smells wonderful
Pours a nice pitch black with lots of long lasting creamy off white head good lacing all the way down the glass 
The taste is bittersweet like semi sweet dark chocolate it is very creamy and rich
Pours tar black with a soapy off-white head.  Aroma is dark chocolate and brown sugar.  Flavor is dry with coffee beans and a slightly milky flavor.  Finishes bitter with a dark chocolate taste.

From 550 ml bottle.  You can tell from the opening of the cap that you’re about to enjoy a fantastic stout.  The aroma is great, strong and thick, if you can consider thick to be an aroma.  Deep brown to black color, great dark tan head.  The myriad of flavors includes some mellow chocolate, some burnt wood notes, and roasted malt.  The overall impression of the flavor ends up much fuller than the 5% ABV would lead you to expect, the bitter flavor is not too bitter to where you cannot taste any of the sweetness, which is by no means cloying.  This is a great beer, and one of the best stouts out there, in my humble opinion.

This is my favourite stout bar none, silky smooth texture. Chocolate and nutty full flavour but not overpowering. The only thing I don’t like is the cost but hey you have to pay a little for perfection.

550 ml bottle from a LCBO gift pack. pours with a perfect stout appearance into my new sam smiths pint glass. opaque black with a mid tan head that lasts and lasts. sexy laces all down the glass. aromas of roasted malts, mostly chocolate, some toffee, noticeable hops. flavours are duller then the aromas and a little thin. all roasted malts in the mouth with a touch of bitterness on the finish. the mouthfeel is quite silky and fuller then the 5% abv would lead you to believe. this is a damn fine stout that i wish was availible year round.

Remarks
Big foamy lacy light espresso head.Clear dark rich red bronze black color.Mellow roasted chocolate mild hop front.Creamy oatmeal silky mellow roasted oatmeal chocolate cookie bisquit mild fruit body.Mild hop bittersweet clean easy end.Small English Stout.

(550ml bottle at home on October 29, 2008) This is a work of art.  Gorgeous brown head, perfectly thick and clingy lacing, and a solid nearly-black brew!  Smells thick and malty and bitter.  It’s obvious this is a stout.  Its taste... fantastic. Creamy, sweet, roasted, slightly bitter.  A little woodsey.  I like it, always have. Has a slightly metallic flavor, but nothing lingering.  Despite its thickness, this brew goes down sweet and easy... Sam Smith makes good beers...

550 mL bottle.  Almost black, with a thich brown head that reduces, but never quite disappears.  Aroma is not strong, but is very pleasant; roast, a slight acidity, a sweetness underneath.  Flavour is not overwhelming either, with some roast, some malt sweetness, some milk chocolate, some bitterness.  It just works.  Incredibly smooth, lingering, creamy finish.  Very well done.
Good stout. Bittersweet taste. Surprisingly silky texture. Palate is medium-dry. I like to drink stouts alot and this one was very good.

Good solid stout. Mild nose of malty sweetness and a pleasant, milky sweet lift. Palate shows the attractive sweet kick but this dries out relatively quickly through some mild bitterness and astringency. Not sure what the fuss is about here and surprised the beer is a 98%er.

Pours thick black, with a hefty tan head that leaves nice lacing behind. Roasted sweet lactic aroma, with some chocolate. Lightly roasted, similarly milk chocolate sweet flavor. Velvety smooth palate, a very good beer, but it really should be considered a sweet stout.

Coffee like taste--sits on the tongue--slides down smoothly. Great after taste. Splendid Oatmeal Stout. Felt less masculine though after reading up on it, as it was originally produced for lactating mothers ; still would drink it any day.

This beer is balanced really well. The flavors are straight up the middle and represented well. sweet but dry, smoky but bright, smooth but sharp. a touch too much wood and smoke maybe? its really hard to criticize. Setting standards for stout makers.

550mL bottle from my mixed gift pack. Pours what is, by stout standards, a ’light’ colour. Smells very faint of stoutness, I guess. What strikes me the most about this stout is just how sweet it is, I can’t believe it’s not listed as a sweet stout. There’s absolutely NO bitterness. Good thing I like sweeter stouts. Very velvety smooth. Caramel is apparent, mild milk chocolate, coffee, with the most subtle hint of roasted malts, but no detectable bitterness. Almost dry in the aftertaste, but not really. Extremely drinkable and tasty, there just really isn’t much in there. Quite mild, but well done.

Great stout.  Pour is jet black small tan head.  Nose of soy, leather, roasted almost burnt malt, chocolate, and toffee.  Flavor is very rich complex.  Light oats, bitter with chocolate, coffee, molasses.  Loved it!

Very black pour, like a black hole with just the slightest hint of a tan head reminding us that there’s life out there somewhere. Extremely roasty mouthfeel that warms the palate and the belly as it slides on down. This beer just makes a guy feel loved and at home with the world. Superb.

Pours  very dark with a decent tan  head. Aroma of roasted malts. Sweet oats, detect a metallic aroma, Taste sharp metallic to a very smooth mouth feel,very slight bitter finish, very smooth, metallic taste kills this one.

dark dark brown color, quickly disappearing tan head, nice lacing.  sweet, sweet roasty malt aroma.  flavor of dry fruit, sweet malt which, thankfully, is not very cloying.  hint of roasty malt.  oily smooth mouth feel, bitter sweet finish.   a tad (caster) too sweet for me, but not an unappreciated brew.

Bottle. Pours darkest brown, lighter around the edges, with a fluffy tan head that dissipates into a creamy film. Nose is roasty, with some licorice, espresso, just a hint of dark fruit and even a whiff of oats in there also. Smooth and a bit sweet, without a hint of harshness. Taste is smooth and roasty, a hint of acidity, a nutty quality from the oats, hint of molasses, and a dry, espresso-like roastiness in the finish. Mouthfeel is silky smooth but light, with a subdued, light carbonation. Superbly balanced and drinkable offering perfectly in line with the generally stellar quality of other Sam Smith products.
Bottle, 550 ml.  Malt, roasted, dark coffee  chocolate and some fruit in aroma. Very dark brown color with a persistence brown foam.Very Creamy palate.

The aroma is of very dark roasted barley. And a little alcohol. It pours black with a light brown sugar thick head. Thick beautiful laticework. The flavor is pretty good. Very malty but not overly sweet like a milk stout. Very balanced with a little bitterness. The mouthfeel is outstanding. Realy. It’s very smooth but it has a kinda...good grittiness on the tongue. I guess it might be called dry? I think that might be my favorite aspect of this beer ( the mouthfeel.)

Dont know any lactating mothers whod take the challenge for this one! Aroma of a campfire-aged, dark coffee and roasted malts Thick light brown foamy head whithering into quickly disspating lacings leaving a lingering smoky finish. Took a few tries with this one....bet I will come back for a "refresher" course!

Pours a dark amber color with a tan foamy head.  Aroma of roasted malts.  
Sweet caramel initial flavor with a slighly bitter finish.
Malt sour fruit aroma. Very dark brown color with a small brown head. Sweet strong malt with oat and fruit mix. Creamy palate.

55cl. Aroma is rich with roasted chocolate malt--lightly sweet and deep with very mild hop aromas. Caramel head quickly swallowed by the beer. Pleasantly sweet with a balanced bittern finish. It’s a bit viscous and has a very even and pleasing mouth feel. I don’t want it to end.

Black in color with a medium sized light brown head.  The aroma is of oats, chocoalte and alcohol.  The flavor is suprisingly sweet for a stout, with notes of coffee, oats and chocolate.  The palate is creamy.  Overall I’d say its a very good stout.  The english sure know how to make a good beer...I’M A FAN!

Pours black (obviously) with a tan head that settles quickly. Aroma is of wood smoked malt, fruit, coffee, licorice, and brown sugar. Taste is of sweet chocolate malt, a little hop tang followed by a silky oatmeal finish. Wow! This is amazing. Paired with some raw oysters and clams my wife brought home - I was in heaven!
This was beer number 23 for me at beerfest.  I tasted oatmeal.  This girls at the tent were friendly.  Very unique in my experience, the beer not the girls.

sweet and roasty oat(y) aroma - nice off-white head with great lacing.  Poured a dark dark amber allowing little light thru.. just enough to see the amber tint.  Very smooth and creamy palate and flavor.   Nice oatmeal flavor with a dry finish - very nice thick palate.  Flavor is very nice and I think better than many of the Oatmeal Stouts that I have tried.  I think I like the Bells Kalamazoo better but this is very good.

Cheers.

Very mild roasted grainaroma with almost no coffee to speak of. Esters low at best and very little hop aroma. Overall this beer really lacks in aroma all together.Closer to medium brown than black and somewhat thick.Started off with a 1.5 inch head that lasted about 3 minutes, then finished to an 1/8 inch. Sweet yes, all be it closer to heavy versus medium. Definite oat with dark roasted grain along with a nutty flavor that compliments well. Diacetyl  level closer to medium high with toffee flvor and slickness that does not take away from the beer. Very little hop flavoer if any. Full body, very smooth and creamy. Very sweet upfront, oats and slight toffee taste. It finishes dry and clean with a wonderful aftertaste. I drank this close to room tempature and the carbonation was medium.I feel that for the most part this beer fits its style catagory closely and it makes for a great beer. I will drink it again for sure and foer many reasons.It tastes amazing, low in alchohol for the flavor and very drinkable. This could be a session beer for a regular RIS drinker.

Pours thick like maple syrup, very dark black colour. Tan, almost oatmeal coloured head. The nose has cloves, and  brown sugar. Taste is great, it has molasses, brown sugar and a subtle oat meal finish. The mouth feel is very velvety and just glides down your throat.

Black as midnight, sweet as the morning dew.  Very good stuff here.  Nice stout flavor, subtle oatmeal sweetness balance this out perfectly, not too thick, and goes down quite easily.  This is one to try if your not too fond of traditional bitter stouts, yet are a bit curious about the darker beers.  Deeelicious!!!!

35.5cl bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown to black with a massive, pillowy and foamy tan head that settles slowly and gracefully laces the glass. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of maple syrup, honey, toffee, and maybe just faint hints of coffee. Flavor has much stronger roasted malt and coffee notes with fainter hints of caramel, honey and toffee. Some ripe dark fruit notes as well. Generally medium to full-bodied with a sweet malt and slightly bitter coffee finish.
An easy drinker here, but if you were expecting a big beer, you’ll be disappointed. Basically a Guinness with a little anise, licorice, and chestnut flavors thrown in. Good, but nothing special.

Poured a dark brownish black.  Thick tan head with decent retention.  Toasted malt aroma and lots of coffee malts in the flavor.  Taste is a tad burnt, but not bad.  A hint of toffee sweetness.  A very nice stout.

Pours dark mahogany with a 2-3 finger tan head that lasts and leaves a little lacing. Aroma is rast malt, chocolate, and fresh baked granola. Flavor is very sweet at first, a little oatmeal molasses cookies (just like mom used to make?), and roast malt. Followed by a rich wave of barely sweetened mocha coffee and a little bitter hops for a second right at the end. Mouthfeel is smooth, almost slick at first, dry overall. A great winter snack in a bottle!

Bottle.  Pours a clear dark reddish brown with a 2 finger light tan head and minor lacing.  Nose is sweet malt, light roasted barley and mild coffee.  Taste is brown sugar, light chocolate, burnt caramel malt and a mild, coffee finish.  Mouth feel is fairly light for the style.  Its just ok, but highly drinkable.
Very, very nice stout.  Flavors are subtle until the finish when a huge rush of dark chocolate and coffee hit home.  Even though it’s a little watery, still damn good.
Bottle. Very smooth and easy accross the palate. aroma of vanilla. A light sweetness with a short finish.  My friend said it tasted like an outmeal cookie and i agree. Great beer!!

550 ml bottle. Dark brown body,starting off with a huge tan head. Impressive lacing. Smell of even amounts of malt, coffee with cream and chocolate. The taste starts out with a creamy mouthfeel that has the taste and nuttiness of sugared coffee and finishes with a thinner dark fruit taste.

A very nice stout. Pours a deep, deep brown with a thick tan head. Aroma of roasted grains, espresso and a hint of sweetness and molasses. Excellent full flavor that finishes on a slightly bitter note; just a touch of hops. Quite smooth. Not quite as thick as some. Overall, highly recommended.
Getting notebook online. Bottle. Rich full color with dark head. Sweet creamy scent. Taste is creamy to start turns to fruity dry finish. Sweetness grows as you go, pretty good, very refreshing.
550 mL bottle. Pours black with thin tan head. Smells of sugared coffee. Taste is smooth up front with a thick licorice finish, not very pleasant. Mouthfeel is full and velvety.
Pint bottle.  Pours black with a tan head.  Taste of chocolate and coffee.  Really smooth and goes down easy.
Pours black with tan head. Strong coffee-oatmeal aroma with a matching bitter flavor. Fine dark beer.
Pours dark with foamy head.  Smells sweet.  Tastes like mollases and raisons with chocolate.

A deep brown, mahogany color and slight garnet hue when held up to the light.  A full, thick, tan foam head with good retention.  Lace sticks well to the sides of the glass throughout.  Good clarity.
Coffee malt aroma.  Some mild roast.  Little hop.
Inititial sweetness with roasted grain.  Mild chocolate/coffee notes leading to a nutty dry finish.
Full body, medium carbonation, with a slick oily texture on the lips.  Very creamy.  Slight bitterness probably from the roasted grain and not the hops.
A very enjoyable beer.
Black dark brown pouring beer. Rich roasted malts with aromas of molasses and fruity raisins. Cereals in aroma and flavour too. Balancing bittering hops.
Bottle.  Poured a dark brown into an imperial pint glass.  Small brown head.  Aroma of oatmeal, molasses and bitter chocolate.  Flavor is simlar to the aroma.  Love me some Samuel Smiths.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2008 This has another great (and somewhat mysterious) Samuel Smith label.  A big, bubbly head and an earthy, molasses-like aroma.  This is pretty smooth and hoppy for a stout.  I guess the oats add mildness and a light, bready taste.  It is a full brew, but still pretty easy and drinkable.  There is just the right amount of sweetness, and I could also taste coffee and a touch of prunes.  The finish has a hop tingle to it.  This is not as awe-inspiring as their imperial, but it is still another winner from an excellent brewer.  Viva Tadcaster, whatever you may be!

This is a different kind of porter. It pours black with a huge tan head. The aroma is of chocolate with barely no hops. The taste is very similar tothe aroma. Roasted malts with lots of chocolate. Some cereal taste to it as well. Low carbonation with a "milky" feel. The thing that stands out the most is the low hops. Very porter done in a traditional, artesanal way. A+

Pours a pitch black with a half-inch beige head with great retention & minimal laceing. Aroma is light fig, grainy, carob, subdued but engaging. Taste is not as sweet as I would have expected after tasting the imperial. Dry, oaty, creamy, grainy, lightly roasted. Light hopping, nice (if brief) finish. A bit watery, though. A touch on the thin side, however still nice and creamy with decent carb. Not exactly what I was expecting,

From bottle.  Part of a Dayton Beer Tasting July event. Paired with Chocolate Guinness Cake.  Pours dark brown with a tan head. Molasses and coffee on the nose. Very silky mouthfeel - not overblown.  Chocolate finish that lingers.

Pours a deep black with a brown head.  The aromas are chocolate and seem smooth.  The flavors are delicious!  It is chocolately, very smooth, and malty.  The body is heavy with low carbonation.  I really enjoy the smoothness of this stout and the low level of bitterness is a nice change of pace.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a nice and big foamy head.  Aromas are a little fruity with a kind of balsamic/soy edge to it.  Flavor has a lot of oats and cocolate with a bit of creaminess to it.  Nice stuff.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Aroma of dried fruit (craisins) with a hint of salt and pepper. Delicious, rich taste...the finish reminds me of Triscuits and Valdosta pecans.. Smooth and clean palate, not too much aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Pours a very dark color with a nice thick head.  Has aromas of sweet roasted malts.  The flavor is much the same.  It is sweeter than what I had been expecting, though not too sweet.  The finish is well balanced and creamy.  This is a very nice brew, especially when the leaves change and the cooler crisp air moves in.  I really enjoy this beer.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2008 Pours deep dark brown, almost black, with tan head, dissipates quickly.  Milky, chocolately aroma with hints of dried cherries and molasses.  Tastes creamy and sweet, feels silky and smooth in the mouth.  The balance and carbonation are great, and I love the cocoa aftertaste.

From Superbest, Aarhus, DK.
Bottled.
Black with brown head. Aroma is malt and roasts. Flavor is malt with an oily palate. Nice bitterness.

Bottle:  Pour is medium clear dark with a fizzy yet creamy head.  Aroma is of chocolate, light burnt malt, sweet oats, and a lot of malt.  Carbonation is spot on making this brew silky to the touch.  Flavors began with sweet cocoa, creamy oats, moving to a ton of malt, and finally finishing with a hint of hop and the residual cocoa.  Damn good brew.  Complex and delicious.

~Pours black with big foamy brown head.
~Roasted malt scent, yet very fruity and with nice chocolate scent. Smells very nice.
~Flavor starts off light and then quickly turns a sweetish sour toasted malt chocolate flavor.
~Smooth and creamy feel. Silky really is a good word for it. Slight tongue tingles as well. This beer feels great. 
~ Yet another very good beer from Samuel Smith. The taste is a bit light, but has lots of flavoring which makes it nice to drink. This beer is definitely one I will have to share. I really like Samuel Smith beers. I am glad I decided to give them a try and they are fairly easy to find.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 550 mL bottle, pint glass.  Pours dark brown, almost black, with an enormous pile of tan suds.  Aromas of vanilla and toast.  Initially greets the mouth with a seltzer water buzz, then drinks smooth and creamy, very full bodied.  Flavors of vanilla and cream, sweet but not overly so.  Hints of raspberry in the background. Muted finish. Afterwards, vanilla lingers in the throat, fruit on the lips.

550ml bottle at the Princess Louise, 15th August 2008. Near black with a brown tint. Beige head that leaves good lacing. Nose of oats and cream. Full bodied and creamy with a smooth, roasted malt flavour. Good but not quite excellent.

550 ml. bottle. Pours a lovely dark brown, bit of exuberance in the light tan head initially, then settling down, minimal lacing, nose of malt, cocoa, taste initially malt layers, ending with a bit of mild hop. Very mild sweetmess, good mouth feel. Thoroughly enjoyable on a cloudy rainy day.

Pours pretty much black. The aroma is nice, with some sweet candy, grain, malts and chocolate. The taste is smooth, rich, and full of chocolate, oatmeal, and cream. Very well balanced and a nice blend. I like it.

Pours a little lighter brown than, say, Guinness or Beamish.  Full palate, very light bitterness...not at much bite as a lot of stouts.  Finishes sweet.  My uncle recommended this one to me...my respect for him just shot up quite a bit!

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown, nearly black, with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of oatmeal malt, and a hint of chocolate.  Flavor of complex malts, oatmeal, chocolate, with a strong bitterness.  Mouthfeel is creamy, with excellent body.  Very good beer, much better than I remembered it.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2008 Small bottle, pours black with a creamy tan head, dark roasted malt, hint of burnt malt, chocolate, licorice in the background, some vanilla cream aroma (from oatmeal?), flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, some bitterness from roasted malt, mouth feel is thin, does not have more mouth feel (oomph!) then your typical lager, I was expecting abit more of it like I had gotten in some other stouts, a good tasty stout but this could use a bit more mouth feel.
Dark brown in color. Rich aroma of malts an chocolate. Smooth taste of malts, nuts, chocolate, and oats. A bit carbonated for a stout but still a fantastic treat for me.

this is a strange one to rate for me.  it’s one of the first "good" beers I was ever into.  and I also spent some quality time with it while traveling abroad.  I’ve had it  many a times, but...  haven’t tried in a couple years and didn’t know if it would stand up to my current snobby tastes.  well, it does.  in fact, I’m kicking myself for not drinking this more often.  it’s one of the better stouts I’ve had.  for the rating:  bottle.  black pour with a big tan head that sticks.  aroma of chocolate, coffee, cereal, cookies and toffee.  malts and light chocolate are well balanced in the taste.  creamy full bodied palate.  great stuff.
bottle:  strong aroma, dark, muddy appearance.  Strong oatmeal flavor, some after taste in the finish.  Overall not bad, just not my favorite...

Very smooth, smells like roasted malts, nuts, chocolate....  The body is silky and the taste is sweet and chocolatey. Almost too creamy for me, the bottle size is too big for me to take in, better to share with a friend the next time.
Dark brown, Sweet, Dark chocolate, oats, roasted malts, dark fruits, creamy, smooth,  with a slight bitter finish.
Oh .... yeah. Dark pour, soft but brilliant aroma, silky feel in the mouth. Creamy body. Complex series of flavors. Lovely aftertaste. Gimme more.

Bottle->plastic cup (all we had): Pours a large, rocky, off-white head that exhibits good lacing atop a black body.  Aroma is of cereal, lemon, and horse blanket and a metallic aroma.  The body is medium, the texture is thin, carbonation is fizzy, and the finish is metallic.  The flavor’s duration is short, it is mildly sweet, lightly acidic and finishes like sour milk.

Poured a reddish black color with large head. Aroma is sweet like bakers chocolate and oats. Taste is smooth at first and leaves you with a slightly bitter tongue. Overall an excellent Stout and easy to drink.

550 mL bottle.  Pours dark brown with a large off-white head.  Aromas of dark fruit, dark chocolate, roastiness.  Flavor is roasty, chocolate, sweet, hint of raisin.  Creamy palate with a roasty chocolate finish.  Mild lacing.  Very nice stout.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 I was EXTREMELY excited to try this beer but I have to admit that I was very disappointed.  It hits the mouth almost like a soda, its very bubbly and carbonated for a stout.  Ill have to hope that I didnt get a bad one and try it again in the future.
Smooth, with sweetness and even a actual hint of oatmeal. Not hoppy at all, one of the best stouts out there.

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown/coffee color with some red coming through when held up to a light.  Has a thin, silky tan head that lasted a good while.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and oat.  The taste is much the same, excpet it is slightly sweet and has a nice bitter finish.  A rather exceptional beer, as it is delicious tasting and incredibly easy to drink as it is so smooth.  Well worth the money it costs and is a beer that I look forward to having again.

Comes out in a similar manner to the pale ale but the head and carbonation last much longer.  The froth is coarse and large with big chesty bubbles.  Very black in colour with 

tinges of red in the light.  Bubbles rise from the bottom of the glass long after the pour.

I could perceive malt loaf, toffee and caramel in the nose, and coffee, bitter dark chocolate and quakers oats (of course) in the taste.  Got an unexpected fizz from this stout. Excellent lacing, almost like watching a film comprised of vignettes as it descended the glass. No compromise.

Surprisingly light for a stout, but with a complex aroma and flavour. i expected a little more body but nothing to much to complain about. Improves as it warms but experienced a slightly metallic finish.

Great beer all round and i much prefer this to the pale ale.

pours similarly to sam smith’s taddy porter, but with a lighter colored head and more lacing. Decent aroma- chocolate, coffee, sweet notes. Flavor is greatttt- malty deliciousness. Phenomonally smooth. Great beer, especially considering its common availability.
The ultimate example of this style.  Sweet and smooth and tasty.  Ubiquitous, one of the best beers you can get basically the world over.
550 ml bottle.  Very dark pour.  Mild clean aroma.  Refreshing and easy to drink.  Quite light, thin and mild overall, but with a prolonged pleasing aftertaste.

Bottle 12 oz. Pours deep brown with a small light brown head. Nose is sweet malt with some roasted notes. Taste is smooth and light with the oats finishing up the taste well. After taste is very pleasing.

Pours very dark, with a light brown/white head.  Great overall flavor, definatly taste the oats.  Smooth finish.  I am impressed and will have again.  Aroma is not overwellming but the aroma that hits the nose is that of a good stout.  Again very impressed.

Dark brown/black pour with a creamy long lasting tan head.  Aroma seemed to be a bit light, but there was some definate sweet roastiness.  Flavor is better.  Sweet dark caramel malt and chocolate, plus roasted coffee and grain.  Palate is just a little thin, but still overall a very nice stout.

Opaque black with a long lasting off-white head. Mild roasted aroma. Taste is slightly bitter with a non-bitter finish and a sense of the oatmeal...drinks like a meal. Quite a good stout and a great alternative to the usual Guinness, especially at the low prices (under $3 USD for a Pint bottle) this can be had for. Will recommend this to all stout drinkers.

Aroma - Stout
Appearance - Stout
Flavour - Cooper-ish
Pallete - easy... very easy
Overall impression - KIller drop. sits between coopers stout & the fabled coopers Vintage stout

Bottle. Pours very dark brown with a tan head. Sweet aroma, with bread, dough, oats, and coffee. Medium body, smooth, a little thin for a stout. Flavor is way more roasted than the aroma lets on, with notes of coffee, toast, and grass. A great beer, usually my dinner beer of choice.

Bottle 50 cl. Pours a dark brown with a light brown head. The nose is pale with tofee notes. The taste is more vinous than i remember but still with hints of the oats, chockolate and cofee. It has a rather bitter finish. For stouts I prefer a heavyer and thicker palate - this one is too waterish

A smooth oatmeal stout but it lacks the backbone and full bodiedness I would like in a stout. The color was nice and the head was good. It was good and I would go back here but it just didn’t sit on my palate long enough though when it was there it was tasty for a bit.
This dark brown ale poured with a fluffy tan head and an oatmeal aroma. The flavor is chocolate malt with a bready oatmeal presence, a bitter coffee finish and a bit of carbonation.

Always reliable Sam Smith.  Pours a black/brown, light tan colored head.  Smells of a slightly overcooked oatmeal cookie.  Nice roast coffee and chocolatey tones.  Just enough carbonation.  Warms very well.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a dark brown almost black with a thick creamy head. Aroma is sweet and malty but has some fruity notes. Flavor very sweet and creamy. Very bready in the start but has some fruit tartness in the finish. Full bodied and thick, it sticks the whole way down to a nice bitter finish. A great example of an oatmeal stout that isnt too overwhelming.
