Dark, opaque color. Tastes of roasted malt, coffee, and dark chocolate. Also a bit creamy. Flavor sticks to the palate after you drink it (which I do enjoy). It ends a little  bitter for and oatmeal stout. Overall and excellent beer, I would encourage everyone to try it.

Pours dark as black coffee with a big creamy head that doesnt want to quit.  Aromas of espresso, brown sugar, and nuts with a hint of dry foliage(!); hops are not terribly assertive here.  Bold, dark malts like burnt caramel up front followed by definite toast flavors.  Palate is balanced between sweet malts and roasted malt bitterness.  Very smooth texture and full body.  Long, clean finish.  Probably best consumed between 55-60 F.

Very nice beer. I had a bottle of the Imperial stout before this one and  it was awesome. This beer pored nicely and smelled nice as well. The taste was very nice. It didnt have the burnt flavor I expected. Highly recommended for fans of stout.
bottle- nice sharpness to this stout. clean, chocolate flavors, with a decent mouthfeel, but not as silky as I would like given the style and name. Roasted malt present as well. Decent.

Appearance: Black, loads of head. Not longlasting.
Aroma: Pretty malty. Hint of coffee and chocolate.
Taste: Malt and burnt coffee. Bitter.
Info: 550ml bottle, 18/4-2006, 103/300, 59/500
Pours black with a tiny tan head.  Roasted flavor with sweetness and mild bitter finish.

bottle thanks to metzlers in denton, tx.  pours a black with red hues.  beige/brown head that seemed to last forever.  the aroma blew me away i hope it will be as good as it smells.  the nose had malt, sweet and floral as well. flavor is equally as impressive as the aroma.  flavor was caramel, dark roast, hints of coffee.  this was a remarkably smooth beer.  felt like velvet across the tongue.  this one is amazing!!
Bottle. Black colour with large creamy brown mostly lasting head. Aroma is roasted malt with strong notes of chocolate. Sweet flavor with notes of chocolate and coffee. Creamy palate.

One of my favorites.
Pours black. Smells of oats and chocolate. Tastes of coffee, oats, malt. Its sweet but balanced. Love it.

Pours a dark dark brown, opaque. 2 Finger, tan head.Aroma is mild, slightly sweet, and little bit floral. Taste is...admittedly complex. It seems like theres so much going on here. Caramel and/or coffee malts, something of a licorice taste. Then theres something a bit nutty. It certainly gets better as you go. Im not completely sold on it, however it is good. Smooth. Tasty. Definitely a solid stout.
Bottle. Awesome!  Sweet and flowing with Creamy malty heaven!  You have not had a stout, till you have had the sammy smiths! A must!
Dark. black colored brew. Nice sweet, chocolate malty aroma. Creamy, malty, chocolate, sweet. Overall nice one.

really enjoyrd this one.Oh sweet bitterness.Black with a creamy medium brown head. Virtually no lace. Aroma of black and chocolate malts, Taste of chocolate malt also, with just enough hops to balance the malt sweetness.

Fantastic brew that I really enjoyed a lot. At the right temperature the nose blows me away. Great stout with a nice, creamy palate. Super malty- chocolate, toasted, brown sugar taste. Not very bitter. I really enjoyed this beer, this is probably one of my favorite stouts ever.

Aromas started coming out quite slowly, maybe too cold at the beginning. Lots of brown sugar, some chocolate, maybe even some bananas... Very dark with a great ever-lasting dark tan head. Sweet malts dominate the flavors, then some chocolate and roasts. Nice body, although not very chewy, more on the watery side but still right. A very nice sweet stout. So nutritive it could be my everyday breakfast from now on...

Bottle.  Pours a dark black with a very nice, thick tan head.  Aroma of sweet malt, roast, coffee.  Flavor is super sweet, with lots of oatmeal, and some roasted malts.  The first time I had this I really enjoyed it, but this time I found it too artificially sweet.  Ok beer, but Im not impressed.  Palate is a little watery too.
UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 I enjoyed this one.  It had everything a stout should, but I fear my lofty expectations were not met.  Good beer though.

550ml bottle - gotta love the nutrition you get from this!  Very sweet with deep chocolate.  Pours out nice thick dark with light mocha colored creamy head.  Finishes lightly bitter but very long and sweet for the most part.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: I absolutely love this stuff. This was the first oatmeal stout I ever had. Its still the best Ive ever had. This truly is a meal in a bottle. Nice, dark color with a small, creamy head. Its sweet but not too sweet. The aftertaste is light yet lingers nicely. I buy these fairly often. Great beer by a great brewer! Still my favorite by them.

Poured thick and frothy with a nice creamy head. I found the aroma wanting but I may have a cold. Taste was good with a rich smoky roasted flavor. Its a bit sweeter than I like but most Oatmeal Stouts are.
The best oatmeal stout I have ever had.  Almost tastes like a Chocolate oatmeal cookie.  Absolutely delightful.  The girlfriend is a big fan too.

550ml bottle.  Very dark opaque brown, with  ruby edges. Tan frothy head that diminishes rather quickly, good lacing though.  Hints of molasses, toasted nuts, and coffee in the aroma.  Lively carbonation at first, yet smooth. Roasted oat, nutty, with a slight hint of coffee in the flavor.  Creamy. Light bitter aftertaste with a lingering nut taste.  Not as heavy as expected, I like it.

...bottle.  I have to say, this is pretty good.  Very smooth, velvety, with great balance.  Dark, roasted malt notes, blended with the oatmeal, make it very tasty, and goes well with a nice steak.  The finish is just enough to make you want more, worth a try, but it should be stronger to actually be a true stout.
Black with a grey head. Sweet aroma of chocolate and roasted malts. Very balanced flavours - relatively low on bitterness and dominated by roasted malts and cherry.

Pours black with long-lived, cream-colored head. Scent is sweet chocolate, licorice, and fruit. The flavor is also sweet, almost sickly, with roasted oats and chocolate and fruit. A great balance is throughout the nose and flavor. The creamy palate perfectly compliments the well-rounded smooth taste. A sweet finish to a very nice beer.

Sampled at Pints for Pets.  Pours a dark brown color with a light creamy head.  The nose is sort of grainy and roasted, but has a bit of wet dog.  Lots of oatmeal in the taste.  The flavor is ok, but I was definitely disappointed.  A sort of bittersweet molasses flavor.  A decent body, but I thought it was a little thin.
A deep black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roated malt and biscuit.  Flavor is a touch of sweetness with that roasted malt.  A nice finish,  good beer.

nice and dark with a rich tan head. slightly sweet with a rich coffee and mapo nose. some kind of fruit and nut combo with a touch of lacing and body out the wazoo. For wat it is it is nearly flawless.

12 oz bottle...poured very dark brown w/ a frothy tan head that yielded some lacing. The nose was malt, light coffee, toasted almonds. The flavors were light coffee, toasted nuts, cocoa. The palate was great. Not a heavy beer, with a quick, dry "tosted nut" flavor. Excellent!
aroma is roasted malt. pours almost black with tan head.  flavor is also roasty and malty with some oats.

Bottle,  Roasted malty aroma with a plum tinge.  Fizzy head, off white in color.  Fully diminishing head.  Blackish amber color.  Sweet initial flavor, medium body with a lively carbonation.  Definitely over priced for what you get.  Goose island or Bells will serve you much better.
Dark red colour. Small head. A quite good stout Some sweetness and chocolate taste.. Also some creaminess.

mmmmmmm the best beer that i tasted [for now] mmh!!! good look, a dark deep color, great brownie head, the taste is amazing, a little notes of caramel , coffe and sugar brown. In nouse is gentile, smooth. Great Beer!!! i enjoy it with one brownie cake and looking a NYC film.

From a 355 ml. bottle  marked SL06C1.  Samuel Smiths products are excellent and when I have some extra cash on hand I like to buy it.  This one is a favorite that pours very brown with a beige/tan frothy head that stays on top for most of the session.  The aroma is sweet and formidable aroma of chocolate or cocoa.  It has such a smooth mouth feel and goes down like cream.  This is one of the smoothest beers I have ever had.

Bottled brew that pours dark brown with a light beige head. Exciting aroma of fruit,nuts, roast and oats. Bit of sweetness and a bitter bite on the first sip, leading to an explosion of rich chocolate, butter, nuts, and grapes. Final aftertaste is lingering oatmeal and molasses (?). One of my favorites!

This is likely my favourite stout, possibly favourite beer at the moment. Its dark and smooth, which is  me all over. Bold coffee and charred something, dont quite know what but it works. If you wanna get into semi-widely distributed stouts, start with this, and expect to work your way down. I think this beer is flawless.

This is a really solid stout, one of the smoothest and best malt profiles I can remember. For only being 5% the weight on the palate and malt depth is very impressive. Soft burnt characters, dark chocolate, that oatmeal smoothness you get. Subtle dark cherry comes through as it warms.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 550 ml in Chicago but can be found everywhere in Chapel Hill and Carrboro. This is fantastic! Massive head for a stout- about two fingers. Aroma is of raisins and chocolate. Initial taste though is creamy and ultra smooth with some malt and bitter sweet chocolate. Body is creamy but still fairly light with I guess the oat flavor coming out, which is new for me. Very drinkable with a slightly bitter malt aftertaste. Reminds me a great Oyster Stout though I reckon this one would be heaps better with seafood than Guinness or an Oyster Stout.
550ml bottle, pours to thick, brown ale,  good sweet smell to it, not overpowering, a slight sweet malt taste, balanced well and is very smooth, cream taste

This is one of the best stouts I have ever had. Nice balance between sweetness and bitterness. Head is nice and light brown in color, very creamy tasting. The taste gets sweeter the closer you are to the end of the glass. Overall, one of the best, if not the best beer I have had.

Pours a deep reddish-black with a large, tan head.  Sweet aroma, hints of maple sugar and chocolate.  Not a heavy bodied beer, but very smooth.  Light bittersweet chocolate and roasted malts prevail in the flavor department.  A good, old standard, just not as impressive as some of the newer, more extreme examples.

550ml bottle. Pours Dark brown with red around edges. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate milk, oat and some cream. flavor is roated malts, chocolate, cream and a little oat. Creamy in texured and a fine stout. Just not a favorite.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2008 Bottle at Harlows in Peterborough. Pours black as night. Oatmeal tan head rises magnificently and gracefully exits by halfway through the glass. Notes of oatmeal, cream, chocolate, some malt, in the aroma. Mouthfeel is top notch. Silky smooth, rich, surprisingly drinkable for such a full beer. Flavor is yeasty, chocolate, oatmeal, cream, vanilla, and a bit of hearty smoked meat. Finishes very smooth, with the mildest of hop bitterness. Really a superb beer, certainly my favorite stout, and the best Sam Smith.

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2009 2/1/08 notes:  bottle. Pours dark brown. Couldnt help but compare this to St. Ambroises Oatmeal stout. Despite somewhat light mouthfeel, this beer features a very creamy texture that feels amazing on the tongue.  Flavor is of roasts, milk, dark chocolate, and maybe oats.  Finishes pleasantly smooth and sweet.  Some toasted flavors round out this beer. My favorite Sam Smith offering.
6/10/09 update:  flavor is bready, milky, vanilla, malty, and with some vinous notes.  Oats contribute a touch of sweetness.  Palate is smooth, though thin.  Still a solid, decently priced offering.

55cl bottle. A pitch black beer with a fine but long lasting tan coloured head. Roasted malt nose with notes of raisins and chocolate. The flavour profile consists of a hearty oat backbone, supplemented by roasted malts, rich chocolate and fruity wine-like tones. Smooth, robust and slightly dry palate texture with a mild bitter finish, partnered by a lasting oatiness. Nicely balanced in all departments; a truly gorgeous stout.

I was anxious to try this dark stout after seeing good review.  Nice sweat coffee and roasted grain and chocolate aroma and flavor, but actually was surprising thin to me.  Kind of sour along the way without an over pleasant finish, at least for me.

Pours a very dark brown with an off white head. Aroma is of chocolate and cream, very sweet. Flavor is much the same, not too much bitterness to be found but well balanced at the same time. Good sweet stout.

Brewed in Tadcaster, North Yorkshire, England.  Has a vibrant roasted malt aroma backed by complex grainy notes and a tinge of alcohol.  When poured it develops a rich creamy tan head with superb brussels lattice and fills out an opaque deep brown (almost black) body.  On the sip, it displays an nice blend of oats and hops finishing mildly bitter with a dominant roasted malt flavor.  I love the texture of this beer!  Light, fluffy, carbonated mouth feel that goes down smooth from start to finish. It reminds me a lot of Guiness but better.  This is the first oatmeal stout Ive ever tried so my opinion may be bias , but this is a damn good beer. This would be a nice addition to a seafood dinner. Rating 3.8

A fantasic stout. 
The Aroma is of chocolate with light licorice aromas. The color is black and slightly opage, with a big lasting tan head, with plenty of lace. Taste is of oats, chocolate, with a very toasty malt flavor. 
Texture is creamy and very well rounded.

35.5 cL bottle. Pours dark brown with a redish glare and a slowly collapsing tan head. Mild roasted and smooth malt aroma. Smooth mouthfeel. Acidic roasted malt with a light smoke flavour. Light coffee-ish note too. Light acidic and mild smoke finish.

ABV: 5 %
Calories: estimated at 150 C
Volume: 12 fl oz bottle
Glass: concave pint
Purchased at: Circle Liquors Super Saver, Pennington, NJ
Price: $2.75
Consumed at: home

Impression: A rich, deep dark body with a thick tan head. Impressive for such a widely available beer. Almost impenetrable but has a deep ruby core in bright light. Deep, rich, and full flavor with good long aftertaste. Chocolate, roasted coffee, raisin, plum, and orange peel are evident. A very good example of a well crafted mass produced beer. Good finish and aftertaste. Enjoyable, drinkable, and with depth of flavor throughout.

Aroma: 8 out of 10

Visuals: 4 out of 5

Taste: 9 out of 10

Palate: 5 out of 5

Overall: 17 out of 20
Very dark pour. Powerful aroma if you let it warm up a bit. A sweet stout with syrupy molasses notes. Smooth, lingering finish. A great, sessionable beer.

2008 Bottle - Pours a thick black with an off-white head.  Aroma is of smoked oats and coffee.  Flavour is pleasently bitter and complex, but finishes very clean.  I will drink this again, a very respectable stout...

This is a lovely stout. Pitch black with an espresso colored head. Smells sweet with malt, dried prunes, and a hint of espresso. In fact, more than just a hint of espresso. The flavor is espresso, but a tad sweet. Leaves a sweet and sour taste on the palate. I have tasted better espresso, but this is a darned good beer.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2008 Bottle.  Pours black with fairly decent tan head.  Smells of raisins, coffee, very dark cocoa and burnt oatmeal.  Taste is fairly strong and complex.  The first thing that hits is the bitter, burnt coffee flavor.  This is followed by a sweeter, fruity raisin and brown sugar flavor.  The beer finishes with a flavor of burnt oats and malts, which lingers in the mouth and throat.  There is also something else in there... nuts perhaps?

This is a pretty heavy beer, even though the mouthfeel is fairly smooth.  It leaves a thick, burnt oat and dark cocoa flavor in your mouth which is quite tasty and not at all obtrusive.  Very rich, strong, smooth, and filling.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2015 355ml bottle (Kaisla, Helsinki) (6:4:8:4:13=3.5)
Practically black, thin head. Bizarrely, theres the aroma of mouldy cheese. However, theres also sweet dark fruits and coffee. The taste starts quite coffee-like, but as you let it sit in the mouth that builds up. And as you swallow, when the vapours rise up into the nose, it gets even stronger. Soft mouthfeel, good full body.  The taste has burnt raisins too. Rich and smooth, and very tasty.
Rerate: 355ml bottle (Pudel, Tallinn) (7:4:7:4:15=3.7)
Lovely roast aroma. Soy, some tar, later even a hint of oatmeal. Taste has bacon too. Delicious. Full smooth palate. So drinkable.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2008 Bottle pours dark brown with little tan head. Not much aroma but slight malt. I havent tried many stouts and this has a good clean malt flavor. Really smooth and not what I expected from a dark stout beer. Will buy again.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 Dark brown with satisfying head on it. aroma of oats and malt, and the taste explodes with roasted malts, nuts and oats shining through. Finish is nice and the body sits well on the tongue.

Bottle.  We tried this one for Sam at Crew in Poughkeepsie.  Poured a dark brown with a nice chocolate head.  The aroma was dissappointingly weak of roasted oats.  The taste was a bit stronger again of roasted oats and brown sugar.  It was a nice thick beer.
Bottle. Really good beer. Dark color and good roasted taste. I highly recommen this one!

550ml bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Sticks to the glass quite well. The aroma was a little weak, kinda smelled like Guiness, but roasty and malty nonetheless. Not a big fan of stouts (dont get me wrong, I absolutely LOVE imperial stouts, but thats a different league) although I really like how they look, this one is no exception. Flavor is malty, roasted and tastes like plain oatmeal with a small amount of melted chocolate mixed in with it. I really like the mouthfeel on this one, and it is quite refreshing. Again, not a huge stout fan, but this one is probably my favorite thus far.
bottle.  Pours nice and dark, thick tan head.  Aroma is all malty sweetness. Roasted malt/oatmeal/sweet flavor, smooth and syrupy, but not sticky.
Pours with a big, rocky, light brown head covering a black body. Sweeet honey and chocolate malt aroma with some oatmeel too. Sweet, grainey taste with chocolate. Syrupy mouthfeel.
UPDATED: MAY 6, 2016 Bottled. Sweet, musty, nutty aroma. Red-black body, light-brown head. Taste full, very silky palate. Mammi, sweet roasted coffee, long chocolatey finish.

12 ounce bottle-  pours out a promising mahogany brown with a huge cola-colored head.  Aroma was somewhat chocolate and malt.  Taste was a little disappointing.  Watery and weaker than expected, the creamy texture found in most stouts is missing here, thin bodied.  Maybe a good choice to introduce as someones first stout.  Needs some work.
wow..this is a beer that I grew up on...and still love....a great roasted malt flavor and super creamy mouthfeel.....great stuff....why cant all oatmeal stouts be this good?

1 finger tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and some caramel.  No hint of alcohol in flavor, roasted malt flavor.  Some mild hops, medium bodied.  Liked this slightly better than the imperial stout.

Pours dark but kinda thin with nice finely bubbled head that disappears kind of quickly.  Smells of chocolate and caramel predominate.  Taste smooth, clean, crisp with excellent and refreshing balance of sweet malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Finishes light with me wanting more.
This is a very smooth, eeasy drinking stout.  It does have a very slight taste of oatmeal, not very sweet and very litttle bitterness.
Looks and tastes like a stout should.  Plenty of complexity here, noting especially chocolate, smoke, roast malt, and of course, an oatmealy finish.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2008 This is a good stout. Even during my times when I did not like stouts I still liked this one. Black in color with a very thin tan head. You could certainly taste a hint of oatmeal and chocolate with some malts in the flavor. Very smooth and easy to drink. Finish is slightly bitter. Warming with a chocolate and oatmeal aftertaste. Very good."

Pours a frothy tan head. The smoothest tasting beer Ive ever tried. The taste is of choclate malts and a slight smoked flavor. Its a little sweeter than expected, but one of the better beers I have tried. I was expecting a bit more alchohol, but still a good catch. Not much of a wow bottle of beer, but definately is a good try and addtion for anyone wanting to try a new beer.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 Ive twice this one twice now. Both purchased at Finger Lakes Beverage, 12oz bottles.

Pours dark brown (black?), tan head. Very creamy, very smooth mouthfeel, tastes of oats, honey, and some chocolate. 

Again, this beer is NOT exciting, but not bad. At $2.75 per 12oz though, not worth drinking more than once or twice.

Black opal in color.   Mouth is somewhat of a  leather taste. creamy and a strong, linger of chocolate malts. Wasnt really into it, just missing that "wow" factor.  And I would of liked to see more alcohol in this.  I think SS has better offerings.

Pours very dark brown with a tan frothy head. Smells chocolate with a slight hint of smoke underneath. Nice feel on the palate, exactly what I would want out of a stout. Tastes of roasted malts and sweetness. One of my favorites.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2008 I was really excited to try this as the first real beer glass I bought was a Samuel Smith tulip and havent had any SS yet. Anyway, pint bottle, pours deep mahagony-red brown, small tan head. Rich nutty smell. Medium roasted taste, medium body, slightly bitter finish
Aroma is all dark malts and caramel. Pours a dark brown with tan head, excellent lacing. The flavor is sweet and so well blended, creamy almost like a spanish flan.

A significant beer for me, this one (on the recommendation of a friend) started me down this long path/hobby/obsession with good beer.  The pour is a near black brown with a pillowy tan head that lasts through the drink, looks like an oatmeal stout should is all I can say.  Lots of dark roasted malts in the nose and a nice feel in the mouth.  It has a weight to it without being creamy like some sweet stouts.  A fantastic stout taste accented by warm oatmeal in the finish.  A near perfect beer.
Oh hell yes.  Sweet and dark nectar! Perfect carbonation and wonderful malt notes wtih an amazing mouthfeel.  A winner for sure!

Pours a DARK brown (black) with a thin tan head.  Sweet roasted marshmallows.  Flavor is sweet and malty, with a fairly nice balance.  Palate is extra smooth (silky seems to be overused :-}).  Love the session strength.  Overall one of the best Oatmeal Stouts around.
Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is a black stout with a light cappuchino head. The aroma is malty and roasted and the flavor is very creamy and silky/smooth.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Re-rate 12/21/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks zvikar. Dark brown. Roasty, some chocolate, nuts, coffee hints, light fruitiness. Bittersweet. 7/3/7/3/14=3.4

(3/14/08) Bottle bought at De Bierkoning and drank at a friends house in Amsterdam. Black with medium light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, some oatmeal and some coffee notes. Sweet malty flavor with oatmeal and some drier roasted tones. Medium bodied and a smooth creamy mouthfeel. A good, well-made stout. 7/4/7/4/15=3.7

Pours an opaque black.  When holding my glass up to the light all I could see was a faint amount of light coming through the bottom.  Relatively thick brew, but still manages to go down smooth.  Has a great flavor that I hope to enjoy again and again.
Truly an excellent stout.  Distinct flavor that you dont grow tired of.  Toffee and bitter chocolate.  Mysterious and playful.

Perfect brew in my opp. 3,5 euro for a top brew. Beautiful dark-brown colour with a nice head. Sweet light-roasted smell with hints of bread. Big mouth fill, the oats really add the extra dimension. Aroma of burnt coffee, malt and aged wine! Has a very slight sour finish in the flavour which gives a wine like touch. Amazing what you can get out og just 5% alc. The Sam Smith brew imp.
Lightly sweet taste to it not too strong. Lighter bodied.Cant really taste the oatmeal part of it but I still enjoy it.
Overall rating is spot on. This is a great beer for those breaking into good beers.

Bottle poured into pint glass- poured very dark brown/black, nice light tan formed, medium carbonation, aroma of roasted malt, dark caramel, with notes of coffee and brown sugar.  Hits the mouth with a full and wide body, sort of just glides down your mouth which is interesting, malt comes through cleanly and there is plenty of it, finish is full and has a note of sweetness.  Very drinkable.

Pours black with a huge tan head. Aromas of roasted malts, coffee. Flvaor is slightly sweet and roasty. Full body with minimal carbonation and silky, creamy mouthfeel.  This goes down sooo easily I find myself through the bottle in no time. Excellent stout.

Bottle. Pours dark brown/black with a large lasting beige head. Aroma is semi-sweet at roasty---coffee, dark chocolate, caramel, and some bits of dark fruit. Flavor is caramel, dark fruit, cherry, a slight fruity tartness/sourness, roast malt, hint of earthy hops. Velvety but slightly thin mouthfeel. A great oatmeal stout, if a bit odd by the standards of others in the style.

Dark black, minimal carbonation.  Strong, off white head that sustains.  Thick lacing.  Coffee, caramel, roasted nose.  Effortless first taste - incredibly smooth, full-bodied of course, and a sweet aftertaste.  Rich and creamy, very fulfilling.

pours well looks great and the flavor is 1st rate. A well desirved 4.0this is the 2nd time I have tried it. Great winter beer as well. I say this and probably as most Americans have served it too chilled.

What a stout!  Pours black with a nice foamy, tan head.  Faint coffee-like aroma.  Underneath the toasted malt, coffee flavor one expects from a stout is a slight fruity flavor, like blueberries or rasberries.  Just a great complex flavor that isnt overwhelming.  Goes down very smooth.
Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is mildly roasted, as is the flavor with a pleasant sweetness coming through.  Very good overall.

The more stouts I consume, the more it appears they are my brew.  This is a delightful brew.  It has a nice malty aroma.  It is classically dark.  Its a full figured brew.  Its flavor is just awesome.  Its supra smooth, MEGA flavored with notes of very mild sweetness.  This is so super smooth, its a marvel.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2008 Nose is malty caramel and bitter roast.  Dark redish charcoal black, not quite opaque with a nice head with some retention, light lacing.  Flavor is very nice, somewhat complex blend of the lightest fruitiness, dark malts, and good bitterness for balance with a medium dry finish.  Mouthfeel is silky and nice, very drinkable.  Overall a very nice beer that show cases everything roasted barley and dark malts can be.
Brown black in coloer with a thich creamy white head.  Goes down a lot smoother than a Guiness.  very maly and full bodied.

Reddish brown in color.  Thick tan head that retains itself well and leaves some nice lacing.  Aroma is very very roasty with notes of coffee and nuts.  Theres also some sweet chocolate.  Taste is similarly roasty.  Lots of coffee with a little fruitiness.  Very malt-dominated and chewy.  Hard to tell if the mild bitterness in the finish is from hops or roasted malt.  Mouthfeel is extremely creamy and velvety, but with enough warmth becomes a bit watery.  A very tasty oatmeal stout, and one of SSs best beers.

Bottle.  Pours very dark brown with a thin, beige head.  Aromas of raisins, and coffee.  Big coffee and caramel flavors and, oddly enough, apples.  Medium-thin on the palate.  Good beer and if any stout is sessionable, this one is.
Dark brown in color with a good head.  Aroma has a little roastiness, toastiness, malts.  Taste has a good flavor with slight chocolate and the oats.  Medium body. Smooth and creamy.

(bottle thanks OSLO) Pours dark brown with a tan head that lasts.  Aroma is light berry, with some cocoa, toasted nut, and roasted malt.  Taste is pretty sweet with chocolate and a very light taste of roasted malt on the finish.  Pretty thin beer, and the flavors are pretty subdued.
Very dark, creamy flavor with a good malt flavor.  A hint of chocolate in there as well, definately can taste the oat flavor.  Very good, not as good as the imperial stout
This is one of my favorite beers dark and creamy with a bttersweet taste.A toasted malt flavor with a creamy head that has a off white color.

Pours deep chocolate with substantial caramel head that clings to glass. Smells of sweet caramel with oats and some nuttiness. Delightfully light, not as creamy as I anticipated. As close to perfect for my palate as possible. Delicate balance of sweetness and bitterness. This one goes down all too smoothly.
550 ml. into English pint glass.  Pours nearly black with thick head.  Aroma of chocolate, toffee, and oats.  Very smooth beer.  Sweet slides nicely into bitter.  A classic.

550ml. into pint glass.  Pours really dark with a healthy head that is foamy and tan (color resembles latte foam) and recedes pretty quickly.  It smells of oats and other traditional stout aromas (wheat, molasses, dark fruit, etc.).  Palate is pleasing and simple; it has a light feel for its appearance, and it is also smooth and a bit sticky on the palate.  The flavor is not really complex; it is simple but makes for a sturdy stout.  Great safety beer.

Large frothy head on a dark pour,biege head.Aroma malty cream grain smell,malt and oats mix well.Flavour velvet creamy roasted hops and coffee,a grittyness,finishis mellowness of malt and oat with good bitterness,the sugar is so fresh in this stout.

Pours a dark color with a medium size brown head. Subtle aroma of malt and chocolate. Has a watery consistency with hints of what should really be in a stout. Not a bad beer, but really this beer just isnt that great of a stout.
Pours very dark with tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Smooth and creamy on the palate.  Went down very smooth, got better as I drank it.

I had high hopes for this beer. Pour is a nice brown/ black with a good sized tan head. Not too powerful aroma, some alcohol and roasted coffee. The flavor is just not there for me. It has a very light, watery consistency for a stout. There is some oatmeal and coffee, but the poster below me was right, there is no "wow" factor. Might be a good entry level stout.

Pours very dark with a good inch of tan head. Smells like a roasted port wine, which is odd for the low ABV... Extremely smooth with a thin consistency... Very subtle oatmeal chocolaty  taste with a thin overtone of roasted coffee that settles to a very mild coffee aftertaste... I think i was expecting more from such a highly rated brew.

Maybe it me but i find Sam Smith beers not worth the money. That being said this is the only beer worth a review in their line up. Nice average oatmeal stout. Medium body and flavor does not really offer any "wow" factor sold beer but I have had much better. Thinking back to when I first started to drink beer about 21-22 I like this beer much more but hey i was young and stupid
550ml bottle. Pours dark black with dense tan head. Nice roast malt aroma. Roasted, chocolate, oatmeal thick palate. Nice stuff.

550ml - Aroma of roasted dark malts, chocolate, oats and the signature Sammy rusty water aroma I get from all their beers.  Pours black with a medium quickly fading head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma with the oatmeal and chocolate standing out.  With a little cocoa powder for good measure.  Palate is creamy, then dry and ashy.  A classic and tasty stout.
Very nice ,black , lightly roasted stout that has the makings of one of the best, bitter but not too much, very smooth finish, I will buy this again

Bottle, pours a super dark black.  The head is frothy and light tan.  Aroma is sweet and creamy.  Flavor is sweet, roast  and chocolate.  Nothing to powerful in this beer.  Pretty good, nothing to special, kinda boring beer.

I just wanted more from this beer! Tasted a bit flat with mocha in it. Poured dark brown with barely any head. It was a tasty beer, but I just wanted a bit more in this beer, but will probably get again!

Pours a very dark opaque black with minimal, circular beige head.  Nose is sweet and sour, with some roasted qualities and a strong milk chocolate sweetness.  Oily on the palate, with dark malt character and a biscuity bite, with fruity raisin esters towards the smooth bitter finish.
Poors dark with copper head... smokey notes with small roast flavor.... finish is bitter and texture is smooth not my favorite stout but not bad.

Dark brown, almost black with a creamy and thick tanned beige head. Nose is milk chocolate, some hoppy gooseberry and malty roastiness. Flavor malty and softly burned with dark chocolate and a hint of liquorice. Finishes dry and quite bitter.  Mouthfeel full and creamy, which is indeed the best part of this smooth stout.

Poured black with a medium tan head.  Aroma was not very strong, but mostly of roasted malts.  Taste was very creamy with strong flavors of roasted and chocolate malts.  The alcohol seemed a little noticeable to me.

I love this brewery, and this is one of their most consistent and delicious beers.  Mildly roasted, not too overpowering...  pours an opaque black with brown hints around the edges.  Aroma isnt too strong (probably because it isnt hugely roasted) but it has the aroma of the roasted malts, with a hint of chocolaty sweetness .  The mouthfeel is thick enough to know you are drinking a stout, but not syrupy.  Hoppy bitterness on the swallow, which is usually almost unnoticeable in a stout, but well balanced in this one.  Beers like this are rare, and its no wonder this has consistently high ratings.

Had great expectations for this beer, but they never fulfilled my dreams. Maybe I like the more roasted ones. As mentioned its too silky. Thats not a bad character, but even after 2 hours I didnt get the best great impressions of it. Must try it again.

The best oatmeal i have tried.  To a stout lover, drinking one of these is like Christmas morning.  Milky palate, well balanced flavor, a sweetness that avoids the overpowering mistake of other oatmeal stouts.  If you havent tried it already, put this one on your bucket list.

Poured a dark brown with a beautiful light brown head. Nose of bitter chocolate and coffee notes. Tasted roasted oats, coffee and cocao. Slightly bitter. Tasted like  a mocha coffee. The best part about this beer is the mouthfeel. It is amazingly creamy and makes the beer go down incredibly smooth. This is one of my favorite beers. Highly recommended.

I remember drinking this beer years ago and enjoying it immensely.  Now, I realize that it truly is a superb brew.  Black as a moonless night with a thin tan head.  Malt, oats, and chocolate make up the wonderful aroma.  A palate as smooth as milk leads to the incredible flavor consisting of oats, chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  Finishes clean.  Wow.

Bottled.  Very dark brown with a small brown head and bubbly carbonation.  Nice aroma of toasted malt with hints of chocolate.  Very smooth mouthfeel.  Definite flavours of oats and dark chocolate in the flavour.  Quick, pleasant finish.  Very nice stout, not too heavy and overpowering.
this beer has a  very good nice deep color almost mike shake like very thick. not a bad price for a 4 pack with this taste this beer is very drinkable

12 oz. bottle, pours a deep brown body with reddish hue and brown head.  Sweet, malty aroma with hints of oats and chocolate.  Smooth, medium-bodied mouthfeel.  Roasted malt and cocoa flavors.  Bittersweet finish like dark chocolate.  Very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 Black in color with very full brown head. Aroma is rather generic. I thought I could smell oats from the bottle. Decent body (a little watery however) with good crisp, but not overwhelming, bitterness. Drinkable. It does have some characteristics of macros however. The finish seems acidic and cheap. Over hyped!

Nice one, had it in a pub in London. Pint glass, rich in taste, dark, almost black in color, smooth and creamy in the mouth, well balanced drinker, after couple of pints it felt like if I had a good full dinner. Shame I cant get it in the states.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown almost black color with a longlasting creamy tan head. Fruity roasted malty chocolate aroma with some hints of caramel. Roasted malty chocolate and dark fruit flavor. Smooth malty chocolate finish with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

Pours a dark brown with a nice medium sized chocolate head.  The nose is slightly sweet with chocolate and licorice showing.  The taste is luscious bittersweet chocolate with a great bitter finish that stays with you.

Very yummy! Atfirst taste it packed a bitter punch to me, but then when I took my second taste it was delightful. It had a lovely and full beige head, and the beer was like a dark root-beer hue.  It would be something that I would eat perhaps with a LITE dinner or lunch with a beef dip sansfries or salad with it. The drink packs a punch though, it is very smooth, not a lot of bubbles - which I love, and the texture is quite unique - soft would be the word, but does not describe the character - body of this brew was heavy - almost like it could be a meal in and of itself, and after that only one I was feeling a very nice buzz coming on me .I would undubitably have it again, even with a bag of peanut butter pretzels. I think the peanut taste, salt and the heavy beer would be pleasing to the palate. The beer is much heavier than New Castle, but so much more pleasant and sweeter than Guinness.

Bottle. Pitch black, opaque, 2-inch creamy beige head. Aroma of cinnamon and molasses. Caramel, coffee, port wine, chocolate, all with just the right touch of bitter-sweetness. Mouthfeel soft, port wine-like. Extremely satisfying with little noticeable alcohol effect.

Definitely one of my favorites from this brewery.  Smooth nutty aroma with hints of caramel and chocolate. Very smooth on the palate, begins malty and leaves a nice rich lingering taste.  Not too heavy and really quite nice overall.

This beer pours a perfect pint from the bottle.  It  is reddish brown with a foamy tan head and smells of hay and oats.  My favorite part of the beer is the hearty, yet smooth and silky, feel in my mouth.

Bought this bottle in Michigan and drank it in Ireland-ironically enough it travelled to the states after being brewed in Englad-lots of miles on this one. 

Very dark brown, almost black pour, with a 1 finger nice off-white head that turns into a nice ring around the glass. 

Some nice malted aromas with some caramel and sweet tones too for your nose. Makes the first sip anticipation mouth-watering. 

Very smooth and rich as it goes down-all of the aromas are pleasant in the mouth along with a bit of toffee/coffee. I dont get too much body initially as I taste it, but it is full when you are able to take it all in. The finish is nice and smooth too and leaves a great taste in your mouth that isnt too strong-makes you want to drink again. 

This wasnt as thick and full as I was expecting it to be more, but rather smooth and easy-going. I would definitely look to try more of this and recommend it to others.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2008 Pitch black pour, potent aroma of almonds and oatmeal. .  good lace.  Smooth beyond belief,  im so impressed by this.  I was expecting a meh offering.  However as far as sweetstouts go, This is the best ive ever  had

Pours black, with a smallish light brown head.  Smells of alot of dark fruit here, I got some substantial banana in there.  Some sweet maltiness backs up the dark fruit as well.  The flavor has a really good dose of that banana and dark fruit as well.  The dark malts and light chocolate seemed to keep it somewhat balanced and keep it from being overly fruity.  Amost had some German and Belgian quad characters to it.  Pretty good.  Nice body.  I know its a sweet stout, but maybe just a little too much for my taste though.
My favorite Oatmeal Stout to date, with a rich, enticing malty aroma, very full mouthfeel, dark fruity flavors, and nice balance of hop bitterness and rich malty sweetness.

Let this stuff breathe - on first pour it tasted metallic. This went away quickly, but you dont want that to be your first impression. Poured a dark black with lots of tan head. Has a deep, dark malty flavor. Very earthy flavors - hard to put a finger on it. Ive had this before and it always takes me by surprise.
This is a nice roasty, earthy oatmeal stout.  Give Sammy a try.  You wont be sorry.
Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is excellent. It pours black with a tan head and the aroma is of roasted malt, chocolate, and oats.

Pours a dark dark brown, opaque. 2 Finger, tan head.Aroma is mild, slightly sweet, and little bit floral. Taste is...admittedly complex. It seems like theres so much going on here. Caramel and/or coffee malts, something of a licorice taste. Then theres something a bit nutty. It certainly gets better as you go. Im not completely sold on it, however it is good. Smooth. Tasty. Definitely a solid stout.

Pours black with a thick coffee head.  aroma is rich malt and slightly sweet.  Low carbonation and a rich body.  Smooth maltiness with a light sweetness.  Feels light on the stomach despite the good flavor.  Nice stout.

This has been one of my favorite beers for a long, long time. Great looking, its dark brown with a strong off-white head.
Subtle aromas of chocolate and oatmeal and sweet malt.
Taste is consistent with the aroma, only more definite. Sweet aftertaste is pleasant, not overpowering.
This beer has texture unlike anything else - very smooth, rich and creamy. A most agreeable drinking experience.
UPDATED: SEP 16, 2008 Almost Perfect!!!  Best beer I have ever drunk.  This is a rich beer with a beutiful palate.  A Must Have!!!!!
UPDATED: APR 19, 2008 Rich dark color, thick head.  Flavors, smoky, nutty, good lasting aftertaste. Thick sweet and overall good.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2008 Bottle. Aroma of chocolate, roast, coffee in the background. Flavor pretty nice with the roasted characteristic spreading throughout, starting with some dark fruit, then the sweet oatmeal, finishing on coffee again. I thought it was a bit thin for the flavors it was carrying. Solid stuff though. 7-4-8-3-15

Rerate: overly sweet, prune-brown sugar quality that dominates the entire flavor and especially the finish. 7-4-5-2-10 (Ive semi-averaged the two since this came from a bar whose beer turnover may not be the best).

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 18.7oz bottle.   Almost black, but some brown on edges, firm tan head.   Sweet burnt sugar aroma with some cocoa, roast, and mild acidity.   Caramel, chocolate, roasted malt flavor.   Pretty sweet, but not cloying at all.   Medium body with  fine carbonation.   Smooth.   Decent stout, but not everything was coming together for me.   Tasted like it had more alcohol than it did, and Im not to hot on that.

Poured from a 550ml (a pint+) bottle into a clear gass tumbler. A one-finger light brown head. Leaves good amount of lacings. Initial impression is roasted malt sweetness, mild chocolate-coffee effect which is smoothed by the oatmeal. The hops are there but integrated so they are not a seperate taste. A very nice, rich stout that could easily substitute for a meal. Highly recommended.

Black as night with strafes of reddish hues in the light as it rests under a head of frothy light brown foam. The aroma is dominated by sweet and roasty notes. Caramel, coffee, chocolate, with dark fruit elements in the background like dates and raisins. In the mouth it starts slightly sweet, with a light mouthfeel and smooth soft carbonation. The flavor is rich with caramel and roasty elements. Towards the middle it turns milder, as the carbonation kicks up chocolate and fruit associations. Before finally ending with a gentle touch of bitterness, balancing out the sweetness nicely.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2009 A nice looking dark stout with a tan, creamy head that lasts with nice lacing.  I dont get much of that roasty aroma from it, but the taste is quite full.  A thick, chewy beer with a roasted, slightly chocolate flavor.  Clean aftertaste.  A fine stout.

Good stout overall.  And the stout is one of my favorite types of beer.  The aroma is very pleasing.  The standard roastiness and chocalte notes, but very nice.  The color has a dark brown/black tinge, but for a stout it was somewhat opaque;light could be seen through the beer.  the taste is sweet, full bodied, roasty and malty.  The mouthfeel is on the thick side.  The palate is a tad bitter, probably from the bitersweet chocolate.  This gives the beer a nice balance.  Definitely enjoyable.
Chocolately full flavor. Cool smell. Pretty excellent tasting and looking. I dig it lots.

I have tried 3 stouts so far, Guinness, Oharas and Samuel Smiths.  I enjoyed this beer, after opening the bottle I smelled some coffeeish smell and possibly some chocolate.  The beer was dark with some red tones as well, and a long lasting head.  The beer was smooth and creamy that was slightly cloying.  Over all my new favorite stout.
bottle. this stuff smelled very bad but the taste knocked me out! loved the dark color and very smooth for a dark beer.it sits a tad heavy but the flavor is so darn good!
UPDATED: JAN 31, 2008 (English) WOW, The smell......But Smooth , Sweet, and very Dark!!  It had Big Head and creamy Oatmeal taste. Yummy, i will drink this again!!!
UPDATED: DEC 20, 2008 A very tasty Oatmeal Stout!  Very dark in color.  Thick and pours a nice head.  Chocolate/carmel and rich in flavor.  Havent tried that many stouts but this is very good.

550 ml bottle.  Pours dark with some red color.  Huge rocky tan head that hangs around a while.  Nose of cream, roasted coffee, wood.  Flavor was roasted - coffee, chocolate, cream, oats.  Im a big stout fan, and I like this one a lot.  I often recommend it to friends that arent big stout fans.

a very dark ruby red color with a tan head. smells of caramelized malts, cereal, and espresso. drinks smooth and sweet. slightly hoppy finish. more carbonated than is the norm for this style, but it works well to balance the silky smooth texture otherwise.

Deep brown to black in color with a light tan head.  There were scents of oats, milk chocolate and dark fruits.  In the mouth it was medium-bodied with lots of carbonation and a crisp balanced midpalate.  The finish was smooth but ended with a herbal edge.

Very dark pour with mocha head and nice lacing. Nose of milk, chocolate and toasted oats. Flavor was chocolate, coffee, winter type spices and a metallic flavor that I didnt mind at all...odd. Creamy body that made it seem richer than it was.

Poured from a 550ml bottle and served in an English pint glass.  This beer poured a deep, dark brown with a huge head of rocky, tan foam that faded away slowly.  A thick coating of foamy lacing covered the inside of the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of sweet milk chocolate notes, toasted oats, and also a bit of coffee.  The flavor included moderate roasted notes, chocolate, coffee with cream, and also a subtle metallic note.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and silky smooth with a nice amount of carbonation.  A decent oatmeal stout, but a bit overrated.
Pours dark, with a thick brown head that laces nicely! Aroma was nice with a hint of coffee. I do believe a stout is the beer for me.

Poured a dark, dark brown with a beautiful tan head that lasted longer than the beer with huge lacing.  A malty aroma that literally filled the room.  This beer filled you mouth and excited your taste buds with maltiness.  This beer has turned me on to oatmeal stouts which I rarely drank before.  However, this has excited me to try more.  Rogue chocolate stout will be next.

Flaske. Esktrem flot næsten sort øl med et flot skum. Kan ikke se holdbarhedsdatoen men ved den er gået over da det er en freebie fra Abigails. Dette kan absolut ikke ses eller smages. Sødlig duft og en udmærket mundfylde gør det til en nydelse at drikke.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2009 fn delicious. the label reminds me of the old circus posters you used to see nailed to telephone poles...and this certainly is the greatest show in my mouth! wakka wakka. a rare oatmeal stout where the oat flavor is very noticable. very sweet and very creamy. dark with a semi thick head. aroma full of oats and barley, with dark cream thrown in. very drinkable. a definite top 5.
pours a thick brown head.  sweet chocolate and coffee aromas fill the nose.  a very clean taste on the palette with flavors of roasted malts and chocolate.  a staple, classic stout.

Theres not much to add that hasnt already been said. This is definitely one of the most drinkable beers Ive had. Nice dark stout with overflowing head. Aroma of mocha. Taste of coffee and chocolate but not too sweet at all. I like the smooth, low cabonated mouthfeel, although I think its just a hint on the watery side.
Sweet chocolate, malt, and coffee aroma.  Flavor of sweet chocolate malt with notes of vanilla.  Great smooth mouthfeel makes this a real pleasure to drink.

Pours dark brown/black with a medium mocha head.  Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, slight coffee and malts.  Taste is silky and smooth, with roasted malt, chocolate, and a bit of coffee.  Good and easy drinking but nothing jumps out at me to make it special.  Falls a bit flat for me but gets extra points for being smooth and easy. A bit overrated, me thinks.

Pours a deep brown with a tan head. Nice lacing. Aromas of chocolate, malts, and slight vanilla. Flavors of chocolate and a slight maltiness. Very smooth delicious beer. Great for an after dinner drink.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: 12oz.  Oh man is this tasty.  Pours black with a tan head.  Nose was closed at first, turned to roasted malts, chocolates, coffee as the beer warmed.  Some raisin in the body, along with a return of the roasted malt, sour malt, chocolate, coffee.  Just the right amount of carbonation makes this smooth and creamy in the mouth.  Extra points for being so widely distributed but still so tasty.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a nice dark brown with a finger-width frothy brown head. Very strong chocolate smell with hints of coffee, vanilla, and nut. There may have been a very slight aroma of bourbon also. Tasted very sweet with strong chocolate and coffee malts with slight hints of berries and vanilla. There was a slight lingering of alcohol also. A very tasty beer!

Poured out of bottle an dark inky brown with a great swirl of light and dark brown foam that lasted throughout my tasting experience.  The smell was of toasted graininess with a slight floral alcohol aroma.  The taste start with a malty sweetness leading to grainy chocolate notes and caramel.  Very smooth finish not much bitterness at all.  Mouth feel was smooth with a full tongue coating of flavor.  Overall a nice smooth creamy beer but slightly too sweet for me.  Not bad for a sipping beer on occasion.

This was one of my first forays into fine beers quite a while back and at the time I was quite impressed and would have likely rated it closer to the rating it has here.  However, Ive had many others since then and revisited this last night and it wasnt quite what I remembered.  Still a very good brew, but I think its somewhat over-rated.  Pours dark brown with a decent sized head that leaves a lot of lacing.  Smooth, creamy mouthfeel and flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice and somewhat acidic.  Did get better as it warmed...to a certain extent.  Toward the bottom of the glass it got rather...eh...  Kind of cola-like.  A solid stout, but there are much better examples out there IMO.

Tasted 12/29/07.  550ml bottle.  Dark brown hue with a slight ruby tint.  Finger width of beige head.  Toffee fruity fudgy oatmeal milk chocolate aromas.  Full bodied and super sweet.  Tingling effervescence.  Chocolate and bready malts.  Rich full bodied and delicious.  Slight fruit note.  Berries and figs.  Great chocoalte and oatmeal grainy flavors.  Slight spice.  Sticky with cocoa and cola notess.  Tart with a touch of citrus in the middle.  So good!  All those Hippies cant be wrong!

A stout with a tall tan head. This brew is dark black, completely opaque, amazing. It smells dry and earthen. The taste is of course malt and oat. Its pretty smooth, with a nice desert like aftertaste.
Nice dark brown-black color with a white head.  Taste was very smooth and roasted flavor with a stout finish.  Very good stout with lots of flavor and nice enjoyable aftertaste.

It poured a wonderful opaque black with a nice off-white persistent head.  It smelled of chocolate and oats.  The flavor was full of oats, chocolate, coffee, caramel with a sweet, tart finish.  It was an incredibly smooth drink though.  Full, thick, creamy palate.  Great beer.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown with tan head w/ large bubbles, almost like a cola.  Aroma is sweet malts, a little coffee.  Flavor was slightly acidic and plain, but definitely improved as the beer warmed (served way too cold).  Palate was a little thinner than I would have liked.  A good beer, but perhaps overrated.  I had this on draft at the Maproom about a year ago, and remember it being better.  I will re-rate at a later date.
Pours pitch black with a lasting head. The aroma is sweet with some liquorice. Taste is dark toffee, chocolate and a bit coffee. The mouthfeel is exceptional. An all time favorite.
Great beer!  Has a roasty, nutty flavor.  This is a beer to really take your time and enjoy.
Bottled. Pours Dark and lots of head. Cocolate and roasted malt aroma & taste. A bit of a bitter finish.

Bottle in the Cittie of York, London. Near black in colour with a decent tan head that left plenty of lacing. Sweet chocolate aroma with some roasted notes. Light mouth feel with plenty of chocolate and roasted malt flavour and a  slightly dry finish. Very good.

Bottle @ The Duke of Argyll, Soho. Mahogany with an off white head. Nose has sweet malt, nuts, apples and candi sugar with a taste much the same. Its ok but Im not as bowled over as I expected by some of the other ratings on here.
For an oatmeal stout, this one just lacked the punch of flavor that sweets usually have.  That being said, I consistently rate Samuel Smiths as such.  Just ok for the genre.

bottle.  average frothy tan head into black body.  good lacing.  aromas of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, and hops.  flavor is lightly sweet with some light bitterness from the hops.  very good stout

Deep brown with a frothy, deep tan head.  Sweet roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, vanilla, oats, milk, smoke; nice.  Medium, smooth body.  Tasty.  Roasted malts, sweet malts, oats, milky, caramel, chocolate, and light fruit tones.  Loved this one for a long time.  An amazingly tasty stout, but this one is lighter and easier to drink than most.  One of the best.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2010 Bottle: 12/27/07. Aroma: Malty sweetness w/ some notes that are borderline fruity, oats, very light smoked ham smell. Taste: Starts sweet, moves to malt bitterness w/ oats. Then, some fruity notes set in just before the finish (strawberry & banana). Finish is muttled. Some acidity. I feel like the last one of these I had was much better. 6/4/6/4/13-3.3

18.6 oz bottle: 1/4/09: Pretty much exactly the same as my last rating. Guess this beer is a mess. Disappointing. I wonder if it has always been this way, and I just dont remember it properly from my earlier days or if they changed the recipe to make it appeal more to the masses like Guinness, aka replacing roastiness with muddled muddiness-literally taste of mud. I understand British yeast character, but this is just a mess. 5/4/5/3/12-2.9

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2008 Pours dark as night. Thick tan head that breaks down slowly. Good lacing. Not much of an aroma though. Hard as I mite I can not pick up too much to smell. Creamy lite taste and very easy to drink. Nice departure from other abrasive stouts and even porters.
I love this beer.  One of my favorites.  Sets the bar for oatmeal stouts.  I enjoy the aroma, taste, palate... all of it.
Black with a creamy head. Tipical stouts nose profile, with a little sweetness you could perceive even in the aroma. I prefer dryer versions but it is certainly smooth and silky.
good beer. creamy, not a lot of carbonation and thats what I like. Its thick and I like that too. Reminds me of dry irish stout. Nice work.
Cant add much to this discourse.  Best thing about the beer is its palate; creamy, low carbonation, easy drinking.
Nice beer, thick and creamy. vary smooth, and avalable in a lot of places in Illinois
Bottle from the fresh. Black pour with nice creamy head.very nice brew especially for the price. Well done.

Bottle 0.355 l at Ravintola Primula, Helsinki. Dark brown/black with nice thick head. Creamy coffee, very roasted. A bit sour and very bitter rather than sweet. My first sweet stout, and I was expecting .. yes, a sweeter stout. For a moment I thought I was having a porter rather than a stout. Nonetheless its a very fine brew with long bitter finish. I had it with creamy salmon soup, archipelago rye bread and I can recommend the whole. Sadly the beer was server way too cool and I didnt get the real deal until at the very end. And it does matter on this beer.
Not much to say that hasnt been said about this one.  The temperature is important though - too cold and you will never get the true flavors of this beer.

Pours black with a large gray/tan head.  Aroma of deep roasted malt, butter, a little sour some nuts.  The body is very drinkable for a stout, more like that of a porter.   Really smooth flavor.  some creamy milk chocolate, hints of licorice, lots of malt.  None of the bitterness found in other stouts... very sweet finish.  Latter in the beer I found some nice oatmeal and lots of vanilla.
UPDATED: JUN 30, 2008 This was a very enjoyable beer. Very smooth to the palate. Mellow carbonation, very dark, great flavor. Sweet with dark roast creamy flavors. Will buy again.
bottle.  Brew poured a deep chocolate brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of toffee, caramel, chocolate and sweet cherries.  Finish was smooth and sweet.  A great stout.
550 ml bottle:  Poured a dark brown with a thick light brown head. Flavor is mild sweet.  Goes down smooth with no bad aftertaste.
Very sweet initially. Malted extremely. Not as creamy as I would like, even very warm. Great flavors of chocolate.

Bottled 355ml. It pours a very dark beer with hints of ruby. A beige head. The nose is of coconut, dark chocolate, rum, molasses and roasted malt. Some oats sneeking in giving this stout even more wonderful qualities. Oaky, vinous notes with a slight salty touch. Wonderful, full aromas. Full bodied. Dark chocolate. Slightly salty. Extremely smooth. Wonderful mouthfeel. Hints of oats, pumpernickel and roasted malt. Vinous. The finish is dry salty with hints of licorice.

Aroma is a sweet caramel scent with light taste tones.  Color is solid black with mellow carbonation and a nice tight tan head.  Taste is smooth and roasted.  Starting with a full body that goes down very easy with a creamy feel.  Finish come in with sweet caramel and roasted flavors then it turns dry with a mild bitterness in the after taste.  This is one of the most well balanced stouts I have ever had.

pours an exceptionally darkened nut brown with a very appealing caramel white frothy head. the head sticks around.. initial hit to the palate is packed with silky smooth malty oatmeal flavor with hints of hoppiness that is mild and flavorful.. I enjoy the lighter sweet, toasty taste of this stout and would say the only heavy downside is its flaky aftertaste but overall a very good stout.. another stout that is pulling me away from my obsession with IPAs and into the world of stout!!

dry roasted toasty aroma with notes of tar like an imperial stout. tall espresso head fell quick to a half inch and stayed there over onyx. very dry and soft with few peaks or valleys but a persistent weight.
Pours a dark chocolate brown, thick light brown head.  Mild aroma.  Very sweet.  I think the flavor is kind of light for a Stout though.  I have others that I prefer over this.
This is one of the tastiest beers Ive ever had. Poured from the bottle, its deep brown color juxtaposes its warm taste.
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma of coffee & liquorice. Full-bodied coffee taste with a long finish. Nice!
Excellent aroma, pours a deep chocolate brown.  Oatmeal flavor stands out making for a delicious treat.

550mL bottle into pint glass. Pours a deep, dark brown with a medium tan head that dissipates rather quickly. Heavy aromas of roasted malts, hazelnut, coffee, butter and oats. Flavor is of oats, coffee, chocolate, and butter with a slight, nutty finish. Mouthfeel is smooth and soft. My favorite Sam Smiths brew, after the Imp. Stout.

Aroma is subtle, and not particularly stout-like. Very soft, with chocolate, cream and oats in the nose. Great looking brew, very thick and dark with small, but persistent dark tan head. The flavor is great- roasted malt, molasses, oat, a hint of chocolate; mildly sweet, but with a nice tart finish. Palate=fantastic. Rich, creamy, smooth and very drinkable. Overall a really excellent brew - pairs nicely with the snowy/icy weather outside.

Bottle. This one excites me. Still got to finish the Arrogant Bastard, cleanse the palate and pour this one. Be back in a minute... OK, Im back. Pours black with a massive brown head. Almost a bourbonesque aroma. Light taste for a stout. Very smoky taste. The oatmeal comes through. I dont like smoky beer (always makes me feel like Im drinking barbecue sauce), so this is actually a bit of a disappointment. Sad.
A fine oatmeal stout. Dark with a bitterness that defies description but rounded out with a sweetish finish. Worth trying!

bottle. Not a big fan of dark beers in general,  but i guess I prefer sweet stouts to dry ones. This otmeal stout was ok. I actually preferred Troeggs to this one...aroma is nut and roast. Taste is coffee, nut and roastiness.

Bottle. Pours black with small off-white head. Chocolate flavor with hints of nuts, coffee, malts. Solid creamy body with nice mouthfeel and subtle carbonation fits style nicely. Bittersweet finish for sure.

Pours brown to black with a khaki head.  To describe the aroma as "Sam Smith" should be accurate enough, but Ill try to decipher it.  Aroma of milk/cream, hazelnuts, chocolate milk, and a slightly astringent roast.  Milky chocolate flavor, sweetened coffee, nutty, with more of that oat/nutty/milk taste on the finish.  Aftertaste of coffee with too much milk in it.  Nice flavor and aroma, so unmistakable.  Creamy and adequately bodied, but still pretty light in a "sessionable" sort of way.  Good beer!  It felt strange buying this on sale in Target of all places though.

Man, this is a wonderful beer.  Had a 550 ml bottle for breakfast this morning.  Poured inky black with a huge creamy head that faded into a slight ring that stayed with me the whole time.  This is some of the best lacing that I have ever seen.  

Smelled yeasty and malty and yet chocolatey at the same time.  

Bittersweet chocolate and roasted coffee taste with a nice bitter touch at the end.  

This is a really nice beer.  I enjoyed this immensely.  My only regret is that I dont have another bottle.
Very smooth, easy to drink, which I like in oatmeal stouts.  Unfortunately, it lacks the punch of flavor that I like.  I dont see why people like it so much.  Its good, but not great in my book.

Pours to an off-white large, full lasting head. 
Aroma of the beer is a strong yeasty smell.
Initially the beer is sweet and ends with a light bitter taste. Flavours of caramel maltiness and light hoppiness are the predominant taste. Mouthfill was creamy. Very good beer.

This is an awesome beer.  Pours a dark inky black color with a creamy tan-caramel head.  The aroma is of semi-sweet chocolate.  It is extremely malty.  The taste is sweet like candy but not overwhelming.  I am really surprised by how much I liked this beer.

While at a bar I requested a Guinness, but they didnt have any. The bartender suggested Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout as an alternative, and thus I tasted my first oatmeal stout. This is a delicious, dark, silky, smooth, bready beer. Buy the 550ml bottle and sip it through the course of an evening.
Nice creamy tan head, sweet aroma of coffee malts, starts mildly sweet, finishes with slight hop bitterness. Awesome beer for the price
I lack the command of the written word to provide a description that would do this beverage justice.

I poured the dark brown ale into two glasses to observe an old friend with whom I had visited before. The malty aroma stood out as the I had to taste it right away. Ah, this was very smooth and easy to drink through the frothy head. It was slightly bitter with coffee and cocoa  flavors rising.

50 cl. bottle pours a black fluid with a decent brown head. Has a malted chocolate and coffee smell. Medium bodied with a nice smooth mouthfeel. Taste is of dark roasted malts and sweet grain oatmeal. Very drinkable and tasty. 
One of the best Stouts around before the Craft brew revolution and still good in this day and age. 
Glad to know that some things dont change.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Pours dark,  a bit of ruby shines through but not much.  Not much flavor or smell for the style,  and always seems a bit skunked even if I get it on tap.  I used to rate this beer a full point higher before I tried others.  I guess a great starter beer for this style.  I should also note I have fallen out of love with beers in this genre.  Nothing wrong with it and very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2008 Dark pour with medium head. Clearly tasted the silky oatmeal flavor with the first few cooler sips along with a touch of chocolate and sugar. Mellow malt flavor with very low bitteness. As the beer warmed and opened up, there is an incredible intense smoky flavor that dominates. Almost overpowering to the palate, but quite interesting. Had with butternut squash risotto and paired nicely, though again the smoky flavor was over the top by the end of the bottle. Worth a try.

Bottled. Deep rubyish black colour, mediumsized white head. Aroma is pleasantly smoked wood with some hops and malts. Flavour is roasted malts, smoked wood and some slight acidicness. Quite pleasant, though the flavour is quite a dissappointment.
Dark with light head: roasty nose, nutty  raisen taste with light spices; bitter finish. Taste like a winter brew
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text:
Bottled (BB 03/2009)
Dark ruby color, almost opaque color, firm beige creamy head. Roasted malty and chocolaty, a bit sticky aroma. Chocolaty, lightly toasted malty, a bit sweet beer. Almost like beer with wheat (=banana fruity), so propably it is oat doing a job.

Oh man, oh man. This is in my top 3, and the other two are also Samuel Smiths (Nut Brown Ale and Imperial Stout). I dont know what these guys do thats different from basically everybody else, but it seems to extend to most of their beers that Ive tried. I dont see heads like this on anything else. Not foamy, not Guinnessy. Rich. Textured. Mature. Classic. Lovely. You can actually taste the oatmeal in this and I love oatmeal. Its got a silky smooth sweetness with just a little tang to offset it. I drank this for years before discovering their Imperial Stout. I was surprised and a little sad that I actuallly liked that better. But I alternate between them these days and love them both. Man, I want to pour this all over my face and down the back of my shirt. I bet it would be good for the skin. Go for the big bottle (or two), not those little weenie four-pack bottles.

$2.99 550mL bottle from Trader Joes.  Pours with little head despite heavy pour.  Small to microbubble tan foam forms around the edge of the glass, slightly clinging as I swirl.  Pitch black liquid.  Mild aroma, some roasted malt, some oatmeal, little hop aroma, Pretty dry taste. Low bitterness.  Has that dry acidic roastiness, but it small quantities.  Not bad, but not my favorite style.
Delicious. Sweet chocolate flavor. Very smooth. Very well balanced. Tastes as if it has no alcohol at all.

Pours with long lasting, thick, abundant foam.  Good dark brown color.  Aroma is yeasty and molasses.  Taste well rounded with good hops and a bit of sweetness.  Body full on the tongue.  Good full-bodied sipper.

Tastes so smooth.  I usually find these sort of beers to much for my taste.  But this is heavenly.  Tastes good no matter what your eating...as a matter of fact, my first taste was at a sports bar.  Its just a damn good sweet beer.
Dark, you aint seeing through this one. Smells earthy with maybe a hint of chocolate but mainly just dark. Smooth texture, dark flavors, deep roasted flavor. Highly enjoyable

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 Excellant Beer!!! Pours an opaque dark brown almost black. Has a complex aroma with hints of chocolate & molasses. A full creamy taste of the chocolate & molasses. Overall smooth, rich and flavorful taste.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2008 Pours a black ruby with a creamy tan head. Mildly sweet aroma of chocolate and coffee. Flavor is solidly of coffee with a dry finish. Silky (from the description) is a good way to describe the texture.

Pours a nice creamy brown head with medium retention. A roasted malt and grain aroma with the typical choco-coffee stout flavor. I also agree with the last rate, it finishes with just a bit of licorice. I like it, and will put this in my will drink again list.

This beer has a massive flavor that, honestly, was just too much for me. Full of chocolate and coffee overtones, it finises with a licorice flavor that lingered just a little too long for me. Color is that of used motor oil, and the thick palate actually left behind a film that precluded any refreshment. I just didnt enjoy this.

Many Sam Smiths in London. Beautiful creamy stout, if you can get it served at the right temperature. Demerara sugar, heavy roasted malt flavours are balanced by the complex creaminess and perfectly juged (i.e. not overpowering) hops at the end. Surprisingly easy to drink, and somehow slightly refreshing at the same time.

With a clean glass free of detergent, the thin beige head stays right to the end. 

To top it off, the 500ml bottle has a beautiful label.
Very smooth and sweet, heady and malty with a slight after taste. Smooth on the palate, good out of the bottle or a glass.

Pours dark brown but not black.  It has light brown head that disappears quickly.  It smells of roasted malts with hints of sweetness around the edges.  The beer has a thick, creamy texture that tastes of roasted malt and coffee.  This is a very good beer with a lot of flavor.
Sam Smiths number one beer. Nice creamy balance to the roasted malts and a very easy drinker with a little hint of alcohol.
Pours a gorgeous, ample dark brownish head.  Rich smoky stout aroma.  Perfectly balanced stout flavor.  This is perhaps the best stout Ive had to date.

bottle poured a dark black in color with a nice thick one finger head that slowly melted down the glass. smell is dark chocolate, toasted malts, caramel, and dark brown sugar. the taste is heavy and thick, malts in the middle, and finishes on the bitter end. heavy but has a smooth creaminess to it. have had many of these over the years and it is consistently just as good as the first one was.

This is incredible and perhaps the benchmark for oatmeal stouts.  Its deep, dark red-brown, almost black, with a thick tan head that lasts and leaves moderate lacing.  The aroma is rich with caramel and dark fudge with a rich fruitiness.  The taste is similar, rich, full-bodied, fudge, raisins, sweetish with wonderful balancing faint bitterness.  The palate is thick, creamy, and silky.  This is incredibly smooth and delicious, essentially perfection.  Ironically, many years ago, this was the 2nd stout Id ever had and I first did not like it much, but then I was young and inexperienced and barely drank beer at all.  This is simply perfect.

Color of shoe polish, stained wood, burnt ochre.  Smell of toast w/ marmalade or apricot jam. First, full mouthfull at ambient temp. goes down oh so smooth.  Flavor of toasted raisin bagels w/ marmalade, hints of apricot and marshmallow. Very soft finish...those Brits.

Pours a gorgeous deep brown color with a large chocolate-milky head.  An immediate sweet, malty aroma.  Roasted, sweet taste that goes down smoothly.  This will be a repeat buy, Id really like to try this on tap.

1 ot. 2.7 oz. bottle.
Very dark brown with creamy tan head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Prominant brown sugar taste with hints of oats and smoke.  An excellent stout.  I will be purchasing more.

Pours black with nicely sized tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, and oats. Bitter flavours at first subsiding into sweet malt, oats and chocolate. Full body with smooth finish but a little too sweet. Like this one quite a bit.

550 ml Bottle.  Samuel Smith lays on the intensity again.  Pours black with a dark brown head.  Burnt chocolate and molasses aroma.  Taste is pretty much the same.  Not as bitter at Samuels imperial stout.  Finish is sweet and smoky.  The palates a rich mouthful.  Very drinkable.  An excellent stout.
Bottle. Near black with a full tan head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Very clean finish and lot of mouthfeel.

Faint aroma with a deep dark color. This beer is among the best oatmeal stouts in the market, hands down.  Head is somewhat loose, palate has very faint bitterness backed by a delicious sweet creamy finish with a subtle oat essence.
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2007 Pours dark black with a thick tan head. Full-bodied beer with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Pours thick, rich, and virtually opaque. Cappucino-colored head. Smokey aroma that gives way to a similarly smokey flavor. Also aroma of chocolate, prunes, and figs. Flavors also include chocolate-covered raisins. Lots of cocoa. There is a silken smooth richness to this robust stout. Nice bitterness in the aftertaste makes it delicious!
12 oz bottle,pours black with ruby highlights off tan head,roast coffee,oaty nose.smoooth slight carb,malty roast coffee,chocolate,slight bitter finish.very nice stout.
12 ounce bottle available at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL at $2.29 Excellent
Smooth, dark and very nice for a first at 9:30 in the morning as football games get started. Whifs of oatmeal, chocolate and a hint of roast coffee.
Unreal smooth dark brown- black with tan diminishing head. As balanced as it gets for stout.
from a 12 oz. bottle into a shaker.  pours jet black with a small white head that quickly fades.  smooth as silk, with overtones of chocolate and coffee.  extremely drinkable, great stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 17, 2008 Beautiful black poor with a tan head which quickly dissipates but leaves a nice lacing behind.  Sweet malty aroma hints at what is to come. Flavor is sweet, with notes of roasted barley, hops, chocolate, coffee, and malt.  Mouth feel is slightly sweet, silky smooth with little noticeable alcohol.  A very nice stout, generally well regarded by all stout lovers.  One of my favorites.
Bottle. Pours black as black with a nice chocolate milk like head. Unique aroma, cant decide what i think of it. Strong coffee taste and great roasted malts. Nice stout.

Unfortunately, bottle, but allowed me to waft up a dry, tantalizing chocolate malt aroma not unlike Ovaltine powder. Initial taste contained strong coffee and fruity notes, mellowing into dark chocolate and roasted malts in the middle, with an ever present alcohol and carbonation depth to it throughout. A definitive dessert beer.
My favourite beer ever.  A great colour, aroma and texture.  Very smooth and creamy taste.  Poors beautifully with a dark color and an offwhite head.

Poured from a 550 ml bottle. Was a pitch black color with not much of a light brown head. Aroma was weak of roasted/chocolate malts. Taste was smooth and was a stout that one could drink all night. Toffee and coffee flavors stood out, along with a sweet nutty finish.
good stout, very smooth and excellent dark pour with nice tan heads nice flavor of oatmeal malts too
Bottle. Pours black giving brown foamy head. Malts / molasses / coffee aroma. Taste is smooth leaving a hoppy / fruity finish. Definitely drinkable and cannot wait for another.
Bottle: Very black with a great brown and foamy head.  Light coffee aroma.  Very drinkable.  I want another.

bottle.  pours black with a thick tan head... aromas of roasted malts and molasses.  very little carbonation, medium body and a very smooth taste.  sweet, chocolatly, and nutty taste.  excellent stout!

When I woke up this morning from a crazy Saturday night, what did I reach for? This oatmeal stout of course. Malt aroma with coffee and breakfast pastries. Nice dark almost completely black appearance with a nice tan head. Taste is full of grains and all that.  A lot of malts and some sweetness to it. Nutty flavors present. Goes down really nice and smooth.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2011 Re-rate: sweet, dry, metallic, heavily roasted malts and oats. Very rich and drinkable, almost thin in some ways. Is a lot like Guinness FES. Fruity suggestions throughout. Very nice. A spot on Stout. Certainly some metallic bitterness in the finish. 

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a decent light brown head. The taste is amazing; first a burnt chocolate taste followed by a fruity/hoppy mix. Like a Cadbury fruit bar, but better. Great!

Bottle.  Aroma a nice robust malt.  Pours dark with a nice tan head.  Taste is a smooth malt, with a bit of rich oatmeal taste.  A touch of hops comes through at the end, but no real aftertaste.  Very nice.

nice dark brown in color with decent brown head.  aroma was nutty and roasted coffee.   went down really smooth with a taste of roasted nuts and coffee.  really enjoyed this brew but was somewhat dissapointed because i was expecting more.  could definitely make a night of drinking this brew!

550ml bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark mahogany with a thin mocha-colored head.  Aroma is full and sweet with smells of nuttiness, coffee, crisp hops, and caramel.  Taste is full and velvety with strong (but smooth) tastes of chocolate, coffee, and caramel with a somewhat lingering undercurrent of tart hops.  A pleasantly complex and rich stout thats eminently drinkable and widely available.

A dark, coffee-like appearance and viscous consistency give way a wispy, creamy head and subtle effervescence.
Flavor evokes strong suggestions of walnuts, pecans, toasted malt, espresso, and a hint of nutmeg on the finish that gives way to a slightly sharper, boozy flavor and anise.
Would be a fine accompaniment to English clothbound cheddars as well as sweet gruyeres and emmenthalers.
