One of my favorite stouts. Strong, filling, full bodied, and chocolate flavor that leaves the drinker satisfied.

Pours a deep black with a medium tan head.  Smells burnt, with a hint of smoke.  It has a chocolaty flavor with a big body and a certain chewiness that makes this one a classic.  Has a good hop bite on the finish with an oily chocolate flavor that lingers.  This is one of my all time favorites and one of the first stouts that I drank when I started drinking real beer a few years ago.

9/5/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is sweet/bready malt forward with fruity cherry portlike notes and cream flavors.  Appearance is very dark brown with a medium tan head.  Flavor is true chocolate forward with a light astringency that is not objectionable, followed by roast malt into the finish.  Mouthfeel is full bodied with smooth cream and a slight slickness.  Overall, great sweetness and a very well integrated complexity.

Aroma of chocolate malts, roast, oatmeal and maple or molasses? Almost black. Light red hues when held up to light. Super small tan head. Flavor is sweet and roasty. Oatmeal is noticable. A lingering roasty sweetness. This stuff is fantastic!

Pours black with a nice tan head. Strong smells of alcohol, roasted malts, oatmeal and light chocolate. The taste is molasses and oatmeal. Chewy. This is a great beer! Very close to the Imperial, though I think the Imperial is slightly better.

From bottle : Pours a pitch black color with medium frothy off-white head.  A metallic aroma with malts and a hint of alcohol.  Feels very silky in the mouth, with a nice hardy body.  Taste is very good, oatmeal with a roasty finish.  Very tastey stout.
This beer has great flavor and will not let you down.  The best Oatmeal Stout available

[578-20070904] 500mL. Plum boozy raisin aroma with brandied Christmas cake. Very dark brown body with a long-lasting foamy light tan head. Roasted malty dark fruit fig pudding flavours. Full body is smooth. Flavour pulls all together nicely.

Slightly metallic aroma with notes of malt, alcohol and soy.  Pure black, completely opaque in appearance.  Tan head that dissipates quickly.  Lots of carbonation appearing on the side of the glass.  Strong taste of sweet coffee, yet very bitter in the finish.  Very creamy.  Thin mouthfeel, yet it is pleasant with the carbonation.  Good balance.    Overall, I like the taste bu the metal in the aroma ruins it for me.I doubt Id drink it again.
Samuel Smith never misses.  I usually do not like stouts, but this beer ended up my all time favorite beer.  All I can say is try it!

Another winner from Samuel Smith, although my favorite is the Imperial Stout. Less alcohol that the IS, both in % and taste. Pours black with a minimal beige/tan head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. You can taste the oatmeal, which makes this one a great pick for for Sunday brunch.
Bottle. Dark brown color, almost black. Burnt aroma with hints of oatmeal. Oatmeal dominates the flavor, slightly astringent, with the roasted barley balancing it nicely. Somewhat winey. Very tasty.
Poured black with a creamy tan head. Taste reminded me of an oatmeal choclate chip cookie. Extremely smooth mouthfeel.

Name: Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout
Date: 01/01/1995
Source: Three Dollar Cafe



Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 17/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Score: ***4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Pours a rich mahogany, with an off-white head that leaves a bit of lacing. Smells of toffee malts, cookie dough, and fig shisha. Tastes of richly smoked meats, accompanied by hickory maple glaze, and brown sugar malts. Almost no hop bitterness, but a great body. Best oatmeal stout Ive encountered.
scura buona schiuma piuttosto persistente aroma di cappucciono leggermente dolciastro morbida non molto amara poco tostato non in evidenza
dark pour.  minimal tan head.  chocolate and sweet malty nose.  smooth silky feel. very good.
Dark appearance with hints of ruby. Beige head with heavy lacing.   Flavor is a nice balance of sweet and bitter. Hints of chocolate and oatmeal.  Smooth, full mouthfeel.  Great oatmeal stout!

Virtually no head. Galaxian darkness. Thick and creamy viscosity. Notes of coffee and chocolate. Silky texture, roasted malts are abundant. Sweet with some bitterness mild taste to sweet again. For me the archetypal stout and good reason for lauding Samuel Smiths.
Black with a light tan head.  The aroma is of sweet brown sugar malt and fruity esters.  Flavor is sweet caramel, roasted malt with some bitterness at the finish.  Smooth texture and dry finish.

Bottle, August 07. Deep, opaque, black color with a creamy, tan-beige head. Tastes of dried fruits, raisins, figs, some sweet-nutty notes with a pleasant, earthy english hops ending. Mouthfeel is medium, silky, really flavorfull and drinkable. Cake and blackcurrant on the nose with a touch of tobacco. Nice, but in needs of some aroma muscle. Excellent, mild, comfortable stout.
Bottle, pours a murky brown with oatmeal colored head. Really unique brew.  Bitter, yet sweet at the same time with an almost chewable quality. Will have again.
excellent texture, smooth yet bittersweet. the oatmeal blends well with mild roasted flavor

Aroma and flavor of malt, barley, oatmeal, and berries.  The oatmeal was very nice as some many oatmeal stouts have little to no discernible oatmeal.  The flavor and palate were disrupted by a strong acidic and vinegar presence.  This was very distracting and turned what was otherwise a very smooth drink into one big wince.

(To celebrate my 30th anniversary, in Munich) Black colored, medium sized beige head. Strong aroma with roastiness, sweet caramel and some berries, indeed excellent aroma. Medium bodied. Flavor is also excellent with this same sweet caramelly roastiness, mild licorice and berries come also nicely up. Aftertaste is still sweet. Fine way for spending your birthday!

Bottle.  Beautiful, rich, dark appearance with quickly fading head.  More carbonated than I expected - but it didnt de-value the beer at all.  Slightly bitter taste - but it was sweet and smooth.  Wonderful taste.  Really enjoyable to drink.

Hmm surprised at how good the reviews are at this site for this beer.  I thought it was a little better than average.  It could be that it wa served to me too cold, so I may change this review later.  I felt that this beer did not have that much aroma or flavor compared to other stouts.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2008 Wow. Dark elixir...smells.. sweet malt and oats. No head after initial pour. Silky smooth going down following a robust mouthfeel. Nice full taste from a beer with only 5% abv.  Only Smith I really like alot.

I had this beer out of a bottle and I was very much impressed. It poured well and had virtually no head. It has a dark brown color typical of a stout. The flavor is strong, and has almost a sweet aftertaste. Great aroma and palate. Sweet enough to appease the senses but enough body to be manly. Excellent beer.

This beer pours a dark brown color with a mild head. It has a tart aroma and hints of toffee and coffee malt. As you drink it there is a smooth coffee flavor with minor fruit flavors mainly sour. The after taste is smooth and not as bitter as the initial taste.
UPDATED: FEB 24, 2008 Its hard to have anything negative to say about a classic beer like this.  Well made and it shows.  Sweetness that is not overpowering and compliments an exceptional beer.

Bottle from Shores Inn, SCS, MI.  This is a fantastic stout.  One of my favorites.  My friend said it best:  he expected it to be really strong in the oatmeal taste, but it was very subtle and sat well on the palate.  Definitely hints of caramel and coffee.  Fluffy tan head.  One of my favorites thus far.
Dark colour.. crystal. Smell coffee and caramel.Body is creamy and complex.. Flavour is carameal and coffee. Very lovely beer..
Slightly skunked, coffee, toffee, caramel.  Flavor is toffee, dark fruits, caramel, cream.  Nice body

Black, with a good tan head atop.  Smell is slightly sweet, and hearty oatiness.  Light sweet almost caramel like flavor with oat and high carbonation from the bottle initially, but which reduced drastically after sitting out for 15 minutes.  A really flavorful, smooth, easy to drink oatmeal stout with more umph to it that Youngs milder flavored version of the Oatmeal Stout.
12 oz at local pub. pours dark brown almost black with a creamy brownish head.tastes of caramel and oatmeal.finishes clean with an aftertaste of oats.exceptional brew, a must try.

big bottle: Poured a dark black with a creamy tan head. Large head of bubbles eventually settled. Nice aroma of chocolate, caramel, and....oatmeal I guess. Nice mouthfeel with chocolate leading the way. However, I did not find this to be as well balanced as other stouts (especially Beamish) and did not find it to be appreciably better than St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout (which is readily available in my area). What I didnt like was the licorice like aftertaste that seemed to linger. This did improve as the beer warmed but the damage was done. Ok....but not great.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Pours black with lasting big tan head.  Aroma of chocolate milk, cookie dough, fresh turned earth.  Fresh fruity raisiny flavor with strong choclate notes and clean fruity, tangy finish.  Medium body and low carbonation make for great mouthfeel.  In a word: delicious.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2007 one of the top 5 non-US brewed stouts. My wife and I compared it in a year long double blind taste test against a number of other imported stouts available in AZ and it was the clear winner... it also beat the best of the US stouts in the how many can we drink before it loses its charm test... THE BEST STOUT ON THE PLANET... so far

6-pack from Bayville Package Store in Selbyville, DE (just outside of Ocean City, MD)...pours black with a nice almond colored head...very subtle aroma of caramel and chocolate...taste is mildly sweet, malty...somewhat creamy mouth feel...this is a really good stout, one of the best I have tasted.

bottle. black with large pitted tan head and moderate lacing.  nice caramel aroma. very clean, smooth taste.  mild carbonation hits first, water, chocolate and malt.  its a quick burst of flavor on the palate and finishes clean, which makes it an extremely drinkable stout. crisp.

Bottle. Pours thick and almost black, with foamy brownish head. Aroma of toasty malt. Flavor is sweet toasty malt, but the finish is overwhelmed with a lingering almost burnt flavor. I experienced this more in the first 2 bottles of the 4 pack, so either they were bad or my taste has evolved. But the burnt taste was enough to make me uneasy about buying this again. But the other reviews are so positive that I may try this again in the future.

This was just plain awesome. It was very smooth, but very complex. Beautiful dark color, the smallish head had a tinge of red in it. Left little lacing. The taste was fantastic...very robust...and the taste improved as it warmed. Was very rich and sweet...I thought for a moment I couldnt drink too many of these, but by the time my glass was empty, I was lamenting my misfortune of not having another. A fantastic beer...redeemed the good Samuel Smith name after my disappointing encounter with the Nut Brown Ale.
Great beer, very creamy tasting, very smooth. Minor hints of the roasted barley. Be careful when you pour as you could get mega-head syndrome. We put this in our personal and mythical Top 15.

Strong aroma of malt and chocolate and (surprise!) oatmeal.  Very dry throughout -- means you get to drink more...no, you have to drink more!  Caramel and molasses flavors abound as well -- very complex taste and colors of dark brown with an unfiltered appearance.
Excellent stout.  Smells a little than it tastes.  Ends dry requiring you to take another drink.  Very addictive.  Tastes strongly of molasses.

550 ml bottle. pours a dark brown, with an off white head that quickly dissapates. Aroma is of raisins and black licorice. Flavor is slightly sweet, with roasted malts and anise. Mouthfeel is full and slightly creamy. The finish shows some light hopping, more black licorice and a bit of bittersweet chocolate. Overall a very respectable brew.
had this beer with a bake potato covered in chili, and cheese tonite.  i was expecting something a little thicker but was very pleased when it wasnt.  ill definitely be drinking this beer again.

Pours a dark dark brown with reddish hues under a dense tan head, thinning quickly.  The nose is sweet and fruity.  Peach?  Apple?  Apricot?  Not too sure, seems strange in this beer, though not unpleasant.  A bit of roast.  A creamy full mouthfeel, but largely because of carbonation levels, not the liquid itself.  Not a bad thing, still a good palate.  Small bubbles make this drinkable.  Sweet malt, a little chocolate.  Some definite diacetyl.  Some fruit apple sort of tartness?  The roast hits on the backend, but its very subdued.  A bit creamy.  Very strong diacetyl on the back end.  Buttery.  Some roast and fruit lingers.  There was a day when I thought this was a much better beer.

The Celebrated Oatmeal Stout is a deep, barely translucent, aubergine-colored ale topped with a huge, dry frothy head that looks the color of cinnamon sugar.  The retention and lacing are tenacious.  The aroma is of warm cookies, soft, sweet herbs and roasted malt.  Its very soft and even.  A soft, heavy texture slides down the throat.  Despite the rich, sweet flavor of this, the tounge is left a bit dry.  The first flavor is sugar and caramel.  Then comes an herbal element that is somewhere between fennel and tarragon; perhaps licorice.  The lengthy and marked aftertaste is of chocolate malt.  Yes, there is a reason this is an old favorite.  They sure can make stouts in England.

A very dark oil pour with a tan head.  Caramel, cream, oats, earthy, toasted malt, a hint of nuts and molasses. Oaty, cereal and malt taste with hints of cream, chocolate and molasses. Has a creamy smooth mouthfeel. A nice full body beer with lots of flavor and a very smoth slightly acidic finish from the hops. I have been waiting a while to try this beer, now I know what the hype was about. All around a very good beer. Must stock up!

Pours dark, dark brown, virtually black, with a tan foamy head. Nose is earthy and creamy: equal parts caramel and brown sugar against a pleasant roasted malt background. The taste is somewhat of a reverse of this. The sugary flavors, caramel and brown sugar, seem to dilute a little and provide a nice accent to roasted malts with chocolate notes as the latter two become the centerpiece of the taste. This reminded me an awful lot of hazelnut coffee with a little caramel, some sugar, and a lot of half and half, but those are just my own musings. Both the taste and mouthfeel are very creamy. The aftertaste retains the caramel sweetness and a portion of the nutty roasted malt flavor. Its a fine finish for a fine beer.
Malty, sugary, and hoppy. Very smooth and delicious, and Im not a stout drinker.
UPDATED: JUL 8, 2008 The strongest beer in their lineup up. Dark brown pour fluffy tan head.  Fresh oatmeal aroma.  Chocolate and coffee.  slightly thin bodied

Pours a dark pitch with a blood red tinge with a creamy foamy beige head. Aroma of caramel, brown sugar and light notes of roasted malts. The flavour is somewhat subtle for this style of brew, but appreciated, notes of caramel and light chocolate. Palate is not as thick as I like with this style, but not bad, sticky enough finish. All and all not bad, but Ive had better, try St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout.
Very dark with a superb roasted malt aroma.  Goes down smooth with a surprisingly sweet aftertaste.  One of the best stouts Ive had.

Pours a deep transluscent brown with a moderate tan head that forms a moment after the pour and fades quickly to a spotty film. The aroma is of roasted malts, rich chocolate and sweet sugar. Silky smooth palate and a finish that is true to what they advertise, "dry and bittersweet." Chewy and sticky, too. Nice bitterness in the finish to balance out the sticky sweetness. The oatmeal flavour is apparrent too. Not much complexity, but is a pleasure to sip.
Excellent flavor of roasted malt with oat characteristics.  It has that wonderful "chewy" consistency you need in a good oatmeal stout.  A total winner.
Good stout, a little over rated though. It has an excellent roasted malt flavor, but lacks the complexity of some other stouts. Almost completely lacking in hop flavor.

This will undoubtedly turn into one of my most favorite beers. Nice dark brown color and head. Slightly malty aroma but not overpowering. Taste is l;light chocolate malt and smooth, smooth smooth.

This beer can even be called refreshing which I dont think can be said of many stouts.

One of the very best stouts on the market

im probably going to re rate this after i drink it again because the first time i didnt really like it that much but since everyone seems to love it maybe i should give it another go. i think the first taste was situational to me not liking it

(Bottle) Pours dark with a beautiful deep red shimmer. Light brown, big head. Light roasted aroma of milk chocolate and cocoa. Malt also brings some caramel. Undertones of stone, roasted nuts, suede, sweet liquorice, vanilla, birch twigs and black currant. Good malt blend flavour wise, with tones of cocoa, caramel and some hints of coffee dryness. Some milky notes are also present. Light acid. Velvety and round mouthfeel with a soft carbonation. Aftertaste is also a bit acid with bigger notes of coffee. Light dry finish. Medium body.

Pours oily black with tan head.  Roasted malts are obvious on the nose as well as a flowery bouquet with sugary, light figgy hints with a grainy touch to it. The aromas are toasted with features of  both vanilla and chocolate. The flavor is rounded, sugary, features caramel and is certainly "oaty".  There is a drying but smooth biterness to the finish, but it is well balanced by a sweet maltiness. Certianly a nice stout
Very classic stout (and good for you too!).  Tasted of roasted malt, coffee, and darker hues.  A good balanced stout with a nice appearance and good head right from the bottle.
I love this beer. It was very dark and had a nice thick, brown head with staying power. A very malty beer, and I could really taste, well, the oats. A thick drink with a strong, lingering finish.

Poured from a bottle.  Very dark brown, nearly opaque, with a one finger khaki colored head that didnt last long.  At first, oddly enough, the beer smelled like red wine.  After the head died down the aroma was roasted malt and coffee.  Taste is a little sweet, then coffee.  Slightly bitter at the end.  Mouthfeel is nice, but a bit thin-bodied for a stout.  Overall a very good beer.
550 mL bottle.  Dark brown with creamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, grain, and malt.  Chcolate and oatmeal taste with a hint of coffee in the finish.

Pours a dark chocolate color. Thick tan head with an aroma of roasted malt. Smells sweet with an almost cocoa feel. Feels heavy and creamy and finishes off with a slight bitterness. Overall well rounded.
Always a solid choice - Nice dark pour with a plentiful tan head.  Aroma is roasty with some choco/coffee.  Smooth and flavorful with lots of coffee, roast, and a bit of licorice.

Bottle. Pours dark, nearly opaque brown with thick beige head. Pungent nose - vinuous upfront, some sourness and light scent of chocolate. Also some hint of floral aroma. Great fully body is the first impression on tasting. Creamy mouthfeel. Complex malt flavors - nutty, a hint of sweetness, wholesome grain flavors. Also, some very delicate wine notes. Some sourness in the background. Dry bitter finish.

Pours deep brown.  Nice head, dissipates slowly, keeps a rim.  Smells nicely of roasted malt, definitely smells like a stout.  Very smooth mouthfeel, slightly bitter-sweet aftertaste.  Light stout with respect to mouthfeel but maintains a full taste.  Very very drinkable, excellent brew.
Worse Stout Ive had so far.  dark/medium amber, full/medium bodied, wont drink again.  wont have another sam smith again either, very disappointing.

Pours blkack as midnight and offers classic coffee notes on the nose.  The mouthfeel pushes the oat flavor to a nice deep level and the malt shows some light hints of sweetness.  The finish is long and pronounced.

Bottle.  Really surprised by this one.  Pours completely black with a head that settled into a constant little foam on top of the liquid which I love.  Flavor is not super complex but enough to keep it interesting.  It is very drinkable.  I would drink this again and that is the real test.

Appearance: very dark. Big head, beige color, compact and persistent.
Aroma: toasty malty, stewed oat, candy, sweet chocolate and grain coffee. Touches liquory and winy. Notes of black olives, roasted sugar, cherries and figs. Mainly sweet.
Flavor: Sweet, roasted cereals, candy, handcrafted bitter chocolate and coffee. Fruitness of figs, plums and cherries. Presence of clove, moka and smoked. Liquory. Finish with low-medium dryness, but persistent. Complex and balanced flavor.
Palate: medium to full body. Creamy and silky texture. Low carbonation.
I love this beer, is very exquisite, great stout.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 re-rated:  old rating 6/5/9/4/18 - 4.2 on June 17, 2007.

pour is a black with a tint of red, large khaki head, very good lacing.
smell is subdued, it is a definite roasted grain, chocolate and coffee, and a hint of oatmeal.
tastes is a full body, creamy and thick feel, coffee, milk and powered chocolate, oatmeal, end is on the dry side, a little bit bitter comes through.
excellent stuff. flavours of toasted malts, chocolate, treacle, coffee. oatmeal gives a very smooth, balanced, dryish finish. cant wait to try this again.

A great stout, but not as sweet as I would have expected from a sweet stout. Pours completely black with a nice head and great aroma of coffee and sourness. Carbonation and mouthfeel is right on, with a sour rather than milky finish. But great mouthfeel and finish like a good cup of coffee. Id like another.
caramel aroma, black stout with two inches of brown foam, medium sourness, lightly bitter, licorice and chocolate finish. nice stout.

Pours nearly black and has a nice brown head that is rather large at first. Nice strong roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate aroma. Flavour starts with roasted malt and chocolate with a little coffee and smoothly turns to a mostly coffee with some chocolate finish. On the sweet side, but not overly so. Carbonation is just right and the body is on the full side, but it feels very smooth. Im extremely pleased with this brew and with every sip I notice something new about it. The fact that it is smooth and easy to drink are nice bonuses. Its been only very recently that Ive been interested in stouts, and Im glad it led me to try this very good brew.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Great "starter stout." Pours dark brown with a nice tan head. Rich chocolatey aroma. Taste is very smooth and light, yet still packs that stout punch. Very drinkable as far as stouts go. Probably Samuel Smiths finest.

Super dark brown. held up to the light it can almost look blood red. i agree with the "not much on the nose". very sweet. very espresso. i feel like there is a coating in my mouth. like i need a water chaser. for a guy that isnt into the stout and got this as a birthday present, its certainly not bad.

Poured from "Victorian Pint" 550 ml bottle into English pub pint glass. 

Beer is absolutely opaque -- just black, with a nice medium-tan head that retains nicely. 

Flavor is sweeter than Wee Heavy, but with a smidge more hops. Bitter chocolate and espresso notes abound, with a bit of milkiness, and flavor is consistent throughout the warm-down. Not as "chewy" as Wee Heavy, but not as heavily carbonated as Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter. All in all, mouthfeel, flavor and drinkability are spot-on. 

This may well be Samuel Smiths best, and would make an excellent "cordial" for the beer drinkers. I dont believe I would want to drink Oatmeal Stout in a session, but it certainly qualifies as a great beer to start or end the session.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2009 not much on the nose... flavor does not have enough roasted malt. bitter chocolate prevails. nice and creamy with a bitter sweet toffee finish.  needs something up front 648417 3.9 ...bottle aged 2 years...pours woody dark brown with a thin beige head. woody aroma with lots of molasses. flavor is still lightly burnt malts, some creamy chocolate, dry nuttiness and a mild coffee finish. creamy oatmeal texture. 747417 3.9
9/23/09. nutty caramel cremes with a shot of coffee in the aftertaste. not really deep or complex but it is solid and well crafted. 8/4/8/4/17/4.1

Very nice stout and the oatmeal flavor does come across in the flavor. The big head that forms when pouring is mostly gone after a few minutes and leaves a lot of lacing in the glass. Aroma of chocolate with roasty grain undertones. Very good mouthfeel. Sweet aftertaste. Very solid beer.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Bottle.  Pours dark, dark brown/black and fairly opaque.  The head is tan, recedes quickly.  Its silky, silky smooth with a nice long finish, sweet with just a touch of bitterness.  Oatmeal is noticeable without being overwhelming.  Plenty of roasty malts.

One of my old favorites.  Pours a very dark brown to black with a good sized brownish head with some lacing.  Roasted malt is the dominant flavor, but the oatmeal is noticeable and it provides a unique smoothness.  Very drinkable stout that is uncommonly smooth.  Strong recommendation.

woops, didnt take any notes when I rated this, just punch away the numbers. Anyway, black, firm head. Roasted aroma with some malts and oats. Not as oatmealish as I would have expected, very pleasant and nice

Pours a deep dark opaque brown color with a medium, tan head, big bubbles a slight lacing.  Smells of chocolate, roasted nuts, biscuit, yeast and malt on the nose.  The taste completely coats and warms the palate.  There is a slight oatmeal taste on the front, with some maltiness to follow it up.  This is very nice sweet stout.

This beer is dark brown with a nice creamy beige head. Strong sweet smell of oatmeal and molasses with a hint of sourness in the background. Tastes of bittersweet chocolate and slight dry roasted oats with a pleasant, mild bittersweet aftertaste

550 ml bottle.  Pours an opaque rosey amber with a dense tan head.  Roasty nose with hints of toffee and molasses.  Full, well-balanced body with a medium dry finish.  Lingering notes of toffee and roasted barley with a slight edge.

Very rich, dark stout color with hints of amber.  I love how this beer feels when you drink it - heavy body but not overwhelming.  Leaves slight lacing which is indicative of its body.  Very solid taste with an excellent finish for a stout.

I have drank this beer so many times and just realized that I havent rated it, Duh! A nice aroma of roasted cereal with a hint of sweetness.Pours a nice rich oil color with a tan head that dissipated quickly.Lots of flavor here.Roasted malts, oats, and chocolate.Finish was slightly bitter.
Big tan, large buble lasting head.  Black pour.  Malt, chocolate aroma.  Well balanced flavor.  Nice mouthfeel with somewhat dry finish.

Pours black with ruby highlights and a large creamy tan head. The aroma is heavy roasted malt, chocolate, toffee and molasses. Medium-bodied, slick and satisfying with a slightly metallic finish; this is a tasty stout. Sweet roasted malts, molasses and light coffee conclude with a lingering roasted malt finish.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2008 This is my ole stand-by.  If Im not interested in exploring other tastes and want something I know will give me extremely satisfaction, I reach for this beer.  It has just the right blend of oatmeal and other flavors that do not overwhelm nor offend.  It doesn t go out on a limb and has great balance which makes it enjoyable repeatedly.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 May 16, 2007; 12 oz. (?) bottle sampled at The Copper Turret, Morrisville NY.  Unable to take contemporaneous notes, but this is a wonderful sweet stout -- aromatic, smooth and satisfying. Highly recommended.

Re-rate on Feb. 18. 2008. A scrumptious stout -- oats & brown sugar in the nose.  Subtle bitterness on the back end provides enjoyment between sips. Full-bodied & "dessert-like", but not overbearing.  A wonderful brew.

355 ml bottle at $2.75. for some strange reason a bigger bottle is $8? this stout is ok and drinkable. perhaps it goes well with my wifes fresh fruit and honey drizzle. anyway it is surely lacking from some of the best i have had. particularly in body and in appearance.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2007 550ml clear bottle, $3.99.  Aroma is moderately malty with roasted coffee and chocolate.  Average sized light brown frothy/foamy head that mostly diminished leaving virtually no lace.  Dark red/brown body.  Flavor is lightly sweet and bitter the whole way through and finishes short for a stout.  Palate is light to medium and watery with a little carbonation.  The aroma and flavor of roasted malt is really good but its a watery brew with a head thats not creamy enough (too fizzy).

550 ml BROWN bottle. Poured a little thin for  a stout and developed a head that was a little to fizzy also. Aroma is a on the sweet side for a stout and a little one dimensional also. Flavor isslightly better with some roasted malt notes, slight hop bitterness, and a little erthy yeastiness too. This one is average and needs more of anything to set itself off from the rest.
Bottle, aromas of grainy oats and toffee. Black body with tan head. Body had a carbination cola presence. Also sweet malted oats flavor. Sweet malt aftertaste on palate.

550ml brown bottle. The Key word here is molasses. Poured the color of molasses and the undercurrant taste was of molasses. Very smooth. A little on the light side for a stout. I enjoyed it and will buy it again.

As I was looking in my cellar, and at alllll the quality bottles Ive kept as souvenirs...I saw an old friend. This one right here was my perfect introduction into the world of Stouts. Sure theres a lot better out there...but theres many more that are far worse. The definition of a "4" Beer.

deep purple brown with light brown thick head. has a sweet, chocolate lightly spiced vanilla winelike  aroma. medium to thick body  with light carbonation. initially smooth and creamy with plum and chocolate sweetness , and a nice and light roasted, earthy coffee bitterness. overall a greatly balanced beer, classic, and definitive of this style
aroma was nice, but very faint for me.  good dark stout appearance. Does have that great roasted oat taste. Smooth going down, very enjoyable.

Pours a dark beer with a light brown rim. 
Smell s like coffee and dark roasted malt. Little sweet in taste with lots of coffee and dark chocolate. Finishes long, bitterish and a little sweet. Very decent classical stout.

Rated 1/8/06:  For all of the hype surrounding this beer I would consider this no more than average in overall quality. I was so excited to open this up but after a few pulls I realized that although this is a good stout it is merely average to me. Next time I will spend less money on a better stout.

Bottle. A nice black color with some ruby undetones and an amazing and lasting milk chocolate head. Roasted malt aroma mingles with hints of cookies and chocolate. The taste is most definetely of roasted coffee and sweet fruit with the lasting finish bringing through this great chocolate taste. Good feel and complexity.
Dark brown with a big, light brown head. Aroma has molasses, coffe and dark chocolate. Well balanced hops, dark roasted malts. Overall a great english beer.

First time I had this I enjoyed it alot. However the bottle i had this weekend wasnt as enjoyable. Chocolate/molasses taste with a slight hint of coffee. Bitter. My least favorite part was the metal flavor I got. Maybe it was from the foil ever though i poured it into a pint glass. This is a very viscous beer and will leave you full!

Pitch black with creamy brown head. Roasted malts - nice chocolate/caramel & coffee. Both aroma and taste - very enjoyable. Smooth pleasant creamy body & mouthfeel. Light bitter roast end. Overall quite simple - but very nice!
Picked one up at Sun Flower market for 2.50 or so. Pours very dark black. Tasted a bit like dark chocolate, coffee, a little bitter. Overall a great beer to drink after spending all day painting!

Deep and rich chestnut to near black in color with a breathtaking amber head. Slight wine-like aroma with a slight scent of oats as well. Smooth mouthfeel, akin to a fine Port with flavors of plum and raisins that finish quite dry on the palate.

Bottle. Dark brown with a big, light brown head that seemed somewhat unstable. Big chocolate aroma combines with dough and earth. Malty flavours with hints of bitter-sweet chocolate, coffee and some tart fruit. Medium body, quite soft. A classic
Black in colour, with a burnt roats maly nose, a deep roast malt and coffe tones with a a little bitter and a long roast finish
The perfect beer while taking a break on the slopes.  Sweet, yet dry.  Itll warm you up and make you feel hearty.

Bottle. Pours a very dark black with dark red edges. Aroma has molasses, coffe and dark chocolate. Oily mouthfeel, slightly fresh - low carbonation. Roasted flavours dominate, some chocolate, some dry bitterness at the end. Nice and very well-balanced.

Aroma is apple pie and vanilla. Pours very dark reddish brown, with a brown head. Well balanced hops, dark roasted malts, soy sauce. Finish is apple core that lasts just the right amount. Perfectly balanced with good complexity. Absolutely delightful.

You have to love molasses to love this one.  I first tried Sam Smiths about 15 years ago when they entered the US market, and it tastes quite a bit different today than it did then.  Today its almost all molasses, then it was a more full bodied complex stout.  Then it was a 4, today a 3.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2007 Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout
550ml bottle
Recent bottling (SG13B1), celebrated 04/07
Medium pour in an English pint

Poured black with opaque mahogany highlights with a large rocky somewhat lasting head.

Smelt of strong molasses, roasted malt, and light dark chocolate, stone.

Taste was upfront strong bittersweet dark chocolate followed by a strong bitter roasted malt, almost burnt and moderate sweet dark chocolate on a long finish.

Palate was medium bodied, creamy, softly carbonated and moderately astringent.

Overall, a great straightforward rewarding oatmeal stout that tastes great.

Taste was upfront

Roasted malt and some slight chocolate in the aroma.Pours black with a thin tan head.Got some slight chocolate ans someroasted malt in the flavor.Mouthfeel was very thin with a slight bitter chocolate finish.

18.7 oz bottle from Whole Foods in Hillcrest. Pours a deep black with a smallish tan head that left good lacing on the glass. 3rd beer of the night and I am not getting much in flavor. A little chocolate and some brown sugar. Very good but again very little alcohol.
This is the best beer Ive ever had...If you like a full bodied stout with a full and complex roasted flavor, this beer is for you.

I enjoyed this stout much more than the Imperial as well. A pretty seshful brew, not too great of an appearance though. Small head that brings out some sugary notes of molasses and roasted malt. Oats in the flavor bring out a nice earthy flavor  that compliments the palate. A nice brew.

Bottle.Thick off white head.Black.Sweet malt and chocolate and dark brown sugar aroma.Malty bittersweet flavor.Medium body.
Well done.

Im normally not a fan of porters/ stouts, but I enjoyed every drop of this brew. Almost entirely opaque with a pleasant creamy head. Flavor is wonderfully balanced and not offensive in the least, and while it is not terribly thick, just one bottle was enough to satisfy. Outstanding!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2007 I like this one better than the impy - - a little bit sweet, nothing too intimidating and very drinkable.  Nice taste and a good beer to use as a stepping stone to the bigger boys.  Nice brew

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma is lightly sweet.  Smells of roasting, malts, a little cream, and chocolate.  Poured black in color with a large, creamy, brown head that lasted throughout.  Small lacing.  Opaque.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, chocolate, oats, and roasting.  Very well balanced.  Medium, silky body.  Soft carbonation.  Dryish lightly sweet, lightly bitter, malty-chocolate finish.  Overall, a very good sweet stout.

Bottle. 1 Pint 2.7 FL. OZ. Very dark brown with tan head.  Aromas of dark chocolate and malt.  Smooth, full-bodied palate.  Flavor is sweeter than expected at first with a nice bitter finish.  Very drinkable stout.

bottle.  Pours midnight black with a head that dissipates quickly. Aroma and flavor of sweet molasses, chocolate, and coffee.  Tastes sort of like chocolate cake.  Lighter mouthfeel than I was expecting, but still a decent stout.

jet black pour with decent head that quickly disappeared to a light covering. aroma of roasted malt with a light sweet undertone. slightly sweet with the first sip. cereal/grains with a bit of roasted bittterness on the sides. smooth easy drink with consistent flavors throughout. enjoyable session stout.

Been drinking this for a long time but never saw this in dark glass, black pour with creamy lasting lilght brown head with fair lacing, burnt/toasted oat odor, light carbonation, decently malty, light hops,  sweet, thick and creamy to syrupy, a little bit of sour milk.  Hints of chocolate and molassas as it warmed...A decent meal...An old favorite.

When I found out a local bar was serving some new beers, I rushed on over, and I must say, I was glad I did.  First off, the bottle is clear, but the beer is so dark you cant tell that at first.  It also has a dark tan head.  Heavy, but easy to drink the hops are very clear, but so too are the malts.  It gets even better as it warms.

This stuff pours out like motor oil!  It is super thick and almost completely opaque with a dark brown head.  It has a very strong roasted taste with hints of chocolate and caramel that lingers long after the first sip.  This is one tasty stout!

Definitve molasses aroma with light hoppiness. Somehow they squeezed an oak tast into this doughy malt. Certainly, too fizzy for my taste, then I see it is artificial. The head, as an arificial one would, dies almost instantly. The carbonation is lively, to the point of overbearing. It has a slight alcoholic taste to it, and the oatmeal taste never fully comes out, as it does with some others Ive had. Overall, I wouldnt turn it aay, but wouldnt seek it out either.

Very dark brown with creamy tan head. Aroma is sweetish roasted malt. Flavor has distinct molasses, coffee, nutty, and vineous notes. Medium bitterness on the finish. Good, but sweeter and thinner than I remember.

12oz bottle.  Pours fairly dark black with red edges and a small, bubbly tan head.  Aroma is subtle, sweet malts and a little bit of chocolate.  Roastiness increases as it warms up.  Has a smooth, creamy mouthfeel with some sweetness and a chocolate finish.  Very nice body on this.  This is really good stuff.

Appearance: Pours an opaque black body with a small, creamy, light yellowish head.

Smell: Sweetish, malty aroma with hints of milk-soaked, cinnamon-sugar coated bread crusts and red wine.

Taste: The flavor is predominately sweet with flavors of chocolate, coffee, and molasses. Theres also a slight roasty balancing bitterness, though it still manages to finish semi-sweet as the chocolate emerges once more.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body with a soft carbonation, but its silky smooth, I must say!

Drinkability: A nice, light, sweet stout fit for any time of day, including 8:30 in the morning!

Bottled from Trader Joes.  Pours a dark black with large grayish head.  Smells of chocolate and malts, but much weaker than expected.  The taste is also quite weak, but delicious with chocolate and oatmeal.  It would have been better if it was stronger.

Bottle at Angels in the Field in Marylebone (London), pours dark black with a large foamy off-white head. A roasted malt aroma with a good fruity hoppiness. Quite bitter and hoppy in the mouth, roasted malt, but a little grainy. But pretty good.
pours black with a nice foamy head filling 2/3 of the glass.  Aroma is bitter with light sweetness.  Great bitter taste, with the burnt chocolate and bready quality to it.  Perfect cap on an evening.
UPDATED: SEP 10, 2007 Dark brown with big, foamy tan head / Malty, fresh dough nose / Medium body with good finish / Simple, somewhat sweet flavors of roast malts and molasses / Solid, plain stout.
Pours black with a nice brown head. Aromas of chocolate and caramel. Chocolate and roasted malts are very nicely balanced with a dry finish. Very Good stout.

12 oz bottle. Poured dark black with a thick brown head which lasted a long time. Significant lacing. Aroma was of chocolate and nuts. Taste was quite complex. Noticed barley, malt, chocolate and bread. Thick palate with long lasting finish. Very good stuff.

Nice inky black with a thick tan head.  Smells of chocolate, a little bready, probably the oatmeal.  Nice roasty taste, a little burnt coffee at the end.  A very tasty stout.

Winking Lizard Tour 2007

this was the very first beer that made me get excited about beer.  Ten years later I finally got another one - actually another several.  Just a sweet, smooth, wonderful stout made by an exceptional brewery.  This is my fave Sam Smiths, and, in its own way, maybe my favorite stout.  Although comparing the sweetness of an oatmeal to the bitterness of a traditional Irish is apples and oranges.  This feels like silk on the palate, chocolatey and smooth.  Only points lost for me are in appearance - the head goes too quickly, and never looks like other stouts that i have loved. Drink this!

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2009 Light Roast and coffee...mils aroma for stye.  Dark brown with creamy, frothy head...decent lacing.  Mild nutty, coffee, roasted, and blackberry, flavour.  Watery with bitter finish.

Pretty good sweet stout. Pours black and looks pretty thick. The beer has a sweet aroma that opens up more and more as you drink the beer. The beer at times was fruity and nutty, and then also had subtle coffee notes. The beer was nice and creamy and was a pleasure to drink. This and Taddy Porter are my two favorites of the Samuel Smith brand.

Ahhhh.  How refreshing it is to drink something today that meets the definition of stout. Nut browns and porters can jump!  The creamy chocolate of this is pure bliss in a bottle. Silky is right on. If I could make beer like this, id be retired by now. Very similar in body to youngs oatmeal.  A groovy and fine pint.

Bottle.  Pour is deep black, with a settling tan head.  Only aroma present is a faint roasted malt.  Taste is very smooth, with the mild roast flavor.  Finish really wasnt much at all.   I now have had several Oatmeal Stouts from producers I respect, and it is time to come to the conclusion that I am not wild about this style.

Slightly translucent in a generally opaque appearance. A plethora of flavors that is very smooth and satisfying. A slight hint of plum and the oatmeal makes this beer very palatable for a stout.  A very nice beverage.
UPDATED: APR 10, 2012 Now in 12 oz. brown bottle. Sweetish, roasted malt flavor. Excellent head and smooth body.

550ml bottle poured aggressively into a 20 ounce snifter, leaving a one finger, creamy, mocha head which faded to a thin frothy coating and nice lacing on the glass.

Appearance is dark enough to let almost no light through. 

Smell is nice and malty and taste follows with the same maltiness along with some dark fruit and molasses.

The mouthfeel is medium bodied and drinkability is very good.

After seeing this so many times and hearing so many good things about it, I finally broke down and grabbed some. I rarely buy imports these days, due to the high number of awesome domestic craft beers.

Now I can say Ive had it and I enjoyed it enough to know I can fall back on it if I ever find myself with a limited selection. This almost always seems to be available.

Bottle. Alcohol and chocolate malt nose. Some woody and oat aromas, slight hint of cherries, nuts, and toffee. Very faint coffee  at the end. Pours dark black with a very thin brown head. Flavor is way heavier on the coffee and chocolate than oatmeal. Strange sour-metallic finish. Palate is smooth but lacking some body.

dark brown/black  with good tan head.  chocolate, molasses aroma. very smooth mouthfeel. malty flavor predominantly with some dark fruits.  one of my first stouts and still a favorite readily available stout.
Great stout.  3$ for a 550ml.  Taste like grains without a hop/bitter taste. finishes with an easy 5% after.  wish i had his on tap for session drinking at the bar.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2007 Pour from a 550 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown/black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of a chocolate covered biscuit from down home.  Throw in some dark frits and hops and that about sums it up.  The flavor is smooth and balances the sweet malts, hops, oatmeal, and fruits quite well.  This beer is easy to drink unlike other heavy stouts on the market.  From notes.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2007 Bottle poured in pint glass. Opaque chocolate brown with 4 finger, lasting tan head that forms a nice crusty lacing. Aroma is at first cookie or biscuit-like, then molasses with slight chocolate and hops. Taste is incredibly smooth, enticingly sweet malt balanced well with hops, a trace of smoke flavor, and dark fruit. Quite a complex taste. Palate is medium and velvet, beer is not so heavy and filling as some stouts, definitely could have three or four of these. Hard to believe this beer has been pasteurized as in the description? I cant recall sampling a better stout.
Deep black of color with a beige head. A nice aroma with notes of roasted malt, hae, plums and sweets. Nice flavor with roasted malt, coffee, plums and sweets.

Bottle... This is one of the best stouts I have ever had.  Poured a deep black with a light brown, frothy head. A nice smoked, cocoa-like, malt aroma. The palate is really creamy and foamy. Almost like taking a sip of a latte... very silky.  Flavors of choclate and other sweets, barley, caramel, malt and a little hops. Dry finish with a nice aftertaste that has a lingering cookie/oatmeal flavor.  This is definitely a must have beer.
This is great! Smooth and malty with a satisfying bitter edge. Looks fab! VERY dark, head is tight and lasts well. A crackin stout.
UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 OK Stout.. Tastes very similar to Taddy.  Not the oatmeal character that I expected. Somewhat overrated.
Nice stout. Nothing overly special about it. Nice smooth taste, good with a nice steak.

every knows that the best kind of stout is the oatmeal kind. And Sam Smith does a nice job at this one too. Much better than average stout because of the chocallate presence. always wanted to try this on draft. but as of yet that day has not come..........well i guess i will just lay into a hole untill it does.

Not as good as I remembered it to be.. Aroma a bit of vinegar and wine.. I may have gotten an inferior bottle (clear glass), I didnt notice much of the oatmeal and sweet grains that characterize it..

Poured from a 550ml clear bottle into a pint glass. Pours a dark brown, black body with a medium brown head. Resolves to a brown right. Slight lacing. Aroma of alcohol, sweet malts and some hops. Medium carbonation, creamy mouthfeel. Oatmeal and malt on the tongue. Flavor is oatmeal, malts, light hops. Finish is sweet, hint of bitterness, with some chocolate and burnt malt. Overall very, very nice. Now, just get rid of those clear bottles!
A dark root beer brown with at medium tan head; somewhat sweet start with a long lasting finish.

Had this out of a 550 ml brown glass bottle. One of the first really good beers I first had back in 1993. The color is garnet/dark brown. Aroma is slightly alcoholic and moderately hoppy. Frothy tan head. Taste is sweet, with a pronounced chocolate taste as the beer warms.

Classic example of the style should not be missed but why the clear bottle.Had my first one in the Houston airport served in a frosted glass. Page 403 of Michael Jacksons Great Beer Guide and only 264 of his 500 Classic Brews to go.
Twas a good beer! Malty tast to it. Bittersweet ending to this one, oatmealy if thats a word.

Jet black with a solid tan head.  nose is sweet and flavor is also with a malty licorice-like flavor.  a nice balanced finish.  much more powerful than most oatmeal stouts, which tend to be more subdued.  very nice

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2007 Bottle. Black Pour thin tan head. Caramel and sugar aroma. Beer looked amazing taste was suprisingly a little thin for my likings but I really expected worse. Good bittery dry finish. This was pretty goood.
Tap @ Gingerman, Austin. Smells sweet, with a nose of caramel and molasses. Taste is oaty and thick, with a delicate roasted malt flavor. A very good sweet stout.

Pours black opaque with a large mocha colored head.The Nose is of alcohol and dates.The flavor was of chocolate malts.Mild hops and bitter aftertaste.It had a nice palate leaving you refreshed.Overall a good brew I like Samuel Smiths Imperial Stout and Porter much much better and will stick with them.

550ml bottle. Dark brown, almost black color. Nice thick tan head.  Aroma is your typical stout with an amazing hint of grain.  Flavor is nothing less than amazing.  It is roasty, grainy, full of sweetness and has a surpurb bitter dry finish.

WOW...I thought this was dark brown/black on first pour, but when held to the light it was actually a dark ruby! Beautiful large tan head that lasted a while. Smelled sweet, caramel and molases...Taste was thick, sweet, oats, some very light coffee, and a slightly bitter finish...This was an excellent oatmeal stout! Quite enjoyable indeed!

Aroma of wood and roasted grain. Near opaque brown/black with ruby hilites using halogen. Decent tan head with a bit of lacing. Full mouth feel, a hint of sweet, a lot of roasted grain. Very smooth toasty drink. Nice balance of hop and grain at the end, evidencing a burnt/bitter dryness.
Cant go wrong with this beer. Very flavorful if stouts are your thing.
Yea...this is an old friend indeed! This is what we drank at my wedding! A special beer indeed! I usually like my beers a bit more dark...but this one is just fine!
A consistantly well brewed beer. A full malty aroma, medium body, and cerial overtones make this beer a favorite.
Pours a dark brown, small tan head.  Smoky aroma.  It feels a little thin, but has a nice strong flavor.  Creamy finish.
an old friend, simple and balanced.  rich malty texture and taste.  the grains shine in an honest, straight forward beer.

Bottle. Deep rich color, like smoked, burned cedar. Filmy, clingy, bubbly, khaki colored head with broken ring like lacing. Has the scent of a natural nutty whole smell with notes of molasses, dark soy, caramel and oak. This beer has such an intense, deep flavor that is reminiscent of almost a red wine or brandy, but the palate is creamy. Yet it is sharp and refreshing. This is a fantastic beer.
pours a tan head, so smooth, finishes with a hint ofoats and coco, not overwhelming. bottle and damn delicious

An excellent combination of stout and oatmeal. The aroma is delecious with the smell of oatmeal and cinnamon. Pour is nice with a thick head. Flavor is tremendous with the taste of roasted oats and cinnamon. A great brew.
Bottle.  Pours an almost black dark brown with a medium amount of thick, tan head.  Aroma is very malty.  Flavor is very malty...and very tasty.  This is a darn fine brew.  Could drink this all dy.

Poured from a 550ml bottle into a pint glass, pitch black with a big chocolate malt head that dissipates quickly. The aroma was lof grain and malts. The taste was a bit thinner than I expected with notes of sugary sweetness, malt, oats and a hint of chcolate and coffee.

Bottle - Black with creamy tan head.  Malty, nutty, hint of chocolate aroma - silky smooth, good balance of bitterness.  Roasted barley, oatmeal flavor with chocolate overtones.  This is a decent stout, but not the best.  Definitely a beer to pair with a juicy steak - maybe for dessert, cheesecake.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2007 550ml Bottle shared with a friend at Bar Volo. Poured into an English Pint with a fairly minimal beige head. Full-bodied with a medium-thick mouthfeel. Smell was immediately of oatmeal, roasted barley, burnt coffee beans and malt. Taste definitely met my expectations. Flavour was of espresso beans, roasted barley, dark chocolate and malt. Definitely worth every penny. Great stout right here.

One of my all-time favs. i agree with what some people are saying with lacking complexity, but that is one of the reasons i love this beer. i can drink them continuously! 

pours like delicious chocolate, strong, malty aroma, starts out silky smooth and finishes the same way, chocolate and slightly sweet molasses flavors a rich malt. great with italian food.
What a beer.  Is it just me or is this beer a meal.  Like great pizza you will want more and more no matter how full you are.Aroma, Palete, And looks..a great beer.

Delicious! 3rd beer from Sam Smiths and each time a try a new one I cant understand why I dont drink more of them. Pour was a thick dark brown with a thin ring head that went POOF and disappeared. The aroma was sweet malt. The taste was roasted malt, oatmeal and chocolate with a thin mouthfeel and sweet aftertaste. As this beer warms up, it just gets better and better.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: If I am only going to get one more beer before I put beer away for life, this is the beer I am going to have.  Each sip reminds me why I have a spare tire.  Sam Smiths Oatmeel Stout is a must have for any beer lover.  I only rate this beer less than a 20 because I have hope that some day something better will come along.
Extremely smooth.  Just the right hint of oatmeal.  Great balance overall.  Beautiful to see in the glass.  Great partner for spicy food.

Pours dark, almost black with a thin tan head that doesnt linger. 
Aroma is malty with a late hint of molasses.
Nice flavor that evolves overtime.  Well blended flavor that doesnt really stand out to me.  Nice for an introduction to stouts, but not as complex or unique as many others.  
Nice overall palate.  Good amount of carbonation and a nice mouthfeel

overall a nice but not stand out stout

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Good but not great.  Has a mildly sweet flavor that I like but not very much complexity.  Finishes semi sweet with some bitterness that I enjoy.  I wouldnt recommend if you dont like your stouts chocolately.  A little thin, kind of lacking in that dept.  Could benefit from being thicker.  I feel this is an overrated beer but it isnt hard to swallow by any means.
Definately a favorite.  Pricey but well worth it.  Gotta love the presentation

This comes in brown bottles nowadays. Poured a neary opaque black with a off-white head. Sweet bready aroma of cookie-dough, vanilla and sugar, plus that certain metallic Samuel Smith twang. Better than I expected. Pretty dry flavours, decent roastiness but once again that typical metallic/hard-water Samuel Smith taste. Well balanced, yet tame. A pleasant, long finish. Medium mouthfeel, not as substantial & chewy as I hoped, yet good carbonation levels. Decent brew, seems a bit stale & lifeless though (just like Samuel Smiths other offerings - it might be the pasteurization/filtering/artificial carbonation). I prefer wilder & bolder stouts.

Really well done, as usually Sammy Smith does.  Had to wait for this to warm up at The Office but once it did, all the flavor came out, carbonation nice and light, enough roasty to balance the sweet chewiness.

I am sorry but I dont find this drinkable at all, particularly if its served below room temperature (which it invariably is - straight fromt the fridge). The pasteurisation has really killed off a lot of the flavour. Over carbonated. Theres also something I dont like about the sweet flavour. For me this is a real fall back, when in a Sam Smiths pub without a good selection.

This version from Sam Smiths pours a nice deep black with a thin tan buttery head.  Very smooth as the flavor from the oatmeal and the hops is subdued but dont fret, theres still plenty of flavor here.  Light aftertaste will have you reaching for another sip quickly. Very drinkable. If youre not careful youll find yourself taking a cab home.  If stouts are your thing, make sure this ones on your to do list.
Black with a tan head.  Smells deeply of roasted malt and chocolate.  Wonderful balance nad great taste.  Excellent stout.
UPDATED: FEB 11, 2007 Smooth and sweet with a very slight bitter finish.  A tad bit on the thin side compared to Samuel Smiths Imperial Stout.

This thing pours damn near pitch black, with a nice sized dark tan foam head. The smell is sweeeet, with very little alcohol in it. Almost smells liek a Trappist rochfort 10. The taste is very good, but nothing overwhelmingly great. Very light for a stout, in my opinion. Drinkabilty is high due to the lack of potency in this, but a very very solid brew.

This was my first BIG love in the world of stouts, and it will forever hold a permanent space in both my heart and my beer cellar. Its Black with a brown hue and the head is huge, nougat colored and creamy. the flavour is like velvet and its very well-balanced. it has notes of chocolate, oats and coffee. Its gentle and smooth, and if you arent fond of the stouts with more bite, this might be just rígth for you! Even if I today like the more powerful stouts - I drink this frequently, its a beer, I would not like to be without!

Very smooth, very complex,  light to medium bodied. Pours dark and appears thick, though it feels light in the palate. Coffee, chocolate, toasted malts, a little oatmeal.... wonderful, comforting beer.

This is the first high quality beer I had.  I didnt quite know what to make of it, but it was reallly good.  I soon after tried Boddingtons double chocolate stout and came to the realization that there is no beer that tastes like chocolate milk.  Somewhat daunted, but still determined, I went on to explore the vast world of beer thanks to this motivating delight.  As I discovered later SS Imperial Stout is also quite lovely, though this was a better starting point as its not so powerful and intimidating.
poors nice brown color. smells of a little coffee flavor. great taste, one of the best beers in my opion.
Pours a sleek brown color with a light brown head. Aroma is malty, coffee and very ripe banana. Flavor is slightly bitter, malty sweetness like a mild iced coffee. Smooth and very drinkable.
this isnt really my style.  pours black with a brownish head.  smell of bannana.  first sip not that great.  its getting better every sip though.  pretty good, and im not even a big stout guy, yet!!!

Bottle. Pours black with a quickly dissipating tan head. Aroma of malts, plums, coffee, hints of chocolate. Taste is quite sweet, reflecting the aroma well. Low carbonation, mild bitterness on the finish, very slightly metallic. Smoove and very easy to drink. Yum.

Pours a very dark brown black, topped by under an inch of cream colored foam. Okay head retention, spotty lacing. Fresh delicious aroma of charred grain, stone fruit, and coffee.

Very flavorful, with dark roasted coffee, sweet chocolate, and tangy plum. Potent flavors, yes, but still very smooth - nearly silky. Medium body, nice carbonation. Coffee and plum in the finish and aftertaste.
nice notes of chocolate, and lots of sweetness. nice beige head. mouthfeel is great! slightly bitter finish. very sweet stout. nice stuff
Nice aroma of spice and brownish head.  Flavors include caramel and brown sugar.  Very sweet and syruppy.  Absolutely one of my favorites of all time.

Ohhh do I love this beer. A completely satisfying meal in itself I picture it shouting at the craft beer aristocracy that are the overly strong imperial stouts. Making a fine case in the matter of subtlety and rich sophistication that it proudly imparts. Creamy, appropriately sweet and delicious, it politely asks all the craft brewers out there, flooding the Ratebeer top 50 with more and more imperial stouts to divert their attention towards sweeter pastures.

Deep caramel with slight chocolate nose.  Nice lacing.  Pours dark red molasses in color with a nice tan head.  Honest to goodness, full caramel taste.  Medium frothy on the palate.  Not as full bodied as I like it, but a damn good, straight up stout.  An oatmeal stout for folks that like a stout that is not too unusual, but a good basic no frills stout.

Pours deep dark brown with a thick foamy tan head. sweet, low caboniation
subtle coffee notes. A very nice stout!

THOUGHTS: At first I couldnt figure out what all the great ratings fo this beer were about but I must have chilled it a little too much because when it warmed a little, all of these great aromas and flavors came out. Plus Im still amazed at getting great imported beer from a clear bottle.
TECHNICAL: Poured a dark brown to black. Aroma was light caramel, chocolate and coffee along with some toffee and maybe some licorice and cola. The flavor is the same as the aroma. The initial vlavore was moderately swee and lightly bitter, while the finish flavor was heavy sweetness and moderate bitterness with an average duration. The body was medium to full and oily with fizzy carbonation.

A nice deep, dark beer that pours with a creamy looking tan head. The aromas are of chocolate, brown sugar, with maybe a hint of hops. The flavor is of roasted malt, chocolate, with a slight alcohol note that reminds me of a good bourbon. The finish has a nice bitterness that balances out the slight sweetness in the taste. Mouthfeel is good, but not as creamy as I expected
Tasty, yummy, mouth watering, delicious, great, smooth, good, nice, perfect, amazing, lovely, plenty of all what a great sweet stout shall have!

Bottle: About time Ive rated this. Dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of oats, some chocolate. Flavor, oats, a little bready, some roasted notes, just not a lot going on for me. Another instance of the evolving palate, I used to swear by this stuff.

Bottle:  Rocky tan head, very dark brown body.  Coffee, breadyness, metal and nut in the aroma.  Milky-sweet flavor at first with coffee notes, that build throughout.  Tart, fruitiness with sherry notes hits, right before the swallow.  Then one is left with a refreshing dry, coffee finish.  Not very complex, but excelent quality in this beer.
Pours almost opaque dark brown, thin off-white head.  Toasted oats, coffee, and toffee present.  Small bit of dryness in the finish.  Subtle cream in the body.

Short medium grey head.  Dark reddish color.  Aromas of freshly cut apples, smokey malt, and chocolate.  Flavors of chocolate, coffee, toasted oats, and roasted aromas. (toasted yeast??)  This was light enough to be refreshing yet was satisfying.  It is even reasonably priced and easy to find!  Very nice.
Has body that is rich but not too thick or heavy. Good hoppy flavor with just a little sweetness and a pleasant stouty aftertaste. This is one of my favorites.
Bottle. Pours dark, heavy off white head. Smoky, roasted barley aroma and flavor. Semi-sweet. Chocolate and hint of coffee. Mild bitterness in finish. More hop presence than most stouts. Very solid.
chocolate, red, brown, clear, aminimal head, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, oily feel, soft carbonation, bitter

18 oz bottle.  Pours very very dark brown, almost black, with a light brown head.  Aroma is slightly hoppy but dominated by malt and coffee flavors.  The flavor is amazingly complex.  The oatmeal adds some sweetness that balances this perfectly delicious stout.  Best stout Ive tasted.

12oz bottle.  Sweet caramel aroma with some other sweet undertones.  Pours dark brown with a small head.  Very thick beer with a light tingly carbonation and a smooth caramel chocolate flavor with a slightly bitter finish.  Can taste the alcohol in this more than others, but this is not a detractor in any word.  Excellent beer, youre missing out if you dont try!

opaque with moderate tan head.  aroma caramel and chocalate and a touch of some dark fruit.  flavor caramel and chocolate with a little raisin coming through.  finishes a little dry.  nice and smooth very nice except it has a bit of a metallic taste do to poor bottling techniques.
Dark black in colour with toffee coloured head. Sweet choclate aroma, hint of current. Fruity flavour with rasins. Dry finish.

Bottle. Dark,dark brown with tan head.  Nicely balanced between roasty malt and mild hops.  Thin to medium mouth feel but substantial at the same time.  I would not call it sweet.  Left a layer of flavor on my mouth surface after drinking.  Good beer.
Very good stout.  Nice malt flavor and very smokey.  Not to heavy of a stout a very good drink. Best in winter months
Dark brown pour, light brown creamy head.  Aroma of oatmeal and malt, faint raisins as well.  Taste of hops and caramel, with nice oatmeal throughout.  Slight bitter hoppy aftertaste.

Enticing smell and appearance, very dark with a fudge-brown, frothy head. Flavour a bit variable, normally thick and malty, but occasionally a rogue bottle disappoints. Not too heavy mouth-feel. Sam Smiths best stout, and a regular in my pub ordering roster

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 Holy moly, that was one darn good review from six friggin years ago. Time to retate. $3.99 at OB Quik Stop. 550mL, no date. I actually pretty much agree with everything I said way back when, but I mean it all in the best of ways. Creamy lasting head, creamy body with soft moderate pillowy carbonation. Lotta good dessert stout like aromas and flavors, great oat creaminess and flavor.Tinge of ashy roast in the semi-dry finish, bitterness peaked at a 2-3. Wow, I bumped this from a 3.1 to a 4.0. I mustve been quite the fool back then.Old review follows (fromsunday, january 07, 2007) . From my tasting notes at an "earlier" date,  @ Old Chicago.  Pours a deep ruby with a small tan head.  Aroma of raisins, molasses, light coffee, and oats.  Taste was of bitter chocolate, raisins--seemed "cappucinoish."  A bit thin bodied with moderate to high carbonation.  I dont remember trying this one nor how long ago did I do this, so I may have been schmammered and need to rerate this, but for the time being this rating stands. 7-3-7-3-13--3.3
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Very dark color with a long lasting heavy head. Great flavor. A sweet almost oatmeal cookie flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 Had a sweet overall flavor, with a grape flavor like finish. Color was extremely dark brown, with a nice thick head that didnt stick around too long.  Went down nice and easy.  For me, this beer definitely had a distinctive taste, unlike any other beer or stout I have ever tasted before.  Even so, I really like it.  That said, it is not my favorite stout, and it did take a bit getting used to the overly sweet flavor.  The beer did finish a bit on the bitter side, with an aftertaste of grapes, as I mentioned, that I could do without.

550ml Bottle: Obtained in a dark bottle as part of an LCBO gift set.  Pours dark brown with tints of copper, offering a very large and thick foamy brown head.  Definite malts in the aroma, a hit of the sweet stuff.  Chased by vanilla and marshmallow, some chocolate; I only wish I wasnt on the comeback trail from a cold so I could pick out even more.  The flavour is terrific!  Sour and sweet, making way to rich chocolate and sugar notes, roasted malt, a definite oat presence, and some excellent bitter hops that arent instantly noticeable but definitely there on the tail end.  The only drawback might be an odd sour metallic taste Im getting, sadly somewhat prevalent.  But its rich and heavy in body, exactly what Id hoped it would be.  Good stuff.

Strong aroma as I open the bottle. A rich syrupy charcoal flavour, charred hops with alcohol to follow through. Fantastic black appearance with a muddy frothy head. great balance with fruit. A rich smooth taste. This beer is has a great flavour and not to over powering like some. This is an excellent stout. Sammy Smiths never disappoints.
Quite enjoyable. Pours red/black with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasty malts, oats, even some hops. The flavor is caramel, chocolate, nice oats, roasty malt and a hoppy finish. Very nice.

dark brown pour with tan head. wonderful chocolate aroma and initial taste. this is followed up with a soft roasty flavor with hints of berries. very smooth finish. by far the best beer that can be purchased in the state of alabama as we still have unfortunate and outdated blue-laws prohibiting high-gravity beer. cry a tear in your Great Divides for me

Found this one bottled in St. Charles, Illinois.  Rich, deep dark brown pour, completely opaque, with a nice fluffy tan head, a milky, chocolaty taste with roasted coffee throughout and a bit of plum and artificial grape.  Finished dry.  Nice!

Bottle. Poured a dark black color with some red around the edges.  Head was tan and creamy, but didnt leave a lot of lace behind. Pleasant aroma of vanilla ice cream and milk chocolate. Slightly sweet up front with raisin, milk chocolate and molasses flavors. Finishes dry and a bit roasty.

Sammy Smiths flagship brew.  Great features all around.  I normally shy away from the heavy, heavy stouts but this one was forgiving enough to make it thoroughly pleasurable.  One of the top 5 beers Ive had.

This goes under the WTF catagory for me since I know Ive had good bottles of this in the past.  Pours dark bronw with garnet hue and large sudsy tan head.  The aroma is faint - what is there is roasted malt, light chocolate and light sour dark fruits.  Medium body with a light amount of soft carbonation.  Starts with sharp dark fruits, some roasted malt and sourness.  The finish adds very little to the mix, just a bit of spice.  This was highly disappointing.  Hopefully I get a better bottle in the near future and can rerate this higher.
Pours black with a yellowish brown head.  Smells of sugar and molasses.  Smooth feel, goes down well.

Black in color with a beige head...aromas of brown sugar, ice cream and molasses.  Flavor of browned oatmeal cookies with some musty red grapes.  Very merlot like the imperial stout.  Smooth and dry in the mouth.  Displeasingly thin...but it goes down easy.
Delicious.  Pairs well with heavy meals.  Smooth.  Flavorful and complex.  Great body and longevity.  Smells like bread dough and tastes hints of oatmeal.  wonderful.

Pours black with a thick creamy tan head.  Aroma is of roasty malts and some oat and alcohol.  Taste is smooth and of roasty dark malts and oats and a hint of alcohol, I assume from the cane sugar.  Very good overall.
Bottle. Coffee colored head. A rich deep brown color but not opaque. Sweet with a pleasing silky mouthfeel.
Quice or green apple peel on top of cocoa and roasted oat aroma.  Flavor is similar with a short acidic hazelnut finish.  Nice.

Large foamy but also creamy tan head atop an inky black puor.  Pleasing coffey and whiskey aroma with slight nutty notes.  Thinner than I had hoped mouth feel.  Brief sweet nutty flavor followed by a slightly sour tangy lingering finish.  Slight metallic taste becoms  increasingly noticeable.

Beautiful pour, head seemed to last forever! I can smell the oatmeal, I agree with after4ever, definately smells like cookies. I really like this beer overall. Hard to find in my area though, and expensive when you can get it. About $3.00 a bottle.

bottle poured 355.  think whitish head that quickly disappeared although the lacing stuck to my glass until i finished.  light carbonation, looked like a slightly flat cola.  very dark and opaque even when held to bright light.   malty sweet flavor.  very pleasant finish that lingers happily.  good stout ESPECIALLY AS IT WARMED UP A BIT.

550. Pours a deep black, essentially opaque, with a thick, moussy tan head. Plenty of clingy, webby lace. Big chocolate and oats nose--its the original cookie-smellin beer without a doubt. The attack is restrained in a diginified way, but not to the point of anonymity. Medium body, very light carb, subdued chocolate flavor. The mid palate wakes up a bit with that nutty, oaty flavor, chocolate, and maybe a bit of chalk at the end. Clingy sweet finish, though not very pronounced. Everything about this beer is polite, especially by stout standards, but its complex and satisfying and, maybe best of all, its light enough to drink all day. Great stuff. Ya gotta respect your forebears, especially when they make it this easy.
Great stout beer if you like light after taste.  Smooth and very satisfying!

Bottled at The Cardinal, Westminster. Surprisingly tasty for a mass produced, pasteurised beer. Very dark colour. Infused with creamy chocolate throughout. Also some ripe jammy fruit. Very smooth on the palate, but not too sweet. Nice enough but, for the life of me, I cant see why it averages nearly 4. But Sam Smiths beers always seem to have been more highly regarded in the US than here.

This beer is simply amazing.  Pours a black body with a frothy khaki coloured head that never quite disappears.  Slightly sweet aroma with hints of chocolate and caramel.  The palate is perfect, full without being overbearing and a bittersweet finish.  Incredibly enjoyable all around, I cant wait to have another.

550 mL bottle.  What can I add that hasnt been said over and over.  Actually looks a bit lighter than it tastes, head was not as dark as Id expect, but the final ring of foam was a dark tan.  Ive enjoyed all the SS stouts as well as the Taddy Porter, and I never mind picking up a couple for the weekend.  A solid, thoroughly enjoyable stout.
Pours black with cappacino head. Roasty, inky, with liqourice and coffee top notes and a satisfyingly smooth bitterness. Malty body provides bread and butterscotch. Beautifully balanced!
Seems very similar in almost all respects to the SS Impy Stout which has a little more alcohol. Quite good in that sort of reserved, understated way that seems to characterize so many english brews.

Thicky, creamy head.  Medium body with a bit of a sweet flavour and a nice hop finish to balance out the sweetness - very easy drinking stout.  This is probably the most enjoyable stout I have ever had keeping in mind I am not someone who goes wild over stouts.

12 oz. bottle(clear fucking dammiitt.......)aww well darks stand up good too light.pours a jet black, but when held up revels red hightlights, small thick and creamy tanish head.aroma of choco,coffee,raisens and brown sugar.taste is creamy sweet with all sorts of differnt flavors too many too type at this hour.creamy and rich mouthfeel.finsh has a sorta choco gumball flavor(i know sounds weird but I taste it....).overall wonderfull it is what all other oatmeal stouts should be judged by

Ill have to agree with Illini08. 550mL bottle, poured dark brown. Very sweet with slight bitter aftertaste. Could not pinpoint all of the flavors but there is definitely molasses and chocolate. A little too sticky at the end, but great tasting beer.

550 mL bottle.  Dark brown pour.  Aroma was sweet and bready.  Taste some faint coffee notes and lots of sugar.  Best part of this beer was the finish, bittersweet, as advertised.  Tasty stout, maybe just a tad too sweet for me.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 12 oz bottle...wow!...so ok, expected the bottle to be brown..."holy shit the bottle was clear"-quotes the queer...color is of moleasses...smells like muddled fruit(holiday fruits) mingled with a nice malty taste...very pungent molasses with notes of chocolate and caramel...light and creamy texture...taste is very similar to the smell...sweet caramel finish...a very tasty easy to drink stout,,this beer spilled 3 times during the tasting...its so good, you cant even keep it in your glass

550ml bottle. Almost black, dark brown with a thick light brown head. Rich, roasty nose, malty, sweet dark chocolate. Deep roasted flavors, dark sweet chocolate. Very smooth satin mouthfeel. Excellent.
A very delicious stout.  Full bodied, mildly sweet, and easy to drink.  It leaves a pleasant aftertaste that doesnt linger.  Perfect with pizza.
Had 2, 550cl bottles with a friend last night. A really sweet beer, left my mouth feelin a bit sticky and me no likey. Although Id recommend this beer to others, not a personal favorite.

Pours a very dark black.  Lots of roasted malt and some coffee/chocolate, although I was surprised by how subdued they were for such a dark beer.  Nice aftertaste, with just a kick of sweetness lingering on the palate.  Not the best stout around, but a good one!

550 ml bottle.  Pours black with brown head.  Nice roasted malt aroma.  Coffee, malt and chocolate flavors throughout but never overpowering.  Very smooth drink with just the right lingering aftertaste.  For it to be as easily accessible as it is, this is fine drink.
Very nice smooth stout.  Well balanced flavor..the malts, the bitterness, the sweetness....its all very nice.
Bottle, dark brown color with average head. Excellent aroma. Rich, dark taste. Smooth finish. Very drinkable. One of my favorites!

Very dark with light brown froth.  Good texture, but not such a fan of Sam Smith, a bit of metallic, fake aftertaste.  Aside from that, some coffee, malt, and sweetness, very silky, but not overly flavorful or interesting otherwise.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2007 Amazing.  Extremely dark pour with rich creamy light brown head.  Aroma is above average with brown sugar, roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate and some roasted malt.  Palate is pleasing.  Finishes nicely, only slightly bitter.

Bottle, 550ml. A dark brown colour with an average-sized brown head. A good strong aroma with some sweetness, chocolate, pear and malt. Taste is similar with bitter dark chocolate, pear and roasted malt. A somewhat sweet (but not too much) finish with moderate bitterness. Delicious.
good oatmeal stout.  nice dark rich taste.  oats are very noticable.  tastes good too

Poured very dark with a nice creamy head.  Dark roasted barley and malts. Medium palate with a bitter sweet finish. I bought the Samuel Smiths Christmas pack. Came with its own Samuel Smiths pint glass. Very nice.
Dark pour almost black with a sweet smell and a thick tan head.  Im a big fan of the oatmeal stouts and this one is very nice

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2006 Poured a dark black brew with a thick brown head. Smelled sweet, malty, and slightly fruity (hoppy). Tasted very sweet, malty, and slightly hoppy. Had a smooth full mouthfeel and a smooth finish. A very smooth and drinkable stout.

Bottle, pours nicely with a dark brown color with a carmel color head with a tint of auburn in it.  The aroma I really cant put my finger on it, must be the nubie coming out.  However taste and aroma very very good.  Was told it had to be ice cold to be enjoyable, and was not steered wrong.  Very nice beer after a long gobble gobble day.
