Cold 550ml bottle:  Pours a dark brown with cherry colored highlights.  After pouring, bubbles came up to the top to form a thin layer of foamy caramel colored bubbles.  Aroma and taste are of rich malts, brown sugar, and dark berries.  Medium bodied, smooth and well carbonated.  Light dry and bittersweet ending.

Bottle; pours black with a medium tan head that dissipates, no lacing.  Nice aroma of sweet malts, cherry and blackberry, which follows through on the taste with some carbonation.  A nice sweet stout.
sweet malt and oatmeal influence.  black cherries and chocolate. Slight bitterness to finish.  well balanced and very nice.
Bottle. Very dark, with wonderful creamy head. Smooth taste and good feel. This is what a stout should be. Really outstanding.

18.7 oz Bottle-Pours a dark brown cola color w/almost no head. Full aroma of chocolate & malt. Sweet roasted flavor of nuts & malt, chocolate & toffee.  Dont really get the oatmeal, but I guess its in there. This is a good solid stout-not spectacular or amazing but solid. Long bittersweet finish.

Very dark frothy beer, amazingly smooth taste that finishes and taste similar to guinnes draught out of the pint cans.  This beer is good but overtly expensive for the overall value, id just recommend buying the guiness.

the 18.7oz bottle is wonderful.  its a deep dark brown pour with a nice light brown foamy head.  though it dissipates rather quickly, the lacing on the glass is very very consistent.  the roasted oats flavor is very distinct to this very brew.  many breweries have oatmeal stouts, but sam smiths is very discernable.  the hops are balanced perfectly with the malts in that the hops provide a lively mouthfeel and a solid palate.  overall, this is a very solid, successful beer from every angle.

Dark brown, little head.  Aromas are malty with a little smoke.  Very smooth in the mouth; flavors are somewhat sweet, with just a hint of bitterness.  I cant detect the oatmeal influence, but perhaps that manifests itself as sweetness.  Great sweet finish, very pleasant.  A very drinkable stout that brings a smile to my face.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 OK, never thought Id get to drink thistoo expensive.   Samuel Smith Old Brewery Tadgster the Celebrated Oatmeal Stout a product of England. For a 12oz bot, $3.75 @ 3Sons, Wexford. Pour turns my steeler stein black.  Sweet aroma.  No offense in the initial taste.  Nice palate, not too carbonated. Roasted hops finish but not too much lingering bitter.  Very happy!  One cool thing about the bottle; when I bought it I thought it was dark brown.  After the beer was gone, bottle was clear! This is more like a sweet stout than a regular stout.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Very good oatmeal stout, not my favorite, but very good. Very dark with a creamy head.....Damn good!

550mL bottle: Pours a nice dark, almost black, brown. Head was small and tan. Smell is very sweet, almost to sweet for my liking.  I smell something that almost smells like licorice, I wonder if its supposed to smell like that. Actually, I smell a little deeper and I am thinking its some sort of fruit, but I cant place it.  Taste is bitter sweet, with a very smooth feel. I still cannot place it, but there seems to be some sort of lingering fruit flavor to this one. This is very smooth and very good, if only I could place the fruit taste I seem to be finding in this one. 

edit: After trying this more and more, it seems to be some sort of sour green apple flavor. I dunno where it comes from, but it definitely seems present. Doesnt seem to fit the normal stout flow, but its still good.

Poured out thick and dark, like a very rich chocolate.  Formed a huge brown foamy head.  Aroma of malts, chocolate, some coffee and brown sugar.  Taste of oatmeal, chocolate, and a bit of hops.  A little complex, a little sweet and bitter at the end.  Well I geuss thats what makes Samuel Smith so world renowned.  Thier porter is really good, and so is this.  I love our American Micro/Macro brews, but this is so traditionally good.  Like thier Porter, Sam Smiths/Brits have a good beer here.  Being fond of my Scottish/Irish roots, this beer makes me proud.  However, us Americans have some kick ass brews that the rest of the world must respect and acknowledge.  Bottom line, this beer is quite delightful, big bonus, I bought at local Lowes Foods for $2.50.  Enjoy!
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: 550ml bottle. Pours very dark with a thick tan head. Smells like roasted chocolate with toffee. Taste is very maltly sweet and chocolately. Very complex goes down full bodied and creamy. Exceptional.

Pours dark black with a light brown-ish head. the nose is very chocolatey. 

as far as flavor goes, this is one sweet stout. really taste the chocolate and coffee flavoring I REALLY enjoy this beer

550ml bottle - a fantastic beer from Samuel Smith, the best Ive had from their lineup. Pours black with an ample mocha head. Wonderful, sweet aroma. This is such a smooth stout, very full and creamy in the mouth. The flavour is full of roasted malt, barley, licorice, some fruit, and oatmeal, with a finish of chocolately coffee (a lot like Coffee Crisp actually) that lingers and lingers. Fantastic oatmeal stout, a fine example of the style beat out only (in my experience) by St. Ambroise. Rich and complex.

Drank in a stout glass.  Nice thick brown head.  First aromas of roasted malts,  starts with a twist of black liquorice, brown sugar, chocolate coated nuts. Second aromas of a nice sweet date quares and a third aroma of sugar tart and raisins.  Perfect mariage between the sweetness and bitterness in this beer. Not spicy at all, nice long smokey finish to it.  The aromas are more and more predominant when it gets to room temperature.  Fantastic Stout!

Good stuff.  Bought a bottle while on break from school.  Didnt pour, as I was riding around, and didnt observe the color-although by the taste it was quite dark.  Nice and smooth, good coffee flavors coming through with a somewhat bitter finish.  Reccomended.
Pours completely black and thick.  Creamy tan head and lots of coffee, chocolate, dried fruits, and licorice on the nose.  Finish is bitter and a little sweet.

Bottle. Bitch black colour with a light creamy head. Aroma is moderated roasted, with some notes of coffee, dry fruit like raisin and plum. Flavour was sweet but well balanced with light bitterness. Medium bodied. Finish is slightly coffee bitter.
Bottle. Black colour with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted, coffee, fruit. Flavour is roasted, coffee, fruit, hop

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2006 550ml bottle - pours virtually black, with some reddening as you go deeper into the glass.  Big rocky beige head.  Aroma of green apple, ripe dark fruits (plum, raisin), roasted barley, and above all, a pleasant malt sweetness that is indicative of the flavours to follow.  Flavours of all of the above, plus a bitter coffee finish.  Smooth and sweet, this is an excellent full-bodied and complex brew.  Huzzah!

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2007 Almost black in color, with a tan, lacing head. The aromas are of toffee and barbecue, and the the flavors I detect are sweet molasses, mild hickory-smoked bacon, coffee, and just a hint of alcohol. The aftertaste reminds me of chicory flavored coffee, but its very subtle. A gentle, drinkable stout, and certainly one of my favorites.

Pours very dark brown/black with a thick dark tan head. Aroma has heavy raisin/plum notes, molasses, sweet creamy coffee, malted grain, and a little toffee. Flavor has some nice notes of raisin up front, some dark chocolate, underlying coffee, and some slight but nice bitterness that carries nicely onto the finish. Palate is medium, creamy, mildly bitter, and some mild chocolate. Overall, not what I expected at all, but still a decent stout.
550 mL bottle at Flat Rock Saloon.  Pours black with tannish head.  Sweet flavor with lots of licorice and some chocolate present.  A bit sour.  Thin body.  Unimpressive.
A very dark with thin tan head. The taste of oatmeal and armoa of it is very present hints the oatmeal stout.

Bottle. Dark pour with huge dark tan head. Malty and licorice aroma, light hops. I cant taste any oatmeal at all, I was expecting a very creamy palate and creamy oatmeal flavor, but its very light and oatmealless. Long lasting aftertaste. Realy good, but not what I expected.

Bouteille claire de 550 ml de HogTownHarry. Brun très foncé, bon collet. Arome plaisant de malte roti avec un soupson de caramel. Très bon goût malt chocolaté, un peu de caramel et un arrière goût de petit fruit.

Clear bottle, 500 ml, 5 %, sipped from its glass, best before 11/30/2004; eye: black with a nice tan head, no effervescence, clear, opaque, light lacing; nose: roasted malt, bitter black chocolae, coffée, molasses, really light hops, basemen; mouth: roasted malt, caramel, hops, basement that becomes more present as the beer warms, finale in malt with a hint of caramle and basement, lightly sweet, bitter and lactic, rather thin, lightly carbonated; overall: enjoyed

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille transparente, 500 ml, bue dans son verre, meilleure avant 11/30/2004; oeil : noire avec une belle mousse tan, pas deffervescence, claire, opaque, dentelle; nez : malt torréfié, chocolat noir amer, café, mélasse, très léger houblon, cave; bouche : malt torréfié, caramel, houblon, cave qui devient plus présent à mesure que la bière se réchauffe, finale en malt avec une pointe de caramel et de cave, légèrement sucrée, amère et lactique, plutôt mince, légèrement carbonatée; en résumé : bien aimé

550mL bottle, part of a gift set from LCBO.  Pours very dark and seemingly opaque (deep cherry red-brown with strong backlighting).  Fairly decent mocha head, lasts a little while.  Some decent "dark" aromas (coffee, chocolate, roasted), a hint of fruitiness, ....  Feels fairly full and smooth in the mouth, very little carbonation.  Balanced sweetness and acidity, a sourish, bitterish finish,  a little smokiness.  Lingers in the back of the throat for a short time.

Ive heard many people refer to this as a world-class beer, yet everytime I drink I think someone has poured soy sauce in my beer.  The dry, bitter aftertaste of licorice is not what I expect of a world-class beer.
Pours and feels very thin.  Not too bad, but there was a strong licorice taste at the finish.  Not what I expect from a stout.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2007 A better stout than the dry stout that Samuel Smiths makes, it is an excellent beer for when youre in a stout mood.  One of the best stouts Ive ever tasted.  the flavor of Oatmeal/Malt is noticible though it isnt strongly overpowering.  It is very bitter like a good stout, but not as bitter as an IPA.  Definately worth a try.
again in the gift pack, lotsa head when i poured choc some esspresso notes, good stout choc flavour some hops but not too much bite

Very pretty beer, even though one have to pour rather powerful to get a high head. Medium powerful aroma (maybe a little more) with liquorice and especially chocolate. Sourish, very fruity and refreshing for a stout, but nice. There is a lot of liquorice and chocolate in the taste - but also a nice and obvious touch of smoke. The aftertaste is a little sweeter than expected, and medium hopped - still with the touch of smoke. It is a little thin for a stout, but its to live with. You must consider that this is only a 5% ABV.

An excellent beer. Poured dark brown with a foamy head. Aroma of berries, vanilla, and coffee. Feel is creamy and semisweet. Taste is smooth with a touch of sweetness followed by coffee and roastiness.
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2006 Reddish/brown in colour with similar coloured foamy head. Mildl bittersweet taste. Coffee, chocolate, vanilla, barley taste. A king amongst Oatmeal stouts.

I loved this beer.  I had it at a bar (North Gate Tavern in Baton Rouge), so forgive me if I cant be very specific about it.  The girl who shared it with me said it reminded her of Werthers Originals candy.  I cant disagree.  Sweet, but not too sweet.  Bitter but not too bitter.  Looked dark from inside the bottle.  I thoroughly enjoyed it, and I will try it again.
Dark brown pour with a big tan head. Flavor of roasted malts, a bit sweet, a little bitter. Velvet mouthfeel, very smooth. I found it a bit dull.

550ml bottle - very attractive bottle design. Ruby black in colour with red-brownish, frothy foam. Marked aroma of dark fruits. Flavour of dark berries - plums and grapes - with supporting components of roasted malts and coffeebeans. Dry palate. Almost full bodied (Cittie of Yorke, Holborn 20.09.2006)
Dark brown color, sweet, but not too sweet.  Definitely a solid choice no matter what the mood.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 this is my very first oatmeal stout and is very good .tan head, dark poor but not as dark as a regular stout. nice sweetness to it and is not as bitter as a regular stout went down really nice i probably would drink it again.

Ive had this beer many times in the past, but most recently I sampled it at Rivers Bend on 10/06/2006...

This is the beer that really put Oatmeal Stout on the map.  It was the first Oatmeal Stout I ever had and was my favorite for quite some time.  The Anderson Valley Barney Flats Oatmeal Stout has edged out Samuel Smiths as my favorite Oatmeal Stout, but it is still an excellent beer that is really hard to beat!

Very deep mahagony color with a creamy brown head.  Aroma and flavor are sweet, roasted barley, coffee, a little chocolate, and some vanilla charasteristics.  Body is full; mouthfeel is creamy, yet silky, and smooth.

I have found that newer, fresh bottles of this tend to be slightly less creamy and more bitter.  I recommend letting this beer age a couple of months in order to experience it at its best.

550 mL clear bottle.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2006 Bottle. Its always difficult when rating a highly regarded beer to separate the product from the reputation. However, Samuel Smith almost always lives up to its name. This beer pours a dark brown hue with a very thin tan head. The beer actually looks darker in the glass than it does during the pour. Head disappears quickly. Delightful aroma dominated by oatmeal and alcohol, with a slight hint of chocolate. Taste is consumed by oatmeal, and is extremely sugary. However, there is a nice under laying roasted bitterness, especially in the finish (which also has hints of coffee). While this beer mostly tastes like oatmeal, it is well balanced with a nice silky texture (which seems to be a trademark of the Samuel Smith brews I have tried). Ive never tried an oatmeal based beer (stout, porter, or otherwise) where oatmeal has dominated the taste to such a degree. And you know what? I really like it.
Bottle. Dark brown/black with a large light brown head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted barley, some hops. Taste is roasted barley, coffee, sweet malts, smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2006 550 ml bottle pours chocolate black with a big tan mousse head and long finger lacing as it fades down.  The aroma is the standard for quality stout as these guys set the bar, doughy, chocolate, a little roastedness and vanilla.  Sweet oatmeal is the first flavor that hits my tongue followed by chocolate and roastednesss as the creamy mouthfeel laces down the inside of my mouth as it did before down my glass.  The carbonation tinges on the tip of my tongue leaving the flavors of bakers chocolate and a lasting sweet bitterness.
(Bottle) Pours opaque black with beige head. Sweet malts, with a decent level of hops as well. Pretty carbonated and not as rich as I expected. Still a great, creamy, balanced stout.

black pour with a creamy tan head.  Creamy texture and a bit sweet with a nice roasted malt and slightly bitter finish.  The beer feels more like a black lager to me than a Stout.  Lots of roasted malt in the nose and toungue.  Very light textured though for a stout.  A great beer for a dark beer lover!

This is the first beer I have reviewed on RateBeer. That said, it has quickly become one of my favorite, and has given me the kick in the butt to start reviewing!

Upon first pouring, this beer did not have any particularly strong smell. Dark character and a light head. If you really want to stick your nose in it, the smell is almost creamy.

As others have mentioned, this stout has a smooth, milky flavor to it. An almost (but not overpoweringly) sweet taste increased drinkability and evened the drink out nicely. The mouthfeel was not incredibly noteworthy, though I would categorize it as thicker than average if necessary.

Im still working on the identification of tastes and smells, but when it gets down to it, the bottom line is a great drink. It is going to the top among my favorites. I would buy it again if I had the chance; in fact, though I typically try something new each visit, I am making an exception for this drink, and am planning on picking up an extra one for the reserve.

Popped the top and poured at arms-length because of the table and I was lazy.  Man, could smell it quite easily.  Lots of sweet chocolate, sweetened condensed milk, oatmeal, also smells of smoked wood.  Also, some similarities in the aroma to Traquair beers.  But, theres a light soapyness.  The beer has a nice dark garnet transparent body with a tall frothy tan head.  Nice lacing.  The flavor is nicely sweet, chocolate oatmeal brownies, has some nice spicyness in the hops and raw quality sugars too.  Perhaps a light fennel seed.  The palate is initally slick and watery, but it seems like a light airy mousse and has a nice licorice lingering taste.  Quite refreshing.

opaque with silky smooth texture ... medium dry palate with a sweet & sour like finish ...

You cant go wrong with Sam Smith, the Tadcaster brewery. I havent tasted anything average from this producer yet (the Organic Ale comes closest to "average") and I hope the company will never be tempted to cash in on some horrid licenced stuff ... this one is a refreshing, nutritious stout ...

WOW.  This beer really rocks. As with any stout, it presents a challenge at first, but the sweetness and surprisingly lean character give this beer an unmatched drinkability.  Excellent even in the summer.
Good looking beer, nice plesant taste, not a lot of bitterness, sweet, Id buy this one again if I can get my hands on it.

This beer pours a glowing dark brown cherry with a tall, creamy, pale tan head. 

Smells of brown sugar and molasses blended into a dry smoky oat.

The flavor begins with a touch of brown sugar with a sweet red grape that then fades into a slightly sour and woody smoky flavor that seems to be based on a thick oat.

The mouth feel is light with a plentiful, small bubbled carbonation that accentuates the slight sourness of the flavor.

This ones really fantastic. The flavor is very simple and delicate, and the mouth feel works exceptionally well with it. Very nice.

(Bottled) Almost black with a smallish, tanned, lasting and lacy head. Very roasty-licoricey, sweetish oatmeal-porridge aroma with a hint of smoked oakiness. Sweetish, very malty, salty-licoricey flavor, with ashy hints in the lingering, mildly roasty and bitter finish. Medium-bodied, somewhat sticky-syrupy palate with pretty low carbonation. A very nice and tasty, balanced stout - especially for the  ABV. I wish all British brews were this tasty...

Bottle 46F Pint. Pours a very dark and opaque black color, with a brown loose head. Huge Malt aroma, tons of malt flavor, smells quite sweet. Moderate hops, but then again they should not be too big based on the style.  Very rich aroma, tons of espresso and chocolate and deep dark tones. Nice rich malty and chocolatey taste, with very subtle hops, very rich taste. A bit of a sweet taste with a touch of copper or maybe iron metal taste. Lots of carbonation which makes the beer lighter for the style.  Not bad very sweet and is a meal unto its own. Not quaffable but should be great on a grey and rainy afternoon.
Very dark brown with little thin head. Malt, vanilla notes and hops. Slighty sweet and nice carbonation.

Pours a very dark brown/black with a large light brown head.  Aroma is of coffee, roasted barley, some hops.  Taste is roasted barley, coffee, sweet malts, smooth mouthfeel, medium bodied.  Dry lightly astringent finish.

Pours black/brown with a thick tan head. The aroma is light, some roast and chocolate. The flavor is sweet, chocolate, molases, oats with some grassy hops. The mouthfeel is thin and light with a bitter, slightly astringent end.
A good treat as far as beer goes. Very hoppy with interesting oatmeal flavor. The color of the beer is wonderful, nice and dark!!

A truly awesome head greets you when you release this genie from its bottle. The nose is all barley but a mouthful of oats sweetening cracked barley, a tad of cream, and the suggestion of caramel greet the tongue. Mildly hoppy in the finish. The only critique I would have of this brew is that as complex and refreshing as it is, it is rather light for a stout. Still, a thoroughly enjoyable brew.
Dark brown color with a firm tan head. Rosted with notes of dark chocolate and coffe. Medium to full body with some bitterness in the finish.
Aroma of toasted grains, alcohol. Huge brown head approximately 3 x height of liquid. Toasted chocolate malty initial with slight coffee and short-lived bitter aftertaste.
Deep Black Brown with brown head.  Dark chocolate and toasted oat aromas.  Molasses flavors mild bitterness that fades away leaving a hint of coffee finish.

Huge frothy tan head.  Pitch black color with very slight ruby highlights.  Aroma of malts, very dark roasted grains, hops, some slight sweetness, a hint of cocoa and a hint of coffee.  Nice sweet malty and roasted grain flavors.  Some hints of coffee and cocoa.  A very slight touch of hops to the finish.  Smooth, silky mouthfeel.  Not too heavy or dense, but certainly not too light or watery.  A pretty awesome brew.

550ml bottle.Pours very dark almost black with a tan head.Aromas of bitter sweet dark chocolate,roasted barley,sweet malt ,dried fruits and hops.Flavor of chocolate ,coffee,raisins,and sweet malt finishing dry.A very good stout.

I really dont care much for English beer. But Sam Smith Oatmeal Stout? Man, there is no other stout like this one. Im not going to get all high and mighty and give an intense description. Ill just say what all the others on ratebeer already know: this is the best oatmeal stout you can get.

Bottle to pint glass.  Smooth pour into a deep black color with a slight brownish head dissapating quickly.  Very little in the way of bubbles and while it has a heavy beer look I find it has a surprisingly light feel.  Caramel, toffee and cinnamon raisin with a slightly bitter aftertaste reminding me of coffee.  Certainly not overpowering but in some ways I almost wish it had a bit of a heavier feel.  Absolutely no lacing on the glass at the end.  Certainly one of the better stouts.

Bottle at home.
Dark brown with a off white head, ok lacings. Aroma heavy malty (caramel, custard, raisin), light hoppy. Flavor heavy sweet, light bitter. Light body, watery, soft carbonated.

Almost black in color with a foamy head.  Very smooth and full-flavored.  Enjoyed this immensely.  I started brewing my own beer about 9 months ago, and my next venture will be an oatmeal stout (and an IPA) because of this beer.
Bottle 35,5 cl. Dark brown - big offwhite head. Burned, roasted, raisins, chokolate, sweet. Good but not enough power.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2009 Jet-black body and the filthiest caramel head youve ever seen in your life. An intoxicating gust of whiskeyish toffee. The texture of a full-cream Guinness original milkshake. Except nowhere near as vile. Oaty black custard with a bitterly coffeeish finish. Just want it to go on and on. What more can you say? Bonus point for bottling it by the English pint (almost). Approaching perfection.
848517
RERATE Utterly pitch with an undulating beige collar going nowhere. Surprisingly sticky sweet sherry, prune and BlackJack aroma dusted with iron and background roast. Sweetly roasted flavour oozing sherry, liquorice and choc spread on burnt toast. Not the big roasty treat I remember,  just a fine silky sweet stout. 474715

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2007 Spongy-cream tan head tops a extemely dark stout.  Head resolves to a thin crown quickly, leaving below raisin, dark chocolate, custard and roasted malt.  Slightly unfinished and sweet finish.

bottle.  dark maple pour with thick head that quickly goes down to a nice tan thin bubble head.  very hoppy aroma.  great body.  oats, coffee, chocolate and hops.  chocolate and sugar in the aftertaste.  one of my all time favorites.  reminds me of Phish shows.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2006 Large foamy tan head.Leaves an average amount of lace. Black in color. Mild aroma with slightly sour hints of vanilla, caramel and licorice.mmm what flavors.
This is very complex with lots of notes and layers. I taste raisin, plum, apple, chocolate, licorice and toffee. And a wonderful finish. Only complaint is i wish the incredible aftertaste stuck around a bit longer.
Poured a black dark color with a thick lasting creamy light brown head. Sweet caramel roasted malt aroma. Nice rich sweet caramel roasted malt flavor. Simply awesome!
A dark brown pour with a light lacing. A nice aroma of roasted malt. A flavor of chocolate and a bitter from the grain. A nice mouthfeel not watery but not hardly as thick as I like. A nice beer.

1 Pint 2.7 oz Bottle: Dark brown with light brown ring head.  It has a dark choco aroma as well as dark brown sugar.  The tastes are similar: chocolate, cola and alcohol.  There is a mildly metallic sense in the aftertaste which is unpleasant, but overall very easy to drink and smooth.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2006 1pt 2.7oz bottle from Hy-Vee Liquors St. Joseph poured into english pint - Pours DARK brown with a minimal, quick fading light brown head; Strong aroma of chocolate, sweet malts, and a little coffee to the nose that I smelled right at the start of pouring; A pleasant mix of chocolate, malt, roast, coffee, the slightest hint of hops or roasted barley (almost undetectable) on the initial taste; A full backtaste of caramel, oatmeal, sweet malt, hints of coffee; My first oatmeal, and a good one! The mouthfeel and carbonation remind me of soda from a fountain. One thing I said was that this tastes like it looks, if that makes sense.

Well, possible this is unfair because I am rating it after having a DFH Raison Detre, but I have had it on other occasions. Why do they put this in clear bottles? The mouthfeel is very weak. I can detect a slight coffe like flavor, but thats about it. Nothing spectacular here, I say, and certainly not worthy of almost a 4. Perhaps it is due to the pasteurization and filtering which the commercial description tells us about. I have to admit, it is a nice looking beer, and the head i got to form on it looked rather nice.
Bottled. As soon as I sipped it, I wondered if this is even considered beer! Its like drinking a combination of coffee and chocolate! Had a dry finish though, it made me want to drink water...

Best stout ever.  Pours black with a huge light brown creamy head with excellent lacing.  Aroma was of molasses, dark chocolate and mild coffee, like kona.  Light hopping of flowers, and something that gives a hint of leather.  Palate was bitter sweet and not at all offensive very drinkable.  Creamy texture that reminded me of milk.
Great for a session  or just to have on hand for a special treat now and then. Loved it.

Opaque black pour, with a frothy tan head...minimal retention.  Nose is of chocolate caramel malt.  Nice roasted choco flavor, with a roasted smoky-hop finish.  Feels smooth to the palate and dry enough to be quite tasty.  Not overdone, and decent, but I was honestly expecting a bit more from this high rater.

Fairly good but not great.  I know I might get emails for writing this, but I think Samuel Smiths is overrated.  When I lived in Alabama, it was awesome, but outside of a beer-starved locale, their beers are just above average.  Nothing special here, certainly not as good as Mackeson which is almost 1/2 the price.

Bottle.  A nice stout.  Ive had a few oatmeals and havent been happy but this was actually quite delicious.  An average pour, head, apperance in general.  Nice flavor and balance which is where I think that so many other stouts miss the boat.  I do like stout to be a bit thicker and more challenging. Very nice texture, though.  A repeat, I believe.
Pours dark brown with a medium tan head that fads in a few minutes.  The aroma is prunes and raisins.  Very sweet and heavy.  Smooth finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: 12 oz Bottle on 8-6-06... Heard good things about this so i said what the hell... It pours an almost black color with a min. tan head.. Smells of roasted burnt grains and coffee... taste is very similar to smell..   i dont care for the mouthfeel because its slightly carbonated.. - Overall a good stout ...

12 oz. bottle from Weidert.  Drank on 7/21/06.  Very dark, almost black, but not quite.  Can see a little light through it.  Nice 1+" dark tan head.  Drops slowly to a small ring of foam.  No lacing.  Aroma - not too strong.  Mostly roasty and coffee-like.  Flavor - little bit of up front bitterness, but not much.  Pretty smooth and well balanced, towards malty in the middle.  Some nice roasty coffee flavors in the finish.  Palate - medium, a little bit of creamy smoothness.  Sort of high carb.  Overall - a very good beer.  Kind of a classic.  Very good, but not all that special at the same time.
A ver nice stout.  This beer has it all, nice sweet coffee taste with a smooth mouth feel.  A strong smell of oatmeal. I had this beer many times, just never rated it.  It is pricy also.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2006 A wonderful stout.  Has a deep color with a rich thick head.  Nice lacing.  A sweet smooth flavor of cocoa and oatmeal with aftertastes of coffee and banana.  A great overall brew.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2007 This is a great oatmeal stout!!  A good pour will give you a great head.  Rich and complex yet smooth and easy to drink.  Aroma was full and color is very dark adding to the experience.  I love this beer.

Wow how great can it be.  Full head and great aroma.  Totally black and yet the flavor was smooth.  Stout was to be strong and bitter.  This offering is just not overpowering.  Although one is all you need per session, this beer is a great experience.  This one is a must for the beer experience!
very dark with a fine head.  Slightly sweet flavor with a nice medium bitterness.   A great stout.

Bottle: Completely black with a quite firm tanned head; big fruity (raisins, almost vinous) nose, toasted malt also detectable, but mainly espresso; full bitter-sweet flavour, smooth mouthfeel; sweet coffee, bitter chocolate, toasted malt and traces of hops in the long, long finish. A very rich, complex and tasty brew. Great pleasure.....

I can distinctly remember having this for the first time in the late 80s at a friends wedding.  
Very black with a great frothy head. Not much lacing, though.  As my daughter says, "it smells like oatmeal".  Not as much coffee as some, but some nice roasted aroma.  I like the sweetness of the aroma.  Next to no carbonation.  Hints of vanilla is nice.
Great beer!!!!!!  The aroma was a nutty oatmeal but was a bit faint.  The taste was perfected.  The balance between the flavors was amazing.

Amazing.  In this case appearance almost compares to what was inside-- the aroma was very enticing; oatmeal with hints of nutty sweetness.  This carried over to the taste palate, it was very pleasing and left me with wanting more. ;)

Oh wow, what a nice looking stout. Recommended by a good friend and beer geek. Pours jet black, blacker than night with hints of obsidian, ebony, and darkness. Yeah, this beer is very black. 

The aroma is sweet, romantic almost and very perfume like for a stout. Sweet like brown suger, caramel, vanilla, maple syrup and cake batter.The carbonation is non existent, making the palate a bit gross for me. Still, with a bit more carbonation this beer would be among the best. Hell, it is among the best.

chocolaty, smooth, silky. One of the best beers Ive had in a long time. not very bitter, just right. Pitch black with a tan head. sweet.
A great Beer..

Looks and feels like any other oatmeal stout youve had ... nothing bad or good to write home about there.  Taste is quite thought and leaves most of the rest in its oatmeal dust.  Its dry but with a biscuty sweetness - not sweet just good.  A little chocolate and maybe hints of a subtle fruit like apple.  Utlimately a smooth and very drinkable oatmeal stout

Disappointing.  This is probably more a function of the fact that this beer was shipped overseas and sat on a shelf in a clear bottle (wtf? switch to brown bottles already) lit overhead by a fluorescent lamp, but every time I try a Sam Smith, it just tastes like pure skunk.  This one is no exception.  Pours black with a creamy tan head like any proper stout, but man, I just cant get past the odor.  Too bad... you kinda sense that, under the ass, this is probably a pretty good one.  Guess Ill have to wait until I can get it on tap somewhere, like, not here.
Dry as a bone and bitter.  Not a lot of oatmeal silkiness but a great stout anyway.  Raisins and nuts; even a little something that reminded me of peanut butter.  Somewhat oily texture.

Aroma of chocolate and coffee.    Surprisingly bitter flavor profile, with notes of chocolate, coffee, roasted caramel malt, and nuts.  Palate seems silky yet watered-down somehow.  A fine quality beer.
An excellent stout with wonderful mouthfeel, aroma, and hints of coffee/chocolate throughout. One of my favorites and a great beer to fall back on.

I was very dissapointed in this oatmeal stout. Other oatmeal stouts Ive had have been more impressive, including the much less expensive Goose Island version. The Samuel Smiths is too bitter in my opinion for an oatmeal stout. I thought the flavor was less than satisfying as well. Not a terrible beer at all, but not worth the price.
Nice and sweet with a little chocolate aftertaste, but in general kinda bland.  Seemed a bit too watered down for my taste.

Had it last night in a restaurant in NJ with a great variety of brews. Thought it to be an excellent brew, easy drinking. Dark, with chocolate/coffee hints of flavor. Recommend it to all who have not tried it.

pours dark brown almsot blach with thin white-tan head.  Aroma is sweet, with roasted hints and oat hints.  Taste has coffee hints, with a lot malty sweetness.  Low bitterness.  Mouthfeel is too thin, and it lacks the warmth of a good stout.  A bit overly carbonated also.  Does some important things well, but lacks the balance and the thickness of a truly great stout.
Very nice, sweet, a little alcoholic, very good brewed. The taste is just awesome. Reminds me some Stouts from Central and SouthAmerica which are not really known.
It is one of the better English beers available in Georgia. Dark color, nice creamy head, and smooth after taste. Warm sinsation while drinking.

Bottled. Pours a clear black-brown with a lacy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and burnt toast. The body is medium, with light carbonation. Taste starts creamy sweet with chocolate, coffee, oatmeal, molasses.  Finish has some coffee-bitter and and slightly sour elements to it. Tasting Sam Smiths again for the first time in a long time. It seemed bigger and fuller before, but this is the beer that led me out of the land of lagers, lo those many years ago. Probably still the best "supermarket stout" out there.

Nice dark brown body, fluffy off white head, nice lacing.  Aroma is mild hops, but mostly caramel, malty, oaty, and a mild skunk.  Flavor is caramel, malty, with some tart notes.  PRetty good body, decent beer overall.

12 oz. bottle:pours dark brown with decent tan head.  Aroma is very roasty.  flavor is much of the same with the flavor.  Coffeeish, with lots of nice roastyness.  much like a porter because it is lightly hopped.  malts are showcased nicely.  Palate is medium, not quite right for a stout... but is very smooth feeling because of the oatmeal cheers
Not to fond of this beer, mabye it was too sweet for my taste not a big fan of this beer, I was rather disapointed

Pours very dark with a small dark brown head. Aroma is soft but nice kinda like toasted walnuts with chocolate. The taste more dark chocolate with malty sweetness and then soon followed by a toasty bitterness. Palate is a little thin as I expected this beer to feel thicker in the mouth.
Pours almost black with a thin head. Spicy but somewhat lacking in flavor. Like a watered down imperial stout.
Pours with a rich tan head full dark ruby color.  Wonderful aroma with hints of chocloate and molasses.
UPDATED: JUN 23, 2006 Bottle @ Ds 6 packs. Pours dark ruby color with tan head. Aroma is molasses and caramel. Flavor is molasses, caramel, and chocolate. Nice bitterness.

Dark brown appearance with a litle more carbonation than I expected.  Coffee and chocolate flavors are mild - oat and malts are more prevalent.   Aroma is also not a strong as expected, but it has a sweeter aftertaste.

18.7 oz bottle.  Cola colored; kicks up a big head that looks like sepia-tinged cooked oatmeal.  Band-Aids, wheat/oats, touch of molasses.  Mild malts with citric carb.  Oats fade to hops, dries into chloraseptic.  Expected the body to be fuller with some oatmeal smoothness but a little watery.  OK.

Gotta take care to store this beer correctly since it comes in a clear bottle.

Its pretty tasty, but im not a fan of the artificial carbonation.  If i want that ill drink a soda.  For the style however, this is a very good sweet stout.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 Current Rating:

I tried this again and I though it was very good, so time to re-rate.  It actually came in a brown bottle (not clear).  Smooth chocolate, coffee, and roast flavor.  Almost creamy, with a little bit of hops.

Past Rating:

I tried this awhile ago and I remember it being very good, so I decided to try it again.  Maybe I got a bad bottle or something, it may have been in the light to long with that damn clear bottle.  It looked good, but tasted very strange almost like something had gone bad.  I will give it more points than I think it deserves because I might have got a bad bottle. (7,4,5,3,11  3)
A very nice stout. Pours almost black with a small tan head. A mild coffee and nutty flavor. A slight skunky aroma at first but that went away after a few minutes. Overall very good.

Hands down the best Sam Smith.Great with a steak dinner or on a cold night...
........................................
Nice dark color, just without that rich smooth stout taste I crave. The clear glass bottle cant be good for the beer either. Im actually surprised by such high ratings. I may do a re-rate later.
Very sweet and dark, almost like a barleywine. Low carbonation. Toasted chocolatey malty goodness. Very smooth and not too much bite.

This is a classic.  Its the standard by which I measure all stouts.  This does not mean its perfect, but it is what I consider a fair, complete representation of this beer style.  The texture is what youd expect, thick with coffee and caramel notes and caramel aromas.
My favorite Stout in the world. I prefer this over Guiness any day. Great roasted aroma, velvet like pour a stout that should be enjoyed many times. Cheers !

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 <!-- i -->550 ml bottle.<!-- /i --> Well, only when I poured did I realize this was a clear bottle. Well, there were no skunks waiting as I opened, so I should be okay. Instead, an enticing waft of roast barleys, "beer" alcohol, and the slight hint of marshmallow fluff I think about with some oatmeals. Pours deep black under a brown-eggshell head the consistency of root beer foam. Taste is quite mild and warming. Those roasties come through well, but not with astringency. Oats keep a nice creamy mouthfeel  as I go along. Kind of sugary at the start, but tends to want to dry out further along. Kind of surprised that the description up front is about its being pasteurized and CO2-conditioned, but perhaps that’s how it could travel so well.
Must say its one of my favorites. Smooth, rich, bit of a roasted aftertaste. Great stout, not much of an aroma.
Very dark and rich sort of like an expresso sweet, coffe taste, and chocolate. The Finish is bitter with alcohol good stout!

This is definately one of my favorite beers. It has a great flavor that can be enjoyed at any type of event. I love the thickness and the fact that the taste does not smack you in the face. It is the beer I choose when I want something I know I will enjoy.
All the stuff you would expect from  a good stout. Ive had better stouts  but this is definitely near the top of my list.

A nice dark and thick oatmeal stout. First ordered this (a bottle) after giving up on Fosters on draft at a bar in Miami. Typical burnt, chocolate, and coffee aromas and flavor. Seemed thinner than other stouts, but still enjoyable. Enjoyed more on draft in May 2005 and bumped rating up a tad.

Bottle - Pours thick deep dark brown with tan medium head.  Aroma is roasted coffee and sweet chocolate.  Medium silky smooth palate.  Flavor is full of chocolate and roasted coffee with just a touch of hoppiness on the follow-through.  Nice bittersweet chocolate in the aftertaste with a touch of alcohol warming.  Overall, this is an excellent stout......one of the best Ive had.

Bottle: Poured with a gloriously cascading wall of bubbles that piled into a nice solid milkshake-like tan top over a dark brown glass of goodness.  Unfortunately, the aroma is scant, and the flavor is pretty much restrained ... a light roast flavor is the predominate character with perhaps a light chocolate tinge.  Good, but not as good as Id hoped.

Very dark with a tan head - smooth mouth.  Definitely tasted the oatmeal which was sweet but not overly so.  Unfortunately for me, this beer (while in all other respects was fantastic) had a licorice finish that I didnt care for.  I definitely found the Taddy Porter much better suited to my palate.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Black. Starts off strong then dissipates to a light finish. Malt chocolate taste that lingers in the mouth and then works its way down the throat. A Great beer.
Bottle 0,55l. Pitch black. A pretty creamy head. Aroma of coffee. Well balanced. Outstanding - but served too cold at Princess Louise London WC1

550 ml bottle -   Pours a deep dark brown color with a nice long lasting light tan head. Has a noble hop aroma.  Light roasted malt flavor with just a little sweetness.  Smooth taste with a bitter finish.  Medium body.  A good beer.
This is one of the best beers Ive ever had. Smooth, rich, full of flavor. Definitely get your hands on it if you can.

Bottle.  Very nice.  Pours like a Guinness, with a lasting, big, foamy, tan head.  Great thick, mouthfeel.  Deceptively sweet aroma of chocolate.  Taste is very nicely balanced.  Oats are noticeable but not too sweet.  An enjoyable brew.
One of the best beers I have ever had the pleasure of trying.  Rich, thick flavor with a nice smooth after-taste.

Beer pours a thick, brown, and foamy head with an aroma of rich chocolate and molasses. It must be a perfect blackbody because of how dark it is (Physics Humor).  The palate is somewhat dry yet delightful. The flavor is bursting with chocolate, coffee, oats, molasses, and other rich malts. The beer goes down extremely smooth. After injesting the beer a smooth coffee malt is left in the mouth just long enough to say holy shit that was good and long enough to open another. One of the best beers I have had. Upsetting that it only comes in a four pack!
yup, thick opaque black colour. thick foamy head. chocolate oats and extremely dry. bitter sweet finish.
This is one of my favorite beers.  Sweet taste with hints of caramel, molasses and butter.  Extremely good beer with a nice dinner.

<!-- b -->1 pt 2.7 oz Bottle.<!-- /b --> Almost an opaque black pour but I can still see a little through it with a nice large tan head.  Scents are of buttery, quite high malt notes, oatmeal, light sugar notes.  Taste is malty and sugary, but not so sugary that its offensive.  A nice blend of hoppiness and nice malt texture buttery oatmeal.  Rather watery and sweet on the palate.  Wasnt super thick, was a little watery, but I liked it all the same.  <!-- i --><!-- b -->Nice!<!-- /i --><!-- /b -->
slightly lighter in colour than most stouts, and a little bit of sweetness with a bubbly head, not so thick as head on other stouts I have tried.

Poured out opaque with a tall brown head. Aroma is light with hints of the highly roasted malts awaiting in the flavor. Yum! Some sweet molasses cut with some dryer tasting roasted chocolate malts. Thick and creamy mouth feel. This is very tasty. If I nitpick Id say it could use a bit more aroma, a bit more gravity and body. Good beer.

This beer pours a dark red almost black with a large tan head.  It has a very smoky kinda skunky bitter smell.  The flavor is incredible!  Very smokey, coffe flavors kinda deep roasted.  This is a very good beer!  Cheers!

This was a good beer, but nothing spectacular. Poured to a deep black with tan head that faded quickly. Deccent lacing as I drank. Aroma was hints of chocolate, but faint. I enjoyed the flavor, especially at mid-glass, but the body seemed light, and slightly watery. Had an okay finish, but nothing to write home about. Enjoyed the SS Taddy Porter and Impy Stout more.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2006 Bottle.  Pours very dark brown.  Nice off white head.  Creamy texture.  Chocolate and some Coffee.  A bit of sweetness thrown in there as well. 
Re-Rate:  Liked it much better the second time

UPDATED: APR 6, 2009 Highly drinkable for a stout beer. Distinct roasty flavors of coffee, chocolate. Slight sweetness on palate, with a short lingering dryness in the finish. Highly satisfying and recommended.
Bottle. Nice creamy tan head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma is sweet with hints of coffee. Taste is malty and a touch of caramel and coffee. Good palate.
not quite what i was expecting. very drinkable, not a full flavoured beer. best poured on cornflakes.

[clear bottle] Pours out black in color with a light, coffee colored head. Aroma is sweet, with a touch of coffee. Flavors are quite sweet up front and malty towards the middle. Mouthfeel is pretty oily- this brew definitely coats the mouth, the only downside seems to be the heavy carbonation. I really dig this beer, and I like that its so readily available.
Bottle.  Great Beer!  Pours black with substantial beige foamy head.  Aromas of coffee and caramel.  Full flavor.
Bottle (BBE Dec 06). Cola, roast and smoke aromas. Thin with seemingly unfermented sugar feel. Poor.

The head on this was very large and tight.Lasted a while also.Aroma was a deep malt,.barley.Tasted rich,and filling ,like oatmeal.had a dark brown color,and hearty taste.Finished just right.This is a heavy duty beer.At first i thought it was too strong flavor for me,but by the time I finished it ,it tasted pretty good.Too bad I only bought one.Good thing theres plenty more at Trader Joes!!.

550ml bottle. Poured dark, near-opaque brown into an imperial pint with a large moderately-diminishing foamy tan head. Interesting nose for a stout.. chocolate, cherries, and a hint of yeast character(??) with a whiff of alcohol. The flavor is striking/strange: bitter coffee and toast, very sweet, with cherries again. Slight alcohol in the finish and a little sourness. Overall the flavor could stand to be a little stronger. Medium-heavy body, rich and creamy, highly drinkable. The sweetness is a bit much.

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2006 Bottle.
Pours a dark color with generous head that sticks. Sweet aroma that gives a hint to whats inside. Taste is very sweet light hop and heavy malt hide on the palate and goes down very smooth. Great food stout. Cheers!

(Bottled 20 Apr 2006) Colour is dark brown, almost black, with ruby hints. Firm, beige head. Nose is mildly roasted, with chocolate, some sweetness and tobacco. Full taste of roasted oatmeal and chocolate. Bitter-sweet with some hops in the finish. Very smooth and nice.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2006 Pours dark with a tan head. Aroma of roast, caramel, hops. Flavor is coffee, roast, caramel, and bitter.

bottle from bevmo.  Pours a rich black color with a medium sized tan head that not very large but is super thick.  Aroma is rich and roasty, but not as bold as I expected.  Flavor is roasty and smokey with strong hickory hints through-out.  Very smooth on the palate and overall a very enjoyable stout that is reasonably priced and easy for me to find locally.

Dark with a gentle sweetness and well rounded body.After a while there are traces of dryness.This is when you realise what a well crafted stout this is.
Very drinkable and highly recommended.

Black body, huge light brown head, stays long, leaves beautiful laces; Quite big nose, deep and complex: loads of oatmeal, but also a sugary sweetness, figs and fresh fruit like apple and pear; Balanced body, perfectly smoth, with perfect amount of carbonation, all elements in play; quite long finish (I expected a bit more fill) complex with loads of character, bitter, fresh with a little sweetness, some malt and again fruit, pear and cherry. Great and very, very well made beer.

Sammy Smiths oatmeal stout has been a classic among my friends for years. Its one of the best tasting stouts that can be found just about anywhere. Of the many things that make this beer great, even people who are afraid to drink any beer darker than a glass of water will find this beer tasty. This is the kind of beer that makes people realize that there is a whole world of beer out there to be discovered. And after they discover it, theyll keep coming back to Sammy Smith and his oatmeal stout.

Really delicious!  Had from big 550 ml bottle.  Poured a rick, burnt red with solid, thin head.  Aroma of berries and slight bitterness.  Taste was at first very roasted, chocolate and grains, but as the glass got lower more fruit and sweetness arose.  More carboanation than I expected, nice touch.  great beer!

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a tint of red.  The head is quite frothy, but only for a minute.  The aroma is bitter and unsweet with hints of berries.  The first touch of the toungue brings a taste of unripened fruit with a toasted hit to it.  The finish ends more on a bitter note, with just a tiny touch of hops near the end.

Bottle. Pours very dark ruby with brown, slightly soapy head. The aroma is crabapple, unripe berries, bitter chocolate, and a touch of cheese. The flavor, while less, erm, sour than the aroma, still has a lot of unripe fruit; quite zesty for a stout. A lot of toast and caramel in there, too. I can only pick out the hops if I concentrate. The finish is very clean. The mouthfeel is a bit thin.

Had on tap at the Three Goats Heads, Oxford, 07-04-06. Pours dark, dark brown, creamy slightly dirty head, tastes very smooth, smokey coffee chocolatey taste that is really pleasant. Really enjoyed this.

One of my favorites as you can tell by the rating.Very rich tasting and the color is dark brown.What a beer.Chocolate malts i tasted and a very thick and smooth beer.The only down side is it is hard to get in pa.for a decent price. WHAT A BEER,DELICIOUS.

Bottle.  Dark blackish brown, with a thin tan head.  Chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee notes in the aroma.  Delicious taste with some chocolate, burnt cane sugar, smoke, roasted grain, and a touch of anise.  Finishes clean with some bitterness to nicely balance this sweet stout.  Palate is complex and very smooth.  Really, really good brew.

Dark brown with a beige head. An intriguing aroma of chocolate and some fruit I cant name. Possibly redcurrant. The taste has liquorice, alcohol, coffee, black treacle sweetness. Combined with only slight bitterness this makes a stout that it would be hard for anyone not to enjoy.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2014 Bottle from Once Upon a Vine South on 05/01/2011. Dark brown body with ruby highlights and a large frothy tan head. Sweet roast and chocolate aroma with light fruit and caramel. Sweet roast and chocolate flavor with some fruit, caramel and light sulfur. Medium body with moderate carbonation. 7/4/7/3/14 3.5

On 04/06/2006. Dark cherry color with a creamy light brown head. Sweet caramel and dark malt aroma. Sweet slightly bitter flavor with a light touch of smoke. 8/5/8/3/16 - 4.0

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with spectacular ruby highlights in light, and was capped with an impressive tan head.  The aroma was semi-smeet with a smokey coffee dominating.  Brown sugar molasses type flavors are evident but quickly give way to smokey burnt toast character that lingers.  It feels creamy and full bodied in the mouth, silky and a joy to drink.
Pours a dark brown with a tan head tha thas good retention.  Medium bodied with a sweet malty taste with molasses, chocolate, and bitterness being able to be detected.  A decent beer.
Pours deep brown into a pint glass.  Mild malt aroma.  Light and well balanced maltiness.  Good sweet stout.

Smooth and refreshing brew.  Beautiful dark color with tastes of roasted maltiness, brown sugar, coffee, and a hint of (you guessed it) oatmeal.  Wonderfully balanced throughout, finshes like a sweet stout should.
Bottle. Creamy light brown fully lasting head. Nice chocolate aroma.  Average finsh, very licorice-flavor. Oily palate. A very good oatmeal stout.

Sable head, soiled melting snow aspect. Dark brown almost black color, with a slightly red tint, it doesnt show through.

Strong oat aroma, sugar cane sweet smell. Traces of olives. It tends to dry plums.

Sweet taste, great body.

Thicker than water, thinner than a cream. Frothy texture.

Very concealed alcohol.

Slightly sweet bitterness and vage roughness like oporto.

550 ml bottle. Black or very dark brown pour with a light brown head. Very sweet choclatey maltey aroma. Feels very light in the mouth and could be perfected by adding a little body. The lightness of this beer allows it to be very smooth and easy to drink and is not overpower at all.
12oz: Pours a dark pitch black w/huge tan brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, oatmeal.  Taste of roasted malts, oatmeal, chocolate, creamy taste.  Medium body.

Pours opaque black, great tan fluffy head, faded quick but left great sticky lace.  Aromas of toast, crackers, smoke, coffee, citrusy yeast, dark ripe fruit, oatmeal and maple syrup.  Flavors of smoky malt, coffee, oatmeal, brown sugar, some grapefruity hops, sweet flavors like dark fruit, toffee and chocolate were in the background.  Thick and chewy on the palate.

Pours a nearly black color with a thick off-white head. Decent lacing. Aroma unfortunately shows some signs of light damage (a little funky) but it there is a rich malt profile in their and some hints of coffee. Rich roasted malt flavor with strong coffee notes. Soft carbonation gives a fairly smooth mouthfeel. Very enjoyable. Not the thickest stout in the world but very enjoyable.

(Bottle.  03/2006) Roasted barley aromas.  Some fruitiness with a definite musty note.  Dark amber with thick, moussy, tan head that lasts nicely.  Decent lace.  Dry, almost astringent, roasted characters in the flavor profile.  Slightly metalic at first, but that is quickly lost to the maltiness of the flavor profile..  Smooth on the back end.  Slightly bitter, but creamy aftertaste.  More spritzy than expected.  Medium bodied.
Bottle.  Pours black with an off-white rocky head.  Plenty of bitter roasts that give way to a slighly creamy finish.  Hints of chocolate and molasses in the backdrop.

550 mL bottle at cellar temp. Thick tan head with moderate retention and some lacing. Sweet malt and chocolate in the nose with a fruity, berryish quality. Nice sweet chocolate malt and coffee with some roast flavor. A touch of lingering hop and subtle roast chocolate aftertaste. A fine sweet stout.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2008 550 ml bottle.  Surprised after pouring this to find its a clear bottle.   This stout is oaty, with that familiar roasted chocolate malt flavor.  Bittersweet.
Its certainly not the more thick flavorful stout Ive had, but it very good nonetheless.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2006 Bottle 12oz. IT has a chocolate appearance with a light brown head, its smells sweet and malty, but the flavor is fruity, roasted not too sweet though, i was expecting to find more oatmeal taste to it. This is a good beer, but not as good as its rated. Ive had it twice now, and as far as stouts go its very good overall, just expecting a little more taste to it. The body is a bit light but very smooth. Aftertastes of vanilla, oatmeal and roasted barley.
Bottle 12 oz. Appearance: Deep dark with a tan head.  Aroma: sweet malt, chocolate, fruity.  Flavor: roasted, toffee, malty, sweet.
poured a very dark brown with minimal head but decent lacing.  aroma was of malt-o-meal and taste had some vanilla notes.  slight hops finish was a nice surprise, enjoyable.

550ml-bottle.This famous stout poured out a dark black/brown color with a small tan head.Aroma was sweet with hint of chocolate and molassas.The taste was also sweet,but a felt the body was a little thin.This beer was ok,but a little over-rated.
12 oz. bottle.  Poured a dark brown.  Aroma was malty and a hint of chocolate.  Flavor was more of the same with the oatmeal thrown in.  A pretty good brew.

This beer offers a good hearty aroma of oatmeal, licorice, and malt.  It is a black solution with a thick brown head and heavy lacing.  This thick smooth beer produces a taste of oatmeal with mild licorice hints.  A mild indication of smoke can be detected right at the point of swallowing.  The a mild nutty aftertaste lingers well.

550ml bottle: Faint malty aroma that doesnt give any indication of flavor. The first sip slightly warmed gives a good tasty malt and toasted coffee and slight chocolate hint. The oatmeal is mild and barely evident except on the tail end. The body is medium and disappointly thin for a stout but earns points for a nice smooth slick mouthfeel. A good drinkable beer but nothing extraordinary.
Deep dark and toasty.  Great roasted malt with caramel hints.  Not much to add other than it goes great with bread pudding.
Wonderful dark chocolate brown ale with a strong foamy head. Spicy caramel hints, fruity aroma, an exceptionally smooth body. Excellent value and well worth its high score.

12 oz bottle. Pours a cola brown with a rapidly fading light brown head.  Smells barely hoppy with just a hint of sweetness.  The taste itself starts off smooth, with an earthy,  grainy, and smoke-filled mid taste with a slightly dry bitter streak towards the end.  Theres a spice lurking about in there, maybe cinnamon.  Meduim-bodied and smooth overall, a stout worthy of its ratings.  Its only drawback for me, personally, is the dry state it leaves your mouth in.  Still worth a try by far.

Dark red/brown pour.  Earty smell filled the room as poured.  A thick bubly and foamy head.  Earthy, herby, tart and spicy scent.  It smells like a full course meal.  Immediate strong taste, with quite a mix of flavours.  Earthy, coffee, malt, tart (berry?).  A lot of coffee taste.  Somewhat suprisingly sweet.  Rich easy drinking but I wouldnt session it.  One of the best stouts I have ever have, only beaten by a couple I have had in Quebec.
you should try Higland brewerys Oatmeal Porter!!!!  Much better  I feelt that all aspects of the beer is better, including the fact that it is a small time brewer

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 Black-brown, tall tan head. Chocolatey and charred toast aromas. Big roasted malt flavours, coffee, chocolate, black cherry hints. Rich and creamy mouthfeel, rounded balanced palate. A fantastic stout.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: An excellant beer. The aroma was of dark chocolate and mild coffee. The head was large, creamy and light brown in color. The lacing was excellent, the head was fully diminishing and the body was cloudy and black in color (surprised that i\this is a clear bottle). The initial flavor was light bitter and the finish was light bitter. The finish was average. The body was medium, the texture was soft and the finish was a light astrigent.
Pours dark black with large brown creamy head. Very good. Odd that it is in a clear bottle. This beer goes down very smoth.  A++

cereal, coffee, toast,  come to mind. Carb bubbles are very fine and overall carbination is very light.  Long creamy head and beer goes down silky.
(Bottle) poured a dark, black cherry color.
$4 a pop in Boca Raton.

Pours dark with moderate long lasting head.    Sweet caramel and fruity malt aroma.  All the nice chocolate, coffee, and caramel flavors that one would expect but with delicious smokey hickory and nutty overtones.  Bittersweet finish.  Id like a little thicker body, but other than that its perfect.
My favorate beer. At $2.85 a bottle a steal! Chocolate, Coffee,Carmel, and a head that lasts all the way down to the bottom of the glass. DONT chill this beer to much. Enjoy with a THICK steak.
Extremely good beer. Very rich flavor with heavy oatmeal taste. Slightly bitter but not over the top. Would highly recommend.

Bottled(550ml). -this is one of the best beers that ive tried in last six months, deep dark coloured, airy pale brown head, chocolate cake and sherry nose, fruity(cherry) and roasted flavor, roasted malty and roasted coffee aroma with nice strong dark chocolate notes, slight bitterness, nice moderate bitter-sweet finish

Nice stout, a little bitter, but the head was nice...as was the overall flavor. Nice oatmeal flavor...with a malty overtone. Finish leaves a bit of an aftertaste...cant tell whether is from hops or not. Not as warm a flavor as say a Rogue Chocolate or Oatmeal...a little thinner. Very nice brew.Would do again.

Oatmeal stouts tend to be hard to perfect, but Samuel Smiths version comes close. It has to have bitter undertones, but not overwhelm. Appropriate amount of carbination. An excellent, but very pricey beer.
Pours dark black with large brown creamy head.  Long lasting sweet roasted malt flavor with alcoholic/wine like ending.
I love oatmeal stout, and was looking forward to finally giving this a whirl....Very disappointed.  This might be a tad bit overhyped I mean come on 99.
very nutty stout.  was dark when i poured it so i dontk now what color it is(some shade of black obviously)  very smooth with a roasted malt.  was a little sweet.
Pours a deep brown almost black with a fluffy tan head. Nice lace "leave behind". Aroma and flavors are malty and roasted coffee. Wonderful.

Pours a deep blackish brown with thick tan head that persists throughout. Nose is heavy with english yeast notes, with lackluster black malt aroma. Flavor is thin and metallic and once again heavy with english yeast, some mild sweetness. Overall a little thin and yeasty.
2/5/06: Bottle.Malt and cream nose.  Dark brown caramel body with a light almond head; x-s in size.  Creamy, caramel malt flavor with some hops.  Slightly bitter.  Finish is chalky but clean.
a really pleasing beer with a robust taste that pleases the palate and is rather refreshing. easily accessible, too, so thats a nice convenience.

Armoma was a mix between dough and wine maybe? dark beer with a large head that goes down quickly. can really taste the oarmeal with this. Carbination was neat at first but the more i drink it it starts to get annoying. good beer and would definatly try again.

550 ml bottle.  Pours dark brown with some garnet highlight when held to light.  This thing has a super creamy tan head that has on intentions of leaving me soon.  Some roasted oatmeal cookie aroma, but its very unimpressive.  Flavor is of light roasted coffee, with some sort of bitter bite.  The palate is silky-ish and the finish is dry.  Not a beer I will be drinking again soon.
Bottle- The pour was nearly opaque with a nice tan head that quickly dissapeared. The aroma was unfamiliar, almost like that of wine. It was really sweet, and overall a very good beer.

In my humble opinion, there is no better moment than the first taste from a bottle of Sam Smith Oatmeal Stout. When the stout hits your palate, there is nothing smoother, creamier, and more satisfying than this beer. Very dark color, great head with wonderful lacing, a perfect beer all around. If you want to enjoy a beer on a casual summer night, this is the one.

Dark brown with large tan head that quickly disappears. The aroma is noticably malty sweet with strong notes of chocolate. The flavor is sugary with notes of chocolate, sweet and roasted malts, coffee, and a bit of plum. The aftertaste has a slight bitterness that lingers. The texture starts silky smooth, but turns raspy from the carbonation as the beer covers the inside of the mouth. Thin to medium body. Comfortable balance of aromas and flavors.
Bottle. Brown head. Very dark red brown body, almost black. Mild roasted malt aroma. Tickling your tongue this flavor is rather molasses dominated.
A dark brew with full nectar. A dry style with a defined oat character. I caught a hint of celery on the finish. Overall very mellow, bland, and uninteresting which seems to be the style of S.S.

550ml bottle. Pours a very dark black color holds the head for a few minutes till it thins out. In Taste this beer make a great beer that holds its own. It may not stand up the best beers in the world but its a greate beer for most people. It has a great taste.
Had this about 4 pints in and boy did it sit me up at attention. Smokey and molasses flavor  with a bit of alcohol. Very good beer.
Bottle: Black with small head, smoked aroma, taste is full and bitter some acidity.

Pours very dark black with light tan head which dissipated on me rather quickly.  You can smell a bit of alcohol in the aroma.  Also quite a bit of malt.  A wide array of flavors in the mouth.  Little bits of chocolate and oatmeal, definately some molasses, and oddly and unfortuantely a tinge of sausage/hot dog as well.  Smooth finish.  Pretty good if I can pretend there wasnt the meat flavor in there somewhere.  Quite roasty.  Ill actually have another soon to see if there is any differences.

Great!  Pours brown-black with a small tan head.  Roasted nose, with maybe a hint too much alcohol.  A nice sour start leads into a choco-coffee middle and nice warming port finish.  Maybe a little more like an imperial than an oatmeal - but still great!

Also this is my 100th!!!!!!

Not a bad one for 100.
Jet black with thin tan head. Smoky malt nose. Robust roasted malt taste with lingering mild bitter finish.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2006 From the bottle.

Pours a deep black with a reasonably-sized light brown head.
Here is another beer that is almost too familiar to rate. The aroma? "Well, it smells like Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout!" (I guess that is some combination of molassas, chocolate, oak, and a hint of alcohol/wine, though I keep smelling Sam Smiths and have a hard time thinking beyond that.)
The flavor is sweet, chocolately, before turning to a lovely and gentle lactic sourness followed by a subtle and smooth bitter roasted cocoa bean finish. The mouthfeel is superb, especially at 5%, creamy, substantial, delicous, luxuriously smooth and amply carbonated at the same time.

To me, this is the benchmark sweet stout. There may be others out there that are better, but this is the familiar and thoroughly excellent reference point to which I compare them.

Seems to me a lot of times when I get imports they are way past there due date or something. This beer is no exception. Very dark colored beer (brownish black). Very small head. Beer smells like alcohol and an aroma of bananas believe it or not. There is also a wine like smell.  The beer is sweet with a strong taste of bananas. Not much aftertaste and fairly smooth going down. Not extremely impressed but I think the beer must have sit on the shelf for a while for a highly recognized beer.
Very dark brown with a medium thick kaiki head thta dissipates quicly but laces the glass sides. Sweet malty aroma, with a taste ofchocolate and coffee, combined with sweet malts.

Pours a black color with a tan head.  Aroma was of roasted malts and a hint of chocolate and coffee.  Taste was the same with a slightly sweet taste. Finishes smoth.  Yet again another good Samuel Smiths brew
Smooth, delicious, rich and creamy.  What a great beer!  The glass was empty before I wanted it to be.  A nice combination of sweet malts and bitter is noticeable.   A quality beer to be tasted!
sweet and malty, some slight chocolate and mocha flavors, but i would have liked them to be more prominent, a little on the thin side, but not bad overall, their are alot better stout out their.

Bottle: Pours with a nice tan, creamy head and a black body. Fine lacing. Aroma of roasted malt. The flavour is rather sweet with a taste of dark malt, notes of black coffee and chocolate. Medium to full bodied. Smooth and light bitter finish. A top beer in this style and very enjoyable too.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2006 Ahhh what an excellent beer!! Pours almost a complete black with a loverly (2 fingers) dark brown head! Nice roasted malt aroma with hints of coffee which is reflected in the flavor. Smooth and creamy. One of the most satisfying beers around!!

agreed - this beer rocks the house. 
Its up there with Mackeson. Dont forget the convenient four pack bottles too :)

I have recently been on a stout kick, and this one has made me decide to continue it.  Definitely one of the smoothest, most pleasant beers Ive ever tasted.  Its a full, well-rounded stout with a creamy dark chocolate character.  Pours nice and dark with a tan head, and the finish is excellent.  Awesome beer!

A very nice pour with a nice thick head, I didnt detect much aroma (not like I do most stouts). Ive consumed this beverage many times and have just gotten around now to rate it. A very nice "blue collar" stout that wont leave you guessing what you drank. Chocolate, oatmeal and some coffee notes make this a very nice beer. Well done by the Brits who do three things real well...Beer, Acting and Rock N Roll.
morrdt...no pun apparent. Nice work.
Wow.  An outstanding beer.  Pours dark with a nice tan head.  Very aromatic.  Very smooth drinking and I am astounded by this stout.  No pun intended.

Bottle. Pours dark black body with thick brown/tan head. Aroma fills nose with molasses, coffee, and maybe toffee. Flavor covers the entire tongue with sweet malt molasses. Moderate smooth and bitter aftertaste lingers with coffee feel. Medium body with soft creamy feel which finishes moderately alcoholic. My first rating and a great beer to start with.

i didnt really taste the oatmeal, but otherwise it was a solid stout.  the aroma almost seemed spicy to me, like cinnamon or nutmeg.  the mouthfeel wasnt as creamy as, say, a guinness. it was quite good.

550 ml bottle.  Pours a very dark mahogany with ruby highlights.  Thick creamy light brown head with good retention.  Roasted malt nose with some coffee, oats, and light alcohol.  Roasty and chocolate malt flavor with a dry light hoppy finish.  A little light in the flavor department.  Nice smooth and soft mouthfeel, light fine bubbled carbonation.  A little thin perhaps but maybe not too much for a Sweet Stout.  A decent solid beer.  You can pretty much count on these guys for well made beer provided theyve been handled well (read: not light struck).

Bottle.  Deep black color with nice tan hean.  Alcohol, anises and molases aroma.  Taste is quite the same, alcohol, molases and anises and nice carbonation.  Thats a strong beer, taste like an imperial stout.

Bière de couleur noire opaque avec un bon collet beige.  Odeur dalcool, danis et de mélasse.  Au goût, cest pas mal la même chose, alcool, mélasse et anis, avec un niveau correct de co2.  je lai trouvé pas mal forte en alccol (au goût) pour une stout, on aurait presque dit cétait un imperial.
Great stout. SS needs to lose the clear bottles, but this was a good non-skunked beer.

10 Sep 05 - Big sweet fruit and nicely hopped aroma.  Clear, dark brown-black colour with a good lasting beige head and suds lacing.  Light roasted malt with herbal flavours.  Light malt lingering finish.

550 ml bottle poured a clear, dark brownish black with a lasting beige head. Aromas of dark fruit, molasses,licorice and a hint of coffee. Palate was light, crisp and smooth. Flavors of coffee, roasted malt,and bitter chocolate with a smooth, lingering mildly bitter finish.
"It was very smooth. Poured a dark black color small head little bit of lacing The taste was awsome sweet little thin/lighter then other stouts Tastes even bettter as it warmed."

This was the last beer I had at our Beer Club that featured the Samuel Smith Brewery and it was a great beer to finish up with. It has a complex flavor which is rich in coffee, chocolate and roasted hops with the great oatmeal flavor to smooth everything out.  I have finally worked a stout in to my beer club that even the light beers drinkers started to warm up to.
Dont understand the attraction to this beer or sam smith in general.  At best an average oatmeal stout.  Good mouth feel, decent flavor, skunk every thing else.  RATING INFLATION

This is quite simply, the worlds best stout, bar none. Perfectly balanced with excellent creamy  mouthfeel with the right blend of spice, bitterness and sweet malt. Superb. Sam Smiths is one of the worlds very greatest breweries. (But why the clear botttles!?)
Woe.  So well made.  Roasted malts and some bitter hops.  All kinds of flavors from chocolate to fruit.  Beauty.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 Glorious accomplishment of a beer. Wonderful aroma of malt present on top of a darker than normal brownish head that laced out nicely. Beautiful black body. Taste nearly knocked my socks off, not too strong, but a wonderful taste from a dark beer. Oatmeal was slightly prevalent in the taste. This has to be one of the top three beers that I have ever had!

This beer rocked. I had this to accompany a festive fondue meal with friends. It went extremely well with the meats and the overall meal. Very, very tasty, with a mild chocolate malt finish. This is very good moderaly cold and holds well when warmed in the glas sover time. If it wasnt so expensive, I would keep this in standard rotation in my fridge. Beautiful carmel/cola color when in glass.

Several nights ago, I decided it was time for an introduction to the Oatmeal Stout style, so I went back to back with Bristols Winter Warlock and Samuel Smiths own interpretation. Needless to say it was quite an oatmealicious evening. The pour produced an ordinary dark beige head cascading into a deep black body reminiscent of every other stout I have had. Nothing bad about that, as I generally enjoy the mysterious yet comforting aura that they reveal - more so than say pale lagers which are also commonplace. The aroma was of straightforward coffee and dark chocolate, with notes of Irish creme, soap and a certain alcohol tinge. Not complex but still a pleasant nose. The flavor shared a similar composition with a notable glue-like component that I found hard to get past but edulcorates over time. The finish is sweet and makes this brew easy to enjoy.

the best Ive had to date but still searching for the best. It may look to stout but is very light fo the color.  It has a sweet after taste. I would recommend drinking it not too cold. It allows you to taste all the flavors.
Dark brown with a reddish brown head.  Aromas of soy, chocolate, grains, coffee and banana.  Taste started out good but got funky as it went down.  Maybe this was a bad bottle.  Ill try it again.
Bottle, dark brown with red tones, thick brown head with nice lacing, Aroma of caramel and roasted grains, taste chocolate and grains with a smooth balanced finish.  nice.

Very dark (yet unclouded) with mahogany around its edges, topped with a huge, tan head that settles rockily over the course of the beer. Initial aroma struck me as a prune & caramel ice cream sundae! Rum & soy emerge later. A musty background suggests oxidation, but I find it rather fitting here. Bitter coffee flits about in the flavor, but the experience is mostly sweet malts with chocolate & dark fruits. Soy sauce shows late, adding a "meaty" character. Mouthfeel is sticky-smooth and the finish is a little bit dirty. Given its availability in my area, this would make a fine "everyday" stout.

<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Bridgeview, IL 60455<font size=-1>
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2007 One of my easy to find favorites.  Flavors of chocolate, oats and malt, a nice slight bitter aftertaste.  I kind of wish it had a bit thicker of a mouthfeel.

Great aroma of roasted malt. Coffee and chocolate flavors with a sweet aftertaste that yields to a slight bitter finish. The bitterness overtakes the sweetness in the finish as you work your way through the beer. So take your time and note the subtle changes in the palate and finish.
This has got to be one of the best oatmeal stout, I have ever had.  Tasty flavor that is not to sweet with a great aroma.

what a great oatmeat...aroma of roasted malts (the usual chocolate and coffee u would expect)....flavor is wonderful, and is very rich for an oatmeal (rich in chocolate and coffee, with a crisp bitter finish....) great flavor and great palate; good stuff

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2014 Re-rate from the pint+ bottle, this was the first really outstanding (4+) beer I had, from back in the day.  Aroma is thick and meaty, heavy chocolate with coffee and toffee, strong maltiness.  Ruby pitch pour with a rocky, creamy brown head.  Powerful taste, roasted malt is much stronger here, with all the mentioned aroma notes, and a strong, classy dryness.  Well-hopped and slightly vinous in feel.  Could use additional body.  Sourness evident after about a half-pint.  Really yummy. [Revision 2006.08.25: 4.0]I remember this being one of my first true gateway beers, but I never could seem to find it fresh.  This ones from a gift set and, judging by the India Ale from the same set, very fresh.  1 PT 2.7 OZ, foil-capped.  Nose is inky with light blackberry, very sweet with light cream under the strong fruit.  Pitch pour but still with a hint of mahogany-red peeking out from the bottom, a large and dense rocky tan head.  Taste very sweet with lightly tart fruity undercurrent, overall fruit still strong, some nice clean burnt and roast notes, but no coffee or char domination.  Lightly silky-creamy but not as much as other beers Ive had.  The sugary character isnt enough to cloy, but it does take a big toll in the mouthfeel, which the oats arent able to improve significantly.  Medium body is still slightly creamy, not too airy.  The yeasty may be the best part of this thing.  [2014.11.19: 3.5]

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2005 This beer is one of my all time favorites.  When I drink it my body feels like it has come to life, almost like I was filled with the divine light.  If god drank guiness, he would pee Sam Smith.  This is an amazing beer that only gets better the more you have it.  It is relatively inexpensive and has a aroma and color that rivals all other stouts.  It has an amazing head.  Darker than guiness yet light and frothy with all of the mixture of aroma and flavor.
