A great beer for all occasions and for all times, one of my favorites.

Pours a black color with brown highlights, the light brown heads is thick at first but diminishes to a thin line of foam that sticks nicely to the glass. The chocolate is dominant in the aroma, theres also faint roasty notes. The flavor has chocolate, oats, roasted malt and sugar, its more sweet than roasty, it finishes sweet but when the beer warms up the finish is more and more bitter . The body has a medium thickness with a velvety mouthfeel, the carbonation is low. Its nice to revisit old classics once in a while, its still the solid oatmeal stout I fell in love with years ago.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 Literature about London life through its many generations is in no short supply.  Prolific masters of the pen like George Bernard Shaw, Hillare Belloc, G.K. Chesterton and others have guaranteed that London, as a symbol of civilization, will remain in our imaginations well into the future.  Amongst these writings and polemics we find quaint stories and epic tales, and through many of them we begin to see patterns, and trends that get to the very heart of old London life.  Take, for example, the chimney sweeps aloofness, a ladys pointed wit or the brusqueness of the Indian colonel.  They seem to act by a universal code.  An English gentleman is as sure to tip his hat as gravity is to bring it to the ground should he bow before taking it off.  My favorite among them all is the one that concerns the portly and gruff looking old man, who lassitudinously clomps around pubs looking sour.  I argue he clomps around seeking good company, is gruff because hes seen whats in the London shadows and is portly because he appreciates the gourmands grasp on lifes finer bits.  We will call him Samuel Smith; Oatmeal Stout by trade.  Clad in an unassuming cloak of vintage labeling, the ineluctable SSOM practically glowers from the bottle, but really eases up when it comes to the task at hand: that is, drinking.  The cavernous, dark demeanor is no different from the Cro magnon brow our imagined blue collar Englishman has.  This deep shadow may cover the expressiveness of the beer in an unnecessary obscurity, but behind it is a convivial and curious brew.  Speaking of curious, the Oatmeal Stouts smell, which we will not extend to the analogy of the Englishman because that would be weird, is a strange collection of chocolate, coffee, dust and wet stone.  Also, it smelled a bit like perfume which we will DEFINITELY NOT extend to the imaginary Brit.  The taste is also dark and brooding, but a closer inspection tells a different tale.  Here we have a delicious flavor base of chocolate liqueur, supported by an overarching sweetness and oatmeal graininess.  After the chocolate dwindles were left with an oozing, trickling coffee taste, sloping down to a settled stomach and a great wide smile.  And lo, thats really what the Englishman was.  Behind the wild whiskers and the oft wild eyes was a hardy soul looking for a little beverage satiety.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2006 Dark ruby and black, light coffee flavor, light chocolate flavor. Very complex taste, but not in an overwhelming way; the stout retains a real drinkability to it. Slightly expensive, but a great overall stout.
Dark black with a light brown head that has a nice foam to it.   Nice roasty aroma.   Good  coffee like undertones and a lot of malt.  Malt sits well on the palate.  Solid Stout.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2006 2+ inch head with black thick body.  Not bad taste, though a little strong...  Nice thick creamy tan head.   Probably not something Id get again (especially for FOUR DOLLARS per a 550 ml bottle!!!)  But worthwhile to try.ORIGINAL RATING: 2+ inch head with black thick body.  Not bad taste, though a little strong...  Nice thick creamy tan head.   Probably not something Id get again (especially for FOUR DOLLARS per a 550 ml bottle!!!)  But worthwhile to try.





RE-RATE (10-14-06): Black, almost completely opaque body with just a slight ruby-red highlight, and a couple of fingers of tan head.  Smells malty and chocolatey.  Roasted coffee/chocolate and caramel dominate the flavor.  A couple of slightly off flavors in the background, but roasted chocolate dominates them.  Fairly sweet.  Fairly full-bodied.  Better than I remember.  I am extremely impressed!

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2006 Beautiful color and creamy head. Roasted coffee and fig(?) hints in the nose. Very rich texture to the tongue and a very nice blend of chocolate, malt, maple hints. A terrific oatmeal stout.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2006 A beautiful tan almost black colour with wonderful froth, aroma hint of chocolate, taste very oaty chocolate and malty, smooth velvety, lovely long aftertaste. A gorgeous brew, well done Sam Smiths. Bought at Beer Paradise/Estate Wine in Holstebro, Denmark.
Thick, tan head.  Pours jet black with dark brown highlights.  Aroma is sweet, possibly chocolate, with a hinto of malts.  Tastes sweet with oatmeal and malts.  A fine offering from Sam Smith.
This beer has a somewhat  malty aroma and is very light in body.  Not one of my favourite members of the stout family, probably in my bottom 50% of oatmeal stouts

Pours dark black with a absolutely beautiful thick tan head.  The head reminds me of the river from a quickly moving river, very sexy.  Smells somewhat sweet; perhpas a bit fruity and whisky-like (?).  Taste is sweet and a tad bit tart, can taste the oatmeal a fair bit in this one.  A good bit fruitier and more complicated than most Oatmeals, with a thinner body and less pronounced a flavor.
Pours jet black with a nice tan head.  Aromas of chocolate/coffee w/some malts.  Big full flavor chocolate, coffee, some oats.  I love this beer.
Bottled. Looks delicious, brown/black with a light brown head. Aroma of coffe, milk-chocolate and salty licorice. Flavor much the same. Full bodied and with some dry bitterness in the end. (051104)

Little to no khaki head. Nose is malt sweet with a noticeable dryness. Mouthfeel is creamy, even and nice. Flavor starts out briefly chocolate sweet followed by a prolonged oat dryness and ends with a slight bitterness of hops. This is an excenllent oatmeal stout that forefronts the oatmeal in a way that still manages a layered drinking experience. A classic for a reason.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2006 Very dark and beautiful, almost black color with red wine tones and a beige rocky head that lives for a while. Aroma has a malty and roasted character  with notes of cane sugar, prunes, dry apricots and olives. Flavor is essentially sweet with a superficial salty hint. The malty sweetness is noticeable and the finish is also sweet and long. Yummy. Oily texture complemented by a soft carbonation and a touch of wine in the medium body. Alcohol is subtle. Great!.
Pours dark, but not black. Aroma is nicely malty and chocolaty. Taste is absolutely delicious. Chocolate and oat taste come through. Very pleasant mouthfeel. Nice mild hop finish.

(Bottle 55 cl) Pitch black with a neat, little brownish head. Roasted, malty aroma. Quite light in body, notes of roasted/burned malts that dont leave any real bitterness though. Appears smooth with an unusual underlying slightly tart note. Could be the oats. Unusual. 050201

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2006 18.9 oz bottle - Pours up a thick, frothy head , very dark brown body.  This is a somewhat sweet, easy to drink stout.  It has a creamy, almost oily mouthfeel.  Its quite good if you want to reach for the malts tonight.

Pours black with 1/4 inch tan head.  Aroma is like the Cinnamon & Spice instant oatmeal, only with hops.  Wow, oatmeal is definitely present in taste.  A little sour, but creamy.  Swallow is smooth.  Aftertaste is sweet oats.  I enjoyed this stout and would like more brews to have a palate this smooth.

One of two things happened here.  Either I got an old old bottle or this is the worst Oatmeal stout Ive ever had.  Ive been a little scared to retry it on the thougt of the second option.  This was one of only three beers Ive ever had to pour out.

Aroma:chocolate,light coffee.....
Appearance:dark,good belge head...
Flavor:chocolate,light acidity,,roested malt....

Pours a black color with a small beige head.  Aroma is malty and coffeeish with hints of hops, oatmeal, barley and brown sugar.  Taste is slightly sweet, yet bitter with hints of roasted coffee, brown sugar,hops and oatmeal.  Excellent.

Marvelous complex sweet nectar of the gods!  Sweeter yet not too sugary or syrupy ... nice balanced mouthfeel.  Smooth upfront and in the midpoint with a delightful bitter crisp finish.  Dark in color and overall lovely.
Bouteille-Noire opaque with une mousse généreuse. Goût de malte et davoine. Crèmeuse en bouche.--Bottle-Black with a generous head. Taste of malt and oatmeal. Creamy in mouth.

Dark brown with a fully diminishing slightly rocky head.  Body wasnt bad, but  a little weaker that I would have expected.  Roastiness overpowers any oatmeal I detected.  Finished a bit cloying.  Perhaps I had unreasonable expectations, or had an old bottle, but Id call this one mediocre.

Poured with a thick tan head that lasted most of the pint.  A nice malt, oatmeal and molasses taste.  Bitter as a good english stout should be.  Finish was smooth with a bite at the end.  Highly recommended for those who like a dark english.

Inviting toasted oats, molasses, meal and cinnamon bun on the nose.  Somewhat roasted, but not overly so.  Thick and oily in the glass after the tan half inch of head fades.  Some lacing.  Flavors are oaty, malty, and delicately roasted with a smooth, bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is nutty, full and rich.  Lots of thought and care went into this brew.

This beer was very smooth, almost a chocolaty taste, this is a beer with a lot of good flavors.  However, the after taste was a bit dissapointing.  Im not a big fan of the metallic taste that stayed in my mouth after the beer went down my throat.
user_location: New York City, New York, USA

text: Nice beer.  Slight Soy sauce to the nose.  Coppery aftertaste.  Hearty flavor.  Roastiness is a good word here.  Robust and faint nut shell flavor.

Deep brown, but not as rich as I was expecting.  Light caramel hues shown through.  Toasty tan head evaporated quickly.  Semi-chocolate sweet on the palate with a smooth finish.  Good, but not as stout as I expected.

Served at (approx.) 10 degrees celsius.

Beautiful, with some coppery highlights peeking through the blackness.  Nice looking head as well.  

Aroma is too sweet, reminiscent of kosher wine.  And the taste is nice, but there is a sweetness that makes it a bit of an ordeal to finish.

A dissapointment - have realized that sweet stouts are just not my cup of beer.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2005 550mL bottle.  Deep dark nearly opaque brown, medium sized light tan head.  Sweet lactic aroma, some maltiness.  Deep earthen maltiness with a rising current of lactic sweetness.  Vestiges of a smooth roastiness in the finish.    Mouthfeel is medium, and smooth.

55 cl bottle. No yeast in bottom. Black colour with a great white head. Smooth roasted aroma. Wonderful roasted flavour with notes of oats, very light and smooth taste. Overall very nice and good oatmeal stout.

From bottle:

I didnt pour into a glass, but rather could see through the bottle a huge tan head. Aroma was light caramel scent. Taste was malty, and sweet. Nice velvety texture, smooth going down. I picked up hints of grapes, caramel, chocolate, and the oatmeal gave it a slightly bitter finish.
Smooth and rich at the same time. Dark and pleasing. Finishes well, with plenty of malt representation. A good beer to sip.

Some of the scents I get are: chocolate, caramel, raisin, maybe even a touch of grape, very sweet indeed.  As the label says, "The Celebrated" Oatmeal Stout.  Lets see if Id like to celebrate with this.  Pours dark, opaque, off white head.  Im waiting to let it warm, see if I can get the taste to improve.  Okay, here goes...first sip...didnt detect much of a flavor...oh, wait, there it is.  I can taste the oatmeal.  It is...not bad, but not great either.  A step up from Guiness, although there are many other better stouts out there.  Not sure where the high ratings come from.  I think my favorite stouts are the imperials, these oatmeal sweet stouts need a little more...just a little more punch.  The description states, silky texture, I can see that.  However, it also states complex, I wouldnt necessarily say that.  A little better than average is what it is.

Very smooth, like an oatmeal stout should be. Aroma was light, but sweet, like super light molasses. Color is wonderfully black, I thought at first that it was in a brown bottle. Small white head. Slightly thin feeling for a stout, but far from watery. Flavor is smooth, with lighter chocolate tones. Easy to find, so if the need for a good winter time beer hits ya, go grab one.

Unfortunately I didnt have a glass to drink this out of, so Im guessing on aroma.  Kind of like teriyaki in that it is sweet and syrupy with some strong smokey, malty flavors.  Id need to try it in a glass before I made a good assessment.

(BJCP Class)  Awesome smooth, creamy nice overall flavor.  Great color and a nice aroma.  Good fruity but was a slight Dyacetyl. Just need to know what in a clear bottle everything is almost perfect why would they still use a clear bottle when they know it hurts the beer?
I enjoyed this beer.  Reddish brown, opque body.  Has an excellent aroma but somewhat over-malty finish.  That said, decent mass-accessible beer.

You never know with beer packaged in clear bottles. I was unimpressed with this brew. I can taste the quality but it just really didnt do anything for me. Either the beer is old, skunked, overrated, or I just dont appreciate the oatmeal stouts. That being said, my rating is only slightly below the site average, primarily due to high marks in aroma, appearance and palate. I prefer beers that score well in Flavor. Molasses aroma with dark chocolate notes. Very nice aroma. Dark, reddish brown, almost opaque body. Large, tan, tight bubble head. Nice lace and lasting head. At 1st sip I thought it was much milder than I expected. Perhaps this is due to the Ratebeer big beer bias. I figured a brew rated over a 4 had to be big. In fact, without looking, I am guessing this is the highest rated 5% or less ABV beer on the site. This is a nice stout; creamy with some dry dark chocolate and some lactose. Has an English aftertaste. This just isnt my favorite beer at all and Im not overly impressed.
a nice stout.  well balanced with malty flavors.  a little thin.  some of the higher potency stouts out there put this one to shame in terms of complexity.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2010 My previous rating was when I just started drinking dark beers. Back in 2005, Id never even had a Guiness. Now I see how naive I was to rate this so high. I hadnt yet tried an Imperial Stout. Had to re-rate

wow. Very pleasant stout. Not too sweet, not too bitter. Not too strong, but of imposing character. Deep and rich warm caramel flavors with scents that envelop the senses and ring in the ears. Simply awesome.

550 ml bottle, Pours a very dark brown with a large, mostly diminishing, light brown, creamy head.  Aroma was somewhat malty reminesent of fresh dark bread with the slightest hit of molasses.  Flavor reminded me of a sweet dark roast coffee with a bit of grains (bread).  the finish was longer than average with a sweet creamy texture offset by a bittersweet hop.  Overall not a bad brew but I preferred the Imperial stout by the same brewer as it had more flavor and complexity.

Pours very dark brown with a long-lasting, creamy tan head. Very smooth, full flavor with plenty of sweet malts. Slightly bitter aftertaste with hints of chocolate. A great stout, I wish I could get this by the case!
Black with a thick, creamy head. Wonderful roasted malt aroma. Smooth, full mouthfeel. Sweet malt flavor with hints of chocolate. Finishes with a lingering sweetness. Simply a terrific sweet  stout.
good full bodied beer.  Pours dark brown with a light brown porous head.  stout nose with hints of roasted grains.  spicy and warm on the palate.  fillout in your throat and flows down smooth.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2006 Good, I would describe this as chewy, it has good thick body.  Nice depth, caramel, smoke, thick grain.  Im not sure if I would call it oatmeal, but it is nice.  Well balanced.  Not overwhelming, little hop presence, but its good stuff.

Black. Average size creamy off-white head with excellent lacing.  Aroma is lightly hoppy with roasted grains.   Initial flavour is lightly bitter with a sweet finish.  Although the flavour is sweet, it is balanced: tastes like lightly bitter chocolate.  Full bodied with a creamy texture. A very good stout.  Its too bad the LCBO doesnt stock this regularly.

this is my first "Oatmeal" stout. If this is the best, as far as the oatmeals go then I geuss its just not for me. Nice color and aroma. Roasty, oatmeal present in the aromas. Smells very nice. The taste just doesnt stand up to the task. It is complex though, coffee, oatmeal woody at first. nicely balanced palate, smooth and clean finish. I would like to see what smiths has to offer to make or break my opinion on this brewer.

Aroma is complex, sweet and woody at the same time, with chocolate clearly noticable ..... Appearance, nearly jet black with diminishing head, a beautiful beer to behold ... Flavor is bitter/sweet at the start, with a transition to fruit/coffee/chocolate and powerful malts.  Its mouthfeel is unique also.  Sort of creamy/soft. ... On the palate it is malty/chocolately.  Very smooth with almost no bite.

This is one of my favorite beers.  very complex flavor with an apparent roasty and oatmeal flavor at first and sweet after taste.  Definitely Sam Smiths best.  Im going to be drinking this one often.
Bottle-Like it, not my favorite stout though.  Looks absolutely wonderful, draws in the light like a black hole.  Tastes better as it warms up.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2005 This beer was excellent! Stout, but not too stout. The palate was pretty light, could maybe use a little more "girth" so to speak. Tastes like brown sugar a little bit, I didnt really taste the oatmeal for some reason. It has a sexy look when you pour it into a nice mug that was frosted over. I started off the night with this baby girl. Shes one of my favorites.
Pretty good for the price lll say. Not going to post the same description as everyone else since it seems spot on already. I like it. You will too.
Bottle: Huge head of chocolate/tan color, aroma is of chocolate and carmel. Decent body, nice mouthfeel. Flavor starts out sweet ends bitter, a very enjoyable brew!

This beer has a great color with a very nice tan head.  The body is more thin than other stouts.  The aroma is thick with chocolate, and caramel.  The beer feels good on the palate.  And the flavor is somewhat sweet, with roast, and a slightly bitter finish.

Wow. First, this beer looks gorgeous: dark, dark body and a full tan head. Second, it is  bitter at the end and slightly malty as every good beer should be. It is also a little sweet, which I really like. This is all wrapped up, however, by the smoothness of it. It just rolls down your throat. Definitely recommended for anyone who loves stouts.
Sammy Smith does it again. A great oaty-richness pervades this one. Cant handle more than one, but who needs to when its so delightfully rich.
This is a very good Oatmeal Stout...It is a very very smooth and very very refreshing stout, but its also not to sweet like most. one of the better oatmeals ive had!

Beautiful nice, roasty stout, begins slightly sour with aromas and flavors of French coffee and dry cocoa, lightf acrid burntness, sourness soon transforms into a light integrating bitterness that mingles in the caramelly soul of this generous-bodied lightly sweet stout. Masterful.

Wonderful malty caramel aroma. Dark brown colour with reasonable head. Yummy flavour of malt hop and the right amount of bitterness. Smooth palate. This is a great stout. Just what you need on a cold winters night.
Black colour with a nice lacing and medium lasting head. Fruity aroma with hints of roasted coffee and caramel. Nice full body.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a very thin head and nice lacing around the glass. Smells of chocolate, coffee and fruit. Beer is creamy, sweet and smooth, and tastes of oatmeal (of course), chocolate and cherry (I swear it tastes nutritious). Moderate carbonation. Midway it becomes slightly bitter, and finishes with chocolate and coffee. Leaves a wonderful lingering cherry taste. An excellent beer.

The color of this beer is interesting in itself. It appears to be a mixture of very dark, almost burnt amber & dark brown. The head is a bit disppointing as it disapates very quickly. The mouth feel is lusious, creamy, rich and full. The flavor profile is very complex. Every taste seemed to offer a different flavor, with nuances of chocolate, molases, coffee and nuts! This a truly an enjoyable beer!

Black. Small light brown head that quickly diminishes. moderate carbonation. head retention not as good as it should be. pronounced sweet vinous smell with some alcoholic whiffs. Has some subtle fruity smells in the background as well. Nowhere near as bitter as a regular stout. A sweet fruity vinous flavor with some oats in the background. Somewhat like coffee and cream with alcohol. A very dry aftertaste finishes this fairly sweet beer. Nice moderate body with moderate-high carbonation. A bit too much in my opinion. Dry aftertaste, low alcohol. Easy as pie.  This was a fairly solid beer that was a nice sweet alternative to the Sinebrychoff Porter, which I also enjoyed.
UPDATED: NOV 25, 2005 Great beer. One of the best that can be easily found. Rich. Smooth. Complex.
I said "damn" when drank this beer.  ohh the flavor makes me fell great!  I love beer

My 1st rating, so take with a grain.  Very dark, nearly black color.  Very small tan head.  Wonderfult coffee and chocolate aromas.  A meal of a beer that is heavy on the palate with a fairly clean finish and little aftertaste.  Coffee and chocolate flavor.
Hmm...delicious. Roasted malt and mocha aroma. Sweet tasting dark malts give a huge mouthfeel with a chewy grain and coffee finish. A beer truly worthy of all its praise.

(550 ml bottle) Frothy tan head, dark mahogany body. Good lacing.  Aroma of molasses, roasted grain. Taste is sweet, molasses-like, also toasted cereal. Rich, smooth mouthfeel. Im not a big fan of sweetness in beer, but wow this is just so good anyway.

This in my opinion is a perfect beer. Roasted flavors dominate the pallete with definate coffee and chocolate undertones.  The color ais a dark brown, nearly black.  The aroma is strictly malt, with no hop presence.  Finish is nice and dry.

550 ml bottle, bought in Denmark. Nearly black (= very dark brown with a reddish hue) colour, thick tan head. Moderate roasty aroma, notes of coffee and chocolate. Strong roasty flavour with coffee and bitter chocolate elements, dry roasty finish. Clearly a good beer.

[bottle from brewery] Pours pitch black with a moderate tan head. Nose is roasted coffee, dark chocolate, with some nutty notes against a backdrop of sweet fruits, orange, plum with a faint vinous note floating around somewhere.
body is silky and excellent, espescially for the abv. finish is sweet. The only bad thing about this beer is that my glass is almost empty.

Sampled from the Bottle. My reactions to the Oatmeal Stout are similar to their Imperial Stout, namely that this is above average beer not worthy of its 4.02 average. Theres some decent oatmeal and roasted coffee notes here, but a thin palate and a poor finish lacking any alcohol backbone are this beers demise. Sorry Sammy, but there are quite a few better Oatmeal Stouts out there. (May I suggest Founders Breakfast Stout?)
Pours black with a tan head.  Smells of nuts and coffee.  Taste is watery and boring.  Not one Id seek out again.
A really heavy beer. Does have a coffee flavor to it but still has a nice taste.

Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is a luscious and complex beer.  Its almost black and with a tan, dense creamy head.  After the initial bitter flavor, the complex flavors sweep over the tongue, slightly sweet, chocolatey, oaty and more.   I agree that this stout should not be drunk cold, nor room temperature, but somewhere in between.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 bottle.  Pours black, to the point where its a little surprising to see that the bottle is clear. It leaves a huge tan head on top in the glass. The aroma is sweet and malty with chocolate, coffee, and oats. Very palatable level of oats, some tame soy sauce, chocolate, raisins, semi-nutty flavor, all are in the mouth. This is quite smooth and exceptionally balanced.
------ 27, 2007]------- Bottle. This is one of the best done English stouts. It is mild and easily sessionable, but it has a wonderful balance of sturdy  flavors akin to chocolate and mild coffee with suggestions of apples and a faint tart note present. If ever there was a tasteful oatmeal stout, this is it.

WOW!!! my first introduction into the oatmeal stouts, and the finest ive ever had. i love the aroma which is very rich with hints of coffee and chocolate. goes down very smooth and creamy and not as heavy as one might think. drink it slightly cooler than room temperature and its flavors explode on the palate

Light aroma of raisins and coffee. Pitch black pour, with a delicious looking tan head. Very creamy. Watery is my first impression, but as the beer this moves into an intricate silky seductor. Notes of oats, grass and light earth, over a rich chocolate and cream background. A little fruit, with a finish of cognac. Palate is somewhat watery, but slick and smooth.

Pours black with a very off white head. The aroma is chocolate and some licorice. It tastes VERY sweet and has a nice warming effect. Its not to overpowering and the texture and taste is mellow. As it warmed up it got better and better.

Pours very black with nice tan head. Aroma has hints of coffe, chocolate and dried fruit. Flavor is sweet with a nice bitterness. Aftertatste is like eating bitterchocolate covered dried figs. nice mouthfeel, you can feel it as well as taste it. Very nice stout. Always a favorite.
Bottle. Nice dark color with a creamy colored head. Sweet malt goes with the dark roasted flavors.

Maybe I just dont like sweet stouts.  If I want Pepsi Ill drink Pepsi.  Incidentally, I dont want Pepsi.  I had to try this because it is so high rated, but I was pretty disappointed.  I really dont know what it is people get out of a beer like this.
very smooth.  I  have had better oatmeal stouts but this one is up there with them.  Nice roaste overtone that blends in well.  I could drink this all night.

From the intial tasting to the final drop, this beer proves itself to be a contender in the stout realm. Dark, almost ebony in color with nominal head but peaks out to provide an edgy taste that flows down surprisingly smooth for such a dark beer. Excellent choice for any dark beer lover...

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2006 Bottle. Pours opaque black with a hint of ruby on the edges and a creamy tan head. Aromas and flavors include burnt oats and sugar, black licorice, and roast flavors that could be red peanut skins or a hint of blood sausage. Hints of muddy black chocolate. Still, that red metallic taste is distracting - and annoyingly dry at the finish. Tasty, but theres a lot of hype around Sam Smith beers.

Bottle. Ive always thought of Sam Smiths as quite a small brewery so I cant believe the number of ratings this beer has.  Not that it is a bad beer, quite the opposite.  Pours black with a cream colour head. Lots of roasted malt aromas including coffee, chocolate, cereals and liquorice. Good im mouth with a good dryness to balance the slight sweetness of the malts with a good finish. Excellent stout.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2007 550 ml bottle.  Poured very dark with a decent head.  Actually pretty nice head and lots of lacing.  Ok, lets up that appearance one point...  Ok, good.  Aromas were nice with some serious roasted coffee and sweetness.  Flavors were a little metallic, but the bittersweet definitely came through and some chocolate as well.  Why do they insist on sticking with this clear bottle?
bottle, tastes of dark roasted coffee and chocolate.  body is medium to full.  this is a very nice readily available beer, but probably not deserving of the 99 overall score.

Bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours ruby-black with a large rocky light-brown head. Looks perfect. The aroma is a wonderful complex mix of caramel, oatmeal, chocolate, fruit, roasted malt, spices, spruce, toffee and much more. The flavour contains the ingredients of the aroma and is sweet with a balanced bitterness in the finish. A delicious, creamy, sweet stout and one of my favourite beers.

Bottle; Black in the glass with a large, creamy light brown head that lasted. The aroma started out with strong chocolate and coffee smells but some light hops were detected. The flavor mimicked the smell with nice hits of caramel, chocolate, and coffee. Medium body with a creamy texture. Very nice!!
rhis beer was pretty good, but I was expecting awesome.  very mild flavor, very smooth but jusr not great.  Blue points oatmeal stout is MUCH better

This is one of my favorite beers of all-time.  I often joke that its kind of a cross between a beer and a milkshake.  It is very creamy and even a little sweet -- like an oatmeal chocolate cookie.  It has a beatiful velvety tan head and is the perfect consistency, not too thick, not too thin.

Pours a dark brown color, with tan head.  I would imagine this being better on tap.  However, this is the first Sam Smiths I have had in GA that hasn;t been skunked all to hell.  Got it at Bankhead Beverage on the way back from Carrollton this weekend, with a mismarked pricetag.  But onto the beer.  Deep chocolate and oatmeal, grainy aroma.  Lots of malt and hops mixed with a very sweet buttercream and oatmeal flavor.  Yumm.  Dry on the finish.  But all in all definitely a fine oatmeal stout.

Great! flavor, sweet aftertaste. Nice head-n-body. I was very pleased be able to drink this beer.  It was very smooth and creamy and had a molassas flavor in the end... the oats were evident on the back of the palatte but nor overwhelming...  A very drinkable beer and still maintained its robust chocolate flavor in the last gulp.  Found myself wanting more... The initial taste was odd as the narrow neck prevented me from getting a good portion into my mouth.  Great taste.

Pours a darker black with a good layer of tan head. Nose is lots of chocolate and some coffee roastiness notes. Taste is lots of chocolate with some molasses sweetness as well. People complain that it is not thick enough, but most stouts arent much thicker. I think lots of people get too used to drinking imperials, that they forget how simple and flavorful a simple stout can and should be. Good silky mouthfeel. Yum yum.

Bottle.  Big oat malt and hops aroma.  Dark brown/black color - cant tell the bottle is clear and not brown until you pour - moderate tan head.  Sweet oat malt flavor up front with notes of walnuts and molasses.  A nice bitter hops finish.  Smooth and drinkable however a bit light body - I personally would like it to be thicker.

Bottled.
Brown coloured with a solid beige head.
Fruity aroma with roated notes and notes of nuts.
Flavour of nuts and fruits with roasted notes.
Big disappointment, tastes like a bad home brew !
My brother gave me 1 of these beers. And  I all I can say is I absolutely loved this one and am looking forward to my next Sam Smith Oatmeal Stout. A must Try!

Coffe aroma with hints of hops.  Chocolate color and nice brown head.  Initial coffee taste with chocolate undertones and hop bitterness, well balanced.  Finishes with a malty oatmeel  like sweetness and pleasent aftertase on the palate.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2005 Bottle.  Very dark brown appearance, almost black.  Beautiful tan head.  Enjoyed this one from first drink to the last.  Fine aroma and the flavor sweet and chocolatey.  Again, I must try more stouts to truly see where this stacks up, but I definitely enjoyed this one.

A Mes rate:
Typical english drink but oh its a good one. Usual stout flavour and aroma, the oats are clearly there and are joined by coffee beans and toffee. It has a hard liquor hint in the nose almost like whiskey. Finish is British bitter but lovely. Very nice stuff. Cheap too. Bring it on!

Dark Brown Ale very smooth.  One of my favorites!

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2007 Dark-looking but has a watery feel.  Cocoa, cream, and oats in the taste.  Middle is kind of like a "Whopper" chocolate candy.  Oaty finish.
Black with tan head which lingers throughout drink. Taste is bitter upfront with a sweet finish which lingers on the tongue. Was the first sweet stout I ever had and it still holds up pretty well.

Out of a bottle, a nice roast aroma combined with a subtle oatmeal. Poured a dark black and settle with a tan head that thinned but never left.  Flavor was good brown sugar oatmeal,coffee.  Palate was okay a little watery.  Overall a good sweet stout I enjoyed totally.
Black with medium sized tan head. Maple and apple are prominent, as is cherry.  Well balanced, somewhat malty.    Very good but a tad  overrated.
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007  pours dark, tan head a little small, decent coffee like smell, sweeter than usual taste, bitter hoppiness, the body was a little thin for and oatmeal stout.

Tasted this gem after downing a Samuel Smiths Taddy Porter. Aroma was fine but my palate could have done with a break in between tastings. By the end of the pint though this showed to be another winner for Mr. Smith. 
The first Oatmeal Stout I have tasted so I can only go off of some of the insipid Oatmeal stouts I have attempted to brew myself. Poured from the 55cL bottle into a tall stem glass, a dense tan head formed, a good half inch, atop a ruby-red, almost black body. Head remained in its place for the length and laced rings down the glass. Quite a dry gritty and grainy aroma, lightly spicy with a lot of roasted malt and molasses coming through. Rich and complex malt in the mouth, chocolate, molasses, yeast, burnt grain and a noticeable breakfast-style hit of oatmeal crossed the tongue and became quite bitter in the back, before finishing with a smooth, roasted malt swallow.Similar to the Porter, it was unbelievably smooth and well rounded in the mouth, dry and malty, and very well balanced. Flavours levelled out well around room temperature and remained silky smooth and well blended until the end. Another absolute gem from this brewery. Lovely!!!
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2006 Near black with ruby hues.  Aroma of molasses, brown sugar and oatmeal.  Notes of toffee and brown sugar. Long bittersweet finish.  Excellent stout.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 This is quite a beer indeed. Pours whiite thick and nice brown head, excellent appearance. Aroma is sweet and full, not sure what of though. Taste is soo soo smooth, sweet and chocolaty, coffee and a little very little mollasses, but very very smooth. Overall a great great and unexpected winner. RERATE: Down from 4.6- 3.3. Sweet roasty, chocolate. Soft hyowever nothing like as good as i had it before.
Classic balance between sweet and coffee flavors.  This has been a favorite for 20 years.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2005 A deep deep brown color with a deep tan head. Sweet roasted aromal with a nice oatmeal cookie lace in it. Tastes extremely smooth and creamy with a nice refreshing bittersweet finish. Reminiscent of the Taddy Porter in ways, just a great beer.
Talk about taste.  Cant miss the oatmeal in this stout.  And not too tough to find, in my experience.
UPDATED: NOV 6, 2005 This is good stuff, love the flavor and and great strong aroma. Youll be hard pressed to find a better smelling beer. Wish it had more alcohol though.
Pours black with a tan head.  Smells of coffee and chocolate.  Has a strong sweet chocolate coffee taste to it that coats the mouth and lasts for a long time.  A fine stout but not fantastic.

Black with a light brown creamy foam. Quite dry aroma of black coffee, dark chocolate, nuts and oats. Cocoa and coffee in flavour with nutty and roasty undertones. Thick mouthfeel. Black chocolate and almonds in the long aftertaste.

Pours a dark black with thick tannish head that fades.  Smells is caramel malt and alcohol.  Tastes of chocolate, caramel, and something semi-sweet I cant put my finger on.   Seems creamy and slight dry.  Finishes a bit weak and limp.

Deep dark black color with a dark tan and thick head that hangs well and laces nicely. Fruity aroma with some chocolate scents. Flavor is berries, chocolate covered raisons with smooth somewhat overly sweet finish. This beer tasted somewhat like a port and will compliment a good cigar. Recommended if you like sweet stouts.

Bottle.  Nice brown pour. Good sweet  malty nose with some coffee and some chocolate notes.  Flavor is nicely malty sweet and smooth and molassy, with a very good balance of hops (not much) for the style.  Some nice fruity tones too.  Good oatmeal stout.

How can I describe this?  I can identify this beer from smell alone, tasty stuff.  This is one of the beers that originally got me into craft beers and import beers in general.  A great aroma of roasted malt and hoppyness.  The mouthfeel is slightly oily, due to the oats but definately on-style.  An absolute favorite.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Bottle (550ml).  A perennial favorite - I buy a dozen of the gift boxes (Oatmeal, Old Brewery Pale, Nutbrown, a pin glass) every winter, mostly for this one.  Its all been said before - nice friendly stout with fruit overtones, some chocolate.  Colour somewhere between an impenetrable stout and a deep nutbrown.  Starts drinkable, finished drinkable, I never tire of it.  Can drink - and have drunk - three at a sitting without getting restless for something different.

Poured a deep brown with a healthy tan head.  Beer definitely needed to warm up for its true aroma to shine through..  dark chocolate, roasted malts, a little caramel.  Taste followed the aroma, and was quite sweet.  Balance was solid, and carbonation was just right for a smooth coating mouthfeel.  There was a medium-dry hoppy finish with some toffee.  Id bet that they could greatly increase the character and complexity of this stuff if they were to whip up a batch that was unpasteurized and unfiltered...

Dark brown with ruby highlites under a rocky dark khaki head with good retention and lots of lacing.  Nutty aroma with caramel, bittersweet chocolate, roasted malt and a hint of pepper.  Well balanced sweet chocolate, toffee, roasted malt and vanilla flavors with a tight hoppy backstop.  Creamy mouthfeel and sweet but dry finish with lasting coffee, toffee notes.  A really nice Oatmeal Stout.

pours a dark clack color w/ a big tan head that laces well  Smells a tad skunky and yeasty at first but that goes away as it warms then the carmel malts come out a long w/ a light wheaty/oaty aroma.  Palate is rich lightly creamy and nicely carbonated.  flavor is pretty palin a light carmel malt a touch acidic and a little hop in the finish w/ a touch of grain.  Overall pretty solid but lacking in my mind for an oatmeal.

While it was too cold it smelled skunky but when it warmed up to a non-Miller temperature it smelled much better.  Dark brown-black color.  Medium tan head.  Malty molassas smell.  Very sweet taste malt, espresso, caramel, molassas all show up in the taste.  Very light-bodied palate (I was hoping for more here).  A very nice sweet finish with little aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2005 dark dark brown to black.  pretty fancy bottle.  creamy light brown head.  not particularly strong in the aroma department.  but theres some complexity to what I CAN smell.  starts out mildly bitter (chocolate/coffee) and moves to a sweet finish (caramel and some other stuff which I couldnt quite identify).  Some mild bubbles and dryness on the palate.  Kind of an expensive 12oz. bottle ($4.50)

Bottle.  Slightly rubbery aroma.  Mildly sweet caramel malts in the nose.  Cant detect chocolate or coffee.  Mostly opaque dark brown with a frothy tan head.  Cardboardy start with a small astrigency with chocolate, rpasted notes in the middle.  Finishes mildly sweet.  Very smooth and silky.  A nice beer, but not a 4.03...

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2005 A very drinkable oatmeal stout.  The flavor is excellent - roasted coffee, nut, a chocolaty & licorice sweetness and just the right mix of oatmeal/malt & bitter.  However, this great flavor was not strong enough for my taste.  I found it a little too thin.  Maybe its just a matter of taste, but I like stouts a little creamier and robust than this was. ($2.69/550ml)

From a 550ml bottle.

Appears black in the glass save light brown around the edges. Not much head, brown and it does leave lace as the beer recedes.

Smell is hard to place bitter and acidic. Could this be the oatmeal? Light sweet nutty smell as well.

Taste is creamy and smooth juxtaposed bitter flavors. Brew is malty with a burnt-nut taste. Doesnt bite like alot of stouts. This brew is smooth but still complex. I would call it medium bodied despite the bold appearance. Very drinkable.

One of the better stouts I have tasted. Wish there was more than one other oatmeal stout in Maine to compare it with.

This wonderful beer is as black in the glass as it is on the shelf in its clear bottle. Well sustained tan head. Perfect Sam Smith house aroma with the added joy of roastiness. Full in body as it washes over the tongue. Sweetness tempered perfectly by the bitter coffee aspect in the flavor. Long finish....I love it.
Dark nearly opaque with a tan head.  Tastes of roasted coffee.  Not too sweet with a nice bitter finish.  A bit thin and watery mouthfeel.  Not as chewy or heavy feeling as other stouts.

You can quote the description for this and add that the aroma and flavor. Aroma is sweet cocoa, with some roasted grains. Flavor has lots of oatmeal with some coffee and a strange sweetness maybe the butterscotch a few have mentioned. Slight hops detectable in finish.

Abyssal dark color, pours with a dark tan head, sweet cacao, vanilla, mocha and fruity aromas follow through a smooth medium-bodied palate, with roasted coffee, vanilla, hint of dark fruits in a mild bitter roasted chocolate dry finish.

Pours real dark with tan creamy head. Could smell this beer as soon as the top came off the bottle. This is a well balanced stout between the sweet oatmeal and the malt, chocolate, roasted nut and barley flavors.

Very dark brownish red color, nearly opaque...large thick and creamy brown head.  Sweet chocolate, butter scotch, and malt in the aroma...very smooth body with a wonderful mix of sweet oatmeal and a hint of smokiness.   Very delicious and very drinkable.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2005 Nice dark light brown head.  Smells malty, of butterscotch, and coffee.  Has a beautiful mouthfeel.  Has a nice sweetness without being cloying, with some roasty and winey flavors.  This is delicious, and a stout that never fails to please.

500ml clear bottle. Very dark brown pour, not opaque, hints of ruby-brown come through. Nice sized dark tan head, composed of somewhat soapy bubbles.
Leaves sticky lacing. Brown sugar, mild coffee, some dark chocolate. Rich sweet malts first reach the tounge, then some bitter choclate notes, then roasted barley. Slight hops and roasted aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2005 Great Sweet Stout. Oatmeal and roasted malt give this stout a great sweet and velvety taste. Lightly carbonated with decent size tan head. Color is dark black with a slight hint of blood red. While medium minus on the chewy factor, found it very enjoyably to slurp. Man is it smooth. 

rerate: Im hoping this 6 I bought was old becuase this batch was way to sticky and had a somewhat putrid sweetness to it. Will lower a tad but probalby think its just old. Will try again.
Poured dark black with a tall light brown head.  Toasty, vineous oat aroma.  Flavor of chocolate and roasty oats.  Creamy-thin feel with a chalky finish.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2005 Bottle. Pours a dark brownish black with a light brown head. Nice lacin on the glass. First taste - chocolate, coffee, matliness, with a sweet taste. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Not nearly as "chewy" as other stouts - thin mouth feel.

Black as night on the pour and a nice beautiful tan head.  The nose is malt and a little sweetness.. Oatmeal...  Sweet, creamy and smooth. some chocolate.  a great stout and fantastic on the palate not too thick but just right.  Bitter at the end as Ive come to expect from England.  Coffee flavor throughout.. Yummy!!
black, has a nice one finger tan head. taste is coffee, malt, oatmeal. sweet and creamy, has an almost bitter dryness at the end.

Well, Im humming the Jeopardy theme, waiting for the head to come down.  A very pleasant nose, with a nice mix of flavors.  Exceptionally smooth, sweet, with a hint of alcohol, finishing off a beer that has chocolate, lots of malt, and coffee.  Fabulous.

Pours very dark brown. Looks like Coca Cola. Aroma is sweet with hints of something I couldnt recognize. Reading other reviews it hit me as cherry and toffee. Not as bitter as I would like, but not as overly malty and chocolaty as some stouts I have tried either. Nice palate with a bit of a pleasant gritty feel

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2013 This is an old favorite of mine. This used to be a mainstay of my beer fridge. As time has  moved on I find myself drinking it far less but I still find it a most respectable brew. Sampled from a 12 oz clear bottle this beer pours dark black with a large creamy brown head that lingers and leaves good lacing. The aroma is sweetish toasty malts with hints of vanilla and cocoa.  The mouthfeel is thick, creamy and smooth. The flavor is dryish with a strong malted milk presence, some cocoa and a mildly bitter toasted malt base and a hint of wood. Long toasty malted milk finish. Very good but no longer a favorite.
Mostly dark brown pour, creamy tan head. Nice bourbon cask-like sweet chocolate cherry aroma. Yummy nose. Slightly stale sweet chocolate malt with some coffee. Balanced, full and rewarding.

(bottle)  Poured a deep caramel color and resided with a dark violety-russet hue in the glass.  Head was beige and creamy, and persisted as a thin layer throughout joyous consumption.  Smells deliciously of coffee, nuts, and chocolate, none more overpowering than the next.  Round, full, and suave on the palate, with tastes of ever so slightly bitter coffee and oats.  Finishes dry with a subtle sweetness in the aftertaste  that gains strength as the beer warms.  Simply brilliant.

Black, light tan creamy head.  Rich nose of roasted chocolate, light coffee, oatmeal, toffee, with slight undertones of whiskey.  Near perfect balance with dark sweet oatmealish malt blending perfectly with the English hop bitterness (seemed to go well with my mint milano cookie)  Anyway, full bodied, pillow soft carbonation, velvety, bittersweet roasted finish.  Its like a meal in bottle.  Certainly one of the best oatmeal stouts ever made...

Bottled. The nose is chocolatey, caramelly with notes of toffee and licorice and hints of dark fruits. Taste is initially chocolatey, roastmalty and mildly sweet.  There is nothing but bitterness in the finish. Not that it is too bitter; there just aren´t any other flavours in the aftertaste. As it warmed up I could taste some licorice and the finish gained some coffeish notes. A truly nice stout, which impressed me mostly through its aroma. Thanks pivo and yogi_beera for searching this one out for me.
A really good stout, but a little over hyped and would gladly choose some of the American microbrews of this style over this one.  Still its one of the top stouts available in Alabama.
Candy sweet roasty beans in the aroma.  Prickly mouthfeel, something Ive noticed with many Sammys.  Roastiness throughout.  Solid stout.
Wow, man. This is sold at my local grocery store! Pretty sweet, with great malt flavor and a quality oatmeal taste. Dude, this beer is sold at my local grocery store!

This is a dark, dark beer.  I thought the bottle was dark... then I saw that it was the beer that was nearly pitch black.  Wasnt as sweet as I had hoped.  The coffee-ish taste wasnt as pronounced as I thought it would be, so that was a positive.  Very good, but didnt live up to the billing it received.  Attractive packaging, though.
sweet chocolate malt aroma . jet black color . sweet , very smooth and tasty . nice brew liked it alot

Bottle:  Excellent aroma.  Very sweet and malty.  Lots of chocolate, fruit, and coffee.  Pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a tan head that dies fairly quickly.  Rather sweet.   Fruity chocolate is the dominant flavor.  Light oatmeal in the background.   Coffee comes in the finish but for the most part is drowned out by the fruits and chocolate.  A little thin for a stout.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2005 bottle - 3/20/05 - The pour is black.  I smell chocolate.   Nice malty flavor...chocolate, coffee, pretty sweet... very tasty.  I agree with how pailhead described it...fruity chocolate.  A little bitterness in the finish, but its not a long lasting or very complex finish.  This is very good.
a nice oatmeal stout, very simple and tasty.  not much head or aroma, and the flavor is wonderful.
The aroma isnt that full, but, flavor...Sweet, sweet goodness, nice beer to end on, over and over again.

bottle 3/17/05. Pours a dark coke black with a thin off white head.  Very plain and bland from start to finish but the oatmeal aroma and slight touch at the end make this beer incredible. Once again Samuel Smith shows its strength in the world of beer. Very solid brew.

Bottle. After trying a number of stouts and porters recently I found this to be the least interesting. Nicely drinakble. Soft. Sort of like a Big Mac. Easy drinking and comforting. A deceptive beer. But even with the lack of character, and some plastic flavour, it is a beer that I wouldnt say no to. I understand this was the first of the modern Oatmeal Stouts.

2004 bottle at the Downtown Liquors stouts tasting.  Tasting this alongside some rather unspectacular, but good stouts (Grittys black fly, Guinness Extra, Avery Out of Bounds, Dorothy Goodbodys, NC Old No. 38) and two very good stouts (Shakespeare and Freeminer Deepshaft), it is pretty recognizable, to me, anyways, how simple and boring this beer is.  To its credit, it does taste flavorful, with a bit of molasses mixed in with light chocolate and sweet residual sugar.  But there is no yeast presence, no thick, chewy, interesting body.  Fizzy head and a clear body due to huge filtration and forced carbonation.  Why did I love this stuff for so long???

Dark brown body with reddish glints and a thick brown frothy head. Complex malty aroma with hints of brown sugar, roasted barley, coffee and dark berries. Taste is simply amazing. Starts with somewhat of a bitter/hoppy attack. Following, we detect various flavors of fruits, brown sugar, barley and molasses. Hoppiness comes back again for a lovely lasting aftertaste that also leaves a kind of warming effect despite the small percentage of alcohol. The whole thing has a mild oily/silky texture. A real treat!!!
An OK Oatmeal stout. Head did not last long. Not as flavorful as could be. Color was good  and dark. Not the best for the price. Try Youngs for a better stout.

Body is black with a small off-white head that left tight bubbles clinging to the sides of the glass. Aroma of dark fruits and chocolate. Flavors are a nutty, roasty malt, some chocolate, coffee, and cherries with a dryish finish.
Typical stout, dark almost black in colour with a roast malt aroma. Tasting of chocolate and biscuit with a dry  bitterness and a rather extreme finish. not quite my taste.

Very good, but not knock-out. Poured a nice fine tan head with abundant lace. Opaque black, but could pick up no black malt in the nose. I did get some rich fermented red fruit aromas and some roasty malty notes. Theres a sharpness in the mouth with a silkiness and some prune flavors with nice finish. Got this at Bodega last night.

Dark brown almost black in color, malty sort of sour aroma.  Taste was suprisingly smoky, slight chocolate roast flavors.there was a slight metallic taste which dissappeared as the beer warmed.  Kind of failed to live up to its rep for me.

Pours a dark brown, deep red edges, with a tan foamy head lasting a few minutes; little lacing to space of.  Delicious smells of milk chocolate and walnuts, cookies, cereal, interlaced with traces of vanilla.  Taste of nutty molasses, toastiness, butterscotch and grassy hops, overall lightly sweet.  Ends with bitter roasted coffee and a long dry finish.  Softly carbonated and full bodied but wonderfully drinkable.  I will definitely buy this again and would love to actually try it with ham and eggs.

Fruitier aroma than I expected. Also less head than I expected. Fruity flavors upfront then finishes with some smokey flavors followed by bitterness. More body would be nice. Smooth and quite drinkable yet lacking a lot of flavor. Im really surprised at the 99 rating. I think there are far better stouts out there.

Impresset I vas mit ze gut body unt gut headt on zis vun. Dark roastet maltzen  vas in zhere too. Eben Max Jr likes zis bier unt zat be talkink a lot cause he ist Helgas zon too.Earlier Rating: 2/25/2005 Total Score: 3.9beautiful head that lasts the whole beer, roasty malt flavor, This bottle was almost flat which wasnt bad at all but I suspect it should have had a touch more carbonation. Not a complex flavor but not a bad one either. Lingering hop bitterness at the end.

Nearly black, clear, very little aroma for the size of the beer, what there is is chockolate/coffee .  Thin brown head.  Dry, a little sour fairly bitter.  VERY roasted malt flavor with a bit of bitter chocolate.  The mouthfeel makes it.  Like drinking liquid silk. My favorite of the brewery.
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 Bottle. Pours a rich black color with a creamy tan head. Nose is malty and chocolate. Flavor is chocolate, malts and some sweetness.
Very dark,  almost a smoky flavor.  Nice laceing, pours with a thick head.  This is an interesting beer.

Bottle. Pours almost black into the glasswith a brown tan head with good retention. Aroma is roasted and a bit acidic. The flavor has a sharp roastiness. It ends with a long bitter aftertaste. Good mouthfeel, but not as viscous, as I would expect from an oatmeal stout.

Dark with a tan head; great looking beer. Flavor is rich, nutty, and chocolaty with a wonderful sort of milkshake-like  mouthfeel. This beer is tremendously satisfying and could easily substitute for solid food in a diet consisting only of beer.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2005 smells of roasted barley and hops.  almost opaque in color.  brown head.  tastes almost like wine at first, then a great oatmeal with brown sugar aftertaste.  sugary and dark with a medium body.
The initial flavor was of roasted coffee and the finished flavor was slightly bitter. The texture was lightly creamy. Its a good beer, but I prefer stouts with a thicker texture.
At one time my favorite stout, but have since discovered far better ones.  Still, its a dark and tasty beer, just not as thick as I like my stouts to be.

Not a big fan of stouts but I remember TheRimmer telling me about this a couple years ago so I picked one up. Best stout Ive had so far. Thick, black, and didnt feel like I was swallowing a mouthful of maple syrup. Chocolate and coffee are very nice, not overpowering like some other stouts Ive had. If youre looking to try your first stout, this is it.

My favorite stout but Ive had it out of a bottle at the local bar&grille where it seemed to have sat to long and lacked the carbonation of a fresh bottle.  Always drink in a glass.  Coffee and chocolate with very little of the prune aroma and taste of the Imperial Stout.  Wish the abv were higher.
Tap. Dark brown color with medium tan head. Complex aroma of sweet grain and hops with the same flavor with sweet finish. Good combo with strong cigar.
Hit or miss beer.  Being an import and having a clear bottle doesnt help it.  When its good its good, but I still think its overrated.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2007 Wonderful black body with a large tan head. Aroma is sugar, oats, caramel, chocolate, light coffee and roast. Flavor is the same, extremely smooth due to the oats and the sugar. Wonderful texture, but the body and flavors are thin. In 2004 this was my favorite beer, hands down.

The 0.55l bottle pours an enormous long-lasting tan head with great lacing.  There is an excellent roasted grain and molasses aroma; also a hint of coffee.  The palate entry features bold, sugary sweet caramel and sherry gradually giving way to chocolate, coffee, licorice and smoke flavors.  This is a super smooth and silky, full-bodied sweet stout with lively carbonation.  There is a first-rate bitter hop balance to the initial sweetness in the long-lasting finish.

Surprisingly, the clear bottle has no negative effect on the flavor. If it does, Im amazed, as it seems impossible a beer could be better.  Tastes a lot like Youngs chocolate stout when gulped, but even better when drank slowly.  The  beautiful thing about this is I can drink it as slowly as a higher alcohol beer, due to the immense flavor, and drink more because the alcohol level is so low. Guinness tastes like heinie by comparison.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2008 This is by far my favorite stout.  The complexities of the flavor, aroma, and that dark appearance remind me of a fine cigar, which is most enjoyable while partaking of this delicious creation.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: This was a great beer.  I was a little worried about trying it because I had only had one Oatmeal Stout previously and I didnt like it much.  This stuff poured dark, nearly black.  Creamy tan head.  The flavor was unparalleled.  I wish I could find this stuff in South Dakota but we dont have any good beers here.  It had an almost bitter chocolatey taste.  To put it in perspective this beer kicks ass.

Smell is of sweet chocolate and grapes.  Body is an opaque black-brown, but doesnt appear to be too thick.  Head is cardboard brown bubbles with a gray tint, doesnt last too long. Taste is a unique blast of flavor.  Sweet and sour concord grapes, chocolate, toffee, caramel, licorice and oatmeal. This beer is so original, a delicious treat. Only gripe is that some might consider it too sweet of a palate. Damn drinkable and from a damn fine brewery.
The measuring stick for Oatmeal stouts.  A very drinkable and sweet beer.  Perfect finish that leaves you craving another.

One bottle from Beers of the world.  Poured dark with a nice tan head that very slowly melted away.  Sweet malty aroma.  Great mouthfeel, a smooth and flavorful enjoyable drink with a very slight hops finish.
I have been enjoying Sams for quite awhile now- not the worlds greatest stout but its always solid, a full stout with a solid oatmeal flavor and pleasing after taste.  No complaints.
Pours very dark with a small tan head.  Aromas of roasted malt and a bit of chocolate.  Flavors of cocoa and coffee.  The oatmeal gives a smooth-slick texture.  Good balance and quite drinkable.
good sized head dark-very dark red smells smokey w/ chocolate tastes of caramel (?) and chocolate.. a bit on the thin side i thought...i was kind of disappointed..but glad i can get this any time

Definately not worth the hype.  Ive had this stout many times hoping to enjoy the taste that others write about.  In all cases I was disappointed.  It has a somewhat musty odor and a thin tan head.  The thin,chalky taste just gets worse towards the end of the glass. It lacked they common stout characteristics that Im used to.  Theres no rich and creamy undertones, just a somewhat sweet, bitter, musty taste.  There are MANY better examples of oatmeal stouts out there.

bottle. a very nice pour.  chocolate brown with a medium sized head and a bit of lace as I worked my way down the glass.  a very nice semi-sweet flavor with a bit of a dry finish.  I will definitely try this one again.

Toffee, chocolate, sweet and roasty malts and also a hint of smoke in the pleasant and enticing aroma.  Opaque darkest brown with tan/brwon head that recedes slowly to generous and lasting cover.with some sudsy lacing.  Burnt raisins and chocolate in the flavour with some more salty/smoky character.  Unique and intersting.  Texture is very smooth with medium body.  Not as thick as many oatmeal stouts but rather very refreshing.  Bottle (clear).

After many months (and beers)  lurking,  here comes my first review.  550ml bottle with SS pint glass.  Pours out more like a porter than stout.  Aroma isnt overwhelming like other stouts.  Taste is malty,  and mild chocolate and coffee...some sweetness and only mild bitterness at the end.  Texture is what makes this beer special,  very silky smooth.  Easy to drink and enjoy,  highly recommneded.

Last of my Sam Smith sample pack with cool pint glass. Poured a nearly opaque black with a thick creamy brown head. Aromas of coffee, malt, toffee. The flavour was excellent, well balanced and drinkable, toffee, malts, sweet, coffee, mild hop bite and an almost sour tang in the finish. Sampled while watching Shaun of the Dead. Good zombie beer.

pours black as tar with a small tan head.    Aroma of sweet malts and chocolate.  great mouthfeel.  semi thick and good carbonation.  Great mix of Chocolate and malt sweetness with a mild bitter finish.  Very good stout.

Sept, 2002: This is a pleasant if rather thin bodied stout. A pleasant easy to drink beer for old ladies. [2.8]
Jan, 2005: Unpleasant metallic whiff from the co2.  When gas has burned off there are savlon notes, a touch of roasted malts and a hint of fruit. Savlon again in the flavour along with boiled veg. Boiled brown sugar sweetness merging with a stewed bitterness. Stewed and boiled notes throughout. The artificial carbonation gives a silky unnatural mouthfeel. But let the beer settle for a bit and the mouthfeel is more pleasantly neutral.  When carbonated and cold the fruit makes itself felt, with chocolate notes in the finish. But mostly tastes of boiled sugar, socks and cabbage water with a stewed bitterness in the finish.[2.7]

Dark color with slow forming head. Has a hint of chocolate and a hint of coffee in the aroma. Tastes like more than 5% ABV but surprisingly didnt hit me hard. A 22-oz bottle cost me $3 and it was worth every penny.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2005 Just the smooth silky palate you expect from a good oatmeal stout, this one pours black as espresso with a creamy head the color of brown-sugar-cinnamon oatmeal.  Rich coffee/chocolate aroma but like the inside of a truffle on the tongue--silky indeed.  A slight sour note balances the rich flavor, adding to the sense that this oatmeal stout is both homey and multi-dimensional.

Rich dark color with  small head. 
Sour port like nose. 
Rich mouthfeel with an initial  sweet sourness but ending dry. 
Tastes port like w/sweet Fruit,Chocolate and a light bitter roasted note.

Looks like a stout should, black, completely blocks the light when you hold up the glass, thick tan head that turns to a thin layer and coats the sides of the glass.  Smell of malts with a little bit of chocolate.  Taste and body are awesome.  The flavor is a sweet blend of chocolates and coffee with malt tones and just swimming in roasted flavor.  The aftertaste was a bit harsh on the first sip, but after that, was unnoticable.  The praise this beer gets is well deserved.
UPDATED: FEB 18, 2005 a malty beer with a slightly sweet flavor from hints of chocolate along with a hint of nuts and coffee.  no foul after taste and no real complaints.....enjoyable

Black with a small tan head. Nice smoky, roasted malt aroma. Flavor of sweet roasted malts, smoke and a hoppy, bitter finish. I dont know what it is about Sam Smith beers. I like them enough, but they dont WOW me at all.
Even though this beer claims a 5% alcohol content it tasts like 10% which means this one delivers a real kick from the first swallow. A very sweet stout with as much taste as anyone can handle.

Dark ruby colour, lovely rich oatmeal head, a nice bready armoa, and not at all skunky (as I thought it would be).  There is a hoppy bite to the first few sips, and not too much carbonation.  It has sweet malty notes, but a not-too-sweet finish.  Very smooth.

I know, I know.  I swore last month never to drink another Samuel Smith beer because theyre all bottles of skunkiness, but I saw that this was the only beer on the top 50 accessible beers list I hadnt had yet, so I broke down and got it.    Interesting light roasty aroma combined with a much bigger banana-y smell over a black as all hell color.   Wow, Im impressed...no skunkiness!  This is a first with their beers for me.  Like the description says, its extremely silky and slips off the tongue so quickly Im finding myself taking sips over and over trying to better place the taste.  Light flavors but it has a lingering roasted chalky-ness to it.   Its good, but not as amazing as the percentile suggests.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2005 This wasnt worth the hype - too thin and too dry.  Faint traces of dark roasted coffee and malts, but not the right balance with bitterness.  I liked the rich head, but Ill reach for a different stout next time Im at the beer store.

Bouteille de 550 ml achetée à la LCBO. Arôme: Odeur de café, de vanille et possiblement de mélasse. Apparence: Couleur noire opaque avec un petit col beige. Carbonisation faible. Saveur: Goût de café chocolaté et de caramel (côté sucrée). Palette: Légère impression de fumée dans la bouche.Texture douce. (Rating #32)

Smooth, almost creamy. Sweet for a beer but not cloying, and I expected it from the style. Tastes like coffee, molasses, brown sugar, maybe a little vanilla, but I think that was more the smoothness that got to me. Excellent. Just wonderful.

Black opaque color, with a ta head. Aroma is very sweet and malty: coffee, molasses, brown sugar, vanilla and berries. The flavor follows the same track, starts sweet with caramel, chocolate and a hint of vanilla, and slowly slides on the coffee side to end with a smokey, slightly hoppy bitter finish. Smooth and round, the texture is somewhat silky, almost oily.

Wow I was not expecting such a good beer, I had to come and check rate beer to see that my opinion was shared amongst the masses.  The color is dark dark brown, which can barely be seen through if at all.  This is the perfect sweet flavor with a medium to small amount of tan head.

Poured black with frothy tan head.  Leaves behind a nice amount of lace.  Aroma is of coffee, wood, vanilla.  Taste is slightly sweet, chocolate, and roasted malts.  Very smooth and nicely balanced.  Not as thick as some stouts, but this is very tasty.

bottle. Poured dark and inviting, with a large frothy aoff white head. The color was so dark, I could not see thru it when held up to my computer screen.Heavy nose ofmolasses  and roasted malt.I really enjoyed this, a fine example of my favorite; dry stout. The last few brews I tried were only so, so. It was a pleaseure.

Very mild stout, with semi-sweet aftertaste (not bitter like strong stouts) and smokey finish afterwards.  Short lived tan head.  Not what I expected by the label (in a good way)....good beer, one of the best stouts ive had!

Black body with nice beige head. Roasted malts in the aroma along with some coffee and hints of bitterness. Flavor has a light sweetness, some roasted malts hints of coffee and chocolate and finishing with a bitterness. Palate was too thin for me.

Bottle.   What a great stout.  Black and beautiful with a thick tan head.  Aroma is very complex and balanced .. chocolate, wood, smoke, coffee, vanilla, very sweet.  The flavor is a little too sweet, but good none the less.  Caramel, chocolate, roasted malts and more vanilla dominate the start.  It finishes sweet and bitter.  Great beer and better dessert.
Pours (as I would have guessed) black.  Aromas of blueberries and chocolate.  Taste is creamy and smokey with a hint of barbeque sauce.

Pours a rich black, with a large tan coffee colored head. Head recedes slowly and leaves behind thick lace.
Aroma is sweet, mocha, roasty, malty,fruity. 
Flavor is sweet creamy, chocolaty coffee with a roasty bitterness at the end.
Mouthfeel is definitly smooth and silky, but also thick and chewy at the same time. Good stuff.

Umm good. From bottle. Poured dark brown with nice tan head.  Aromas are to die for.  I dont think I have had any beer better on the palate.  Compex flavors, and the last drop is as good at the first.  This beats US tap poured Guinness by a mile.   Jast as advertised, with a bittersweet finish.  The best beer I have tasted to date.

deliciously smooth and rich stout. dark and hearty, good for a meal or drinking by itself. its too thick to have much of, but it has great malty cofee and chocolate flavors.  the flavor is similar to a dominion oak barrel stout, and replacing the oak/bourbon taste with sweetness. probably the best of the samuel smiths

This is an unbelievable Oatmean Stout!!!  Ive been waiting so long to rate this beer its not even funny.  Everytime I go to beers of the world in Rochester NY, I for go trying something new so I can buy this beer again.  The aroma is so sweet and fresh, it seduces you to drink immediately.  This oatmeal stout is so smooth, full, and well-balanced you want to make out with Samuel Smith.  If this beer wasnt as heavy I coule definitely drink a bath tub full of it.  TRY this bargain find!

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2005 From 550ml bottle. Tasted at 53 degrees.  Black with a frothy tan head, nice lacing.  Huge nose. Really huge. The smell is bitter-chocolate covered cofee beans, with vanilla, wood?,  malt.  The taste is sour/sweet, maybe smokey.  There seems to be some hops trying to break out from the malt, they give it a flowery/fruity taste. This is a very complex beer with several things going on at once. I just tasted the Bells Kalamazoo Stout before this and I can say they are two very different beers. They are both classified as "sweet stouts" but this easily fits that category while the Bells didnt.  The commercial description is dead on with the finish, I would say that it is "bittersweet." I gotta tell you, these last two beers have really opened my mind as to what a good stout can taste like. I am so used to having American Tap Guiness and these beers are so much more.  The mouth feel is not as nice as the Bells but it is pretty good. This is a good beer that I will be buying in the future.

This poured out a nice thick dark black with about half an inch of tan head. The head dropped fairly quickly and didnt leave much lace. Aroma is packed full of chocolate and malty goodness with a bit of coffee thrown in the mix. Very sweet and creamy tasting with chocolate standing at the forefront and a roasted malt and coffee flavor blending in. A good blend of bitterness and sweetness balances this out fairly well with sweetness being more dominate, the finish is slightly bitter and dry. Mouthfeel was a good medium body and creamy feel to it. Very good drinkability as I had no problem downing a few of these. Excellent Oatmeal stout that I would recommend to anyone.
This was pretty good, im not a big fan of stouts but if you are this would be for you, real good flavor to it.
This was good. Nice dark colour with a almost brown head. Sweet, coffee, bitter, and a bit of roast. A pretty good stout, though i worry about the clear bottle...
Only the second oatmeal stout Ive ever had. Hated the first one loved this one.  Pours dark, with a brown head.  Everything that a stout wshould be with a hint of oats in the mix. very nice.
Without a doubt. This is one of the finest beers in the world. Coffee, slight chocolate, and just enough bitterness to scare off the sissies.

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown/black body with foamy brown head.  Aromas of coffee, malt, and biterness.  Smells somewhat sweet but alos slight smokey smell was present.  Tastes is also sweet.  Also present are flavours of oats, malt, and coffee.  Could taste a slight smokeiness as well.  Has a smooth finish and leaves a tingle and bitterness on the throat.  It was an alright beer, it grew on me.  But the smokiness that I had gotten from it, turned me off a bit, I have had bad experiences with smoked beers.
Deep, opaque dark brown with thick brown head. Roasty aroma, coffee and a little chocolatey flavor. Soft, almost flat. Somewhat creamy mouthfeel, long finish.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2008 Ahh finally a beer worth talking about!!
Very nice example of the style.
Pours a dark body, brownish/black colour, with a bubbly, frothy brownish head that leaves a nice lace on the glass. Aromas are slight coffee, sweet malt, mild chocolate, and a slight bitterness that leaves this brews aroma quite complex. Taste is distinctively sweet, strange for the style, but suits nicely! Also present are oats, sweet caramel malts, and espresso mildly accompanies. Leaves a nice throat tingle, with a smooth finish overall.
Well done Mr.Smiths!

bottle 550ml. The crystal clear glass bottle is kinky. Very dk brown almost blk w nice tan head that fell rather quickly. Good carb. Moderate lace. Aroma is nice, rich, creamy dark roasted malt/oatmeal w European chocolate & mild hops. Flavor is somewhat sweet, bitter, & sour dark roasted malt/oatmeal with minimal hops that have the typical European from the bottle skunked taste. I at one moment thought of Karo dark corn syrup. Mouthfeel is thin, watery, neither rich nor complex. There is a somewhat pleasant, delicate, European type flavor but it is faint. I bet they could get a hard candy ball to taste just like this stuff. This stout is only medium bodied in my book. I really didnt expect much. Now I have to try their Imperial stout.

1/2 liter clear bottle. Pour reveals a dark black viscous ale with a tight pored mocha colored cap with great retention. Wonderful lacing. Nose fills with aromas of unsweetened chocolate, pine and some burnt toast. Wonderful thick, silky mouth feel....burnt cocoa, lactose, dried currents and figs, damp oak....wonderful complex body....finish is delightfully lingering where the smoothness of this ale is detected...no shrarp edges (acidic charred grain presence in some stouts) the oatmeal does its trick in the finish giving an impression of thick cream and tart cocoa. An oatmeal stout to be savored.
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2006 Pours opaque black, with a beige head. Vanilla aroma. Some notes of sweet chocolate malt in the flavor. Quite good.

Deep, dark red color. Aroma like other SS beers, first sour, then some coffee and caramel. Their trademark tartness matches well with the rich, chocolatey flavers of this stout. The most outstanding quality of this ale is the silkiness of body which might be accented if served on draught under nitrogen.  A treat.

A mixture of every color except black.  The aroma is deep yet mild.  A subtle perfume of chocolate, vanilla, pit fruit, milk, wet leaves and currants.  I love the creamy texture and the suprising full body.  Rich, deep malts, nice chocolate, coffee, minimal but identifiable sourness and a nice pleasing hop bitterness on the finish.  A lovely brew.

Favorite Oatmeal Stout, great head and body!  ot the driest stout by any means, depends what you want in an oatmeal stout...  Now lets make one just like this we can all afford on a regular basis, Cripes!

Color is fantastically matte black, very foamy coffee brown head. Head thinned out but stayed consitantly there and laced very very well. A sweeter stout, but very flavorful. Best non-bitter stout that I know of. Very good.

Bottle.  Nice pitch black with big bubbled head that stays with you for a while - this is a good looking beer and it laces well.  Like ever Samuel Smith beer that Ive had, the nose is sour & sweet, a bit like a cheap sweet red wine.  Not great.  Taste is sweet - too sweet - with a smoky slightly bitter finish but no real good smack to the buds, more like a sweeter porter.  A little boring.  The body is a little lighter than I expected for an oatmeal stout, and it has very low carbonation.  Im a bit surprised with the accolades on this one.  Too sweet for an oatmeal stout I think.
Exceptional stout.  Couldnt really taste the oatmeal but I could taste kind of a toffee like taste.  Very smooth.  Nice dark appearance.

Mmmmm!  Black body with a creamy brown head that actually grew throughout the experience.  Creamy mouthfeel with chocolately sweet finish.  I was happy to shell out $7.99 for this 20.3 oz bottle of bliss.

glass: Nice dark stout. Cola coloured head. a little lasting. Not much oatmeal flavour, somewhat of a bitter chocolate flavour with a flat dry taste on the back of the tounge. I actually enjoyed this more than other oatmeal stouts...Maybe for its lack of oatmeal flavour and toffee aroma. Dry. not over-smooth:)

My opinion is a slightly skewed, because after trying this brew, Id say that Im not a big fan of oatmeal stouts. It was a good looking beer with a faint toffee aroma. The flavor however was just not what Im used to...actually it tasted a little flat so maybe it was a bad sample. Just not enjoyable overall for me, but I can appreciate the complexity.
Very drinkable stout. I didnt think it had much oatmeal taste. The oatmeal just added a mellow smoothness that makes this a joy to drink.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2004 Very solid brew but I didnt think it merited the raves I see in the reviews.  Appearance, aroma, silky texture and body were top-notch.  Alcohol completely hidden. I just didnt care for the too-burnt espresso coffee bitter flavor. Very drinkable nonetheless.
11/09/2004  rerate.  it bugged me that the first time I tried this it seemed too bitter, so I had a second go at it...   nothing but delicious..  raised the flavor 1 point and the overall 2 points.  Excellent Oatmeal Stout.  Love it!

I didnt read the other ratings here before I tasted this so I could form my own unbiased opinion. So when I came to add this rating, I was amused to see one of the more recent rating say "I didnt even realize it was a clear bottle until I poured the beer." Um. Yeah, me too.
Wow--this is beautiful beer! Pours incredibly deep black with a perfect abundant carmel brown head of fine bubbles that lace picturesquely down the sides of the glass. Buttery toffee aromas, with a hint of fruity esters. A pleasant yeastiness that is very much in the fam for Samual Smiths brews. The head has a velvety, creamy feel on the lips like a latte made with whole milk. Palate is smooth, with none of the harsh bite that shows up in some stouts.Tastes of toffee, espresso, smooth roastiness, with a pleasant vinous feel. Thank you sir, may I have another?

This beer is not bad.  Its a bit sweet for my taste.  The mouthfeel has a nice consistency and thickness.  The flavor is very complex, and has a lot of things going on.  I couldnt put my finger on all of them, as I was distracted by the sweetness.  A good stout, however.

Nutmeg aroma thats pleasing.  Good solid blackness and snowflake lacing.  I liked this, and I dont usually like oatmeal stouts.
