Were it not for being as sweet as it is (which is fitting for style, if not m,y pallette) I would rate this tops. Hey. it's summer in Texas and I'm drinking a stout and loving it. If that doesn't show some respect, think about it a minute. Lovely full head that makes me take a minute before burying my face in it. fantastic finish, but did I say I find it a tad sweet? Once I get past that I just love it.

Exceptional color, extremely dark.  The taste is definitely of a stout, but unlike any other I have ever tasted.  Great head, mocha/oatmeal flavor.  The texture is just right too.  Highly recommended.

Deep brown/black with gorgeous ruby flashes when held up to the light, and a soft mocha head. Aromas of bitter chocolate, sweeted coffee and roasted oats. Silky, creamy mouthfeel. Sweet chocolate malted flavour, with a perfectly balanced bitterness in the finish. Mmmmmmm!

This beer pours almost black, with a bit of red around the edges.  Aroma of toasted malt assaults the nose.  I taste toasted malt and oatmeal (of course), in addition to an almost berry-like sweetness, towards the finish.  I enjoyed this very much, and can see myself drinking it after a nice cook-out, beside the pool, with a good cigar.
This beer was good. Especially with desert. Satiny, creamy choclate taste. Pours thick. Yummy.
Very dark with a fairly dark tan head. Perfect blend of toffee, chocolate, and roasted malt. Silky mouthfeel. Good stuff.

The bottle I'm drinking now is a little skunky, but I've had this before and will again -- one of my favorite beers that is easily accessible in my neck of the woods. Dark -- very dark brownish red, thick head, nice lacing, sweet chocolatey aroma and flavor that has a nice, smooth finish. Almost a little too sweet, though, but no complaining here.

Not much aroma noticed. Dark brown/red in color. Poured a very nice tan head and left a beautiful lacing on the glass.  Had a very sweet and toasty malt flavor wiht a nice chocolate finish. I really didn't find this beer as enjoyable as I was lead to believe. Overall not bad.

Comparable in quality to Anderson Valley's Barney Flats, Sam Smith's Oatmeal Stout in nevertheless quite different in both its bouquet and flavor. Not as smooth and a little more roasty, a worthy Oatmeal stout nonetheless. I will say more after a side-by-side with Anderson Valley's Barney Flats and Hoptown's Oatmeal Breakfast

Aghast at my sheer ignorance, I was surprised to find, recently, that I had not rated one of the quintessential "stages" of a ratebeerian's evolution.  Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout.  The natural progression of Budweiser to Guinness is furthered for many a beer fan by the wide availability and quality of this oatmeal stout.  While its relatively thin body and "safe" flavor may leave the advanced connoisseur a bit wanting, I am still satisfied by this creamy brew.  Pours dark brown with a nice, dense tan head (much like Mackeson XXX).  Aroma is roasted, sweet, and a bit chocolatey.  Flavor is succulent, smooth, creamy, and surprisingly sweet, consisting of toasted malts, malt sugars, and a note of chocolate.  In my opinion a better brew than their Imperial Stout.  A return from more venturesome territory proves pleasant.

Black, opaque color. I thought the bottle was brown (it's clear). Roasty coffee-chocolate flavors, sweet but subtle and nothing overpowering here. Exceptionally smooth and creamy. One of my favorites.
UPDATED: NOV 3, 2005 Black with nice light brown head. Roasted, sweet, chocolate aroma. Silky body. Sweet, with dry and coffee-bitter finish. Nice.

Very Nice!  Yeasty, hoppy aroma.  I was a little worried about the clear bottle, but everything worked out well.  Very soft mouthfeel, black as any beer I've had, roased, nice neutral middle, smooth finish.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2003 Excellent beer.  Not my favorite.  It's just a little too sweet for me.  It's very complex with some raison and cocoa.  No skunkiness in my bottle.  Very smooth and creamy.  Rerate:  Not to sweet to me now.  Very smooth and tasty.  Excellent even on this hot day.  I need to compare it to Rogue Shakespeare.
One of my favorite oatmeal stouts.  the nose is roasted along with the taste.  the beer is as smooth as a stout can get on account of the oatmeal.  not too heavy - this is a beer you can enjoy
Very good! Great roasted malt aroma, and full bodied toasted dark malt taste. Long lasting after taste with coffee and chocalate malt flavors. Wow!

Perhaps my bottle was not treated well during it's journey across the pond. I see how high this stout is rated and I am puzzled - this was a very unremarkable example and a big disapointment. Did not seem skunked, perhaps a bit flat but just plain lacking in flavor. Won't bother to re-rate until I've tried this in it's homeland (someday).

Ok, Now i'm finished with beer in clear glass. This one was slightly skunked as well. I'll never make another attempt at this. Looks nice, dark with foamy head. Aroma is sadly tainted. Same with flavor, although not as bad as the nutbrown I had earler. Good mouthfeel and probably a good hopped stout. Maybe I'll plan a trip to England and try this one. On draught.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Dark brown, less opaque than I thought it would be, some reddish hints, light head.  Really shy roasted aroma at first.  It comes out more as the beer warms up.  One heck of a chocolate flavor.  Actually, it tastes like dark chocolate with crushed coffee beans in it.  Smooth palate.  A real dessert beer.  Close competition to St-Ambroise but still 2nd place.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2004 oh man, haha what a great dark beer.  great chocolate flavor, nice pour, dark as hell, creamy, you name it dark beer does this one does it.  update- i dont know what i was thinking rating this at 4.6- its good, its damn good, but its not 4.6 good.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 Nice dark brown with a creamy tan head, great lacing, medium to full-bodied. Malty aroma as expected with hints of raisins and vanilla. Sweet tasting without being syrupy, great balance. The mouthfeel was heavenly, creamy with a minimum bite. A statement to the craft of the brewer. If there is better Oatmeal Stout I have yet to find it, Highly recommended!

I did a beer comparison, Samuel Smith vs. Young’s Oatmeal Stout. The Samuel Smith Oatmeal was highly victorious! Smith’s has a sweater taste, a fuller aroma, and a fine dirty brown two finger head. This beer looks beautiful when pored and taste like a quality precision crafted beer. --Young’s was a little rough all around.
UPDATED: DEC 21, 2007 Definitely one of the best beers in the world. The oatmeal finish is so creamy. A meal in itself.

Another great beer from Samuel Smith.  Dark in the glass with a nice head to it.  Smelled like a bowl of otmeal, laced with sweetness.  Taste was like "a bowl of blended up otmeal" as one friend put it.  Oats, carmel, and overall greatness in the taste.  Wonderful to drink.

Roasaty yeast aroma, caramel, dried fruits, ice tea, bread, and light licorice. Toasty flavor, semi-sweet with and earthy toasty finish. Amazing that Sam Smith could fit so much flavor into this relatively light colored stout...
Black in color with a small tan head. Aroma of malt and choclate. Thick mouth feel, moderately sweet. Smooth bitter and sweet finsh.

This IS the oatmeal stout to illustrate what an oatmeal stout should taste like. Has mouthfeel like chewing on some oats. Beautiful tannish brown head. Dark brown color that cannot be seen through. You can't go wrong by buying this beer!

Robust sweetness as soon as it is opened. Not too many brews offer a mild whisper of sweet vanilla, but here it is nicely balanced.  Not much to the pour, but soft smoothness to the mouth. Lingering sweetness, but not overwhelming.
I love this stout.Very dark but smooth. Coffee,chocolate and vanilla is tasted. Creamy all the way through with a nice roasty finish. A great oatmeal.

I really liked this one from Sammy's. Great example of the style, without being overdone.
Chewy texture, and smooth on the palate make this an easy drinking session beer.
Nose: Rampant oatmeal and molasses attack.  Vanilla and spice and ooey gooey feel.  Creamy start.  Roasty finish.  Yes, I believe I will have another.

Big-bubbled, sudzy, tan head; dark brown in color. Smooth, milky texture with very mild carbonation. Roasted coffee, chocolate, and hints of subtle fruit. Lactic with a corn syrup sweetness. Yeasty, "wet rag" notes. Very mild bitterness.
Coffee in colored with a cream colored head. Nose of malts and coffee. Taste is sweet and alcoholic with nuts and malts. Finishes smooth.
Opaque appearance with red hues. Fantastic oatmeal and chocolate flavor. A meal in itself.

Note: Very fresh bottles. Black color with a small light tan head.  Aroma is malty and oaty.  This beer is silky smooth.  Tastes of oatmeal, chocolate, and malt blend perfectly.  Sweet smooth finish.  I love this beer.
The oatmeal is surprisingly obvious, but not overdone. A little on the thin side, but this gives it the great combination of rich flavor and crisp finish.

(550 ml bottle) Samuel Smith makes wonderful beer, and this stout is no exception. Offwhite head laces on the glass. Lovely sweet toffee flavor, solid, dry feel with excellent complexity and not a trace of bitterness. Roasted sugar aroma. Outstanding.
fantastic malty choco-coffee nose, silky and smooth to the tongue. bursting with flavor, complex tastey stout :]
Big frosty head, malty aroma, smooth texture. Bittersweet finish with a nice lace in the glass. Black gold, I'm in stout heaven.

Bottled. Black with red brown at the edges, good beige head and a good (almost excessiven level of condition. Chocolate aromas with some fruit and oak noticable and a suggestion of dandelion and burdock. Oily licorice and roast barley flavours that linger long into the finish.

A black beer with a fine light brown head. The flavor is fruity, roasted, and oaty. The flavor is sweet with a slight but nice bitterness and notes of fruit, oats, and roasted malt. A very nice stout.
UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 Dark brown pour with small carmel colored head.  Sweet smelling aroma of of oats and chocolate.  Sweet taste with mild bitterness and watery mouthfeel. Dry finish.
dark reddish black, light tan head. chocolate and oatmeal aroma. light carbonation with small bubbles. sweet at first, somewhat bitter finish. mildly fruity, cherry taste. beautifully smooth.

sweet flowery aroma, reminiscent of oloroso sherry, porter like appearance .. very dark tawny hue with an off-white head, toasted, malty, black coffee-like flavour, very creamy with a long dry finish, excellent stout.  Very attractive bottle as you would expect from Samuel Smith

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2003 Re-rate: This was one of the first beers I ever rated, and this is the first time I have had it since. I still like it, but not as much as I used to. Aroma is malty with a slight chocolate note. Smooth texture. Bittersweet flavors with a slight coffee taste.
very dark with a reddish tint. roasted oatmeal aroma. Tasted like sweet oats, fruity and toasty tast. light carb nice texture.

Almost a creamy, tight packed tan head.  Dark ruby, black color.  Sweet, malty aroma.  It makes my mouth water like few other things.  Hearty flavor, sweet but just the right amount.  The grains come through well.  Malty.  I think this may be my favorite stout when factoring price, availability, and taste.  A definite winner and repeat buy.  If you can get your hands on this, and you probably can, give it a try.

Very dark brown nearing black body with a huge creamy tan head.  Aroma is chocolatey and roasted nuts.  Flavour is silky smooth malts and roasted cocoa with a slight fruity note.  Finish is sweet and chewy.  A beauty!
I found this brew to go down easy which is much to my liking with a nice smooth flavor.A good stout in my opinion.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This brew has a mild hoppy malt aroma. Invigorated pour with a light brown head of small to medium bubbles and a opaque dark brown body with a receding lacing on the side of the glass. It has a surprisingly smooth flavor with very subtle taste. Hard to place the flavor, but it went down very easily and was very much to my liking.

Great big frothy tan head which settles like a guinness.  Very little carbonation.  Awesome color of dark brown.  Arome of chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor is very smooth with dark chocolate and grains present.  Slight iron taste also.  Finish is creamy and smooth with a slight lingering bitter finish.  Also not much alcohol present for a stout.  A decent stout and one I would recomend for someone who does not like big thick hearty stouts as the beer is a decent but thin consistency.
Dark color with a thick, milky body.  Wonderful mouthfeel!  Roasted profile is well done and the oatmeal adds a nice creaminess to the brew.  Sweet and fruity at the end, a really good stout.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2009 When poured out had little to no head and a very dark color. The nose is quite complex and wonderful, with the graininess shining through.  Nice malty sweet palate with a strong though well balanced hops finish.  A great stout.
Black in color with a large tan head.  As dark as this beer is there is only a subtle roasted malt aroma.  I detected some sweetness but mainly focused on a stale aftertaste.  I did not like this.

This is the best Oatmeal Stout I've ever tasted! It is most excellent. I guess I've been lucky in that I've yet to have one that has gone bad. The head is beautiful, the taste sublime, the color is gorgeous, mouthfeel is just right and the carbonation is glorious going over the tongue. What more can be said?

really enjoyed this sweet stout ... poured as thick as an imperial as you would expect from an oatmeal ... the 'sweet' in sweet stout isnt TOO sweet at all, which is to my liking ... overall very nice feel and flavors, that could be stronger, but work well ... low ABV is curious but then im not a brewer ...

after i picked this up i was terrified it was going to have gone sour because of the clear bottle, but it must be my lucky day because it's just perfect. pours a beautiful deep black color with a fluffy tan head that fades fairly quickly. there's something just a little bit odd in the aroma; i smell chocolate and coffee and something else that i can't identify. thick and sweet with a bit of hop and roastiness with a dry, bitter finish. fantastic beer, all around.

This beer poured a dark black with a picture perfect tan frothy head. No way to see through the body of this beer. The aroma is of coffee, chocolate and wine-like alcohol. A flavor of oats, chocolate malt balls and some coffee. A very nice full palate and some dryness in the finish. A very fullfilling stout.

What can I say as reviewer #432? Generally, I like to be able to see light comin' through the other side of my beer glass, but the occasional stout's fine. This is a real English stout, by which I mean that aroma and flavor components include all the traits one would expect from a good English ale - fruity, bready yeast, toffee notes, and a clean herbal hop bite. This, of course, in addition to the smooth stout palate, the hints of burnt toast, and the deep color and creamy head. It almost tastes like a blended beer, with both ale and stout in the mix. Anyhow, its very good.
Dark brown in color almost black. Small tan head. Can smell the alcohol. Fizzy for a stout.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2003 This is one of my first ratings. I was blown away! Dark as night appearance with hints of ruby. Beige head that has a beautiful lacing effect. Please note its very rare I would ever use the word "beautiful" in a rating but it fits here. Flavor is a nice balance of sweet and bitter. Hints of chocolate and oatmeal. Silky texture and a pleasure to drink. It can vary because of the clear bottle, but even the worst one Ive ever had was still at least pretty good. Im having a fresh one tonight and its amazing. Awesome beer!

Mmmmmmm. Thick pour and creamy head. Oatmeal fills up your nose and mouth with a hint of residual suagrs. If anything bad can be said about this one it may be that it carries a mild cloying quality with it that some other inferior Oatmeal stouts don't have.

This beer rocks.  It is a staple for starting out almost any night of drinking.  It is smooth with a nice creamy light brown head.  You can taste the oatmeal in the beer and the sweetness it leaves you with is just perfect.  I don't generally like sweet stouts, however this one is unavoidably likable.  It actually gets better as it warms and when its done you want another.

Although I'm not a big fan of this style, I sort of liked this stout because it wasn't overly sweet the way a lot of stouts are. Nice aroma and taste even though I feel that the taste is lacking a little in depth.
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2004 Rich brown head; very smooth feel; slight coffee taste with finish that is bitter, but not excessively so. May 2004: the aroma is among the best
Chocolat aroma. Very dark brown color, brown head, good lace. Intens flavor, sweet, chocolat, hint of cola, very drinkable, light roasted. Long lasting coffee liquor flavor finish.

Totally opaque, very thick pour with no head.  More than any beer I've had, this one could pass for a wine.  At first, I swore I could smell the grapes in the aroma.  However, it somehow manages to taste much much better than any dry, bitter wine.  There's a small note of sweetness and grain flavor to offset the winelike flavor.  Unrelentingly bitter/sour aftertaste.  Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2003 Black.  I thought it was a brown bottle before  I poured.  Tan head that disappears soon but leaves a nice lace on the glass.  Coffee and bitter chocolate very noticeable in the aroma, and also a little tobacco.  Flavor of the same coffee and chocolate with a little cream.  Faint malt and hops tastes as it warmed.  Mildly bitter finish. excellent beer.
Love it. Once I got hooked, I couldn't get enough. Creamy bowl of oatmeal flavor really comes through, but oh so much more!

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2003 Deep dark and creamy pour. The creamy head faded far to fast. A nice aroma of chocolate and coffee.
Slightly sweet, medium body, creamy texture. Very light alchoholic finish. Great balance. Very nice brew!
dark with a good head on it.  not very creamy.  buttery and bitter with not much after taste.
wonderful dark colored beer with a thick slowly dissipating head. Bitter & sweet taste with mild aftertaste. My first & not last oatmeal stout
Unpleasant aroma.  Very dark color.  Flavor was kinda sweet, slightly bitter, and it felt slightly creamy in the mouth.  I dont think these kinds of beers are for me.
Dark brown colour, nice pale brown head. Disappointing aroma, but the taste is wonderful, with a bittersweet complexity. Another great beer from Samuel Smiths!
Sweeter than normal, I like it!  A slight metalic taste, but I'm thinking that was just this bottle.
A very enjoyable oatmeal stout.  THe Samuel Smith Old Brewery does not disappoint with this brew.  One of the best available here in the NW!
Great looking and tasting beer.  Tastes like it has more alcohol than it really does.  Awsome beer.

Perfect (I mean perfect - creamy, lacy) fluffy brown head.  Dark but not opaque.
Sweet, roasty malt notes in nose.  Smooooooooth as silk ... rich roast, sweetness, a little bitterness on the finish (barely).  You could drink several litres of this stuff without much fuss.  Divine.  If only  this was available in place of Guinness!

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2003 A very nice stout, and certainly a staple of the stout diet, being easily found.  Not TOO sweet, and less emphasis on the coffee/chocolate flavors in a sweet stout is a nice change of pace.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2003 A great beer but it is heavy. Great consistenacy and the mild flavor give you a good treat. Slightly sweet this is similer to Gunniess is feel but no aftertaste and no bitterness.
The best stout I have ever had.  A little to carbonated, but the flavor is great.  Little bitterness, and you can actually taste the oatmeal.  My only problem is the clear bottle.  Why??

Black. There's black lettering on my glass and I can't see it. Tan head with good retention. The aroma is sweet. You can taste the roasted malts and the oats give it a sweet taste. Smooth, medium dry, and slight bitter finish. Good stuff!

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2003 I've many of these before I started Ratebeer, always like them.  I got a gift box with pint glass and this and two other Sam's included.  This is an excellent stout.  I got to agree with the "Commercial Description" all the way.  Medium dry, balance between bitterness and sweetness.  Soft mouthfeel.
Beautiful stout. Creamy and smooth. A little caramel, liquorice, roasted malt. Well-balanced. Full-bodied. Slightly bitter finish.

Dark brown to black color. Bottle is clear- looked brown because of the color of the brew. I try not to buy beer in clear bottles because of usual skunkiness that occurs in them. Flavors of chocolate, tofee,walnuts,chicory, cardboard. On the dry side. Carbonation - Can't tell because of extremely dark color. Creamy mouthfeel. Odor of alcohol and cardboard.Plenty of bitterness and not sweet at all. Thick medium brown head. Medium to thick consistancy. Bitter aftertaste.

Almost no carbonation but the head lasts until you finish the bottle. A very balanced oatmeal stout. Balanced in every possible way. There is a hint of oxidation in the back ground (a little cardboard on the finish-in my bottle at least) that can be detected but the effect is overpowered by the hopbitterness as you drink.  It is a perfect amalgalm of roasted malts, hop bitterness and malty sweetness.  HOWEVER, this is not the best oatmeal stout I've sampled, not even close.  Try St-Ambroise Oatmeal stout (McCauslan) if you want richness, roastiness, chocolate and a healthy dose of bitterness (balanced on a much higher scale).  A superbly pleasant brew nonetheless. As the beer warms up, alchohol and fruit notes are more apparent and the roastyness in the nose is more noticeable.
This is a truly amazing beer. A thick, dark beer with a thick light brown head. It has a very smooth taste, sweeter than your every day stout thanks to the oatmeal. Try this beer, you will like it
One of my favorite beers, a little more bitter than I usually like.  Doesn't go well with roast beef.

A beautiful beer!  rich and thick black body.  Some fishiness about it though (I'm thinking it was just this bottle).  Faint smokiness.  Well roasted with hints of alcohol in the nose.  Nice creamy mouthfeel, smooth and full.  Nice and sweet from the oats, I assume.  A beatiful smooth malty finish.
Delicious! Pours a thick brown head. Incredible smooth roasted malt. Well balanced. Oatmeal, part of a well-balanced breakfast!
Little sweeter than i like but teh flavor is far from boring.

An Oatmeal raisin cookie recipe in a bottle.  I love this stuff, and would be more than happy to drink it all the time.  Has the appearance of a coffee liquer, with a bit of a malty coffee taste, but smooth right up till the end.
damn fine beer.  had forgotten how much I liked it.  Smooth beer, wonderful flavor, nice head.  Would drink again in a heartbeat.
Dense dark body with creamy tan head. Complex layering of flavors, but burnt coffee and dark chocolate dominate. Not too thick, smooth with a malty finish. Very good.
Sam Smith's was not an enjoyable beer for me. The sample which I had was soupy and thick. It tasted like a beer which had been sitting for a good deal of time. I didn't enjoy this one at all.
Off aroma otherwise a great beer

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2005 Now THAT is what a sweet stout is supposed to taste like. I have found the sweet nectar of life here. Aroma is of roastiness, dough, gingerbread, malt, chocolate and dark fruit. The pour is black as night...with a thinly creamy dark tannish head gracing its presence on my glass and coating it with a thin reminder of lacing to remember this glorious event. The taste is magnificent....a beautiful blend of roasts with a mild fruity and ever so slightly bitter finish. The carbonation is practically non-apparent here, and i dont feel as if im chewing my drink down..sometimes a definite plus. The aftertaste is definitely smokey with chocolate and plum residue apparent and a heavy helping of malty dryness. For a stout that is such a staple around the household, this sure took me a while to get my hands on it..but let me tell you i will never let go!!!
One of the best beers I've been able to taste.  It's too bad it's so hard to find.
Complex nose.  Good course head. Smooth, Sweet choclatety taste. A little too sweet for my liking, but overall a great beer.
UPDATED: MAR 20, 2003 Very light in body. Sweet and creamy. Low hop bitterness. Pasteurization is evident. Fishy nose. Lots of butterscotch flavors.
Bizarre nose, couldnt quite put my finger on it. Deep brown color with small head. Quite dry in the mouth but a clean finish. I really like this beer.
UPDATED: APR 20, 2007 Deep brown with small tan head.Great chocolate malt nose.Roasted chocolate malt flavor with toffee overtones and a hint of cherry. Great balance and body
Not the best aroma - but thats about the only thing wrong with this one. Great color and flavor. Seems like Sam Smith doesnt make a bad beer!

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2003 (Bottle) Pours a nice rocky beige head with a opaque black body. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Tastes malt and strong cocoa and finishes incredibly smooth and milky. Absolutely lovely, darling!
Surprisingly Creamy taste, and appropriately sweet
Roasty, tasty, smooth, and very palateable. Gets just a little too sweet at times.
UPDATED: JUN 12, 2006 Bottle - Dark pour, lighter head than I expected.  Smells like roasted coffee.  Taste was normal at first, hearty stout, but aftertaste was like milk and cream, very smooth.
Black colour.  Aroma is roasty, mocha.  Flavour of malt, roasted coffee, notes of chocolate, quite filling and very creamy.  Finishes with a long bitterness.
Sweet beer courtesy of the oatmeal, a great dark colour that looks great, and a full-bodied taste that makes it an all-around great beer!
One of my all time favorites. Easy drinking drinking, full feel, great flavors.  Have not had one in years, I do miss it.
The best, it dosent get much better than this.
Pours BLACK! Small short head. Roasted and toasted to the max. Vanilla? Excellent creamy mouthfeel. Not overly bitter, well balanced. Top notch for someone who isnt a big Stout fan.

Very dark brown almost black in color. Nice looking head. Aroma was not to powerful yet was quiet sweet with soft bitterness. Flavour is more pronounced but we cloud say that it is still gentle. Light roasted java coffee beans, some bitter walnuts.  Nice composition yes, but I did expect a bit more heart in it.  A bit to bland, unrefined to the excellence. This was my 700...Thans Doug for this interesting beer !
Deep brown/black in color, firm but short lived brown head.  Aroma of roasted grains and toffee.  Bitter finish, with sweet under the tounge aftertaste.
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2004 I love this brewery.  Smooth dark beverage.  Surprisingly good chocolate head that quickly disappears.  Chocolate and smoke and everything good for a stout.

UPDATED: JUN 3, 2003 Poured out of bottle, bought at Sam's Wine & Spirits in Chicago, 12/10/02.  Deep, dark dark brown beer with a slight, murky brown cream head.  The head forms in what I can only describe as small glops along the surface and on the edges of the glass, and it quickly gives off a wonderful malty cocoa (almost nutty) aroma.  A very nice flavor of cocoa and malt, this one is a very easy drink for a stout, but does not lose any of the richness of flavor to make it so.  It's just very tasty and feels wonderful going down.  The finish is perhaps a little too bitter (like with some dark chocolates), but that mostly just makes me want to take another gulp to get rid of it!  I   This is one of the better stouts I've had, and I'll surely try some more.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2008 Nearly black.  Great high head that clings to the glass in clumps.  Velvety smooooooth, barely carbonated body, goes down like chocolate milk.  Perfectly balanced mocha flavors.  Nice subtley hoppy finish.  Unfortonately my experience with this stuff has been inconsistent, but at its best, this is great beer.

Very thick head produced when the beer is poured.  The beer is a very smooth drink, with a cocoa and malty aroma, and a coffee and bitter flavour.  The beer is only let down by a slightly sweet tang after the beer is swallowed.  A great beer nonetheless.

A grainy coffee goodness floats in a fragrant cloud above the glass. The deep dark blackness of this beer reveals no secrets. An everlasting lacy head dribbles and etches down the side of the glass and lingers patiently on the surface. The taste is initially pure butterscotch and chocolate, then just a hint of hops hits you up the middle. The end is just a smooth fade away. This is a classic. Watch out for skunked samples, the bottle probably doesnt travel well. Stick to well cared for bottles.

This is one way my mother never told me I could get my oatmeal! Silky so smooth!! Poured and looked like cola. Wonderful! And as a side note do not eat a hungarian salami sandwich with it because it makes it taste like fish and it takes awhile to get the flavour out.
While most of Sam Smiths beers are a bit of a disapointment this one always seems to be just fine.  Good solid balance of Mocha and creamy oats.  Not the biggest or baddest, but a very pleasant brew.
This beer has a deservedly good reputation.  Silky sweetness is apparent from the first sip.  Of the easy-to-get beers, this one also happens to be one of the best.
probably the best stout i had in awhile. it was very rich and creamy texture and a bitesweet on the palate.
Dark and smooth and beautiful, probably my favorite stout of all.

My favorite beer in the whole world for nearly 20 years!  A wonderful sweet stout with incredible smoothness and balance.  The only challenge is to ensure that you get fresh bottles - these can get skunky if your supply is not fresh.

Huge head on dark brown to black beer.  Not really a stout, not really fair to compare it to stouter stuff, but at 5% abv it is a great session beer.  Good mouthfeel, pleasant taste but not memorable.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2004 Widely available and redily drinkable. Sweet stout flavors, goes down smooth like cream. Could use a dark bottle as it is occasionally strongly skunked, usually lightly skunked. The a aroma is very fruit and balanced with just the right notes for the style. Seems kinda dead overall but it's still a deliciuos beer.
ME LIKE BEER, THIS BEER GOOOD!!! So thick you cant see through it with a flashlight, but light a creamy down the hatch.
MMM... Well crafted beer.  Very thick and creamy.  Sweet taste and heavy mouthfeel made this beer exceptional.
Nice balance you could taste the oatmeal.  This one is smooth and creamy.  Good Stuff

One of the best stouts I have ever had, oatmeal or otherwise. Incredible head and creamy body, almost a roasted nut flavor on top of the chocolate flavor typical of most stouts. God I love this company.
Full but quickly dissapating head, very fragrant aroma rich smoky.  Nice bitter finish but initial taste a little thin.  Overall enjoyable but unlikely to become a regular stout for me.
Great stout.  I could actually taste the oatmeal.  Wonderful thick brown head.

Black color. Very thick full cascading “G” type head. Aroma is roasted malts and chocolates. A nice silky smooth. Medium bodied sweet stout. Mild malts and hops. A very flavorful beer. Nice chocolate and coffee flavor. Well balanced. Just wish it were in a brown bottle. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter and a touch dry. What a sweet stout should be
Just plain good.

Damn fine beer!!  This has the full flavors that make beer worth drinking.  It has better a cleaner creamy finish that comes unexpectedly after that full bodied flavor as well.  You can taste a hint of coffee among the complex roasts, but nothing overpowers ... just tastes great.

I really do not get the smell form this brew as I do with other Oatmeal Stouts.  It lack that, and the taste is good but cannoot amke up for the missing strong smell present in most oatmeal stouts.  A good smell gets the mind and the mouth going in antisipation of the beer taste to come.
Its good, but not that good!. Has something like a aroma as sherry, which is found again in the taste. But I didnt find it so good a combination for a beer.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2003 (need re-rate, preferably draft) Very good sweet stout.
Beautiful appearence; deep ruby color with a frothy,lacy head.  Not highly effervescent.
Very complex, and mostly appealing aroma: Roasted malted grains (perhaps this is the 'oatmeal'), hops, caramel, chocolate.  But, I also smelled URINE!  I did buy it from Safeway, and it does have a clear bottle, but I didn't think 'skunky' meant 'pissy'.  Hmmm.  I dock a couple "aroma" points.
I found the flavor pleasant, very well balanced, but not particularly complex.
A thick, flat sweetness is balanced well with hop acidity and some other source of subtle sourness.  Lightly astringent.

Wont rate it as high as  some  have.  Ive read someone noting a bacon aftertaste at one tasting but not at another.  Could be a sign of age (its age, not mine) but I noticed it too and that mitigates my score.  I suppose though, that with its low ABV, I cold have half a bottle with my eggs in the morning.

I hate to do it, but I must admit that this beer is in fact the best stout Ive ever had. The first time I had it it was a little skunky from the idiotic clear bottle, but since then its been sublime.  If you know me then you know I have a hard on for Rogue Shakespeare Stout, but this is better. Just so incredibly smooth and creamy, with a perfect balance of roastiness, chocolate, coffee, sugar, plum and grape in flavor and texture.  Oh God, its so good...

Deep and rich chestnut to near black in color with a breathtaking amber head. Slight wine-like aroma with a slight scent of oats as well. Smooth mouthfeel, akin to a fine Port with flavors of plum and raisins that finish quite dry on the palate.
Very very tasty, the best Sam Smith beer by far, and Im not even a big stout fan!
Very nice hints of coffee.  Aroma is a bit on the weak side, though I dont think it is bad.  Nice foamy head and a beautiful dark look.  Would absolutely recommend.
Loved it.  The oatmeal flavors add a creamyness that really complements the typical stout characters in this beer.
Sour milk in the nose. Dark black color and a huge foamy head. Root beer-like taste with coffee tones, also a little butteryness. Medium bodied. Good stuff.
A very good and different tasting stout beer.  Not easy to come by but I drink it whenever is see it on the menu.
Roasted malt aorma. Black with a rocky light brown head. Roasted coffe aroma. A nice one!
Samples vary widely.  My latest was rather pruny, thin and unrewarding. American stouts offer so much more for the money.

This beer is a classic stout. One of the first beers I tried as a young lad. Since this beer comes all the way from england & its in a clear bottle, it is always slightly stale by the time it gets here.
Good for what it is, but Im not too fond of such sweet beers.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2003 5/31/02: dark dark brown with a big & creamy tan head which dissappears quickly, not overly aromatic, smooth but full bodied, nice oatmeal-like finish
Re-Rate 8/25/02: An english hot and sour soup..tending to be extremely sweet in oatmeal ways..
excellent.  thick and sweet, yes i taste the oatmeal.  favorite oat.stout. could it be marketed as a great breakfast beer?
outrageous stout!! very t6hick and very tasty,nice dark color of course, get you some!!!

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2005 pours black with a tan head.  aroma of coffee, raisin, and toasted oats.  very smooth mouthfeel.  more coffee in the flavour aswell as milk chocolate, burnt sugar, and figs.  beautiful.
My favorite beer! Its bittersweet finish complements a hearty dinner.  It is great both chilled and at room tempature.
An amazing oatmeal stout. Great color and aroma, almost like gingerbread. A full mouth-feel and a raisiny finish.
Aroma has oats and fresh coffee. Rather sweet, but also bitter taste with roasted malt. Firm coffee and chocolate flavors. Good lacing. Delicious and complex beer with a long finish.

I wanted to try something special for my 50th rating. Seeing as this was a top 50 pick on RateBeer and readily available, it was a perfect choice. A beautiful an inviting black colour but with a quickly fading head. Left a ring of lace at the top of the glass but no more for the remainder. The bottle I tried might have been on the shelf too long. Leaving a hint of skunkiness in the otherwise pleasant roasty aroma. A bit watery but smooth on the palate. Just a touch of fruit in the flavor. Finish is pleasantly bitter after the initial sweetness, although with some slight acidity. Cant help but be a little disapointed with my first top 50 beer.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2007 Why put such a beautiful beer in a clear bottle? What a crime...couldnt tell at the store because the beer is so dark. Seemed a little thin--on texture but not on flavor. Overall this is excellent; it is hard to beat a good sweet stout. I can taste the oatmeal in this one. I wish I could think of more superlatives but this is damn near perfection.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2004 As I initially couldn't buy the Imperial Stout, I'm left rating the Oatmeal Stout, which isn't a bad thing at all.  Although I was expecting more flaring oatmeal overtones, this has to be one of the best beers I've ever had as far as sit down drinkability. Upon first examination, this beer has the consistency of worcestershire sauce, not nearly as thick as other stouts.  Pleasant aroma, mildly sweet, minimal carbonation, bearing a creamy roasted flavor.  Awesome texture and finish.  This is going to become one of my standards.  Bring on the St. Ambroise so I can rate it next!  RE-RATE:  After pairing two of the Victorian pints to a St. Ambroise, I am prepared to say that this is the smoothest stout I've had to date.  I guzzled down two of those suckers like it was water; the pure brewed lager didn't go down as easily.
Very, very dark with lasting fluffy tan head that left great lace.  Dark roast coffee smell.  Dark chocolate sweetness with a roast coffee bitterness in the finish.  Smooth mouthfeel.
This stout pours to a dark black-brown color with a rich tan head. The flavor has hints of chocolate covered raisons, molasses, and just a hint of coffee. Deep, rich and profoundly enjoyable
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 Bottled. Indeed sweet, rich, thick. I cant help feel these are a little overrated.
When it comes to oatmeal stout it doesnt get any better than Samuel Smith

RE RATE: I had nothing of importance to say before. but i gave this another try and was blown away. Drinking this i found candy and raisins and smootheness. This is a versatile beer for many occasions.

Stout is an understatement.  Beer pours out of the bottle thick like burnt motor oil.  Head on beer is caramel color; not even close to white.  Super bitter, hints of burnt coffee and oatmeal of course.  Nice feel in the mouth; real flavor kicks in 10 seconds after a sip.  Im not a fan of bitter brew, but I believe this beer would appeal to most stout lovers.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2003 good stout, not quite as good as Koff, Carneigie or Coopers. Its a stout so I can only rate it so high. If I real like something I should be able to drink about 12 without getting bored, but as with all ale/stout a few are good then I want to  graduate to another taste. Lager is like a meal, ale is like dessert.

Now this has a wonderful flavor... hazelnut aroma and flavor, along with chocolate, perhaps chocolate covered orange... old fruit and a finish of nice, dry coffee-like goodness. I couldnt put my finger on a few of the flavors, which was nice... it was just a good, smooth, malty stout bursting with flavor. I mean it too... velvet palate? youre damn right.

A nice aroma, with both roasted notes and sweet notes.  The beer itself is pretty, with an almost, but not quite, opaque dark body and a sizable tan head.  It has a well-balanced flavor to it, with perhaps a bit more toasted malt than some other sweet stouts.  It sits in the mouth with a slightly velveteen feel to it.  Overall, a good beer, if not on the level of some imperial stouts.
An alltime favorite! Pours evenly leaving a tan head that will be there for awhile. Drinks quite easily with a silky smooth feel. Sweet maltiness that just keeps tasting better.
Very good beer.  Full flaoved without being overpowering like many stouts.  Smooth and silky.  Black color with a tan mostly lasting head.  Moderate maltyness and well balanced.
Thick and hearty, pours almost like chocolate milk.  Has a nice combination of flavors.
Opaque black color. Nice fat head lasts. Smells like smoky chocolate. Fruity nutty flavors, figs? The more of these I drink, the more flavors I taste. Bitter sweet chocolate finish. Nice.
Was not quite what I like in a stout. The Imperial Stout I felt was much better. I really cant complain, but I think a lot of American stouts are more complex than this one.
Wonderful and delightful drink, strong start with no lingering bitterness.
Wonderful deep brown with a dark beige extremely rocky head.  Wonderful roasted malt aroma.  Flavour is like smokey and sweet, image if you could smoke chocolate in a BBQ pit.  Wonderful!!

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2012 My favorite beer, which has been now for about 9 years I guess. Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout. She doesnt come cheap though, at around $5.00 (for a 18.7 ounce Victorian Pint), only the most privileged and discerning people will choose the luxury of her presence, but she is well worth it my friends. She is dark, rich and beautiful, with a creamy mocha head and complex yet well balanced personality. Her medium-full body is exceptionally smooth, silky and well-rounded, carrying the delightful scent of dark malt, chocolate and toasted oats. Her subdued flavors will please any palate, and will leave you wishing for more to drown out the slightly bittersweet aftertaste once she is gone. As an extra bonus - she is also certified Vegan. Such a classic, amazing Oatmeal Stout. Benchmark of the style!

Hmmm, am I talking about beer or my wife? ;-)

Black w/ thick creamy head. Roasted malt aroma w/ notes of figs.  Smooth,  silky texture. Moderately sweet, toasty, hints of nuts, & a dry silky finish.
 Yummy.

Re-Rate 10/13/02: The beer pours a full bodied black color, the generous head is chocolate brown, the lace lays in sheets upon the Chimay Goblet I drink it from, as I think goblets and chalices do more for stouts than the traditional Guinness tulip glasses. When you bring this to your lips for the first taste, the roasted malt, oats, caramel, and an almost molasses like tone greets you. Front is malt sweet; the middle is full, rich, creamy and somewhat chocolate like, the finish is where you find the Kent hops at the semi-sweet dry finish, and a long lasting toasted grain after taste. Stouts are not meant for everyone, as much as I love them, many will find them bitter, overpowering and totally lacking in merit, but then I feel that way about most Lagers/Pilsners, but to me this is what makes beer and beer drinkers so interesting, the difference in taste and opinions.

This silky smooth sweet stout is ALL what it;s cracked up to be. This is the very best stout ans possibly the very best beer ive ever drank. Words cant describe this brew, just go find some and sip away!
This is really good.  This is one of the more balanced sweet stouts that I have had.

Coffee with brown sugar aroma, a hint of chocolate. Incredibly dark, almost purple, with a huge cappuccino head. The head looks like pancake batter, with assorted sized bubbles bursting on top, some lace. Great coffee flavour, strong roasted bitterness. Has a rich full silky texture, and a fabulous liquorice aftertaste. A Wonderful Sweet Stout!
I had this for dessert last night - so good.  Chocolate and roasted barley aroma.  Sweet, chocolate taste with a silky mouthfeel.  One of my favorite stouts.
Black in color nice brown head smokey very nutty flavour,  very thick not the creammy tast I am used to with oatmeal stouts
Very sweet and heavy stout.  Got numerous aromas from it.  Another enjoyable stout from Sammy Smith..
Now this is one fine stout. Sweet, smoky flavor.  Very smooth and balanced. Samuel Smith continues to impress me. ;)

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2003 Yessssss! Beautiful! Strong wood, smoke, coffee, nutty aroma. Kinda like a campfire. The taste was better than the aroma. Wonderful blend of coffee, smoke, nutty, wood, licorice, alcohol, and more. The color was black black, with just a hint of red when held directly in front of a 100 watt light bulb. The carbonation was quite low... which I like in a stout. A hint of sweetness in the aftertaste rounded out the flavor. This is one of the best stouts in the world. Yesssssss! Yesssss! Yesssssss!

Deep brown color with a hint of red, almost opaque.Malty aroma, strong full malty taste, slightly bitter aftertaste. A nice sweet stout. *Note-The first time I tried this, my husband and I nicknamed this the Bacon Beer. It tasted overwhelmingly like bacon and maple syrup. I didnt notice that at all this time. Maybe I had a bad bottle. Much better the second time around.
Earthy musky aroma.  Deep black hue.  Tan head, slowly diminishing.  Lovely malts, sweet caramel/mocha, medium bodied, slightly hopped finish.  A wonderful sweet stout, a classic, no doubt.

Very, very good stout.  I was impressed with this stout, and plan to put it head to head with Youngs Oatmeal Stout sometime soon.  This stout definitley tastes better as it reaches a room temp.  Nice, creamy head, although it doesnt stick around too long.  The oatmeal flavor was suttle  IMO.  Very smooth beer.  Thin mouthfeel.
Wow, this is good stuff.  Drinks extremely smooth.  Excellent appearance.  Taste, although thin, is very agreeable with me.  Ill definitely try some more of this.
Typical looking stout very dark.  The taste is rather thin and it smells and finishes like soy sauce.  Overall it is not bad, but the soy sauce flavoring is kind of weird...
This is a great oatmeal stout. Very smooth and well balanced with just the right amount of carbonation. Excellent!
What can I say that hasnt already been said? Its sammy smiths oatmeal stout.  If you dont know it, get to know it.  You wont be disappointed.

Slightly sweet malt aroma with bread-dough tang riding shotgun. Color is that of espresso--moderate tan head and fine speckled lace...Substantial malty front with slight tang that builds gradually towards the finish along with light hop accents that are also most evident in the finish. The mouthfeel is unusual because most of its weight is felt up-front with the initial malt wave.  Some label this as "thin" but I dont concur--I think it is just the tapered contours of the taste profile. It is very smooth but not lacking in assertiveness...Very fine stuff---one of my favorite stouts and another standout from this stalwart brewery.
Smooth but thin, flavorful but with a titch of metallic taste.  Substantial but soon-gone head, appearance of coca-cola carbonation.  An enjoyable drink but not overwhelming in any dimension.
This is one of the best stouts Ive had. Nice body with coffee flavors.
A good looking dark beer.  Smells of sweet porridge (as expected).  But..this beer is too sweet more my bitterness loving taste buds.  Its a good example of an Oatmeal Stout - just aint my thing.

They need to lose the clear bottle. Mine started with a lot of vinegar in the nose and taste, but improved a bit as it warmed. I was expecting something spectacular, but, quite frankly, this particular bottle wasnt any better than Youngs Oatmeal Stout in the nitro cans, so Im rating accordingly. Hopefully Ill be able to get a fresher bottle soon.
Ive had good luck with SSs other (clear bottle) products, so this was a surprise. RE-RATE: St. Patties Day 2002. Gave this one another shot, in light of the praise it receives here. Still full of vinegar, not creamy, and not particularly impressive. I went with the smaller bottle this time, hoping that something was wrong with the (large) bottle I tried before. I just dont get what everyone sees in this one. (6/15/02) Still trying to like this one. First sip is soy sauce, but after that Im getting some chocolate. Better than before, but not a religious experience. Out of respect to the consensus, Ill add a few points. Closing the book on this beer, it has not been kind to me, but perhaps Ill revisit it in a year or two. 7/13/02: Another bottle, another rerate. I left this one in the fridge entirely too long, but nonetheless it has been a better experience than the previous bottles. Smooth chocolate and coffee with none of the off flavors described in my previous ratings. At last, a good fresh bottle!
This beer rocks. If you like other stouts that I rated highly, then this one wont disappoint.
Nice aroma, decent flavor. Not too thin, with a slightly bitter aftertaste.
A real disappointment.  Wanted something with some strengh to it (as you might expect in a stout), but it was very watery.

Now were talking OATMEAL STOUT.  Deep dark opaque brown with just a bit of a reddish hue.  Tan head was on the thin side but leaves a very nice lacing down the glass.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, caramel and much more that I cant adequately describe.  Silky smooth mouthfeel and finishes with just enough bitterness to make it enjoyable.  This is THE oatmeal stout to which all others should be compared!  Great beer.
Very smooth, almost sweet flavor.  Chocolate and roasted qualities stick out.  Nice thick mouthfeel.  Quite enjoyable.
The best English oatmeal stout I have tasted. Very smooth and roasty tasting with just enough bite. Not oily tasting like alot of English oatmeal stouts. Delicous!
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2003 Wonderful stout! Black with a reddish tint/hue. Tastes like some bittersweet chocolate with maybe molasses or coffee in it. Recommended with a creamy or chocolate dessert.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2010 Re-ReRate  Dark black pour - nice khaki head, faint chocolaty aroma.  Nice black dirt earthiness wit a hint of bittersweet chocolate. Solid - but not 4.4 worthy. Original 4.5 Re rate: Ordered at a pizza restaurant because they had it listed as Sam Adams Oatmeal (not heard of that) - oh well - still the same - Smooth, choclatey after taste, nice thick creamy head. Definitely one of the better stouts I have tasted - especially one so easily obtainable. Noticed the sweet aroma as well. Same score.
This is a standard. One of the best beers readily available in this puritan land we call NC

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2003 My goodness, this is a heavy, sweet beer!  It is more in the class of "dessert wine" than good ol' fashion beer.  A very, very full flavor, with a good head and great aftertaste. My only real complaint is the low alcohol content.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 I love the texture the oats add and the color is exceptional.  There is another flavor in this that i cannot put my finger on.  Kind of a molasses, but not quite.  I have yet to find an oatmeal stout that can match the depth and complexity of Sam Smith.
 4.2
Rerate 10/19/09:  That "flavor" is diacetyl and yes, Ive found better and more complex examples. Still though, this is a solid oatmeal.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2013 Bottled. Very dark brown coloured with a light brown dense frothy head. Aroma: Roast, cocoa, vague coffee, light chocolate. Flavour: Light roast, sweetness, vague coffee, chocolate and vague tar. Silk smooth. Medium to full bodied. Ends on a light roasted and smooth bitterness. Still a nice brew in my book, but not at 4,5 as I rated it as a young and unexperienced rater. 
Originalt rate: 8-5-9-5-18. I dont know what it is, but I get high just looking at the drawing black colour, with the huge cocoa-brown head. Amazing. The aroma is cocoa and coffee. The flavour is silk-smoothe and very pleasant again with cocoa and coffee. Very delicious stout
Excellent brew! Good body, taste, & great with foods!

Big thick head that is very light chocolaty brown and sits atop an ebony body. Very nice to look at. Sweet cocoa like nose along with a hint of sourness. The smell is not too profound. Begins with a little coffee. Then, sweet (but not too sweet) carmel flavors begin that lend it an almost rootbeer taste, though not as strong as a regular rootbeer flavor. That may not sound too appetizing but it really was a good beer that is very drinkable.

blackens a gleaming goblet with an inky pour, faint embers of black cherry. head was oatmeal cookie but collapsed into the stellar blackhole. i seldom put my ear over the glass but i could hear this one sizzling like a campfire. the nose is freighted with aromatic cargo: rubber, molasses, coffee, port, anise, dates and yak blankets. delicious sweetness is borne in the gentle arms of full bodied richness, balanced hop, and understated alcohol.
Sweeter than I thought it would be.  Stilll a very good stout from a superb brewer.

This is a great beer.  Its available in most well stocked liquor marts, so its good for when you need a quick good beer fix.  It has a really good, slightly sweet initial flavor, and a great finish.
Very nice mouthfeel.  Great flavor.  So dark, that light does not pass through it.  A wonderful beer in every sense of the word.
The more I drink this the more boring it gets.  Theres nothing wrong with it and it does have a nice texture.  I dont think theres a lot to it.

re-rating - 1st bootle was skunky and I had to pour it down the drain (@#&$%clear bottles), but if you get it fresh it is wonderful, one of my favorites - inviting aroma, smooth, malty sweet, but not cloying, enough bitter for balance
im drinking this at a far cry from ice cold and im very impressed. very big body lots of coffe and bittersweet chocolate flavors and you can just tase the oatmeal which smooths everything out.
Its quite interesting to use oatmeal in beer.  Sweet and very creamy.

This is my first oatmeal stout, and I dont think I was prepared for the strong sweet taste.  The flavor is complex, and seemed to give hints of a winelike character.  For these reasons, I couldnt refuse giving it high marks even if I didnt care for it.  Will try again sometime.

A very tasty stout that keeps you wanting more.  Very smooth and delishious.  Excellent with a nice steak and baked potato on a warm summer evening.  Strong flavor with a foamy smooth head.  I really like this stout.
I couldnt believe it was in a clear bottle After I poured it. A nice thick head sweet coffee smell.

Dark brown in color. Pours with large, tightly carbonated head - dark tan in color. Average-size nose with straightforward notes of roasted coffee and sweet malt. Crisp and medium/light palate. Flavors are not huge, but substantial - light coffee, dark but sweet chocolate.

Not a powerhouse brew, but solid quality and flavors.
This was the first Stout I had ever drank. Guess I started out the best. Caramel and nut flavors and very creamy. YUM!

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2003 WOW!!!Dark,mahogany appearace with complex,vinous,  aromas of oats,stone,iron,nuts,and HUGE roastiness.The silky looking body has a head worth putting on a mantle.The flavors match the aromas perfectly,and are just as complex.Oily,resiny,palate with a semi-dry finish.Finish loses dryness and gains caramelly,nutty,goodness.What could be better than this,as far as style?
This is the classic oatmeal stout. Nice palate, sweet as you would expect of an oatmeal stout, but a great balance makes it very drinkable.
Fine Stout, I prefer the Imperial Stout , but this one is a fine brew also. More on the sweet side and less of a complex flavor that the Imperial, while still being a good choice.

What can I say about Sam Smiths oatmeal stout?  This is the benchmark and progenitor of all the oatmeals you see on the market now ... the Adam and Eve of oatmeal.  Rich and chewy with hints of caramel ... a beautiful creamy body sculpted from chocolate.  This is a rich beer to be savored while wrapped in a sleeping bag on your back porch watching a winter sunset.

HUGEly powerful and pungent stout. I love it. Salty and a bit oily, massively bitter, burnt and creamily grainy thanks to the oats which reappear in a looong finish. big and tarry and not for the faint hearted. when im 87 ill drink this stuff and talk in grunts.

Very tasty.  I have no idea why it took me so long to try this.  I love their taddy porter and have been happy with every beer theyve made.  Its their excellent stout, but a bit creamy due to the oatmeal.  Excellent beer.
UPDATED: MAY 4, 2004 Wonderful appearance. Not as powerful aroma as I hoped. Very pleasant mild, sweetish and grainy flavour with notes of seaweed. A good stout.
only had it once and i was wasted, but i would buy it again
Very roasty stout. Quite sweet, very nice head. I cant recognize the oatmeal, but what the hell it got so many other strong points!

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2006 Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is dark brown to black. Aroma is moderately malty (milk chocolate, caramel, roasted grain), with notes of vanilla, toffee, licorice, raisin, and charcoal. Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy/velvety texture, soft carbonation. Complex malty aroma with many pleasant subtleties, rich mouthfeel, and a great flavor balance for the style.  I think Ive rated this a solid 4.0 every time Ive ever had it.  Though there is some room for improvement, this is clearly a benchmark.

There is a reason this beer has more ratings than any other beer in the top 50. Quite simply a very consitent, high quality brew... the best Ive had as of late.
If youve never had a Sam Smith before, Id suggest starting off with one of these.
I really disliked the oatmeal stout.  Oatmeal and beer do not mix well.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2006 Great beige head and awesome pitch black color.  I cant believe this was so good despite the clear bottle.  Sweet and roasty flavor and extremely smooth.  The best oatmeal stout hands down.
I love the tan head! Very nice.  Excellent roasted flavor.
Not bad even though I dont like dark beers.
Black velvet, dark and smooth. Thick and creamy with a grainy toffee flavor. A stout lovers delight for sure.
Delicious dark malt.  Coffee, chocolate, and as darn near a perfect sweet stout as they come.  It is the standard by which all other sweet stouts should be measured.
Great Oatmeal Stout.  Slightly sweet, with a nice flavor.  Very smooth.

A nice chewy stout.  
lots of chocolate and coffee overtones,only complaint is that the finish is a little oily but still a thoroughly enjoyable beverage

This is the first of my experiences with the sweet stouts...Very rich opaque appearance, for a stout goes down smoother than any stout Ive ever had, rich going down, with a slight honeylike aftertaste.  This is definitely one of my favorite beers.
Nothing to say about it, just a great oatmeal stout.

Yes, we have a winner. A SUPREME example of a oatmeal stout. Hearty and strong in flavor, yet smooth going down. A absolute cruxible for beer tasters. If you do not like this, then youre not one for stout.

One of the finest beers ever created. If you drank one that seemed lackluster, suspect it sat on a shelf too long.

Ill not repeat whats already been said a hundred times; its a great, complex, rich, beer. Go try one. Now!
Attention US microbrewers of oatmeal stouts: this is what it is supposed to be like.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2004 Delightful roasted chocolate malt syrup…Boiling caramel and keeping the vapor which arises from the pot…A dash of honey with some licorice...Quaffable grapes in a thinner than usual stout body...

All the Sam Smiths beers used to be MUCH better when the Samuel Smith brewery was independent and you could find Sam Smith pubs throughout London. The new brews from Tadcaster just are not the same: they are pale imitations of the original.
Excellent look, scent, and flavor...one of my favorites.  A toasted/caramel aroma leads into a smooth, sweet flavor.  An excellent stout. Ding!

I was given one of these in the parking lot of a Grateful Dead concert in 1990. Bud/Miller/Coors has not passed my lips since. Black color with a creamy tan head. Very light roast in the nose. Very light and drinkable for a stout and the low ABV means you can drink them all night. Perfect for winter drinking sessions.
Nice frothy head,smooth flavor and creamy mouthfeel. Try serving with frosted miniwheats instead of chips or pretzels.
An excellent, nice dark beer and not as heavy and the color indicates.  Smooth finish and not at all filling. One of my favorite.
An excellent, smooth Stout that is not as heavy as the black color might indicate. One of my Favorite stout beers.

A very nice dark color, but the beer left me unsatisfied.  It was very thin for a stout and tasted too much like a granola barfor my tastes.  Still, aside from a mild unbalancing of the oat malts, I thought it was a pretty good beer.
Nice chocolate flavor, very dark color.  Not a very thick stout, surprisingly smooth.  Sweet finish.
didnt detect much aroma. it has a fairly benign taste. Not bad, but nothing spectacular. Although nearly black in color, it had a very light bodied taste.

Okay, once again, good color and a lovely aroma. This and the other oatmeal with a goose name seem to be running neck and neck(no pun intended). Has a good taste to it, but a bit lighter. Samuel Smith is still the winner but others are obviously learning.

Generally overated. A very nice beer but not deserving of all the praise it receives. And wasnt it a Sam Smiths brewer who said something along the lines of Oatmeal? We dont want that !@#$ in our mash, we just sprinkle it on top. Hmmmm. Still, a very nice stout with a mouthfilling texture and creaminess; as well as a long, semi-sweet finish.
Very good. Head disapears quickly. Aftertaste is sweet with a hint of bitter. Must try another bottle to see if the clear had an affect.
An excellent stout.

A very good stout. Black, with a nice but not excessive tan head that lasts fairly well. The aroma is rich, and the flavor has hints of bakers chocolate. The finish is a little too bitter for me, though.
A very Fine stout.  Good dark color, with a decent head.  Very sweet, but not heacy...Good for after a filling meal!
Smooth and sweet. Burgandy with an enormous head and lots of lace. Great big warm chewy beer.

Smoooth! A great stout that aims to please. Excellent dark crimson/opaque color. Nutmeg/brandy aroma, and rich pleasing body that wont let go. Kind of a wintery seasonal beer that is delicious all year round.
a nice smooth stout suprisingly light yet still has the taste youd expect
Nice burnt/ coffee flavor.Slight chocolate after taste. A hint of bitter. Very good brew.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2007 Smooth, creamy, everything youd expect in an oatmeal stout. Try it over ice cream (no, really).
A toasted oat nose similar to a breakfast cereal like Cheerios.  Very smooth and light for such a dark beer.  Wonderful to have such a delicious stout with no detectable chocolate in the taste.

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2010 Great liquorice and cream flavor, some toasted oats in the smell and aftertaste. Just the right amount of carbonation. Pours dark with great aroma. This tastes way better than beer should taste. This is my favorite Stout. Im addicted to this offering of Samuel Smiths.
This was truly magnificant.  It went down so smooth and it really turned me on to liking stouts.  Great beer!!!
Weak head, decent lace all the same.  The combination of clear bottle and dark color create interesting impression.  Sweet, with a good chocolate flavor.  Pretty good stuff,
Black with a fairly lasting head. Very pleasant flavour of nice roasted malts, coffee etc. Extremely smooth. Medium bitter finish. Definately one of my favourite stouts!

Nice malty aroma and a tan head that lasted.  Very dark with no light coming through the glass.  As for the taste...... it was lovely.  Smooth from start to finish and nice burnt malt/coffee flavors but not at all harsh.  A great change from the everyday Guinness.

Skunky aroma (clear bottle). Even though the aroma is ruined this was still enjoyable. Well-balanced sweetness. Full of flavor yet nothing offends my tongue. Its so heavy I cant feel the alcohol much at all, just the oats in my stomach. Beats Guinness any day.
Well, oatmeal stout may not be my style, dont know... but I felt this one was a little bit intense.  Good flavors, but a bit strong on the coffee for me.

Really good stuff, leaves a nice burnt and coffee aftertaste.. no real sweetness to it, which I liked as Im not nuts about sweet stouts.  This beer ROCKS with dessert foods, like a cookie.  Its tan head really disappears quickly which is a bummer.  But again, awesome with cookies.

Man, this is what stout should be.  Forget that Guinness dry stout crap.  Mocha and roasted malt on the nose foreshadows the flavors youre about to encounter.  Talk about smooth and creamy?  This is the epitome of smooth and creamy.  Mocha and roasted malt flavors and creamy texture do battle with neither coming out ahead, which is a good thing.  Smooth character with interacting flavors just feels great in the mouth.  Smooth chocolate finish leaves a pleasant aftertaste that doesnt linger too long.  Exquisite and a new favorite.
I was really suprised to discover that the glass bottle was clear glass...heh heh
Very black. Instransparent. Roasty, creamy, softly malty. Medium bitterness. Wonderfully balanced.

My first oatmeal stout, and rather different from what I expected.  I dont know if the light got to it in the clear bottle or not, so that may affect my impression.

Dark, perfectly black stout color.  Tan head that didnt last long.  The beer is a lot more hearty and thick in appearance than in the taste and mouthfeel, which I found surprisingly thin and watery.  I was hoping for chocolate or candied taste like what I got in the Smith imperial stout, though I mainly got a light roasty, burnt, woody taste.  A pleasant flavor overall.  Finishes really smooth but uneventful.  Aroma reminded me slightly of sniffing a red wine, though also like the aroma of Anchor Porter.  Gets a little more robust in taste as it warms.  With more of a chocolatey bite to it, I might not tell the difference between this and the Anchor Porter.  

Anyway, a pretty good beer that I could definitely come back to once in a while.
Im a big fan of stouts and this is a smooth and easy going one to enjoy.  It isnt as thick though as a Guinness or Murphys Irish Stout.
Very smooth nice creamy head.I think the bottle I had may be old.
This beer is very good, but it lacks head and mouth feel. The beer is more like a Double Bock than a Stout.. Just my opinion.. The beer is very thin for a stout.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2004 Bottle.  Dark brown color with a lasting foamy light brown head.  A toasted malt and bready aroma with chocolate highlights.  Sweet, creamy smooth, and slightly dry at the finish.  A touch of tart fruit in the flavor which accompanies the toasted malts, caramel, and bread.
Creamy,smooth,nice roasted and chocolate balance.
wonderful beer.
Great tasting stout, nice dark color, wonderful malt and chocolate flavors, and easy to find as well. great beer.
Dark, rich color and good head retention.  A malty aroma.  Great dark roast flavor - pleasantly burnt. Hints of alcohol and malt flavor.  Smooth palate and pleasant finish. Great stout.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2003 Re-rate:  My rating will come down a bit here, but that's the beauty of learning about quality beer.  Anyway, it is a dark, dark brown with a bubbly head.  Immediate strong nose of oat and cereal.  Some roast, meat malt as well.  Tastes of roasted nuts, malts, oat.  Some mild bitterness.  Looses flavor as it sits and has a buttery, slippery type of mouthfeel that was unpleasant.  Too short of a finish.  Some good bitterness.  Original: An amazingly tasteful beer that is smooth and easy to drink one after another.  A definite must for any beer drinker.
Looked and smelled good straight out of the bottle.  Lost its head too quickly.  Body needs some help.  Good stout.

I never understood the concept of silky in a beer until I tried this one.  The body is jet black, and is topped by a minimal mocha head.  Rich coffee and wine(!) aroma.  The flavor is a combination of mocha, malt, butter, mild chocolate, wine, and sweetness.  The bitterness comes to the fore as you swallow.  A delicious concoction -- this beer is one of the reasons Samuel Smith has such a great reputation.

Rich, heady, Italian coffee aroma and a strong, smoky flavor.  The flavor is remiscent of smoked meat, but its not at all unpleasant.  I dont tend to like beers that have smoky flavors, but this one is so smooth and rich, rather than jarring, that I enjoy it quite a lot.  Its balanced by a gentle sweetness, and it has a slightly malty finish.  A pretty complex and interesting beer.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2005 Time for a rerate. After looking at my top fifty there were a few brews that I thought might deserve/need a rerate and this is the first one. Near black color with a moderate, but lasting head of tan bubbles, lots of lace coat the glass. Dark fruit, prunes, lavender and mild pinot noir aroma. Silky and smooth in feel, perhaps a touch thin in the finish. Quite dry and with come dark berries and charcoal. A great brew, just not a top 50 anymore. 
29 April 2002: (9,5,9,5,19 - 4.7)Just the silky feel you want from an oatmeal stout.  Couple that with the floral/sherry aromas and dark/burnt fruit flavors its hard to resist.
Wow!!!  Kinda tastes like brown sugar.  A very thinck, rich, quality stout.  One of the best I have tried.
coffee and chocolate notes, but this stout feels a little different in the mouth than a lot of others...its fairly thick and rich....damn good stout

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2006 Almost black, average light brown head. Full aroma with mellow hints of chocolate,coffee, and smoke.Starts of a little thin but then the roastiness shows along with a vinous quality. The middle is silky smooth, oaty with a hint of smoke and coffee. Damn tasty and enjoyable. Better everytime I have it. And the fact its been around so long and still holds up. Impressive and a classic.

Very Dark, about 98% of light doesnt pass though the glass. the aroma is light but pleasent. The taste is like pleasently like oats. hops are noticable and aftertaste lasts a while. 

The taste is a bit strong for me, but I do think I am begining to like it more.
black colour, few head, coffe and mocha aroma, oily, moderate maltiness, long bitter finish - pleasant
It doesnt get much better than this! Delicious, and creamy, this one is sure to satisfy stout lovers with its complex flavor profile.  If I had to pick one beer to drink, this would be mine.

Smells of Oatmeal,and Raisins, I liked the first few sips of this brew,but eventually It turned ,and then it seemed just bitter,and lost all the flavor for me...very sad, I so looked forward to this one...dissapointed!
Pretty good, but nothing special. A nice coloring, and a great big head. The flavor seems a bit lacking. Overall, Id say go elsewhere, but you can buy this and feel good about it.

Almost black color, a tan head than quickly dissipates, mildly sweet, strong, dry, but not particularly flavorful, it has a kind of neutral feel to the flavor, sort of an artificial substitute coffee flavor instead of the real thing, roasted malts, oats, with a bland, tasteless finish.
I usually dont really like oatmeal stouts - but this one was incredible! The best oatmeal stout by far!

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2003 Rerate 1/30/03: While I still thoroughly enjoy this beer, I need to adjust the rating down a little, as I have tried a couple dozen Stouts since this one that have been better. 4/19/02 (4.6): Wow, what a great beer. Somebody had to tell me the bottle was colorless before I realized that was the color of the beer! Sweet aroma and coffee undertones make this a new favorite of mine. If only it were more readily available! Perfectly smooth and drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2005 Dark reddish brown appearance, thick head formation. Intense rich wine fruitiness in the aroma, jammy, black cherry and cranberry, mild roasted malts/ Dry roasted palate mixed with sweet berry fruitiness, silky chocolate smoothness, mildly dry in the finish. One of the break through beers for me. Incredible fruitiness for a relatively "small" beer.
dark & smooth, it has a sweetness to it, a coffee taste as well.  Really dark beer.  Simply one of my favorites
A decent oatmeal stout with dark color, smooth drinkable with a little chewyness, an easy drinking stout with out overpowering flavors or bitterness.
Excellent beer deserving attention.  Damn smooth, this beer is highly drinkable stuff.
Black. Did I mention this beer was black? Taste that lasts forever. Sweet roasted malt with plenty of hops.
Doesnt have the burnt bitterness of the dry stouts, but it has the other flavors typical off a stout. I like it, but it doesnt floor me.

Samuel smith line is one of the best around and the show no slack with this rich almost chocolate flavor stout. Great after taste that lingers. smooth and not as bitter as i would like it but it definaltey does the trick

A bottle of this was my introduction to Cream Stout.  This brew pours a dark muddy brown with red highlights.  The huge rocky head is the color of brown sugar, is mostly lasting, and has good lacing.  The  nose is roasted cereal, grain, and caramel balanced with herbs, resin, grass and earth.  The flavor is heavy but balanced between bitter and sweet with roasted grains and coffee predominating.  The finish is long and has a metallic feel.  The full bodied brew is softly carbonated with a creamy texture.  Another winner from Tadcastle.
Great Stout... Creamy, thick and smooth with a unique taste.  Recommended for everyone

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2006 Clear bottles are an insult to good beer.  WHy dont they switch to brown bottles like they do with the lager and IPA?  This beer however, when found fresh, the other reviews say it all.  Silky mouthfeel that numbs the tongue, yet very crisp.  What a concept!  Addictive buttery aroma of oats and molasses.  A very unique bitter finish.  Winey, oaty, bubblegum and a sheer joy to drink.  Never has a beer eluded all other styles in its class as does this.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text:
I found an old bottle of this in the kitchen yesterday and drank it today, expecting that it had gone bad, what with the clear glass and all. If this is what its like when its gone bad, I want some more! Very pronounced malt taste, just short of being too sweet, not much head (maybe this is where it showed its age?). Overall, very nice. Ill get another one soon and give it a fair test.
RE-RATE: A fresher (and larger) bottle this time, not as flat, but head does go away too quickly. Still, nice body, coffee notes nicely balanced by sweetness and hints of fruit. Id love to have this on tap some day.
UPDATED: SEP 2, 2003 Becoming more and more of a fan of the dark brew. Non-existent head but tremendous aroma and finish. Not something that I could handle more than one of in a sitting.
Creamy, rich and flavorful. A personal favorite!
Fruity/chocolaty. No discernible hop, but thats OK for the style.
I went out of my way to have this beer at my wedding.  Its among my favorites.
I love Samuel Smith!!

I love this stuff! In fact, this is the beer that got me interested in trying real beers in the first place. Smooth, creamy, roasty, sweetish, and VERY satisfying stout. Goes great with English pot-pies and meat-loaf. Ive never seen it anywhere on tap but would really like to try it that way!  I also like the Nut Brown they make a lot.

This beer is the bomb, the diggity dank. In fact if Bud hadnt stolen the sloagan  king of beers Id crown this jewel of a beer with that title. My only problem with this beer is you simply cant drink 4-5 of these in one night.

To start off...I liked this very much.  The Aroma is nice roasted character to it.  It was very smooth with a weird (in a good way) slight bitter bite in the finish (suprised me for how smooth it was to start).  Excellent Oatmeal Stout....worth the money to try it out.
Sweet creamy stout. By all means try it.
The best $3 I have ever spent on a pint of Oatmeal Stout!  Pleasant aftertaste and smooth going down.  I think we have a keeper here.
This beer has a very hearty taste, give it a try if you can put half your paycheck away to buy a six pack.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2003 It looks like an average stout, and when held up to the sunlight it looks almost like a porter.  The aroma is sweet, and the taste is pretty much the same.  Very little bitterness in the aftertaste.  I reccomend this beer to one and all, if you can afford it that is, sheesh!

simply the best oatmeal there is.  This one has a smooth flavor throughout, with strong coffee overtones.  

I would kill your mother for a bottle
Simply an excellent beer, incredible after taste!

In general, Im not much of a stout drinker.  This ones better than your average stout though.  Its sweet and goes down smooth with no bad bite that Ive experienced with other stouts.  Not something Ill frequent because of the style and the cost, but I certainly understan why people like it so much.

Quite possibly my favorite beer ever. Beautiful dark appearnce that brought a a tear to my eye, nice rich aroma. There description of a silky texture is right on. It does as an earlier rater alluded to, lose its head too fast, but thats the only real flaw I can find in this beer.
Heard plenty of great things about this beer was really great going down but the aftertaste was pretty crappy.
Its good, not great. Sam Smiths gets some points for being available damn near everywhere also. Imperial Stout has a bit more flavor and some kick that this is lacking.

This is definitely a great beer, but just a bit too filling for my taste. One is about all I can handle. Dark and comples, but I feel what it lacks is some kick: Id prefer a little more alcohol in something this soupy.
Nice and dark, the best oatmeal stout I have ever had.
Very dark, deep ruby when held to the light. Pleasant sweetish aroma. Sweet complex taste with a clear oatmeal flavor in it. Finishes off with slight bitterness. A very enjoyable beer.
Wonderfully sweet and dark, this stout is one of the best Ive tasted. Much sweeter than something like Guiness...one of my faves
Great stout!!!!

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2005 As delicious as a beer can get. Ive only had two oatmeal stouts in my life (Youngs is still my fave) but Sam Smith has created a delighful drinking experience with this one.  Hersheys syrup and Caramilk flavours in a beer? Yes, and it works because its not actually sweet. Thick and wholesome ... I would love a lifetime supply of this stuff.
Its a rich dark brocade tapestry, redolent with soft, somewhat sweet roasted flavours.

Dark brown color, big foamy head that lasts.  Soft roasted aroma, some hops.
