Soft, oily mouthfeel, nicely blended hop and roast notes in the body and great subtle coffee notes following through into a surprisingly long palate.  Semi sweet, and a little timid, but otherwise a uniquely balanced oatmeal stout.
Yummy!  Nice roasted coffee/chocolate flavor.  Check out the beige head.....nice!

Dark as night, and a great brown head that lasts. Maybe it was because I had Oatmeal on the brain, but I think I tasted oatmeal. I was a good beer, but not one of my favorite stouts. Good beer though.
Thats one tasty easy drinking stout.
This is hands down my favorite beer.  The taste cant be matched, and the aroma is the most mouth-watering around.  Well worth the price.  Doesnt get better than this.
A great beer...I can only give it my best compliment...TASTE LIKE CHICKEN!!!   one of my top ten.

Mnnn! Thich beer! need I say more? Hoppy yet tasty, this beer is a much darker cousin of their fantastc lager, but I like it a good deal. Is i Taddy Porter, or no! This stuff rates third on my all time stout list behind Mackesons and Dragon. Too bad its so pricey.
I prefer porters over stout and prefer Smiths Porter over this stout. I liked it better than Guiness, not as heavy as I thought, had a strange finish but not unpleasant.
Great stout.
Another classic product from the Samuel Smith Brewery.

Quite yummy.
Feels good in the mouth.
Not a lot of aroma.
But smells a lot better
than mass produced yuck.
Very similar to St. Ambroise(McAuslan) Oatmeal Stout, not quite as complex or as balanced. The 2nd best oatmeal stout Ive had so far.
Tastes kinda like Newcastle to me.  Its better than Guiness!
UPDATED: FEB 5, 2003 I like this beer more and more each time I pop one open. Perfect sweetness for a stout.
This is awesome.  After my first one, I had to have a second to make sure it was really THAT good.  And, yeah...it is.  Thick, dark, smooth, great flavor, great head, and did I mention smooth?
Bitter sweet flavor/finish. Big creamy head. Just the right amount of carbonization. Very good.
A very full and rich flavor, with a dark coloring that is almost black. The malty oat taste is the first to hit the palate leaving a mildly bitter after taste. I like this one a lot.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2003 A dark viscous brew with thick mouthfeel and a sticky sweet aftertaste.  Dark milk chocolate with lactic sweetness dominates the body and can be somewhat overpowering.  Still, this is a very good beer and one of Samuel Smith's best.

I loved the flaovrs of this beer from start to finish it tantalized my taste buds, strong hops flavorings at first and smoothed out to a very sweet finish.  I really enjoyed this beer.  I did have it in the bottle, which I wonder how much different it would be on tap.

Dont let my rating fool you,... this is one of the best examples of an oatmeal stout out there. Thick and roasty with a great head and SWEET! Its just not my cup of tea. For the price of sammys Ill take the imperial!
Sweet start....very rich, smooth body....a very nice, well balanced finish. One of the best sweet stouts available anywhere.
Find it - try it!
Creamy, buttery and delicious, this is truly a cant miss stout.
Tastes excellent right out of the bottle. Creamy beer, that leans on the sweet side, but has a soupcon of bitternes. Sapid combination of malt carmel and smokiness with a pleasant aroma.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2005 Re-rate: a lot staler and sweeter than i remember, not much roasty bitterness in the finish, more sweet chocolate/caramel flavours, either my taste has changed, or Sam Smiths has gotten worse.Original rating (3.5):It was a nice stout, but not really what i expected, had a smooth mouthfeel with a buttery sweetness, which wasnt great, but wasnt bad. A decent brew.
This one is a classic. Great pour reveals creeeeemy head. If you like stouts this one needs to be sampled.
IMO not as good as the regular imperial from Sam Smith. More bready tasting.
This didnt strike me as that great.  It was my first Oatmeal Stout and I should probably try another since most others seem to have thought more about this beer than I did.
Had another one of these this past Thursday. Great beer. Smooth creamy taste. Would drink another one for sure.
user_location: Port Jefferson Station, New York, USA

text: I cantt say anything else that hasnt been said.  Very well balanced.
This one has a great mouthfeel.  Its one of the smoothest and creamiest of English oatmeal stouts.
Great flavor and aroma
Just the perfect mix of sweet/bitter.
Very tasty.  Creamy with lingering chocolate on the nose.  A bit swett as others point out but quite good nonetheless.

I think this actually is the only oatmeal stout built on a dry stout paltform, as opposed to a cream stout.  Could be wrong, but I think the style category this is in is just wrong.  Awesome brew. Not too far off Smiths Imperial.  Actually more drinkable, but less flavorful.  Very nice thickness.  SMOOTH.  you can feel the oils of the oats as a residue on your teeth and tongue.  Seriously folks, is there motor oil in this?

Impressive aroma. Nice head. But too sweet. I know Im in the majority here, but the Imperial Stout was far better, IMO. More alcohol, and less sweetness. :) If your looking for chocolate taste, this is the beer for you.

This is an excellent, classic example of the style. However, very, very rich and hard for me to finish a whole bottle. If you are a stout or porter lover, this is a must have!! Burnt, roasty, yet bittersweet, this beer is absolute perfection.
Great oatmeal flavor.  Not that heavy, but you wont mind.

I laughed, I cried, I wished that I had bought another.  A well-balanced sweet stout.  Pitch black, aromatic and mouthy.  Never met a Sam Smiths that I didnt like.   PS. DO NOT DRINK WITH FISH.  It really brings out the iodine in fish, and messes up really good trout and really good stout.
Grap a fork and knife and dig in!  This is good stout!
Cant really get a decent head out of the bottle.  However, it was still full, creamy, with hints of sweet equaled off with a nutty aftertaste.
major league stout when you are in that mood

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2003 RE-RATE: Wow, I used to drink Guinness regularly!  While my tastes have evolved since my original rating of this, I still carry a torch for this very good English beer.  ORIGINIAL RATING: Very good, full flavored, with hints of coffee, wood, oatmeal.  I'm a Guinness fan, but this makes Guinness look like something advertised on American football commercials.  Try it and you won't be disappointed!

Another fine product from Samuel Smith.  A rich and creamy stout to tantelize the senses. Not only did i get to enjoy a great beer i am also the 100th person to do so. Just thought that was kind of cool.

Excellent.  There is such a nice balance to this stout.  It has a slight sweet taste that combines with that of lightly rosted coffee with a molasses finish.  Man, I sound like a food critic from a fancy restaurant just now.  Ouch.  This is flat-out an excellent stout.
An absolute classic.. Coffee, chocolate, oatmeal.. so overwhelmingly flavorful and smooth at the same time..
A nice creamy beer.
Like a fine cabarnet.  Wonderfully creamy, silky, and smooth and slightly fruity.  Definitely one of the best stouts in the world!!!
Fruity, winey aroma.  Smooth black coffee like taste and texture.  Good balance of bitterness and sweetness.  Delicious.

Dark, velvety pour. Deep tan colored head of thick froth. A roasted aroma  resembling home brew  greets and flavor is earthy and malty with a slight dryness in the finish. Notes of coffee, chocolate and gypsum are present.  This used to be one of my favorite beers but over time many fine American oatmeal stouts have matched or surpassed this one in flavor and character. A classic in every sense.

This is what strikes me as being the pinnacle of what can be achieved in a brewed beverage. It just tastes perfect whatever that is. I guess thats different to everyone, but to me, its just very flavorful and hearty, with a good head. Its what I always dreamed of before I had it. Its what I had in mind when I first had Guinness and was dissappointed. All of the Samuel Smiths brews Ive tried are really high quality, but this one is my favorite tasting one. Of course these brews are also expensive, so if you just are looking for a buzz, and have a limited pocketbook, youll need to go for something cheaper.
G-DAMN I love this beer!!! Oily and sweet. Filling and warming. My wife swears that she tastes Gouda and Worschestire.

I really enjoyed this beer. It was just the thing that I craved after a wonderful dinner.  The great thing about this beer is that it acted like a sweet destert, yet wasnt terrbily filling.  I look forward to trying other products by Samuel Smtih.

Pitch black without dominant ashen aromas or flavors, instead there are pleasant carmel, deep roast and doughy yeast. The creamy oatmeal mini-foamed malt is well-balanced by a medium bitter that nicely continues to follow the lingering sweetness.
You can almost taste the oats in your mouth. I swear I had to pick one out of my teeth. Damn good stuff; even if you dont like stouts, give this one your attention.
Now this is what I call a world class beer.
UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 I am not a stout fan, but this one is like eating candy.  Roastiness is not overdone.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Update to my previous rating (which was nothing at all):  black color, modest charcoal head with beautiful lacing around the glass, sweet nose with notes of toasted oats, licrorice & a touch of brandy, medium body, very smooth, flavors of sweet malts, licrorice, toasted oats & a hint of cream, smooth finish with a little bit of a bitter bite, an excellent oatmeal stout
Smooth, Smooth, Smooth. Aftertaste has the perfect taste.
holly shit,i loved it.
awesome stout...not as bitter as some other stouts.

The bitter/burnt flavor grows on one; however, the mouthfeel doesnt work for me - it seems thin and syrupy, as a couple of others have said. Having drunk this beer a couple of times, I am considerably less impressed with it than the majority of raters are.
A great oatmeal stout...one of my favorites.

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2006 550ml clear bottle:  Pours a dark ruby brown with a thin tan head, aroma has rich dark fruity malts, thin bodied with light carbonation, with an odd fruity ending.  Put it in BROWN bottles!!!!!
A very nice oatmeal stout.
Definitely one of my favorite stouts.
all i have to say is mmmmmm....its like dessert!

Im used to Bells stouts, so this was a bit of a disappointment. Too syrupy, and a teaser of that skunked flavor just like Newcastle. You can brew my beer in dear old Michigan and keep your English beer.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2006 Im not much of a fan of outmeal stout, but this wasnt all that bad. Actually I was quite impressed with it. Samuel smith makes a very fine brew no matter what style and this is no exception.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 2001:  Truly wonderful stout that is just bursting with sweet, winey, chocolatey flavors, a beautiful body and robust head.  A nose that is just a bit too faint and a slightly too strong bitterness running through the palate keep this from joining Mackeson and Youngs in my pantheon, but for those who like their oats more robust and less sweet and smooth, this could be the one.

2003:  Some classics don't ever fade, even after a couple of years of rating like crazy.  Changing the points around a little; can't call it perfect in appearance with the tiny little head it has, but on the other hand I do feel the aroma to be stronger and more complex than before.  The McNeills Oatmeal I had the other night is similar; I think I'm finding I like the more roasty bitter stouts more these days.  Masterpiece.

I love the chocolate/coffee aroma of this beer.  The sweet taste kicks in first with the bitterness sneaking up on you.  But it doesnt get too bitter.  I enjoy a good oatmeal stout, and this is a good one

This really didnt do it for me. It looks great--big robust head on a thick black body. The initial flavor was alright, a bit malty, with a slight hop balance and hints of burnt coffee, but it left a terrible bittersweet aftertaste. Might go better with some salty snacks to cut the aftertaste.
nice appearance and flavor with a strong coffee after taste

Another winner in the oatmeal stout category.
Not quite as good as Heartlands Farmer Jon OS, but still great.
A unique, kinda nutty flavor distinguishes this beer.
The aroma is great as well - it lasts throughout the glass
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text: This is a very good beer. Smooth and satisfying. But the aftertaste on this beer doesnt linger very long.  I prefer Mackeson, but this is a pleasing substitute.
Still one of the best stouts in the world.  Great for stout-lovers and very good for all other drinkers!

This was my first oatmeal stout and I have to say I like it almost as much as dry stout (Guinness, Murphys, etc.). I cant drink as much of it (the sweeter taste becomes a bit sickening after more than a pint or two) but I enjoyed it nonetheless.  It has more of a robust, roasted dark chocolate/caramel flavor than other stouts (I could be confusing the oatmeal taste for caramel, but I didnt taste oatmeal). Only in the aftertaste did I detect a slightly bitter sensation, and not that of coffee.  Very thick and heavy, I was surprised when I held it up to the light that it wasnt quite opaque.  Got better as it warmed.
Perhaps Im used to motor oil, but I found this stout a bit on the thin side.  Quite tasty, but it just doesnt fill the mouth as much as some stouts.
Very very good. Not at all bitter or hoppy. Smooth to the last drop, subtle coffee and chocolate undertones. A toss up between this and Mackesons XXX.
By far the best stout i have had.
I LIKED THIS ALOT VERY SMOOTH AND VERY FLAVORFUL. SMOOTH DRINKING
Please, please dont make me choose between this and my Mackensons. . .
Very nice stout.  Not too bitter, good and toasty.  NOTE: If you are ever making beer bread, this is the beer to use.
Another sickly seet concoction.  I realize this is a classic among stout lovers.  Too sweet for me.  Gimme Mackesons anyday.

On most nights this would be remembered as a great beer.  However, on the same night that I sampled this, I was lucky enough to try the local Tucson brew, Nimbus Oatmeal Stout, which definetely seems to be superior, probably from its more evident oatmeal flavor.

Something was missing from this otherwise widely-acclaimed brew.  I felt that it was lacking the charictaristic flavors of an Oatmeal, but it could be that the bottle that I recieved (from VENOM, thanx a lot!) was shaken and disturbed in the long journey from England to Connecticut to Wisconsin.
One of the first premium imports I ever had. No other stout has surpassed this one for me. Rich and not too bitter.

Very smooth even for an oatmeal stout.
The only favor I dont like is the abundance of
a roasted/smoky flavor.  Otherwise excellent.

I had heard this was a very good beer, so I decided to order it. It had a very odd flavor, much different than what I was expecting from a stout. But it wasnt a flavor that I liked so I was disapointed. Not something I would order again.
Im a big fan of Oatmeal Stouts and this one does justice to the style.
Highly hopped as expected with a nice toffee aroma. Burnt smoothness warms your mouth and makes you grin.

Oh - now this IS an oatmeal stout.  This is what beer drinking is all about.  I kept watching the glass get lower and lower, expecting the wonderful taste and aroma to end, but it simply blew my mind how fantastic it was!  An absolute must for any beer drinker.
Now this is what Oatmeal Stout should me, malty, grainy and a bit of sweet.  Not like that nasty, salty Ipswich junk.
Everyone I know likes this beer.  I liked it so much that I bought an Oatmeal Stout T-shirt!  Typically Samuel Smith-ian character all-around (which is to say excellent!)
Good smooth stout.  Great color and maltyness.  Needs to be served on tap in more bars and resturants.
A good stout, but as long as they make Guinness, I wont be buying Samuel Smiths.
So very very good.  Sam Smith has done me well here.

By far one of my favorite all tiem beers.  This stuff is smooth as silk. The aroma is complex, rich and just incredible.  The flavor takes my tongue on a ride it never soon forgets.  This is the stout against which all other sweet stouts should be judged.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2004 Very dark brown, thin light tan head; aroma like the finest Belgian chocolate mixed with Atholl Brose.  I want to fall into the glass.  Silky body, fruity notes of cherry, redcurrant add an interesting layer to the silky malts and chocolate overtones.  Sweet, luscious finish.  One of those beers that leaves you at a loss for words.  The classic oatmeal stout - depth without compromising stylistic adherence.
Maybe not the best beer in the world but it is good.  Nice and sweet
Very nice, smooth stout.

A good stout, but I dont care for the amount of carbonation.  Sort of like a stale soda.  But, my bottom line is this is no match for Guinness, which in my humble opinion is the true King of Beers.  Just confirmed what I already knew, no one makes a better stout than the Irish!

I hesitate to give this a bad rating, in light of what everyone else thought.  But honestly, I though this was too sweet, and had a somewhat sticky mouthfeel.  Feel free to disagree, Im in the minority here obviously.

This is arguably one of SSs top 3 brews. A superb big, bold stout but at the same time, extremely SMOOTH. It is sweeter than Guinness ( appropriate for an Oatmeal Stout), but does finish with a moderate amount of hop and roasted malt bitterness and dryness. Very classy and enjoyable! Once again, however, watch for the skunk due to the clear bottles.
Nice!
Excellent stout. I like this better than Murphys, but not quite as much as Guinness Extra Stout.
I was expecting something a little smoother. A slight disappointment.
Awesome.  Smooth, sweet and malty.  Really a great drinkable dark beer!
Incredible thick, sweet, and malty brew.  Ill take this over that other stout they make at st. james gate any old day of the week.  Great stuff.

One word - wow! I was actually able to get a fresh and unskunked four pack the other night - and it was a treat.  Aroma - roasted and inviting; Appearance - poured in a imperial, nice off-white 1 in. head hugged tightly to the midnight liquid;  Taste - creamy,chocolatey and sweet but a balanced dryness in the finish - absolutely wonderful; top 5 all time on my beer list - highly recommended to all. Overall Impression didnt get as high because its so hard to find this unskunked. Cheers!
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: Tastes like dessert. Yummy. Chewy and sweet. Lovely.
Very good stout.  Very dark, aromatic, and taste to boot.  Has kind of a creamy, sweet taste to it that finishes off very mildly bitter.  Very pleasent indeed.
This is probably the best of Sammy Smith.  Great drinkability with just the right amount of aftertaste.  Small bubbles and good consistency in the mouth.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2015 Initially rated in 2000, updated 2007 but cant really understand what the update was, original 2000 rate below:
This was my favorite beer before discovering
Shakespeare Stout.  Nice and heavy, full flavor.
Somewhat sweet but not overbearing.
2015 rate: Nearly opaque, pours with a full head that fades fast. Nose is clean with chocolate, mild roast, light nuttiness. Medium palate but a strong carbonic bite leads to a roasty mildly acrid finish that shows alcohol, oily texture. A little sweetness manages to come up, with chocolate and hazelnuts, but mostly its pretty dry. Too carbonic and dry despite having a nice constructions of choc/roast/nut elements.
